glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.definition: The navigation of inland waterways, i.e. navigable rivers, canals, sounds, lakes, inlets, etc. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.name: inland navigation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European Topic Centre on Nature Protection and Biodiversity (ETC/NPB, formerly European Topic Centre for Nature Conservation, ETC/NC), is one of five EEA's topic centres. It assists the EEA in its work of collecting, analysing, evaluating and synthesising information relevant to national and international policies for the environment and sustainable development. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Nature Protection and Biodiversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Topic Centre on Nature Protection and Biodiversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european topic centre on nature protection and biodiversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cop.objecttrans_bg: образуване на нискостъблена гора (след ниско подрязване на дърветата)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cop.definition: The practice of cutting trees at or near the ground and allowing it to sprout from the stamp to generate a new crop of poles. [definition source: The Encyclopedia of Ecology & Environment Management. Ed. Peter Calow. Blackwell Science Ltd. 1998.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEH.definition: Synonyms: Children's Environment and Health Action Plan for Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEH.name: CEHAPE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: A sum of decisions and actions taken during and after disaster, including immediate relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: disaster response

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental compartment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: отдел по проблеми на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: отдел по проблеми на околната среда

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCB.definition: PCBs are mixtures of 209 different chemicals (cogeners) that come in various forms including oily liquids, solids and hard resins. PCBs are organochlorines that were manufactured until the mid-1980s, after which they were banned due to their toxicity and persistence. PCBs have been widely used as insulators in electrical equipment. They have also been used in the production of hydraulic fluids, lubricants, inks, adhesives and insecticides. They are still found in old electrical equipment and releases into the environment continue from landfills. PCBs are very persistent in the environment, taking years to degrade. They are fat-soluble and bioaccumulate in the tissues of animals. PCBs have become worldwide pollutants due to long-distance transport on air currents. Exposure to PCBs can permanently damage the nervous, reproductive and immune systems of the human body. PCBs are known carcinogens and have been linked with the development of various forms of cancer including skin and liver. In mammals, PCBs are passed via the placenta to developing young in the womb and via breast milk to newborn babies. The disposal of wastes containing PCBs is regulated by the Basel Convention. [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCB.name: PCB

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: A philosophy that prescribes a code of practice for ensuring that environmental considerations are fully integrated into all stages of the development process in order to achieve a desirable balance between conservation and development. [definition source: Dep. of Environmental Affairs and Tourism and Dep. of Water Affairs and Forestry South Africa. 1998. A policy on pollution prevention, waste minimisation, iImpact control and remediation.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated environmental management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCA.definition: Synonyms: priority conservation area [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCA.name: PCA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: A scheme that provides fiscal advantages for investors in sustainable projects. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green investment fund

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDG.definition: Synonyms: Millennium Development Goals [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDG.name: MDGs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.definition: A group of bacteria that are normally abundant in the intestinal tracts of human and other warm-blooded animals and are used as indicators (being measured as the number of individuals found per millilitre of water) when testing the sanitary quality of water. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.name: coliform bacteria

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: One year of a non-specified person’s life. Can be used to describe loss of life expectancy. For example, 'thousands of life-years are lost annually in Europe as a result of air pollution'. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life-year

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.name: photochemical smog
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.objectname_bg: фотохимичен смог, фотохимично замъгляване на атмосферата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.objecttrans_bg: фотохимичен смог, фотохимично замъгляване на атмосферата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.definition: A combination of fog and chemicals that come from automobile and factory emissions and is acted upon by the action of the sun. Nitrogen dioxide, in the presence of the sun and some hydrocarbons, is turned into nitric oxide and atomic oxygen. The atomic oxygen reacts with the oxygen molecules and other constituents of automobile exhaust fumes to form a variety of products including ozone. The ozone is harmful in itself and is also implicated in a highly complex series of continuing reactions. As long as there is ozone or nitrogen dioxide and sunlight present, other undesirable reactions will occur. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCT.definition: Toxic and persistent chemical used as electric insulator. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PCT.name: PCT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU2.definition: Bulgaria, Rumania and candidate countries (EU) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU2.name: EU2CC2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical treatment (of hazardous waste)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: Treatment methods that are used to effect the complete breakdown of hazardous waste into non-toxic gases or, more frequently, to modify the chemical properties of the waste, for example, through reduction of water solubility or neutralisation of acidity or alkalinity. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pel.definition: Of, relating to, or living or occurring in the open sea. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001 impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pel.name: pelagic

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.definition: The Arctic monitoring and assessment programme (AMAP) was established in 1991 to implement certain components of the Arctic environmental protection strategy (AEPS). The primary objectives of AMAP are: 'to provide reliable and sufficient information on the status of, and threats to, the Arctic environment, and to provide scientific advice on actions to be taken in order to support Arctic governments in their efforts to take remedial and preventive actions relating to contaminants.' [definition source: Arctic monitoring and assessment programme (AMAP).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.name: Arctic monitoring and assessment programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFC.definition: Synonyms: chlorofluorocarbons [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFC.name: CFCs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.definition: The act or the means of conveying people in mass as opposed to conveyance in private vehicles. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.name: public transport

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Edu.definition: Synonyms: ESD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Edu.name: Education for Sustainable Development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEM.definition: Synonyms: global environment monitoring system [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEM.name: GEMS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European list of notified chemical substances (ELINCS) is an everexpanding list, following notification to competent authorities of the placing of a new substance on the market. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European list of notified chemical substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European list of notified chemical substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european list of notified chemical substances

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: The part of the land affected by its proximity to the sea, and that part of the sea affected by its proximity to the land as the extent to which man's land-based activities have a measurable influence on water chemistry and marine ecology. [definition source: US Commission on Marine Science, Engineering and Resources, 1969). Quoted by EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal zone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SUT.definition: Synonyms: Supporting tourism enterprises for eco-labelling and environmental management [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SUT.name: SUTOUR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: Intentional mixture or solution composed of two or more chemicals. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical preparation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bru.definition: The World Commission on Environment and Development chaired by Norwegian Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland. The Commission's report, Our common future (1987), popularised the notion of sustainable development. [definition source: Agricultural experiment station, Kansas State University. A glossary of agriculture, environment, and sustainable development. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bru.name: Brundtland Commission

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bas.name: basin
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bas.definition: In the context of Hydrology and related subjects this includes a drainage area of a stream, river or lake. [definition source: Choudhury K. and L. Jansen. 1997. Quoted by: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DTM.definition: Digital Terrain Models (DTM) sometimes called Digital Elevation Models (DEM) is a topographic model of the bare Earth that can be manipulated by computer programs.The data files contain the elevation data of the terrain in a digital format which relates to a rectangular grid. Vegetation, buildings and other cultural features are removed digitally - leaving just the underlying terrain.DTMs are used especially in civil engineering, geodesy & surveying, geophysics, geography and remote sensing. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DTM.name: DTM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.objectname_hu: wastebase, az európai hulladék és anyagáramlás témaközpont (etc/wmf) hulladékkal és hulladékgazdálkodással foglalkozó adatbankja

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.objectname_is: wastebase gagnagrunnurinn um úrgang og skylda þætti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.name: Wastebase
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.objecttrans_pl: elektroniczna baza danych o odpadach w Europie (Wastebase)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.definition: An electronic database with information on waste, waste policies, planning, management and treatment in Europe. Wastebase provides inter-connecting electronic catalogues on different aspects of waste. [definition source: ETC/WMF.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.objecttrans_ro: bază de date cu privire la reziduuri

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Practical prevention and control measures used to improve the basic environmental conditions affecting human health, for example clean water supply, human and animal waste disposal, protection of food from contamination, and provision of healthy housing, all of which are concerned with the quality of the human environment. [definition source: After Duffus, 1993. Quoted by: International Society of Doctors for the Environment (ISDE). Primer on international environment and health politics (version of September 2001).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental hygiene

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DTI.definition: Synonyms: Department of Trade and Industry, United Kingdom [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DTI.name: DTI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEM.definition: The general multilingual environmental thesaurus (GEMET) was developed for the European Environment Agency (EEA) by the Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche (CNR) and Umwelt-Bundesamt (UBA), as a reference indexing and retrieval tool for the EEA catalogue of data sources and other EEA databases. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEM.name: GEMET

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_is: úrgangur sem brotnar niður í náttúrunni
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biodegradable waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_bg: отпадъци, които се разграждат по естествен път
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_bg: Отпадъци, които се разграждат по естествен път
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Means any waste that is capable of undergoing anaerobic or aerobic decomposition, such as food and garden waste, and paper and paperboard; [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dro.definition: The naturally occurring phenomenon that exists when precipitation has been significantly below normal recorded levels, causing serious hydrological imbalances that adversely affect land resource production systems. [definition source: UN Convention to Combat Desertification.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dro.name: drought

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EFT.definition: Synonyms: European Free Trade Association [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EFT.name: EFTA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.definition: This indicator is defined as the ratio between tonne-kilometres (inland modes) and GDP (in constant 1995 EUR). It is indexed on 1995. The unit used is the tonne-kilometre (tkm), which represents the movement of one tonne over a distance of one kilometre. It includes transport by road, rail and inland waterways. Rail and inland waterways transport are based on movements on national territory, regardless of the nationality of the vehicle or vessel. Road transport is based on all movements of vehicles registered in the reporting country. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.name: freight transport intensity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_smo.definition: A combination of fog and chemicals that come from automobile and factory emissions and is acted upon by the action of the sun. Nitrogen dioxide, in the presence of the sun and some hydrocarbons, is turned into nitric oxide and atomic oxygen. The atomic oxygen reacts with the oxygen molecules and other constituents of automobile exhaust fumes to form a variety of products including ozone. The ozone is harmful in itself and is also implicated in a highly complex series of continuing reactions. As long as there is ozone or nitrogen dioxide and sunlight present, other undesirable reactions will occur. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: Synonyms: SACs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: special areas of conservation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.objectname_lv: es dalībvalstu atmosfēras izmešu kvotu sadalījums
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.name: burden sharing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.objecttrans_lv: ES dalībvalstu atmosfēras izmešu kvotu sadalījums
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.definition: The sharing out of emissions allowances among the 15 Member States under the EU 'bubble.' An agreement on burden sharing was reached in June 1998 and will be made legally binding as part of the EU's instrument of ratification of the Kyoto Protocol. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eio.objecttrans_fr: Eionet (réseau européen d'information et d'observation pour l'environnement)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eio.objecttrans_bg: Еионет, Европейска мрежа за информация и наблюдение на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eio.definition: The European environment information and observation network (EIONET) is a collaborative network of the European Environment Agency and its member countries, connecting national focal points in the EU and accession countries, European topic centres, national reference centres, and main component elements. These organisations jointly provide the information that is used for making decisions for improving the state of the environment in Europe and making EU policies more effective. Eionet is both a network of organisations and a electronic network (e-Eionet). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eio.objectname_cs: eionet (informační a pozorovací síť evropské agentury životního prostředí)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.definition: Any disease-producing agent or microorganism. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.name: pathogen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.objectname_lv: augsnes pārklāšana, auglīgās zemes zudums urbanizācijas un transporta infrastruktūras attīstības rezultātā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil sealing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.objecttrans_lv: augsnes pārklāšana, auglīgās zemes zudums urbanizācijas un transporta infrastruktūras attīstības rezultātā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: Soil sealing refers to changing the nature of the soil such that it behaves as an impermeable medium (for example, compaction by agricultural machinery). Soil sealing is also used to describe the covering or sealing of the soil surface by impervious materials by, for example, concrete, metal, glass, tarmac and plastic. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SF6.definition: Synonyms: sulphur hexafluoride [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SF6.name: SF6

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecosystem diversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: The variety of ecosystems that occurs within a larger landscape, ranging from biome (the largest ecological unit) to microhabitat. [definition source: UNEP. Glossary of biodiversity terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: The purpose of Directive 2002/96/EC on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) is, as a first priority, the prevention of waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE), and in addition, the reuse, recycling and other forms of recovery of such wastes so as to reduce the disposal of waste. It also seeks to improve the environmental performance of all operators involved in the life cycle of electrical and electronic equipment, e.g. producers, distributors and consumers and in particular those operators directly involved in the treatment of waste electrical and electronic equipment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directive 2002/96/EC on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_en: Directive 2002/96/EC on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objectname_en: directive 2002/96/ec on waste electrical and electronic equipment (weee)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_is: lífmassi, heildarmassi lífvera sem mynda tiltekinn hlekk í fæðukeðjunni eða byggja ákveðin svæði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_is: lífmassi, heildarmassi lífvera sem mynda tiltekinn hlekk í fæðukeðjunni eða byggja ákveðin svæði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biomass
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: The biodegradable fraction of products, waste and residues from agriculture (including vegetal and animal substances), forestry and related industries, as well as the biodegradable fraction of industrial and municipal waste. [definition source: Directive 2001/77/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 September 2001 on the promotion of electricity produced from renewable energy sources in the internal electricity market.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.objecttrans_es: control de inundaciones; control de inundación
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.objectname_es: control de inundaciones; control de inundación
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.name: flood control
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.definition: The management of water resources through construction of dams, reservoirs, embankments, etc. to avoid floods. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NRC.definition: National reference centres (NRCs) are not mentioned in the regulation but have been defined subsequently as a special set of main component elements. National reference centres are also therefore nationally funded institutions/organisations which may be nominated by member countries to play a role in technical coordination within their countries and cooperate with the European topic centre established to cover various topics. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NRC.name: NRC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ISO.definition: The ISO 14000 series is a family of environmental management standards developed by the International Organization for Standardisation (ISO). The ISO 14000 standards are designed to provide an internationally recognised framework for environmental management, measurement, evaluation and auditing. They do not prescribe environmental performance targets, but instead provide organisations with the tools to assess and control the environmental impact of their activities, products or services. The standards address the following subjects: environmental management systems; environmental auditing; environmental labels and declarations; environmental performance evaluation; and life cycle assessment. [definition source: Standards Council of Canada. Quoted by: Industry Canada. Eco-efficiency glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ISO.name: ISO 14000

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.name: risk
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.definition: Expected losses (of lives, persons injured, property damaged and economic activity disrupted) due to a particular hazard for a given area and reference period. Based on mathematical calculations, risk is the product of hazard and vulnerability. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eur.definition: Synonyms: EUR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eur.name: euro

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Ecosystems can be classified according to various criteria: e.g. from the point of view of energy source, two major types of ecosystems can be distinguished. Autotrophic ecosystems have primary producers as a principal component and sunlight has the major initial energy source; etherotrophic ecosystems depend upon preformed organic matter that is imported from autotrophic ecosystems elsewhere. Ecosystems can also be classified in terrestrial, marine and freshwater. In European nature policy a further classification into habitats is widely used. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecosystem type

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste minimisation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objectname_nl: het tot een minimum beperken van afval
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objectname_bg: поддържане на минимално количество отпадъци, редуциране на количеството индустриални отпадъци
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objecttrans_bg: поддържане на минимално количество отпадъци, редуциране на количеството индустриални отпадъци
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Measures and/or techniques that reduce the amount of wastes generated during any domestic, commercial and industrial process. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objecttrans_nl: het tot een minimum beperken van afval

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_es: alternativa efectiva en relación con los costes
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_es: alternativa efectiva en relación con los costes
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.name: cost-effective alternative
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_bg: рентабилна алтернатива (контрол или коректив в резултат на цялостна оценка)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_bg: рентабилна алтернатива (контрол или коректив в резултат на цялостна оценка)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.definition: An alternative control or corrective method identified after analysis as being the best available in terms of reliability, performance, and cost. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.objectname_hu: a lakosságnak városokból a külvárosokba való kitelepülése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.name: suburbanisation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.objecttrans_hu: a lakosságnak városokból a külvárosokba való kitelepülése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.definition: Migration from city centres to suburbs, often linked to the increase of business activities and decrease of population in the centres. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Transport and the environment. A multi-country approach. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LBS.definition: Synonyms: land-based sources [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LBS.name: LBS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental accounting
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: счетоводство на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: счетоводство на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: (1) National accounting: physical and monetary accounts of environmental assets and the costs of their depletion and degradation. (2) Corporate accounting: the term usually refers to environmental auditing, but may also include the costing of environmental impacts caused by the corporation. [definition source: United Nations. 1997. Quoted by: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICC.definition: Synonyms: International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICC.name: ICCAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objecttrans_is: meðferð til stuðnings eða í kjölfar annarrar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objectname_is: meðferð til stuðnings eða í kjölfar annarrar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: secondary treatment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Similar to biological waste water treatment. Processes which employ aerobic or anaerobic microorganism and result in decanted effluents and separated sludge containing microbial mass together with pollutants. Biological treatment processes are also used in combination and/or in conjunction with mechanical and advanced unit operations. 2) [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: dissolved oxygen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: Amount of gaseous oxygen (O2) actually present in water expressed in terms either of its presence in the volume of water (milligrams of O2 per litre) or of its share in saturated water (percentage). [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAS.definition: Synonyms: National Aeronautics and Space Administration [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAS.name: NASA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Operations for preparing and controlling the implementation of plans for organizing human activities on land. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ann.name: annoyance
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ann.definition: A feeling of displeasure associated with any agent or condition known or believed by an individual or a group to be adversely affecting them. [definition source: Linvall and Radford. 1973]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated pest control
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: The rational application of a combination of biological, biotechnical, chemical, cultural or plant-breeding measures whereby the use of chemical plant protection products is limited to the strict minimum necessary to maintain the pest population at levels below those causing economically unacceptable damage or loss. [definition source: Oskam, A.J., Vijftigschild, R.A.N., Graveland, C.1997. Additional EU policy instruments for plant protection products. Final report.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECC.definition: Programme launched in June 2000 by the European Commission. Its goal is to identify and develop all the necessary elements of a EU strategy to implement the Kyoto Protocol. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECC.name: ECCP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.name: half-life of a radioactive element
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objectname_ro: timp de înjumătăţire a unui element radioactiv
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.definition: The time required for one-half the atoms of a given amount of radioactive material to undergo radioactive decay. [definition source: GEMET 2000]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objecttrans_ro: Timp de înjumătăţire a unui element radioactiv

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_des.definition: Synonyms: DOE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_des.name: designated operational entity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: Any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea, and any deliberate disposal at sea of vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea. [definition source: London Convention (1972) on the prevention of marine pollution by dumping of wastes and other matter.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: sea dumping

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Sustainable management means the stewardship and use of forests and forest lands in such a way, and at a rate, that maintain their biodiversity, productivity, regeneration capacity, vitality and their potential to fulfil, now and in the future, relevant ecological, economic and social functions, at local, national, and global levels, and that does not cause damage to other ecosystems. [definition source: Ministerial Conference on the Protection of Forests in Europe, 16-17 June 1993 in Helsinki, Documents.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable forest management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: That component of biodiversity that contributes to food and agriculture production. The term agrobiodiversity encompasses within-species, species and ecosystem diversity. [definition source: FAO. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agrobiodiversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.name: toxic waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.definition: Refuse posing a significant hazard to the environment or to human health when improperly handled; includes carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic or phytotoxic wastes, or wastes harmful to aquatic species, or poisonous wastes. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_win.name: wind energy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_win.definition: Energy extracted from wind, traditionally in a windmill, but increasingly by more complicated designs including turbines, usually to produce electricity but also for water pumping. The power available from wind is proportional to the area swept by the rotating place and the cube of the wind velocity, but less than half the available power can be recovered. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.definition: Exposure to chemicals while in a workplace setting. [definition source: WHO. Hazardous chemicals in human and environmental health. Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.name: occupational exposure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFC.definition: Gases formed of chlorine, fluorine and carbon whose molecules normally do not react with other substances; they are therefore used as spray can propellants because they do not alter the material being sprayed. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFC.name: CFC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: suspended solids
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Solid particles suspended in water. They can be removed by filtration or settlement. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objectname_lv: eifotiskā zona, ūdens ekosistēmu augšējā zona
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objectname_de: euphotischer bereich, durchlichteter bereich, euphotische zone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objecttrans_de: euphotischer Bereich, durchlichteter Bereich, euphotische Zone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.name: euphotic zone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objecttrans_lv: eifotiskā zona, ūdens ekosistēmu augšējā zona
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objectname_fi: eufoottinen vyöhyke, veden ekosysteemin valoisa vyöhyke
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.objecttrans_fi: eufoottinen vyöhyke, veden ekosysteemin valoisa vyöhyke
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eup.definition: The upper, illuminated zone of aquatic ecosystems: it is above the compensation level and therefore the zone of effective photosynthesis. In marine ecosystems it is much thinner than the deeper aphotic zone (below the level of effective light penetration), typically reaching 30 m in coastal waters but extending to 100-200 m in open ocean waters. [definition source: Allaby, 1994. Quoted by: European Topic Centre on Nature Conservation. 1998. EUNIS habitat classification. Final draft with further revisions to marine habitats. United Kingdom.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: The accumulation of soluble mineral salts near the surface of soil, usually caused by the capillary flow of water from saline ground water. Where the rate of surface evaporation is high, irrigation can exacerbate the problem by moistening the soil and causing water to be drawn from deeper levels as water evaporates from the surface. The evaporation of pure water leaves the salts behind, allowing them to accumulate, and they can reach concentrations that are toxic to plants, thus sterilising the land. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil salinisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: A serious disruption of the functioning of society, causing widespread human, material or environmental losses, which exceed the ability of affected society to cope using only its own resources. Disasters are often classified according to their cause (natural or man-made). [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: disaster

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water quality
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Physical, chemical, biological and organoleptic (taste-related) properties of water. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEC.definition: Directive 2001/81/EC on national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants. Its objective is to set national emission ceilings for pollutants causing acidification and eutrophication and for ozone precursors in order to provide fuller protection for the environment and human health against their adverse effects. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEC.name: NECD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM0.definition: particulate matter with an average aerodynamic diameter of up to 0.1 µm, referred to as ultrafine particle fraction [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM0.name: PM0.1

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.definition: A group of persons sharing a home or living space, who aggregate and share their incomes, as evidenced by the fact that they regularly take meals together. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.name: household

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_sl: kombinirana proizvodnja toplotne in električne energije
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_es: producción conjunta de calor y energía
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_pl: skojarzone wytwarzanie ciepła i energii elektrycznej
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_pt: produção combinada de calor e electricidade
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_es: producción conjunta de calor y energía
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: combined heat and power generation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_pl: skojarzone wytwarzanie ciepła i energii elektrycznej
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_pt: produção combinada de calor e electricidade
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_nl: tegelijkertijd opwekken van warmte en stroom
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_sl: kombinirana proizvodnja toplotne in električne energije
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_bg: комбинирано производство на топлина и eлектроенергия (от един и същи източник)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_bg: комбинирано производство на топлина и eлектроенергия (от един и същи източник)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: The consecutive generation of useful thermal and electric energy from the same fuel source. [definition source: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_nl: tegelijkertijd opwekken van warmte en stroom

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFP.definition: The common fisheries policy (CFP) covers the exploitation of living aquatic resources and aquaculture, and the processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products. These activities take place on the territory of Member States or in Community fishing waters or are performed by fishing vessels flying a European flag. Community fishing waters means waters under the sovereignty or jurisdiction of Member States. The objective is to allow sustainable rational and responsible exploitation of living aquatic resources and aquaculture in economic and social conditions appropriate to the sector. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CFP.name: CFP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.name: manure
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.definition: Animal excreta collected from stables and barnyards with or without litter; used to enrich the soil. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dev.definition: Synonyms: ECOEHIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dev.name: Development of environmental health indicators for European Union countries
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dev.objecttrans_en: Development of environmental health indicators for European Union countries
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dev.objectname_en: development of environmental health indicators for european union countries

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: preliminary treatment (of wastewater)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: (1) Removal of large solids, oils, fat and other material from sewage so as to protect wastewater treatment facilities engaged in further treatment. (2) The first stage of wastewater treatment which removes debris, sand, grit and fine particles. [definition source: (1) United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nes.definition: A place where birds gather to lay eggs. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nes.name: nesting area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_KAM.definition: Synonyms: Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_KAM.name: KAMA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.definition: Synonyms: MODIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.name: Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: The Global Positioning System, usually called GPS (the US military refers to it as NAVSTAR), is an intermediate circular orbit (ICO) satellite navigation system used for determining one's precise location and providing a highly accurate time reference almost anywhere on Earth or in Earth orbit. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global positioning system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO2.definition: Gas naturally produced by animals during respiration and through decay of biomass, and used by plants during photosynthesis. Although it only constitutes 0.04 percent of the atmosphere, it is one of the most important greenhouse gases. The combustion of fossil fuels is increasing carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere, which is believed to be contributing to global warming. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO2.name: CO2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sen.objectname_hu: {wat} ökológiailag érzékeny terület (esa - ecologically sensitive area)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sen.name: sensitive area
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sen.objecttrans_hu: {WAT} ökológiailag érzékeny terület (ESA - ecologically sensitive area)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sen.definition: (1) Areas of a country where special measures may be given to protect the natural habitats which present a high level of vulnerability. (2) Member States has to identify water bodies as sensitive areas in accordance with the criteria of the urban wastewater treatment directive (eutrophication, high concentration of nitrates in surface waters intended for abstraction of drinking water, areas where further treatment is necessary to fulfil other directives). In sensitive areas and catchment of sensitive areas Member States have to ensure the provision of more advanced treatment. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000); 2) EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 170. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAR.definition: The Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL Convention) is the main international convention covering prevention of pollution of the marine environment by ships from operational or accidental causes. It is a combination of two treaties adopted in 1973 and 1978 respectively and updated by amendments through the years. [definition source: International Marine Organisation.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAR.name: MARPOL Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: Statistical Office of the European Communities [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Eurostat

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.definition: Regulate, plan and work toward the accomplishment of completion of stated goals, objectives and mission pertaining to air quality. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.name: air quality managment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Map.definition: Synonyms: SOVEUR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Map.name: Mapping of Soil and Terrain Vulnerability in Central and Eastern Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Map.objecttrans_en: Mapping of Soil and Terrain Vulnerability in Central and Eastern Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Map.objectname_en: mapping of soil and terrain vulnerability in central and eastern europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water body
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: 1) Also 'waters'. Landscape features comprising any body of water, standing of flowing, including the water column, littoral zones and bed, such us the sea, lakes, river or stream, etc. 2) Any mass of water having definite hydrological, physical, chemical and biological characteristics and which can be employed for one or several purposes. [definition source: 1) EUNIS (October 1998 version). Quoted by: European Topic Centre on Nature Conservation. 1998. EUNIS habitat classification. Final draft with further revisions to marine habitats. United Kingdom. 2) EEA (GEMET)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sea.definition: Synonyms: sea-viewing wide field-of-view sensor [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sea.name: SeaWiFS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Environmental noise shall mean unwanted or harmful outdoor sound created by human activities, including noise emitted by means of transport, road traffic, rail traffic, air traffic, and from sites of industrial activity such as those defined in Annex I to Council Directive 96/61/EC of 24 September 1996 concerning integrated pollution prevention and control. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental noise

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ECB [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Chemicals Bureau

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.definition: A form of electromagnetic radiation that does not have enough energy to cause ionisation of atoms in living tissue. Examples of this type of radiation include radio waves, microwaves, infrared light, and ordinary light. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.name: non-ionising radiation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objectname_sl: sistem menedžmenta za zviševanje učinkovitosti opreme uporabnika
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objecttrans_es: gestión por el lado de la demanda
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objectname_pt: gestão tendo em conta a procura
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objectname_es: gestión por el lado de la demanda
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.name: demand-side management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objecttrans_pt: gestão tendo em conta a procura
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objecttrans_sl: sistem menedžmenta za zviševanje učinkovitosti opreme uporabnika
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.definition: Implementation of policies or measures which serve to control or influence the demand. [definition source: Adapted from: EEA. 2001. Sustainable water use in Europe. Part 2. Demand management. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water demand
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water demand is defined as the volume of water requested by users to satisfy their needs. In a simplified way it is often considered equal to water abstraction, although conceptually the two terms do not have the same meaning. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 159. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_all.definition: Any antigen, such as pollen, a drug, or food, that induces an allergic state in humans or animals. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_all.name: allergen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.definition: An approach to (environmental) scenario analysis that combines qualitative and quantitative information based on two main elements: a narrative (story) and results from model calculations (simulation). The narrative describes in story-form how relevant events, key driving forces and step-wise changes unfold in the future. The results from model calculations complement the storyline by presenting numerical estimates of environmental indicators. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.name: story-and-simulation approach

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: The status of a soil with respect to the amount and availability to plants of elements necessary for plant growth. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil fertility

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: The determination of the activity or concentration of a chemical by its effect on the growth of an organism under experimental conditions. [definition source: K. ten Kate & S.A. Laird. 1999. The commercial use of biodiversity: Access to genetic resources and benefit-sharing. European Commission. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: bioassay

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.definition: Process by which an aquifer is overpumped creating a flow imbalance within an area that results in salt water encroaching into fresh-water supply. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.name: saltwater intrusion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COR.definition: Synonyms: Committee of the Regions [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COR.name: COR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fish stock
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.objectname_bg: запаси (наличност) от жива риба, рибно богатство
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.objecttrans_bg: запаси (наличност) от жива риба, рибно богатство
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: The living resources in the community or population from which catches are taken in a fishery. Use of the term fish stock usually implies that the particular population is more or less isolated from other stocks of the same species and hence self-sustaining. In a particular fishery, the fish stock may be one or several species of fish but here is also intended to include commercial invertebrates and plants. [definition source: FAO Fishery Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COP.definition: Synonyms: Conference of the Parties [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COP.name: COP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LPV.definition: Chemicals placed on the market in volumes between 10 tonnes and 1000 tonnes per year per producer/importer. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LPV.name: LPV chemical

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Presence in water of harmful and objectionable material - obtained from sewers, industrial wastes and rainwater run-off - in sufficient concentrations to make it unfit for use. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: The EU has defined an Information threshold of 180 µg ozone per m3 air. Any exceedance of this threshold should be reported by the Member State in which it occurs to the European Commission. The threshold reflects a 'level beyond which there is a risk to human health from brief exposure for particularly sensitive sections of the population'. When the threshold is exceeded, national authorities are required to inform the public. See also Alert threshold. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: information threshold

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Sustainable development indicators are indicators that measure progress made in sustainable growth and development. They can provide an early warning, sounding the alarm in time to prevent economic, social and environmental damage. They are also important tools to communicate ideas of sustainable development. Indicators for monitoring progress towards sustainable development are needed in order to assist decision-makers and policy-makers at all levels and to increase focus on sustainable development. Beyond the commonly used economic indicators of well-being, however, social, environmental and institutional indicators have to be taken into account as well to arrive at a broader, more complete picture of societal development. A core set of 58 indicators and methodology sheets are now available for all countries to use. This core set was adopted by the Commission on Sustainable Development (CSD) at its Third Session in April 1995. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable development indicator

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DFT.definition: Synonyms: Department for Transport, United Kingdom [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DFT.name: DFT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: A substance which when added to a material, usually a plastic but also paint or an adhesive, makes it flexible, resilient and easier to handle. Modern plasticisers are manmade organic chemicals; the majority of which are esters, such as adipates and phthalates. [definition source: Euro Chlor. Short glossary of chlorine chemistry.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: plasticiser

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_sl: koncept, da stroške onesnaženja nosi onesnaževalec
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_lv: ekonomiska koncepcija, saskaņā ar kuru piesārņotājs pats atlīdzina nodarīto kaitējumu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_hu: {envins} a külsõ költségek visszahárítása a szennyezés okozójára
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_is: að taka á sig kostnað vegna eigin mengunar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_pl: zasada przypisania kosztów określonych działań sprawcy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_is: að taka á sig kostnað vegna eigin mengunar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: internalisation of externalities
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_pl: zasada przypisania kosztów określonych działań sprawcy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_hu: {ENVINS} a külsõ költségek visszahárítása a szennyezés okozójára
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_lv: ekonomiska koncepcija, saskaņā ar kuru piesārņotājs pats atlīdzina nodarīto kaitējumu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_fi: käsite, jonka mukaan saastuttaja maksaa ulkoiset kustannukset, jotka on aiheuttanut
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_fr: prise en compte des facteurs externes de dégradation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_nl: het intern maken van externe kosten
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_sl: koncept, da stroške onesnaženja nosi onesnaževalec
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_bg: интернализация на външни разходи (причинителят на замърсяването носи пряко разходите по замърсяването)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_fi: käsite, jonka mukaan saastuttaja maksaa ulkoiset kustannukset, jotka on aiheuttanut
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_fr: prise en compte des facteurs externes de dégradation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_bg: интернализация на външни разходи (причинителят на замърсяването носи пряко разходите по замърсяването)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Incorporation of an externality into the market decision making process through pricing or regulatory interventions. In the narrow sense, internalisation is achieved by charging polluters (for example) with the damage costs of the pollution generated by them, in accordance with the polluter pays principle. [definition source: European Conference of Ministers of Transport. Social costs glossary. CEMT/CS(97)12.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_nl: het intern maken van externe kosten

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.name: earmarking
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.definition: Refers to the pre-commitment of taxes to support, or fully fund, pre-specified expenditure items. These revenues may be channelled through the general budget or may be paid directly to a dedicated fund. [definition source: NEI Transport. 2000. Phare multi-country transport programme (ZZ-9610). Road transport charges. Rotterdam.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.name: qualitative scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.definition: Qualitative scenarios describe possible futures in the form of words or visual symbols rather than numerical estimates. They can take the shape of diagrams, phrases or outlines, but more commonly they are made up of narrative texts, i.e. so-called 'storylines'. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: A tax on the annual profits arising from property, business pursuits, professions, trades or offices. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: income tax

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objectname_de: top-down-ansatz, vorgehen von oben nach unten, 'von-oben-nach-unten'-konzept
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objecttrans_de: Top-Down-Ansatz, Vorgehen von oben nach unten, 'Von-oben-nach-unten'-Konzept
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.name: top-down approach
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objectname_fr: approche du sommet vers la base
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objecttrans_fr: approche du sommet vers la base

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hap.definition: Something that takes place or comes to pass. Occurrence and happening are the most general: an everyday occurrence; a happening of no great importance.Event usually signifies a notable occurrence: major world events reported on the evening news. 'Great events make me quiet and calm; it is only trifles that irritate my nerves' Victoria.Incident may apply to a minor occurrence: a small incident blown out of proportion.The term may also refer to a distinct event of sharp identity and significance: a succession of exciting incidents.An episode is an incident in the course of a progression or within a larger sequence: 'Happiness was but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain' Thomas Hardy.Circumstance denotes a particular incident or occurrence: 'Billy had found Alice, thus bringing about the odd circumstance of their renewing their acquaintanceship' Eleanor H. Porter. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hap.name: happening

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: Energy security or security of supply can be defined as the availability of energy at all times in various forms, in sufficient quantities, and at reasonable and/or affordable prices. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy security

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objectname_lv: aot40, atšķirība starp ozona koncentrāciju un standartkoncentrāciju augu augšanas periodā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objectname_hu: {aircha} aot40, 40 ppbhs határértéket meghaladó felgyülemlett szennyezőanyag-mennyiség (accumulated exposure over a threshold of 40ppb)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objecttrans_is: mat á ósonmagni og breytingum á því (AOT40)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objectname_is: mat á ósonmagni og breytingum á því (aot40)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.name: AOT40
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objecttrans_hu: {AIRCHA} AOT40, 40 ppbhs határértéket meghaladó felgyülemlett szennyezőanyag-mennyiség (accumulated exposure over a threshold of 40ppb)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objecttrans_lv: AOT40, atšķirība starp ozona koncentrāciju un standartkoncentrāciju augu augšanas periodā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objectname_fi: aot40: otsonin tuntipitoisuuden ja 40 miljardisosan erotusten summa kultakin tunnilta, jolloin pitoisuus ylittää 40 miljardisosaa kasvukautena
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.objecttrans_fi: AOT40: otsonin tuntipitoisuuden ja 40 miljardisosan erotusten summa kultakin tunnilta, jolloin pitoisuus ylittää 40 miljardisosaa kasvukautena
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AOT.definition: The sum of the differences between hourly ozone concentration and 40 ppb for each hour when the concentration exceeds 40 ppb during a relevant growing season, e.g. for forest and crops. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.name: background noise
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.definition: Noise coming from source other than the noise source being monitored. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CCI.definition: Synonyms: Chamber of Commerce and Industry of the Russian Federation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CCI.name: CCI RF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: COMEXT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Eurostat database on trade data

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TER.definition: The concept of an indicator-based transport and environment reporting mechanism (TERM) for the EU was initiated in early 1998. TERM is steered jointly by the European Commission and the EEA. The main output of TERM is a regular indicator-based report through which the effectiveness of transport and environment integration strategies is monitored. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TER.name: TERM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_sk: hodnotenie úrovne ochrany životného prostredia, ekologické hodnotenie výkonu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_da: vurdering af indsats og resultater på miljøområdet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_da: vurdering af indsats og resultater på miljøområdet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental performance evaluation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_sk: hodnotenie úrovne ochrany životného prostredia, ekologické hodnotenie výkonu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: оценка на поведението спрямо околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: оценка на поведението спрямо околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: The concept of environmental performance evaluation is being developed for use in an environmental management system to quantify, understand and track the relevant environmental aspects of a system. The basic idea is to identify indicators (environmental, operational and management) which can be measured and tracked to facilitate continuous improvements. [definition source: EEA. 1998. Life cycle assessment. A guide to approaches, experiences and information sources. Environmental issues series No 6]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RMP.definition: Synonyms: refrigeration management plan [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RMP.name: RMP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bat.name: bathing water
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bat.definition: (1) Bathing water means all running or still fresh waters or parts thereof and sea water, in which: - bathing is explicitly authorised by the competent authorities of each member State, or - bathing is not prohibited and is traditionally practised by a large number of bathers. (2) Water identified as bathing water includes all running and still inland surface waters, transitional waters and coastal waters that are actively promoted - locally, regionally, nationally or internationally - for bathing (or which are likely to be so promoted in the foreseeable future) and/or are regularly used by the local and/or visitor populations for bathing. [definition source: 1) Directive 76/160/EEC of 8 December concerning the Quality of Bathing Water. 2) Communication From The Commission to the European Parliament and the Council Developing a new Bathing Water Policy COM (2000)860.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mal.definition: A group of human febrile diseases with a chronic relapsing course caused by hemosporidian blood parasites of the genus Plasmodium, transmitted by the bite of Anopheles mosquito. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mal.name: malaria

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: Any movement of hazardous wastes or other wastes from an area under the national jurisdiction of one State to or through an area under the national jurisdiction of another State or to or through an area not under the national jurisdiction of any State, provided at least two States are involved in the movement. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: transboundary movement of waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNECE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations economic commission for europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated assessment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: An interdisciplinary process of structuring knowledge elements from various scientific disciplines in such a manner that all relevant aspects of a complex societal problem are considered in their mutual coherence for the benefit of decision-making. [definition source: Rotmans. 1999. Quoted by: EEA. 2000. Cloudy crystal balls. Environmental issues series No 17]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bla.definition: Synonyms: BSC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bla.name: Black Sea Commission

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global warming potential
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: Term used to describe the relative potency, molecule for molecule, of a greenhouse gas, taking account of how long it remains active in the atmosphere. The global warming potentials (GWPs) currently used are those calculated over 100 years. Carbon dioxide is taken as the gas of reference and given a 100-year GWP of 1. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sei.definition: The phenomenon of Earth movements. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sei.name: seismic activity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEF.definition: Synonyms: Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs, United Kingdom [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEF.name: DEFRA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dia.definition: Microscopic single-celled algae which have two ornate interfitting outer 'shells' containing silica. [definition source: FAO fisheries glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dia.name: diatom

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Foo.definition: Synonyms: FAOSTAT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Foo.name: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations' Statistical Database
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Foo.objecttrans_en: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations' Statistical Database
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Foo.objectname_en: food and agriculture organization of the united nations' statistical database

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GFC.definition: Synonyms: General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GFC.name: GFCM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCF.definition: Compounds used as replacements for chloro-fluorocarbons (CFCs) in various applications because they are less active ozone depleters. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCF.name: HCFC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Areas of outstanding natural beauty, set aside for the conservation of flora, fauna and scenery, and for recreation, if this does not conflict with the conservation objectives of the parks and their landscapes. Hunting, logging, mining, commercial fishing, agriculture and livestock grazing are all controlled within national parks, as is industrial activity. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: national park

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.definition: Accounting tables that provide information on the material input into an economy delivered by the natural environment, the transformation and use of that input in economic processes (extraction, conversion, manufacturing, consumption) and its return to the natural environment as residuals (wastes). The accounting concepts involved are founded on the first law of thermodynamics, which states that matter (mass/energy) is neither created nor destroyed by any physical process. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.name: materials and energy balance

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_de: integrierter ansatz, integrierte methode, integriertes verfahren
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_de: integrierter Ansatz, integrierte Methode, integriertes Verfahren
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated approach
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Integration: The process of bringing together separate components as a functional whole that involves coordination of interventions. [definition source: Scialabba. 1998. Quoted by: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ESL.definition: Synonyms: European Statistical Laboratory [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ESL.name: ESL

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.objectname_hu: {chehea} problematikus / nehezen kezelhető / különleges kezelést igénylő vegyi anyagok
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical of concern
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.objecttrans_hu: {CHEHEA} problematikus / nehezen kezelhető / különleges kezelést igénylő vegyi anyagok
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.objectname_bg: химикал, който е от значение, който води до създаване на проблеми, проблематичен химикал
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.objecttrans_bg: химикал, който е от значение, който води до създаване на проблеми, проблематичен химикал
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: Chemicals considered as problematic by some Member States. [definition source: Adapted from: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: Synonyms: DG [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directorate General

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ind.definition: Noise produced by industrial plants activities. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ind.name: industrial noise

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ESD.definition: Synonyms: Education for Sustainable Development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ESD.name: ESD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppb.definition: A way to describe how much of a substance is contained in a sample: parts of analyte per billion parts of sample. In atmospheric chemistry this becomes volume parts of analyte per volume parts of atmosphere. [definition source: Sam Houston State University. United States. Atmospheric Chemistry Glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppb.name: ppbv

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACI.definition: Synonyms: Arctic Climate Impact Assessment [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACI.name: ACIA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: This is a phenomenon that occurs during the polar winter in which stratospheric air moves in a circular motion, with an area of relatively still air in its centre. The temperature in the vortex is approximately -130 degrees F (-80 degrees C), which assists in the formation of polar stratospheric clouds. Though usually more prolonged and colder over Antarctica, the Arctic polar vortex does form to a degree, and when the temperatures there are coldest and the vortex persists, Arctic stratospheric ozone destruction on Arctic polar stratospheric clouds has also been observed. [definition source: San Houston State University. Atmospheric chemistry glossary, 2000 version.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: polar vortex

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCA.definition: Synonyms: Science, Children, Awareness, EU Legislation and Continuous Evaluation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCA.name: SCALE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_sk: kanál pre odvod odpadových i zrákových vôd
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_es: red unitaria; canal de desagüe unitario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_es: red unitaria; canal de desagüe unitario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: combined sewer
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_sk: kanál pre odvod odpadových i zrákových vôd
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_bg: канал за отпадъчни и дъждовни води
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_bg: канал за отпадъчни и дъждовни води
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: A sewer that carries both sewage and storm water run-off. [definition source: Environment Canada. Glossary]
