glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eve.definition: In statistics, the frequency of an event is simply the number of times the event occurred in the experiment or the study. These frequencies are often graphically represented in histograms. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eve.name: events

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: The use of a biological entity as a detector and its response as a measure to determine environmental conditions. Toxicity tests and biological surveys are common biomonitoring methods. [definition source: US EPA. Glossary: Overview of watershed monitoring.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biomonitoring

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ale.definition: The EU has defined an Alert threshold of 240 µg ozone per m3 air. Any exceedance of this threshold should be reported by the Member State in which it occurs to the European Commission. The threshold reflects a 'level beyond which there is a risk to human health from brief exposure for the general population'. When the threshold is exceeded, national authorities are required to inform the public and give advice. See also Information threshold. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ale.name: Alert threshold

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.name: total cost assessment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.definition: Total cost assessment (TCA) is used to assess pollution prevention projects using environmental cost data, appropriate time horizons, and standard financial indicators. TCA utilises full cost accounting techniques to properly assign environmental costs and savings to all competing projects, products or processes as part of capital budgeting. Under TCA, decision makers will use traditional financial measures in determining the feasibility of an investment project. [definition source: International Institute for Industrial Development Economics at Lund University. 2000. Continuity, credibility and comparability. Sweden.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cle.objecttrans_es: centro de compensación (de una red de información)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cle.objectname_es: centro de compensación (de una red de información)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cle.name: clearing-house
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cle.definition: 1) Originally used in the business sector, a clearing-house is a service which facilitates and simplifies transactions among multiple parties. 2) EnviroWindows (E-Windows) is a combination of web-based networks and an information clearinghouse. Both services are accessible at the European Environment Agency's (EEA) homepage. The clearinghouse contains reports generated by the EEA's publicly procured contracts as well as documents produced by the Interest Groups. [definition source: 1) Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary. Montreal.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTA.definition: The amount of compensation an individual is willing to take in exchange for giving up some good or service. This may be elicited from stated or revealed preference approaches. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTA.name: WTA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_shr.definition: A vegetation type where the dominant woody elements are shrubs which grow to a height of more than 50 cm and less than 5 metres on maturity. The height limits for trees and shrubs should be interpreted with flexibility. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_shr.name: shrub

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GMO.definition: Synonyms: genetically modified organisms [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GMO.name: GMOs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_phy.definition: Physical input-output tables (PIOT) describe the flows of material and energy within the economic system and between the economic system and the natural environment. They also describe the physical accumulation of materials in the economy, but not the stocks of man-made or natural capital. [definition source: Eurostat. 2001. Economy-wide material flow accounts and derived indicators. Luxembourg.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_phy.name: physical input-output tables

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FEC.definition: Synonyms: final energy consumption [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FEC.name: FEC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EBC.definition: Synonyms: European Bird Census Council [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EBC.name: EBCC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cum.name: cumulative impacts
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cum.definition: The impacts (positive or negative, direct and indirect, long-term and short-term impacts) arising from a range of activities throughout an area or region, where each individual effect may not be significant if taken in isolation. Such impacts can arise from the growing volume of traffic, the combined effect of a number of agriculture measures leading to more intensive production and use of chemicals, etc. Cumulative impacts include a time dimension, since they should calculate the impact on environmental resources resulting from changes brought about by past, present and reasonably foreseeable future actions. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.name: habitat
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.definition: (1) The place or type of site where an organism or population naturally occurs. (2) Terrestrial or aquatic areas distinguished by geographic, abiotic and biotic features, whether entirely natural or semi-natural. [definition source: (1) The Convention on Biological Diversity]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LV.definition: Synonyms: limit value [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LV.name: LV

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.definition: In statistics, the frequency of an event is simply the number of times the event occurred in the experiment or the study. These frequencies are often graphically represented in histograms. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.name: repetitions

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_en: deliberate release of genetically modified organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_hu: {natbio} genetikailag módosított organizmusok természetbe történő szándékos kihelyezése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_es: descarga deliberada de organismo modificado genéticamente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_sv: avsiktlig utsättning av genetiskt modifierad organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_it: emissione deliberata di un organismo geneticamente modificato
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_de: absichtliche freisetzung eines genetisch veränderten organismus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_de: absichtliche Freisetzung eines genetisch veränderten Organismus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_it: emissione deliberata di un organismo geneticamente modificato
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_pt: libertação deliberada de organismos geneticamente modificados
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_es: descarga deliberada de organismo modificado genéticamente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.name: deliberate release of genetically modified organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_hu: {NATBIO} genetikailag módosított organizmusok természetbe történő szándékos kihelyezése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_pt: libertação deliberada de organismos geneticamente modificados
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_en: deliberate release of genetically modified organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_cs: záměrné uvolnění geneticky modifikovaného organismu do prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_nl: het opzettelijk vrijlaten van genetisch gewijzigd organismen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_bg: съзнателно допускане, създаване на генетично видоизменен организъм
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_sv: avsiktlig utsättning av genetiskt modifierad organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_ro: degajarea deliberată de organisme modificate genetic
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_bg: съзнателно допускане, създаване на генетично видоизменен организъм
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.definition: Any intentional introduction into the environment of a genetically modified organism (GMO) or a combination of GMOs without provisions for containment such as physical barriers or a combination of physical barriers together with chemical and/or biological barriers used to limit their contact with the general population and the environment. [definition source: Directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objectname_cs: záměrné uvolnění geneticky modifikovaného organismu do prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_ro: Degajarea deliberată de organisme modificate genetic
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_del.objecttrans_nl: het opzettelijk vrijlaten van genetisch gewijzigd organismen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WBC.definition: Synonyms: World Business Council for Sustainable Development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WBC.name: WBCSD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEC.definition: Synonyms: Eastern Europe, the Caucasus and Central Asia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEC.name: EECCA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAO.definition: Synonyms: North Atlantic Oscillation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAO.name: NAO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUN.definition: EUNIS has been developed by the EEA European Topic Centre on Nature Protection and Biodiversity. It has two main aims: to facilitate use of data by promoting harmonisation of terminology and definitions, and to be a reservoir of information on European environmentally important matters. EUNIS consists of a central unit integrating data models on species, habitats and sites; several secondary databases which are managed by different partners; and an increasing number of satellite databases. [definition source: Adapted from: ETC/NPB.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUN.name: EUNIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAI.definition: Synonyms: net annual increment [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAI.name: NAI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BRE.definition: Synonyms: Best Available Technology Reference Documents [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BRE.name: BREF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Applying a monetary rate or value at which water can be bought or sold. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water price

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_THE.definition: Synonyms: Transport, Health and Environment Pan-European Programme [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_THE.name: THE PEP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wes.definition: Synonyms: WAIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wes.name: West Antarctic ice sheet

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wor.definition: The Convention concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage (the World Heritage Convention) was adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO in 1972. It covers both cultural and natural heritage sites. 'Cultural heritage' is a monument, group of buildings or site of historical, aesthetic, archaeological, scientific, ethnological or anthropological value. 'Natural heritage' designates outstanding physical, biological, and geological features; habitats of threatened plants or animal species and areas of value on scientific or aesthetic grounds or from the point of view of conservation. More than 170 countries have adhered to the Convention. [definition source: UNESCO. World Heritage.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wor.name: world heritage site

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.definition: Synonyms: CIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.name: Commonwealth of Independent States

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TSA.definition: Synonyms: tourism satellite accounts [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TSA.name: TSA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.definition: Maximum references laid down in Title IV for the doses resulting from the exposure of workers, apprentices and students and members of the public to ionizing radiation covered by this Directive that apply to the sum of the relevant doses from external exposures in the specified period and the 50- year committed doses (up to age 70 for children) from intakes in the same period. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.name: dose limits

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.definition: Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC). Widely regarded as the most authoritative international voice on the science and impacts of climate change. Established by governments under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organisation and UN Environment Programme (UNEP) in 1988, the IPCC produces five-yearly reports assessing the state of knowledge on climate change which represent the international consensus among the more than 2 000 experts involved. It has also published reports on specific issues, such as sinks. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.name: IPCC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.name: genetic diversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.definition: The variety of genes within a particular species, variety or breed. [definition source: UNEP. Glossary of biodiversity terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.definition: Synonyms: IEEP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.name: Institute for European Environmental Policy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ref.definition: Synonyms: RMP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ref.name: refrigeration management plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.name: emission factor
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: The estimated average emission rate of a given pollutant for a given source, relative to units of activity. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Guidelines for defining and documenting data on costs of possible environmental protection measures. Technical report No 27.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ERO.definition: The Landsat program is the longest running enterprise for acqusition of imagery of Earth from space. The first Landsat satellite was launched in 1972; the most recent, Landsat 7, was launched on April 15, 1999. The instruments on the Landsat satellites have acquired millions of images. The images, archived in the United States and at Landsat receiving stations around the world, are a unique resource for global change research and applications in agriculture, geology, forestry, regional planning, education and national security. History: The program was called the Earth Resources Observation Satellites Program when it was initiated in 1966, but the name was changed to Landsat in 1975.Landsat 1 - launched July 23, 1972, terminated operations in 1978, Landsat 2 - launched January 22, 1975, terminated in 1981, Landsat 3 - launched March 5, 1978, terminated 1983, Landsat 4 - launched July 16, 1982, terminated 1993, Landsat 5 - launched March 1, 1984, Landsat 6 - launched October 5, 1993, failed to reach orbit, Landsat 7 - launched April 15, 1999. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ERO.name: EROS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MEd.definition: Synonyms: Mediterranean Education Initiative for Environment & Sustainability [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MEd.name: MEdIES

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: Agri-environment schemes are Government programmes set up to help farmers manage their land in an environmentally-friendly way. Agri-environmental schemes are important for the conservation of farmed environments of high nature value, for improved genetic diversity and for protection of agro-ecosystems. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agri-environment scheme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_C6H.definition: Synonyms: benzene [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_C6H.name: C6H6

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.definition: A serious disruption of the functioning of society, causing widespread human, material or environmental losses, which exceed the ability of affected society to cope using only its own resources. Disasters are often classified according to their cause (natural or man-made). [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.name: catastrophe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.definition: The biota living on, or very near, the bottom of the sea, river, or lake. [definition source: IPCC. Climate Change 2001 Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.name: benthic organism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIC.definition: Synonyms: European Information & Communications Technology Industry Association [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIC.name: EICTA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: compost
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: Mixture of organic garbage and degradable trash with soil, in which bacteria in the soil break down the garbage and trash into organic fertiliser. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Those aspects of human health and disease that are determined by factors in the environment. It also refers to the theory and practice of assessing and controlling factors in the environment that can potentially affect health. Environmental health includes both the direct pathological effects of chemicals, radiation and some biological agents, and the effects (often indirect) on health and well-being of the broad physical, psychological, social and aesthetic environment, which includes housing, urban development, land use and transport. [definition source: WHO/EURO, 1995. Quoted by: International Society of Doctors for the Environment (ISDE). Primer on international environment and health politics (version of September 2001).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental health

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_F-g.definition: Synonyms: fluorinated gases [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_F-g.name: F-gases

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_ner.definition: A coordinating and integrating system which functions in the adaptation of an organism to its environment; in vertebrates, the system consists of the brain, brainstem, spinal cord, cranial and peripheral nerves, and ganglia. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_ner.name: nervous system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: An expression of both acidity and alkalinity on a scale of 0 to 14, with 7 representing neutrality; numbers less than 7 indicate increasing acidity and numbers greater than 7 indicate increasing alkalinity. [definition source: Environment Canada. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrogen ion concentration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AE_.definition: Agri-environment schemes are Government programmes set up to help farmers manage their land in an environmentally-friendly way. Agri-environmental schemes are important for the conservation of farmed environments of high nature value, for improved genetic diversity and for protection of agro-ecosystems. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AE_.name: AE scheme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: The response of the immune system to irritation or injury of body tissues. Signs and symptoms are pain, heat, redness, swelling and loss of function. For instance, lung inflammation can lead to reduced lung function. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: inflammation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste collection
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The periodic or on-demand removal of solid waste from primary source locations using a collection vehicle and followed by the depositing of this waste at some central facility or disposal site. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: the European Chemicals Bureau (ECB) was established within the Environment Institute of JRC Ispra with effect of 1st January, 1993. The principal task of the bureau is to carry out and coordinate the scientific/technical work which is needed for the implementation of EU legislation (directives, regulation) in the area of chemical control. [definition source: Joint Research Center Ispra.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Chemical Bureau

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NH4.definition: The radical NH4+ [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NH4.name: NH4

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NH3.definition: Synonyms: ammonia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NH3.name: NH3

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objectname_de: recycling, stoffliche verwertung, verwertung, wiederverwertung, kreislaufwirtschaft
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objecttrans_de: Recycling, stoffliche Verwertung, Verwertung, Wiederverwertung, Kreislaufwirtschaft
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.name: recycling
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.definition: (1) A resource recovery method involving the collection and treatment of a waste product for use as raw material in the manufacture of the same or a similar product. (2) the EU waste strategy distinguishes between: reuse meant as a material reuse without any structural changes in materials; recycling meant as a material recycling, only, and with a reference to structural changes in products; and recovery meant as an energy recovery only. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000). 2) European Statistical Laboratory.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EAP.definition: Synonyms: environment action programme [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EAP.name: EAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cor.definition: For the EEA the core set of indicators is a set of story lines by theme/sector, clusters of indicators by theme/sector grouped by generic and more specific policy questions, and sets of indicator fact sheets or description sheets. Fact sheets are available for indicators that have already been developed. More information about core set of indicators is available on http://themes.eea.eu.int/indicators/coreset [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cor.name: core set of indicators

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: Infrastructure capacity means the potential to schedule train paths requested for an element of infrastructure for a certain period. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: infrastructure capacity of railway infrastructure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Any area of land or water that has been set aside for a special purpose, often to prevent or reduce harm to its wildlife and ecosystems. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: reserve

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pac.definition: Packaging shall mean all products made of any materials of any nature to be used for the containment, protection, handling, delivery and presentation of goods, from raw materials to processed goods, from the producer to the user or the consumer. Non-returnable items used for the same purposes shall also be considered to constitute packaging.Packaging consists only of:(a) sales packaging or primary packaging, i. e. packaging conceived so as to constitute a sales unit to the final user or consumer at the point of purchase; (b) grouped packaging or secondary packaging, i. e. packaging conceived so as to constitute at the point of purchase a grouping of a certain number of sales units whether the latter is sold as such to the final user or consumer or whether it serves only as a means to replenish the shelves at the point of sale; it can be removed from the product without affecting its characteristics; (c) transport packaging or tertiary packaging, i. e. packaging conceived so as to facilitate handling and transport of a number of sales units or grouped packagings in order to prevent physical handling and transport damage. Transport packaging does not include road, rail, ship and air containers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pac.name: packaging

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.definition: Developed by the Major Accident Hazards Bureau of the Joint Research Centre, the 'Seveso plants information retrieval system' (SPIRS) allows easy visualisation of important hazard and risk related information from such plants and estimation of their hazard and risk potential. The main objective of SPIRS is to support the Member States in their risk management related decision making processes by giving an insight into the geographical component of risk from Seveso plants. This is done by providing a map of all Seveso plants in the EU as well as a flexible tool to rank the hazard/risk potential of such plants. [definition source: Adapted from: European Agency for Safety and Health at Work.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.name: Seveso Plants Information Retrieval System

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Fra.definition: Synonyms: FWD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Fra.name: Framework Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.definition: The removing of chemical, biological, or radiological contamination from, or the neutralizing of it on a person, object, or area. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.name: decontamination

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental risk assessment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: оценка на риска за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: оценка на риска за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Component of risk management which comprises all processes concerned with identification, estimation and qualitative and quantitative evaluation of risks. Risk assessment consists of hazard identification, hazard assessment, risk estimation and risk reduction The terms risk management and risk assessment are used in many different ways, in different contexts and jurisdictions and by different professions. There is often little consistency of use even within one country. It is therefore recommended, that these terms are explained in the context in which they are intended to apply. Example: In the environmental context the risk is posed to human health and/or the environment by the actual or potential presence and/or use of specific. [definition source: Choudhury and Jansen. 1997. Quoted by: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EEC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Economic Community

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Synonyms: EHPR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environment and health performance review

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_app.name: appraisal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_app.objectname_bg: преценка (оценка) от официална служба, експертна оценка, експертиза на вещо лице
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_app.objecttrans_bg: преценка (оценка) от официална служба, експертна оценка, експертиза на вещо лице
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_app.definition: An expert or official valuation. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fou.name: founding regulation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fou.definition: Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 established the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Information and Observation Network (EIONET). Regulation (EEC) No 1201/90 was amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 933/1999 in April 1999. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU.definition: Synonyms: European Union [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU.name: EU

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: Synonyms: GMES [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global monitoring for environment and security
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.objecttrans_en: global monitoring for environment and security
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.objectname_en: global monitoring for environment and security

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IIA.definition: Synonyms: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IIA.name: IIASA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: The Convention concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage (the World Heritage Convention) was adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO in 1972. The large number of countries adhered to the convention, makes it one of the most universal international legal instruments for the protection of the cultural and natural heritage. [definition source: Based on: UNESCO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Heritage Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Leq.objecttrans_es: Leq (nivel de ruido en equivalente energético)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Leq.objectname_es: leq (nivel de ruido en equivalente energético)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Leq.name: Leq
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Leq.definition: Energy equivalent noise level. It is a time-averaged sound level; a single-number value that expresses the time-varying sound level for the specified period as though it were a constant sound level with the same total sound energy as the time-varying level. Its unit is the decibel (dB). [definition source: Based on: US national nuclear security administration.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BTC.definition: Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan (oil pipeline) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BTC.name: BTC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objectname_lv: bod, bioķīmiskais skābekļa patēriņš, ūdens organiskā piesārņojuma rādītājs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objecttrans_es: BOD (índice de contaminación orgánica del agua)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objectname_es: bod (índice de contaminación orgánica del agua)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.name: biochemical oxygen demand
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objecttrans_lv: BOD, bioķīmiskais skābekļa patēriņš, ūdens organiskā piesārņojuma rādītājs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objectname_bg: индекс за потребност, нужда от кислород в биохомията или в биологията
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.objecttrans_bg: индекс за потребност, нужда от кислород в биохомията или в биологията
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.definition: The amount of oxygen used for biochemical oxidation by a unit volume of water at a given temperature and for a given time. BOD is an index of the degree of organic pollution in water. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EE.definition: Synonyms: Eastern Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EE.name: EE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.definition: The energy dependence rate shows the proportion of energy that an economy must import. It is defined as net energy imports divided by gross inland energy consumption plus fuel supplied to international maritime bunkers, expressed as a percentage. A negative dependency rate indicates a net exporter of energy, while a dependency rate in excess of 100 % indicates that energy products have been stocked. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.name: Energy dependence rate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EC.definition: Synonyms: European Commission [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EC.name: EC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rur.definition: Rural development is closely linked to the common agricultural policy and measures to support employment. Rural development has become the second pillar of the agricultural policy. With its links to agricultural activities and conversion, it is concerned in particular with: a) modernisation of farms, b) safety and quality of food products, c) fair and stable incomes for farmers, d) environmental challenges, e) supplementary or alternative job-creating activities, in a bid to halt the drift from the country and to strengthen the economic and social fabric of rural areas, f) improvement of living and working conditions, and promotion of equal opportunities. [definition source: European Commission. Glossary Inforegio.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rur.name: rural development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.name: user-pays principle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.objectname_bg: принцип на заплащане на разходите от потребителя (ползвателя) на природен ресурс
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.objecttrans_bg: принцип на заплащане на разходите от потребителя (ползвателя) на природен ресурс
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.definition: Variation of the polluter-pays principle that calls upon the user of a natural resource to bear the cost of running down natural capital. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of Environment Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.name: public water supply
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.definition: Water supply by water works. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.definition: Synonyms: RAC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.name: regional activity centre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: conservation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: The management of human use of the biosphere so that many yield the greatest sustainable benefit to current generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations: Thus conservation in positive, embracing preservations, maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration and enhancement of the natural environment. [definition source: Global biodiversity strategy. WRI, IUCN, UNEP, 1992, Glossary. ISBN 0 915825 74 0 (WRI et al.).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.name: toxic equivalency factor
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.definition: Relative toxicity of an individual congener to the most toxic congener, 2,3,7,8-TCDD (which is assigned a toxic equivalent factor -TEF- value of 1.0). [definition source: European Commission, DG Environment. 1999. Compilation of EU dioxin exposure and health data. Task 7 - Ecotoxicology.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.name: cost-benefit analysis
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_bg: анализ на разходи и икономически ефект
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_bg: анализ на разходи и икономически ефект
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.definition: An approach used in evaluating alternatives, including different scenarios. Involves the weighing of the financial and other resources used against the gains achieved. [definition source: WHO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: A set of facts, assumptions, and interfaces about how exposure takes place. Scenarios are often created to aid exposure assessors in estimating exposure. [definition source: The International Programme on Chemical Safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure scenario

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: World Summit on Sustainable Development, held in Johannesburg (South Africa) in August 2002, ten years after the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Rio Conference). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Summit on Sustainable Development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aba.name: abatement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aba.definition: Reducing the degree or intensity of, or eliminating, pollution. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Area that has only private houses, not offices and factories. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: residential area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_pt: elaboração de relatórios sobre o ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental reporting
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_pt: elaboração de relatórios sobre o ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_fr: systèmes de rapports sur l'état de l'environnement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: докладване относно околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_fr: systèmes de rapports sur l'état de l'environnement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: докладване относно околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Environmental reporting can be defined as a catch-all term that describes the various means by which companies disclose information on their environmental activities. [definition source: International Institute for Industrial Development Economics at Lund University. 2000. Continuity, credibility and comparability. Sweden.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.definition: Synonyms: NIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.name: Newly Independent States

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water removed from any sources, either permanently or temporarily. Mine water and drainage are included. Similar to water withdrawal. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water withdrawal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_el: IPPC (ολοκληρωμένη πρόληψη και έλεγχος της ρύπανσης)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_lv: ippc, kompleksais piesārņojuma novēršanas un kontroles process
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_da: integreret forebyggelse og bekæmpelse af forurening (ippc)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_pl: ippc, zintegrowane działanie służące zapobieganiu i ograniczeniu zanieczyszczenia środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_da: integreret forebyggelse og bekæmpelse af forurening (IPPC)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_pt: ippc (prevenção e controlo integrados da poluição)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.name: IPPC
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_pl: IPPC, zintegrowane działanie służące zapobieganiu i ograniczeniu zanieczyszczenia środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_lv: IPPC, kompleksais piesārņojuma novēršanas un kontroles process
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_el: ippc (ολοκληρωμένη πρόληψη και έλεγχος της ρύπανσης)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_pt: IPPC (Prevenção e Controlo Integrados da Poluição)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_fi: yhtenäinen ympäristön pilaamisen torjunta ja valvonta
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_fr: convention internationale pour la protection des végétaux
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objectname_bg: интегрирано предотвратяване и намаляване на замърсяването на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_fi: yhtenäinen ympäristön pilaamisen torjunta ja valvonta
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_fr: Convention internationale pour la protection des végétaux
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.objecttrans_bg: интегрирано предотвратяване и намаляване на замърсяването на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.definition: Legal process, by which large industrial processes are licensed and regulated, refers specifically to the requirements of the European Commission's IPPC (Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control) Directive (96/61/EC). [definition source: European Commission, DGXI. 1999. Final report on the study of the assessment of indirect and cumulative impacts, as well as impact interactions within the environmental impact assessment (EIA) process.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objectname_lt: išsaugojimas esant natūralioms gamtinėms egzistavimo riboms
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objectname_sv: bevarande i den naturliga livsmiljön (in situ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.name: in-situ conservation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objecttrans_lt: išsaugojimas esant natūralioms gamtinėms egzistavimo riboms
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objectname_bg: консервация на екосистеми и други в тяхната естествена среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objecttrans_sv: bevarande i den naturliga livsmiljön (in situ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.objecttrans_bg: консервация на екосистеми и други в тяхната естествена среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_in-.definition: The conservation of ecosystems and natural habitats and the maintenance and recovery of viable populations of species in their natural surroundings and, in the case of domesticated or cultivated species, in the surroundings where they have developed their distinctive properties. [definition source: Convention on Biological Diversity (art.2).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: Any substance or mixture of substances which through physiological action protects the plants against parasites, fungi, virus, or other damaging factors. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: plant protection products

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_sl: ocena uvajanja ekološko ozaveščene politike podjetja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_hu: {envins} környezeti előnyök és hátrányok értékelése (vállalat vagy szervezet készítette ~)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental statement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_hu: {ENVINS} környezeti előnyök és hátrányok értékelése (vállalat vagy szervezet készítette ~)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_sl: ocena uvajanja ekološko ozaveščene politike podjetja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: анализ на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: анализ на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: 1) Assessment made by a company or organisation of the financial benefits and disadvantages to be derived from adopting a more environmentally sound policy.2) In Eco-management and Auditing Scheme, statement prepared by the company in line with the requirements of this Regulation. [definition source: 1) GEMET 2000. 2) Adapted from: Council Regulation 1836/93 on Eco-Management and Auditing Scheme]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objecttrans_is: meginreglan um að koma í veg fyrir
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objectname_is: meginreglan um að koma í veg fyrir
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: prevention principle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: This principle allows action to be taken to protect the environment at an early stage. It is now not only a question of repairing damages after they have occurred, but to prevent those damages occurring at all. This principle is not as far-reaching as the precautionary principle. It means in short terms: it is better to prevent than repair. [definition source: Oskam, A.J., Vijftigschild, R.A.N., Graveland, C.1997. Additional EU policy instruments for plant protection products. Final report.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NSI.definition: Synonyms: National Snow and Ice Data Centre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NSI.name: NSIDC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_is: moltun, vinnsla úrgangs í lífrænan áburð
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_is: moltun, vinnsla úrgangs í lífrænan áburð
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: composting
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: The controlled biological decomposition of organic material in the presence of air to form a humus-like material. Controlled methods of composting include mechanical mixing and aerating, ventilating the materials by dropping them through a vertical series of aerated chambers, or placing the compost in piles out in the open air and mixing it or turning it periodically. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCI.definition: Synonyms: World Coal Institute [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCI.name: WCI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.definition: An evaluation method which assesses the efficiency of use of materials using information from material flow accounting. Material flow analysis helps to identify waste of natural resources and other materials in the economy which would otherwise go unnoticed in conventional economic monitoring systems. [definition source: Eurostat. 2001. Economy-wide material flow accounts and derived indicators. Luxembourg.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.name: material flow analysis

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.definition: A community of salt-tolerant tress and shrubs, with many other associated organisms, that grows on some tropical and sub-tropical coasts in a zone roughly coinciding with the intertidal zone. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint Group of Experts of the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.name: mangrove forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: Action taken to anticipate, identify and reduce the impact of 'surprises' (unknown impacts and therefore unknown probabilities). [definition source: EEA. 1991. Late lessons from early warnings: the precautionary principle 1896-2000.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: precaution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dir.objecttrans_es: insumo material directo, aporte material directo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dir.objectname_es: insumo material directo, aporte material directo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dir.name: direct material input
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dir.definition: Synonyms: DMI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNESCAP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations economic and social commission for asia and the pacific

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: pressure
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: In the EEA indicator system, pressure indicators describe developments in release of substances (emissions), physical and biological agents, the use of resources and the use of land. The pressures exerted by society are transported and transformed in a variety of natural processes to manifest themselves in changes in environmental conditions. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environmental indicators: Typology and overview. Technical report No 25. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: bioaccumulation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: In an organism, concentration of materials which are not components critical for that organism's survival. Usually it refers to the accumulation of metals or other compounds (e.g. DDT). Many organisms - plants, fungi, protists, bacteria, etc. - accumulate metals when grown in a solution of them, either as part of their defense mechanism against the poisonous effect of those compounds, or as a side-effect of the chemistry of their cell walls. Bio-accumulation is important as part of the microbial mining cycle , removing toxic metals from wastewater, as a purification (bioremediation) process, etc. [definition source: FAO. Glossary of biotechnology and genetic engineering.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCE.definition: Synonyms: Western and Central Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCE.name: WCE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.objectname_de: 1) abflussgebiet, entwässerungsfläche, entwässerungsgebiet 2) einzugsgebiet, wassereinzugsgebiet, sammelgebiet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.objecttrans_de: 1) Abflussgebiet, Entwässerungsfläche, Entwässerungsgebiet 2) Einzugsgebiet, Wassereinzugsgebiet, Sammelgebiet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.name: catchment area
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.definition: (1) An area from which surface runoff is carried away by a single drainage system. (2) The area of land bounded by watersheds draining into a river, basin or reservoir. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-intensity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: An indicator for the 'use of nature' (materials + energy + pollution) per unit of output. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Making sustainability accountable: Eco-efficiency, resource productivity and innovation. Topic report No 11/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.name: bottom ash
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.definition: Relatively coarse, non-combustible, generally toxic residue of incineration that accumulates on the grate of a furnace. [definition source: The Global Development Research Centre. Solid waste management. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vol.definition: The processes by which magma and its associated gases rise into the crust and are extruded onto the Earth's surface and into the atmosphere. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vol.name: volcanism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land use
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Land use corresponds to the socio-economic description (functional dimension) of areas: areas used for residential, industrial or commercial purposes, for farming or forestry, for recreational or conservation purposes, etc. Links with land cover are possible; it may be possible to infer land use from land cover and conversely. But situations are often complicated and the link is not so evident. Contrary to land cover, land use is difficult to 'observe'. For example, it is often difficult to decide if grasslands are used or not for agricultural purposes. Distinctions between land use and land cover and their definition have impacts on the development of classification systems, data collection and information systems in general. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.name: noise abatement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: Activity to reduce the emission of noise or vibrations from a given source, or to protect persons and built-up structures from exposure to noise and vibrations. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NSR.definition: Synonyms: Northern Sea Route [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NSR.name: NSR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Synonyms: GPP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green public procurement

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_roa.definition: Any measure, technique or design intended to reduce the risk of harm posed by moving vehicles along a constructed land route. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_roa.name: road safety

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veh.definition: Unit of measurement representing the movement of a vehicle over one kilometre. The distance to be considered is the distance actually run. It includes movements of empty vehicles. Units made up of a tractor and a semi-trailer or a lorry and a trailer are counted as one vehicle. [definition source: Eurostat, ECMT, UN/ECE. 1997. Glossary for Transport Statistics. Document prepared by the Intersecretariat Working Group on Transport Statistics. Second edition.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veh.name: vehicle-km

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_el: χάρτα ευρωπαϊκών δήμων και κοινοτήτων προς τη βιωσιμότητα

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_hu: Az Európai Városok Chartája a Fenntarthatóság Felé (Aalborgi Charta)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objectname_fi: euroopan kaupunkien ja kuntien sopimus kestävyydestä

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_sv: Deklarationen om europeiska städer för en hållbar stadsutveckling
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_fi: Euroopan kaupunkien ja kuntien sopimus kestävyydestä
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objectname_ro: charta pentru susţinere a oraşelor europene
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_fr: Charte des villes européennes pour la durabilité
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_bg: харта за стабилност на градовете в Европа
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.definition: The Charter of European Cities and Towns Towards Sustainability (Aalborg Charter) was approved by the participants at the European Conference on Sustainable Cities and Towns held in Aalborg, Denmark from 24 to 27 May 1994. The Aalborg Charter was initially signed by 80 European local authorities and 253 representatives of international organisations, national governments, scientific institutes, consultants and individuals. By signing the charter, European cities, towns and counties committed themselves to enter into Local Agenda 21 processes and develop long-term action plans towards sustainability, and initiated the European Sustainable Cities and Towns Campaign. [definition source: Union of Local and Regional Government of Latvia.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objectname_cs: charta evropských měst směřujících k trvale udržitelnému rozvoji
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_ro: Charta pentru susţinere a oraşelor europene
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_nl: Handvest van Europese steden en gemeenten op weg naar duurzaamheid
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cha.objecttrans_no: Charter om bærekraftig utvikling i europeiske byer og tettsteder

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_hu: vizenyős, vízzel telített, vízzel átitatott, elmocsarasodott, időszakosan vízzel borított (terület)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_es: encharcado; empapado de agua; impregnado de agua
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_es: encharcado; empapado de agua; impregnado de agua
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: waterlogged
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_hu: vizenyős, vízzel telített, vízzel átitatott, elmocsarasodott, időszakosan vízzel borított (terület)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Saturated, with the water table at or above ground level for at least half of the year. [definition source: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The Annex IIB of Directive 91/156/EEC amending Directive 75/442/EEC on waste, is intended to list recovery operations as they are carried out in practice:R1 Solvent reclamation/regeneration R2 Recycling/reclamation of organic substances which are not used as solvents R3 Recycling/reclamation of metals and metal compounds R4 Recycling/reclamation of other inorganic materials R5 Regeneration of acids or bases R6 Recovery of components used for pollution abatement R7 Recovery of components from catalysts R8 Oil re-refining or other re-uses of oil R9 Use principally as a fuel or other means to generate energy R10 Spreading on land resulting in benefit to agriculture or ecological improvement, including composting and other biological transformation processes, except in the case of waste excluded under Article 2 (1) (b) (iii) R11 Use of wastes obtained from any of the operations numbered R1 - R10 R12 Exchange of wastes for submission to any of the operations numbered R1 - R11 R13 Storage of materials intended for submission to any operation in this Annex, excluding temporary storage, pending collection, on the site where it is produced.' [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste recovery operation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.definition: Synonyms: Eurostat [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.name: Statistical Office of the European Communities
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_en: Statistical Office of the European Communities
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_en: statistical office of the european communities

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: Tiny, free-floating organisms of the ocean or other aquatic systems. They may be phytoplankton or zooplankton. [definition source: University of California. Berkeley.UCMP Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: plankton

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objectname_lv: nfp, eionet nacionālie centri eiropas vides aģentūras pasākumu koordinēšanai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objectname_pl: narodowa komórka węzłowa w ramach eionet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Focal Point
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objecttrans_pl: narodowa komórka węzłowa w ramach EIONET
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objecttrans_lv: NFP, EIONET nacionālie centri Eiropas Vides aģentūras pasākumu koordinēšanai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: National focal points (NFPs) are appointed and funded by member countries and are in charge of national cooperation with the EEA and national coordination of activities related to the EEA work programme. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: A forest largely undisturbed by human activities. [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: primary forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: The maximum amounts of natural resources that we can use sustainably and without violating global equity. [definition source: EEA. 1997. The concept of environmental space - Implications for policies, environmental reporting and assessments. Expert's corner No 2. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental space

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIT.definition: An international treaty to restrict and monitor trade in endangered species, agreed by 123 parties, with a Secretariat in Switzerland. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIT.name: CITES

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Synonyms: ENVSEC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environment and security initiative

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.objectname_en: community assistance for reconstruction, development and stabilisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The process of obtaining materials or energy resources from waste. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste recovery

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LME.definition: Synonyms: large marine ecosystems [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LME.name: LMEs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FWD.definition: Synonyms: Framework Directive [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FWD.name: FWD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rel.name: release of chemicals
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rel.objectname_nl: het (al dan niet opzettelijk) in de natuur lozen of uitstoten van chemische stoffen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rel.definition: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping, or disposing into the environment of a hazardous or toxic chemical or extremely hazardous substance. [definition source: US EPA]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rel.objecttrans_nl: het (al dan niet opzettelijk) in de natuur lozen of uitstoten van chemische stoffen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage lagoon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.objectname_ro: lac de purificare a apelor uzate
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: Shallow pond, usually human-made, where sunlight, bacteria and oxygen interact to help purify wastewater. The term is synonymous with sewage oxidation pond and stabilisation pond. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.objecttrans_ro: lac de purificare a apelor uzate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vir.definition: Submicroscopic agents that infect plants, animals and bacteria, and are unable to reproduce outside the tissues of the host. A fully formed virus consists of nucleic acid(DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein and lipid (fat)coat. The nucleic acid of the virus interferes with nucleicacid-synthesizing mechanism of the host cell, organizing it to produce more viral nucleic acid. Viruses cause many diseases (e.g., mosaic diseases of many cultivated plants, myxomatosis, foot and mouth disease, the common cold,influenza, measles, poliomyelitis). Many plant viruses are transmitted by insects, some by eelworms. Animal viruses are spread by contact, droplet infection or by insect vectors and some are spread by the exchange of body fluids. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vir.name: virus

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste oil
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Oil arising as a waste product of the use of oils in a wide range of industrial and commercial activities, such as engineering, power generation and vehicle maintenance and should be properly disposed of, or treated in order to be reused. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objecttrans_es: Quinto programa de acción en materia de medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objectname_pl: piąty program działań na rzecz ochrony środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objectname_pt: quinto programa de acção em matéria de ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objecttrans_pt: Quinto Programa de Acção em matéria de Ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.definition: The fifth environmental action programme towards sustainability which was communicated by the Commission to the Council of Ministers in 1993, sets targets for the period from 1993-2000, together with a legislative agenda to the end of 1997. The action programmes are policy documents from the European Commission which aim to provide strategic guidance and orientation for the substantive work programmes and actions of the principal actors within the European Community. [definition source: European Commission. 1998. First report on the implementation of the Convention on biological diversity by the European Community.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objectname_cs: pátý akční program pro životní prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fif.objecttrans_ro: Al 5-lea program de acţiune privind mediul ambiant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.definition: Synonyms: European Topic Centre on Biological Diversity [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.name: ETC/BD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.definition: Synonyms: MFR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.name: maximum feasible reduction

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hg.definition: Synonyms: mercury [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hg.name: Hg

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hab.definition: The Habitat Agenda was adopted by 171 governments at Habitat II (UN Conference on Human Settlements), Istanbul 1996. The Agenda provides a practical roadmap to an urbanising world, setting out approaches and strategies towards the achievement of sustainable development of the world's urban areas. [definition source: UN ESCAP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hab.name: Habitat Agenda

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_it: centro europeo di riferimento per le informazioni sull'ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European Environment Reference Centre (E2RC) refers to the pool of authorised data and information maintained at the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Topic Centres for the purpose of being used by EEA partners and, whenever and possible, made available to the public. [definition source: EEA. 2000. EEA annual work programme 2001.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_cs: evropské centrum pro vyhledávání informací o životním prostředí
