glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.objecttrans_is: leið til að verða fyrir (áhrifum af e-u)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.objectname_is: leið til að verða fyrir (áhrifum af e-u)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure route
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.objecttrans_hu: {CHEHEA} szennyezőanyag / méreg szervezetbe való felvételének útja / módja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: The way a chemical or pollutant enters an organism after contact; i.e., by ingestion, inhalation, or dermal absorption. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: Synonyms: WTO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Trade Organization

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Landfill gas means all the gases generated from the landfilled waste; [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landfill gases

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sea.definition: Synonyms: SAUP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sea.name: Sea Around Us Project

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICM.definition: An approach to farming which aims to balance production with economic and environmental considerations by means of a combination of measures including crop rotation, cultivations, appropriate crop varieties and careful use of inputs. [definition source: English Nature. 1996. Glossary of Agri-Environmental Terms. Research Reports No. 159. Mitchell, K. and Baldock, D. ISSN 0967-876X.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICM.name: ICM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dB.definition: A logarithmic scale used to denote the intensity, or pressure level, of a sound relative to the threshold of human hearing. A step of 10 dB is a 10-fold increase in intensity or sound energy and actually sounds a little more than twice as loud. [definition source: Australian Academy of Sciences. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dB.name: dB

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.definition: An instrument to assess accurately and regularly the extent of progress being made towards the Community's commitments under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Kyoto Protocol. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. Report from the Commission to the European Parlament and the Council under Council Decision 93/389/EEC as amended by Decision 99/296/EC for a monitoring mechanism of Community greenhouse gas emissions. COM(2001) 708 final.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.name: monitoring mechanism of Community greenhouse gas emissions
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.objecttrans_en: monitoring mechanism of Community greenhouse gas emissions
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.objectname_en: monitoring mechanism of community greenhouse gas emissions

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.name: municipal waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.definition: Waste from households, as well as other waste which, because of its nature or composition, is similar to waste from household. [definition source: Directive 1999/31/EC of 26 April 1999 on the landfill of waste.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.definition: Highly stratified region of atmosphere above the troposphere extending from about 10 km (ranging from 9 km in high latitudes to 16 km in the tropics on average) to about 50 km. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.name: stratosphere

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objecttrans_el: παράγοντας που διαταράσσει τη φυσιολογική ενδοκρινική λειτουργία
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objectname_da: hormonforstyrrende stof; kemikalie, der påvirker det endokrine system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objectname_pl: substancja chemiczna zakłócająca funkcjonowanie układu hormonalnego
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objecttrans_da: hormonforstyrrende stof; kemikalie, der påvirker det endokrine system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.name: endocrine disrupter
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objecttrans_pl: substancja chemiczna zakłócająca funkcjonowanie układu hormonalnego
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.objectname_el: παράγοντας που διαταράσσει τη φυσιολογική ενδοκρινική λειτουργία
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.definition: Chemicals that disturb the endocrine system and the organs that respond to hormonal signals. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: sectoral indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Sectoral indicators show links between the activities of societal sectors (transport, energy, forestry, etc.) and the environment. As well a sector's absolute burden on the environment and the development in its eco-efficiency, sectoral indicators deal with a sector's development in size and character and its specific responses to environmental problems. Sectoral indicators can be used to describe progress made in individual sectors, but they also serve to compare sectors. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Environmental signals 2000. Environmental assessment report No 6.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.definition: The avoidance of disease and injury and the promotion of normalcy through efficient use of the environment, aproperly functioning society, and an inner sense of wellbeing. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.name: human health

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WGM.definition: Synonyms: World Glacier Monitoring Service [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WGM.name: WGMS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Euro V vehicles that comply with the emission limits as defined in Directive 99/96/EC, which will enter into force in 2009. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Euro V

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ten.definition: The general direction in which something tends to move. A general tendency or inclination. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ten.name: tendency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_pt: cálculo do custo do ciclo de vida
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life cycle costing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_pt: cálculo do custo do ciclo de vida
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_fr: estimation de la durée de vie
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_nl: berekening van de kosten van de levenscyclus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_bg: калкулация на разходите на цикъла на живот, калкулация, статистическо обобщаване (оценка) на разходите на цикъла на живот
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_fr: estimation de la durée de vie
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_bg: калкулация на разходите на цикъла на живот, калкулация, статистическо обобщаване (оценка) на разходите на цикъла на живот
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: Developed from life cycle analysis, which is a system-oriented approach estimating the environmental inventories (i.e., waste generation, emissions, and discharges) and energy and resource usage associated with a product, process, or operation throughout all stages of the life cycle). Through life cycle costing, managers assign a cost to each impact quantified in the life cycle assessment and sum these costs to estimate the net environmental cost from a product, process or project. [definition source: International Institute for Industrial Development Economics at Lund University. 2000. Continuity, credibility and comparability. Sweden.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_nl: berekening van de kosten van de levenscyclus

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dl.definition: Synonyms: decilitre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dl.name: dl

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HC.definition: Synonyms: hydrocarbon [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HC.name: HC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.definition: The fragile shield of ozone is being damaged by chemicals released on earth. The main chemicals that are depleting stratospheric ozone are chlorofluorocarbons which are used in refrigerators, aerosols, and as cleaners in many industries, and halons, which are used in fire extinguishers. The damage is caused when these chemicals release highly reactive forms of chlorine and bromine. Over the past 30 years ozone levels over parts of Antarctica have dropped by almost 40 % during some months and a 'hole' in ozone concentrations is clearly visible in satellite observations. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.name: stratospheric ozone depletion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: The landward displacement of the shoreline caused by the forces of waves and currents. [definition source: US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal erosion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.name: aquaculture
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.definition: The farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants with some sort of intervention in the rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being cultivated. [definition source: FAO Fishery Glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Link between the exposure of a given system to a substance over time and the magnitude of a specific, continuously graded change to that system [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: concentration-effect relationship

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PPP.definition: Synonyms: purchasing power parity [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PPP.name: PPP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.definition: Portion of rainfall, melted snow or irrigation water that flows across the ground's surface and is eventually returned to streams. Run-off can pick up pollutants from air or land and carry them to receiving waters. [definition source: United Nations. 1997. Quoted by: FAO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.name: runoff

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: The catch of non-target species and undersized fish of the target species. By-catch of commercial species may be retained or discarded along with non-commercial by-catch. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fish by-catch

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.definition: A line of pipe connected to valves and other control devices, for conducting oil. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.name: oil pipeline

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.objectname_hu: {ene} olajszennyezõdés, olajkiömlés, baleset okozta olajkiömlés / olajveszteség; {nathaz} olajszennyezõdés
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.name: oil spill
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.objecttrans_hu: {ENE} olajszennyezõdés, olajkiömlés, baleset okozta olajkiömlés / olajveszteség; {NATHAZ} olajszennyezõdés
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.objectname_bg: разливане на масло или други петролни продукти в сладоководни води или морски екосистеми, замърсяване на околната среда с разлято масло или други петролни продукти в сладководни води или морски екосистеми
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.objecttrans_bg: разливане на масло или други петролни продукти в сладоководни води или морски екосистеми, замърсяване на околната среда с разлято масло или други петролни продукти в сладководни води или морски екосистеми
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oil.definition: The accidental release of oil, or other petroleum products usually into freshwater or marine ecosystems, and usually in large quantities. It can be controlled by chemical dispersion, combustion, mechanical containment, and absorption. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WAI.definition: Synonyms: West Antarctic ice sheet [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WAI.name: WAIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HP.definition: Synonyms: hydroxypyrene [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HP.name: HP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Synonyms: R&D [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: research and development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dif.name: diffuse pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dif.definition: Pollution from widespread activities with no one discrete source, e.g. acid rain, pesticides, urban run-off, etc. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rai.definition: Railway network means the entire railway infrastructure owned and/or managed by an infrastructure manager. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rai.name: railway network

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.definition: A pseudo-hermaphroditic condition in female gastropods (snails) caused by TBT and manifested by the development of a false penis. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.name: imposex

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOE.definition: According to Aarhus Convention the state of the environment report represents comprehensive publication (in printed or electronic forms), which provides information about the state of elements of the environment, such as air and atmosphere, water, soil, land, landscape and natural sites, biological diversity and its components, including genetically modified organisms, and the interaction among these elements; about the factors, such as substances, energy, noise and radiation, and activities or measures, including administrative measures, environmental agreements, policies, legislation, plans and programmes, affecting or likely to affect the elements of the environment, and cost-benefit and other economic analyses and assumptions used in environmental decision-making and the information about the state of human health and safety, conditions of human life, cultural sites and built structures, in as much as they are or may be affected by the state of the elements of the environment or, through these elements, by the factors, activities or measures referred above. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOE.name: SOER

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AMA.definition: The Arctic monitoring and assessment programme (AMAP) was established in 1991 to implement certain components of the Arctic environmental protection strategy (AEPS). The primary objectives of AMAP are: 'to provide reliable and sufficient information on the status of, and threats to, the Arctic environment, and to provide scientific advice on actions to be taken in order to support Arctic governments in their efforts to take remedial and preventive actions relating to contaminants.' [definition source: Arctic monitoring and assessment programme (AMAP).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AMA.name: AMAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_no-.definition: Greatest concentration or amount of a substance, found by observation or experiment, which causes no detectable effect. [definition source: WHO. 1994. Assessing human health risks of chemicals: Derivation of guidance values for health-based exposure limits. Environmental health criteria 170. World Health Organization, Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_no-.name: no-observed-effect level

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: Synonyms: CEPI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Confederation of European Paper Industries

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrofluorocarbon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: Family of industrial gases included in the basket of six greenhouse gases (GHG) controlled by the Kyoto Protocol. HFCs have replaced ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in many applications but are powerful GHGs, with 100-year global warming potential of between 140 and 11 700. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: intermodal transport
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_cs: transport více než jedním přepravcem během jedné cesty
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_cs: transport více než jedním přepravcem během jedné cesty

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Legal process, by which large industrial processes are licensed and regulated, refers specifically to the requirements of the European Commission's IPPC (integrated pollution prevention and control) Directive (96/61/EC). [definition source: European Commission, DGXI. 1999. Final report on the study of the assessment of indirect and cumulative impacts, as well as impact interactions within the environmental impact assessment (EIA) process.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated pollution prevention and control

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: secondary productivity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: The rate at which primary (plant and organisms) material is synthesised into animal tissue per unit area in a given time period. [definition source: Arctic Borderlands Ecological Knowledge Society. Canada.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Integrated product policy (IPP) is an approach that begins by asking how the environmental performance of products can be improved most cost-effectively. It is founded on the consideration of the impacts of products throughout their life-cycle, from the natural resources from which they come, through their use and marketing to their eventual disposal as waste. It is also a relatively new approach to environmental policy. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated product policy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biocoenosis
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Association of living organisms, animals and plants, which occupy the same geographical area (biotope). [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated coastal zone management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Integrated coastal zone management (ICZM) is a dynamic, multidisciplinary and iterative process to promote sustainable management of coastal zones. It covers the full cycle of information collection, planning (in its broadest sense), decision making, management and monitoring of implementation. ICZM uses the informed participation and cooperation of all stakeholders to assess the societal goals in a given coastal area, and to take actions towards meeting these objectives. ICZM seeks, over the long-term, to balance environmental, economic, social, cultural and recreational objectives, all within the limits set by natural dynamics. 'Integrated' in ICZM refers to the integration of objectives and also to the integration of the many instruments needed to meet these objectives. It means integration of all relevant policy areas, sectors, and levels of administration. It means integration of the terrestrial and marine components of the target territory, in both time and space. [definition source: CEC Communication 2000/547 ICZM.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European environment information and observation network (EIONET) is a collaborative network of the European Environment Agency and its member countries, connecting national focal points in the EU and accession countries, European topic centres, national reference centres, and main component elements. These organisations jointly provide the information that is used for making decisions for improving the state of the environment in Europe and making EU policies more effective. Eionet is both a network of organisations and a electronic network (e-Eionet). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European environment information and observation network
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European environment information and observation network
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european environment information and observation network

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: The science of poisons and toxic substances occurring in the environment and their effects. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint Group of experts of the scientific aspects of marine environmental protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecotoxicology

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: Synonyms: DG SANCO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directorate General for Health and Consumer Protection
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_en: Directorate General for Health and Consumer Protection
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objectname_en: directorate general for health and consumer protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: Synonyms: HC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrocarbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.definition: Synonyms: CENEf [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.name: Center for Energy Efficiency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.definition: A residential district situated on the outskirts of a city or town. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.name: suburb

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: Sea-water bodies situated at the coast, but separated from the sea by land spits or similar land features. Coastal lagoons are open to the sea in restricted spaces. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal lagoons

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.objectname_sk: znak ekologicky šetrných výrobkov, ekologická klasifikácia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecolabel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.objecttrans_sk: znak ekologicky šetrných výrobkov, ekologická klasifikácia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A mark, seal or written identification attached or affixed to products that provides comparisons with other similar products, or instructions on how to safely use or properly recycle or dispose of both products and packaging. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: Synonyms: WCI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Coal Institute

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a group of compounds formed during the incomplete combustion of coal, oil, gas, wood, garbage or other organic substances. In most cases PAHs occur as a mixture of several compounds, not as a single chemical. Several PAHs are produced commercially to be used in the industrial organic synthesis. Once released into the aquatic environment, degradation by micro-organisms is often slow, leading to their accumulation in exposed sediments, soils, aquatic and terrestrial plants, fish and invertebrates. In terms of human health, prolonged exposure to PAHs can have a deleterious effect, and individuals exposed to mixtures of PAHs, [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water supply
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water supply refers to the share of water abstraction which is supplied to users (excluding losses in storage, conveyance and distribution). [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 159. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IFO.definition: Synonyms: International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IFO.name: IFOAM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water resources
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Distinction is made between renewable and non-renewable water resources. Non-renewable water resources are not replenished at all or for a very long time by nature. This includes the so-called fossil waters. Renewable water resources are rechargeable due to the hydrological cycle unless they are overexploited, comprising groundwater aquifers and surface water like rivers and lakes. Internal renewable water resources comprise the average annual flow of rivers and groundwater generated from endogenous precipitation. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objectname_sk: spravodajský mechanizmus zameraný na energiu a životné prostredie
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objecttrans_el: μηχανισμός υποβολής εκθέσεων για την ενέργεια και το περιβάλλον
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objectname_lt: energijos ir aplinkos apsaugos pranešimo mechanizmas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objecttrans_es: Mecanismo de información sobre energía y medio ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objecttrans_it: Meccanismo di relazioni su energia e ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objectname_de: mechanismus für die berichterstattung über energie und umwelt

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.name: Energy and Environment Reporting Mechanism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objecttrans_pt: mecanismo de informação sobre a energia e o ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objectname_fr: mécanisme de rapport sur l'énergie et l'environnement

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objectname_bg: механизъм за докладване и отчитане в областта на енергията и околната среда
