glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.objecttrans_ro: Mecanism de raportare despre energie şi mediul înconjurător

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ENEA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European network of environmental authorities

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.definition: Contamination of water, soil and air with pathogen bacteria. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.name: bacteriological pollution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Initiated by the EEA and UNEP/GRID-Arendal, the project seeks to enable cities in Europe to use the European common indicators on urban sustainability as the basis for on-line state of the environment reports. The urban communication platform provides indicator-based information and data at city level. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban communication platform

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.definition: Any structure, machine, or contrivance, especially a vehicle, designed to be supported by the air, either by the dynamic action of the air upon the surfaces of the structure or object or by its own buoyancy. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.name: aeroplane

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_asb.definition: Fibrous natural product used in asbestos cement, brakes and clutches, insulators and fireproof textiles. Asbestos is carcinogenic. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_asb.name: asbestos

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RoH.definition: The purpose of Directive 2002/95/EC on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment is to approximate the laws of the Member States on the restrictions of the use of hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment and to contribute to the protection of human health and the environmentally sound recovery and disposal of waste electrical and electronic equipment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RoH.name: RoHS directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ate.definition: another test element [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ate.name: atest2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazardous waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: A term applied to those wastes that because of their chemical reactivity, toxic, explosive, corrosive, radioactive or other characteristics, cause danger, or are likely to cause danger, to health or the environment. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEP.definition: Synonyms: Danish Environmental Protection Agency [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEP.name: DEPA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.definition: Synonyms: l/L [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.name: litre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objectname_lv: sekundārās daļiņas, daļiņas, kas rodas atmosfērā sēra un slāpekļa dioksīda, amonjaka un organisko savienojumu reakciju rezultātā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: secondary particles
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objecttrans_lv: sekundārās daļiņas, daļiņas, kas rodas atmosfērā sēra un slāpekļa dioksīda, amonjaka un organisko savienojumu reakciju rezultātā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objectname_fi: hiukkaset, joita syntyy rikin ja typpioksidien sekä ammoniakin ja orgaanisten yhdisteiden välisistä reaktioista
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.objecttrans_fi: hiukkaset, joita syntyy rikin ja typpioksidien sekä ammoniakin ja orgaanisten yhdisteiden välisistä reaktioista
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Particulate matter originated from atmospheric reactions between sulphur and nitrogen oxides, and ammonia and organic compounds. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Environmental signals 2000. Environmental assessment report No 6.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: Synonyms: EfE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.name: Environment for Europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Properties and characteristics of the environment, either generalized or local, as they impinge on human beings and other organisms. Environmental quality is a general term which can refer to: varied characteristics such as air and water purity or pollution, noise, access to open space, and the visual effects of buildings, and the potential effects which such characteristics may have on physical and mental health (caused by human activities). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental quality

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIS.definition: Synonyms: Interstate Statistical Committee of the Commonwealth of Independent States [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIS.name: CISSTAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objectname_lv: envirowindows, eionet vides informācijas apstrādes centra interfeiss
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objecttrans_is: miðstöð eftirlits fjölmargra evrópska aðila í umhverfismálum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objectname_is: miðstöð eftirlits fjölmargra evrópska aðila í umhverfismálum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objectname_pt: envirowindows (sistema de informação ambiental em rede para utilizadores externos)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.name: Envirowindows
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objecttrans_lv: EnviroWindows, EIONET vides informācijas apstrādes centra interfeiss
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objecttrans_pt: EnviroWindows (sistema de informação ambiental em rede para utilizadores externos)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objectname_bg: енвироуиндоус: комбинация от интернет информация и информация, предоставяна от клирингови къщи за информация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.objecttrans_bg: ЕнвироУиндоус: комбинация от интернет информация и информация, предоставяна от клирингови къщи за информация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: Envirowindows is the EIONET's interface to external partners. It provides an information 'marketplace' for businesses, local authorities and their stakeholders. The service is designed to:(a) facilitate consumer access to company's information on products, best practices, use of natural resources and corporate environmental performance, and;(b) help local authorities to communicate with concerned citizens, professionals, policy-makers and companies. Envirowindows is based on two main services: interest groups and information portals. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_net.definition: Synonyms: NAI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_net.name: net annual increment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEE.definition: The purpose of Directive 2002/96/EC on waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) is, as a first priority, the prevention of waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE), and in addition, the reuse, recycling and other forms of recovery of such wastes so as to reduce the disposal of waste. It also seeks to improve the environmental performance of all operators involved in the life cycle of electrical and electronic equipment, e.g. producers, distributors and consumers and in particular those operators directly involved in the treatment of waste electrical and electronic equipment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEE.name: WEEE directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: concurrent uses of soil
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_bg: алтернативни начини на ползване на почвата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_bg: алтернативни начини на ползване на почвата

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENP.definition: Synonyms: European neighbourhood policy [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENP.name: ENP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Synonyms: ECP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecoregional conservation plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Directive 2001/81/EC on national emission ceilings for certain atmospheric pollutants. Its objective is to set national emission ceilings for pollutants causing acidification and eutrophication and for ozone precursors in order to provide fuller protection for the environment and human health against their adverse effects. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Emission Ceilings Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_kil.definition: Synonyms: km [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_kil.name: kilometre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cli.name: climate change
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cli.definition: Climate change refers to any change in climate over time, whether due to natural variability or as a result of human activity. This usage differs from that in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which defines 'climate change' as: 'a change of climate which is attributed directly or indirectly to human activity that alters the composition of the global atmosphere and which is in addition to natural climate variability observed over comparable time periods.' [definition source: IPCC. Climate Change 2001 Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MFA.definition: A monitoring system for national economies based on methodically organised accounts and denoting the total amounts of material used in the economy. Material flow accounting enables monitoring of total consumption of natural resources and the associated indirect flows, as well as calculation of indicators. [definition source: Eurostat. 2001. Economy-wide material flow accounts and derived indicators. Luxembourg.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MFA.name: MFA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.definition: Energy consumption denotes gross inland energy consumption (GIEC) and represents the quantity of energy necessary to satisfy inland consumption of the geographical entity under consideration. Gross inland consumption does not include energy (fuel oil) provided to international maritime bunkers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.name: Energy consumption

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Environment Agency
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European Environment Agency (EEA) was established by Regulation (EEC) No 1210/1990, amended by Regulation (EEC) No 933/1990, and has been operational since 1994. The EEA aims to support sustainable development and to help achieve significant and measurable improvement in Europe's environment through the provision of timely, targeted, relevant and reliable information to policy-making agents and the public. The Agency processes data from the member countries to knowledge at European level, and cooperates with the European environment information and observation network (Eionet) and other international partners to gather, process and distribute data and information. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.name: acid rain
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.definition: Rain having a pH less than 5.6. The acidity results from chemical reactions occurring when water, sulphur dioxide, and nitrogen oxides, generally released by industrial processes, are chemically transformed into sulphuric and nitric acids. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biotope
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Well-defined geographical area, characterised by specific ecological conditions (soil, climate, etc.), which physically supports the organisms that live there (biocoenosis). [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: Legally enforceable limit on the physical, chemical or biological characteristics of a point source of emission to water or air, normally expressed as a maximum permissible concentration of a specified substance. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.name: emission limit value

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Landfill gas means all the gases generated from the landfilled waste; [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landfill gas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mil.definition: Synonyms: MDGs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mil.name: Millennium Development Goals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tro.name: trophic level
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tro.definition: Position in the food chain, determined by the number of energy-transfer steps to that level. [definition source: UNEP. Glossary of biodiversity terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PIC.definition: The Rotterdam Convention on the prior informed consent (PIC) procedure for certain hazardous chemicals and pesticides in international trade was opened for signature in 1998. It will come into force when 50 countries provide final ratification. The Convention will enable the world to monitor and control the trade in various chemicals that threaten human and environmental health. It will give importing countries the power to decide which chemicals they want to receive and to exclude those they cannot manage safely. If trade does take place, requirements for labelling and provision of information on potential health and environmental effects will promote the safe use of these chemicals. [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PIC.name: PIC Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MFR.definition: Synonyms: maximum feasible reduction [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MFR.name: MFR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.objectname_sk: zložky siete európskej agentúry životného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.objecttrans_el: μέρη του ΕΔΠΠΠ (Ευρωπαϊκού Δικτύου Πληροφοριών και Παρατηρήσεων για το Περιβάλλον / ΕΙΟΝΕΤ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.name: Eionet elements
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.objectname_el: μέρη του εδπππ (ευρωπαϊκού δικτύου πληροφοριών και παρατηρήσεων για το περιβάλλον / ειονετ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.objecttrans_sk: zložky Siete Európskej agentúry životného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIO.definition: Eionet elements are: national focal points (NFPs), main component elements (MCEs), national reference centres (NRCs) and European topic centres (ETCs). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TEM.definition: Terrestrial ecosystem monitoring sites (TEMS) is an international directory of sites (named T sites) and networks that carry out long-term terrestrial monitoring and research activities. The database provides information on the 'who, what and where' in long-term terrestrial monitoring that can be useful to both the scientific community and policy-makers. [definition source: FAO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TEM.name: TEMS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal waters
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: (1) The waters outside the low-water line or the outer limit of an estuary. (2) Surface water on the landward side of a line, every point of which is at a distance of one nautical mile on the seaward side from the nearest point of the baseline from which the breadth of territorial waters is measured, extending where appropriate up to the outer limit of transitional waters. [definition source: 1) Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May 1991 concerning urban waste-water treatment. 2) Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUC.definition: Synonyms: European Union Coastal Conservation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUC.name: EUCC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.definition: A gas with a high vapour pressure used to force formulations out of aerosol spray cans. Among the gases used are butanes, propanes and dinitrogen oxide. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.name: propellant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_min.definition: Inorganic fertiliser means a fertiliser in which the declared nutrients are in the form of minerals obtained by extraction or by physical and/or chemical industrial processes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_min.name: mineral fertiliser

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.definition: Synonyms: IPSC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.name: Institute for the Protection and Security of the Citizen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.objecttrans_en: Institute for the Protection and Security of the Citizen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.objectname_en: institute for the protection and security of the citizen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: The Convention was adopted in Paris on 17 June 1994. It entered into force on 26 December 1996. The objective of this Convention is to combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought in countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in Africa, through effective action at all levels, supported by international cooperation and partnership arrangements, in the framework of an integrated approach which is consistent with Agenda 21, with a view to contributing to the achievement of sustainable development in affected areas. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations convention to combat desertification in those countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in Africa
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations convention to combat desertification in those countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in Africa
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations convention to combat desertification in those countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in africa

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIS.definition: Group of principles, methods, instruments and geo-referenced data used to capture, store, extract, measure, transform, analyse and map phenomena and processes in a given geographic area. [definition source: Fisheries and Oceans Canada.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIS.name: GIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: The entry and development or multiplication of an infectious agent in the body of a living organism. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: infection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.definition: Synonyms: EE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.name: Eastern Europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAF.definition: Commission communication of 4 May 2001 The clean air for Europe (CAFE) programme: towards a thematic strategy for air quality'. CAFE is the first of the thematic strategies announced in the Sixth environmental action programme . [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAF.name: CAFE Programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.definition: Substance in air that could, at high enough concentrations, harm human beings, animals, vegetation or material. Air pollutants may thus include forms of matter of almost any natural or artificial composition capable of being airborne. They may consist of solid particles, liquid droplets or gases, or combinations of these forms. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.name: air pollutant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: Something that takes place or comes to pass. Occurrence and happening are the most general: an everyday occurrence; a happening of no great importance.Event usually signifies a notable occurrence: major world events reported on the evening news. 'Great events make me quiet and calm; it is only trifles that irritate my nerves' Victoria.Incident may apply to a minor occurrence: a small incident blown out of proportion.The term may also refer to a distinct event of sharp identity and significance: a succession of exciting incidents.An episode is an incident in the course of a progression or within a larger sequence: 'Happiness was but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain' Thomas Hardy.Circumstance denotes a particular incident or occurrence: 'Billy had found Alice, thus bringing about the odd circumstance of their renewing their acquaintanceship' Eleanor H. Porter. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: incident

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.objectname_hu: {marenv} partot és a hullámverést felölelő terület
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal area
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.objecttrans_hu: {MARENV} partot és a hullámverést felölelő terület
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: The part of the land affected by its proximity to the sea, and that part of the sea affected by its proximity to the land as the extent to which man's land-based activities have a measurable influence on water chemistry and marine ecology. [definition source: US Commission on Marine Science, Engineering and Resources, 1969). Quoted by EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_APH.definition: Synonyms: Air Pollution and Health: A European Information System [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_APH.name: APHEIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.name: acidification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.definition: Change in an environment's natural chemical balance caused by an increase in the concentration of acidic elements. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our Future. Brussels.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.objectname_hu: tengerparti környezet, tengerparti élőhely, tengerparti közösség
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.objecttrans_hu: tengerparti környezet, tengerparti élőhely, tengerparti közösség
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. Coastal habitats are those above spring high tide limit (or above mean water level in non-tidal waters) occupying coastal features and characterised by their proximity to the sea, including coastal dunes and wooded coastal dunes, beaches and cliffs. Includes free-draining supralittoral habitats adjacent to marine habitats which are normally only affected by spray or splash, strandlines characterised by terrestrial invertebrates and moist and wet coastal dune slacks. Excludes dune slack pools and rock pools. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: trans-European networks
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: Generic term for interconnected networks and services available on a pan-European basis. [definition source: European Commission. 1996. Towards a European numbering environment. COM(96) 590.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Euro IV vehicles that comply with the emission limits as defined in Directive 98/69/EC, which will enter into force in 2005. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Euro IV

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MOP.definition: Synonyms: Meeting of the Parties [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MOP.name: MOP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_REC.definition: The objective of the project is to map the international environmental conventions signed and ratified by the European Commission and assist the European Environment Agency to streamline the reporting systems implemented in them. [definition source: EEA. 2001. EEA support to the European Community in reporting obligations within the framework of international environmental conventions - Legislative instruments, international programmes and conventions. Technical report No 62.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_REC.name: REC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.definition: Energy released by nuclear fission or nuclear fusion. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.name: nuclear energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gre.definition: Synonyms: GBP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gre.name: Great Britain pound

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_adv.name: advanced wastewater treatment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_adv.definition: The process which remove pollutants not adequately removed by secondary treatment, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus; accomplished by means of sand filters, microstraining, or other methods. Similar to tertiary treatment. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.name: noise map
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: The presentation of data on an existing or predicted noise situation in terms of a noise indicator, breaches of a limit value, the number of people affected in a certain area, the number of dwellings exposed to certain values of a noise indicator in a certain area, or on cost-benefit ratios or other economic data on mitigation methods or scenarios. [definition source: Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council relating to the assessment and management of environmental noise. COM(2000) 468 final.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AMD.definition: Synonyms: Armenian dram [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AMD.name: AMD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wha.name: what if scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wha.definition: The term 'what if' is used to reflect potential effect under different assumptions. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. page 16. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_ver.definition: The act of verifying or the state of being verified. A confirmation of truth or authority e.g. results of image processing of satellite data is verified by terrain recognoscation. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_ver.name: verification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Synonyms: EW-MFA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: economy-wide material flow accounting

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: contaminated land
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Any site or region that is damaged, harmed or made unfit for use by the introduction of unwanted substances, particularly microorganisms, chemicals, toxic and radioactive materials and wastes. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Ber.definition: The Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats was adopted in Bern on 19 September 1979 and came into force on 1 June 1982. Forty-five European and African States as well as the European Community are parties to the convention. It has a threefold objective: to conserve wild flora and fauna and their natural habitats; to promote co-operation between states; and to give particular emphasis to endangered and vulnerable species, including endangered and vulnerable migratory species. [definition source: Council of Europe.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Ber.name: Bern Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Euro II passenger cars are cars that comply with the emission standards as defined in Directive 94/12/EC. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Euro II

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Deu.definition: Synonyms: GTZ [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Deu.objecttrans_de: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit GmbH
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Deu.objectname_de: deutsche gesellschaft für technische zusammenarbeit gmbh

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: Land use corresponds to the socio-economic description (functional dimension) of areas: areas used for residential, industrial or commercial purposes, for farming or forestry, for recreational or conservation purposes, etc. Links with land cover are possible; it may be possible to infer land use from land cover and conversely. But situations are often complicated and the link is not so evident. Contrary to land cover, land use is difficult to 'observe'. For example, it is often difficult to decide if grasslands are used or not for agricultural purposes. Distinctions between land use and land cover and their definition have impacts on the development of classification systems, data collection and information systems in general. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil use

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_A-w.objectname_pt: nível sonoro ponderado a, em decibel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_A-w.name: A-weighted decibel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_A-w.objecttrans_pt: nível sonoro ponderado A, em decibel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_A-w.definition: Decibels with the sound pressure scale adjusted to conform with the frequency response of the human ear. A sound level meter that measures A-weighted decibels has an electrical circuit that allows the meter to have the same sensitivity to sound at different frequencies as the average human ear. There are also B-weighted and C-weighted scales, but the A-weighted scale is the one most commonly used for measuring loud noise. [definition source: Australian Academy of Sciences. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_orn.definition: The branch of zoology that deals with the study of birds, including their physiology, classification, ecology, and behaviour. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_orn.name: ornithology

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.definition: A community of salt-tolerant tress and shrubs, with many other associated organisms, that grows on some tropical and sub-tropical coasts in a zone roughly coinciding with the intertidal zone. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint Group of Experts of the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.name: mangal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.definition: In the 1970's, Europe decided that bathing water quality should be monitored and tested in order to protect bathers from health risks and to preserve the environment from pollution. This resulted in 1976 in one of the first pieces of European environmental legislation: the Council Directive 76/160/EEC on Bathing Water Quality.The Directive was updated in 2002. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.name: Council directive 76/160/EEC concerning the quality of bathing water
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.objecttrans_en: Council directive 76/160/EEC concerning the quality of bathing water
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.objectname_en: council directive 76/160/eec concerning the quality of bathing water

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_irr.objectname_hu: a környezet visszafordíthatatlan károsítása, visszafordíthatatlan környezetkárosítás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_irr.name: irreversibility (of environmental damage)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_irr.objecttrans_hu: a környezet visszafordíthatatlan károsítása, visszafordíthatatlan környezetkárosítás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_irr.definition: Permanent loss of environmental assets or environmental quality, requiring preventive action rather than restoration or clean-up. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAI.definition: Synonyms: Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAI.name: SAICM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ads.name: adsorption
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ads.definition: Removal of a pollutant from air or water by collecting the pollutant on the surface of a solid material; e.g. an advanced method of treating waste in which activated carbon removes organic matter from wastewater. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.definition: The concentration in air of a pollutant to which a human being is normally exposed, i.e. between the ground and a height of some 2 metres above it. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.name: ground-level concentration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DWD.definition: Council Directive 98/83/EC of 3 November 1998 concerning the quality of water intended for human consumption. The Directive is intended to protect human health by laying down healthiness and purity requirements which must be met by drinking water within the Community. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DWD.name: DWD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.definition: It is an essential component of living systems and is found in nervous tissue, bones and cell protoplasm. Phosphorus exists in several allotropic forms including white (or yellow), red, and black (or violet). White phosphorus has two modifications. Ordinary phosphorus is a waxy white solid. When pure, it is colourless and transparent. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in carbon disulphide. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.name: phosphorus

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: CISSTAT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: Interstate Statistical Committee of the Commonwealth of Independent States
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: Interstate Statistical Committee of the Commonwealth of Independent States
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: interstate statistical committee of the commonwealth of independent states

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objectname_de: schwebstoff, schwebstaub, staubpartikel, schwebepartikel, schwebstoffteilchen, schwebeteilchen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objecttrans_de: Schwebstoff, Schwebstaub, Staubpartikel, Schwebepartikel, Schwebstoffteilchen, Schwebeteilchen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: particulate matter
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objectname_nl: stof in deeltjesvorm (vast of vloeibaar), fijn stof
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objectname_bg: вещество под формата на малки твърди или течни частици
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objecttrans_bg: вещество под формата на малки твърди или течни частици
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: A collective name for fine solid or liquid particles added to the atmosphere by processes at the earth's surface. Particulate matter includes dust, smoke, soot, pollen and soil particles. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.objecttrans_nl: stof in deeltjesvorm (vast of vloeibaar), fijn stof

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.objecttrans_es: Nivel de presión sonora en equivalente energético expresado en decibelios (A)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.objectname_pt: (o) laeq (nível sonoro contínuo equivalente ponderado a)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.objectname_es: nivel de presión sonora en equivalente energético expresado en decibelios (a)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.name: Laeq
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.objecttrans_pt: (o) Laeq (nível sonoro contínuo equivalente ponderado A)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lae.definition: Energy equivalent sound pressure level in dB(A). [definition source: EEA. 2001. TERM 2001. Copenhagen]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.objectname_lv: potenciālā deva, vielas daudzums ieelpotajā, norītajā vai saskarsmē ar ādu nonākušajā materiālā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.name: potential dose
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.objecttrans_lv: potenciālā deva, vielas daudzums ieelpotajā, norītajā vai saskarsmē ar ādu nonākušajā materiālā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.definition: The amount of a compound contained in material swallowed, breathed, or applied to the skin. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste disposal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Disposal means any of the applicable operations provided for in Annex IIA to Directive 91/156/EEC:D1 Tipping above or underground (e.g. landfill, etc.), D2 Land treatment (e.g. biodegradation of liquid or sludge discards in soils, etc.), D3 Deep injection (e.g. injection of pumpable discards into wells, salt domes or naturally occurring repositories, etc.), D4 Surface impoundment (e.g. placement of liquid or sludge discards into pits, ponds or lagoons, etc.), D5 Specially engineered landfill (e.g. placement into lined discrete cells which are capped and isolated from one another and the environment, etc.), D6 Release of solid waste into a water body except seas/oceans, D7 Release into seas/oceans including seabed insertion, D8 Biological treatment not specified elsewhere in this Annex which results in final compounds or mixtures which are disposed of by means of any of the operations in this Annex, D9 Physico-chemical treatment not specified elsewhere in this Annex which results in final compounds or mixtures which are disposed of by means of any of the operations in this Annex (e.g. evaporation, drying, calcination, etc.), D10 Incineration on land, D11 Incineration at sea, D12 Permanent storage (e.g. emplacement of containers in a mine, etc.), D13 Blending or mixture prior to submission to any of the operations in this Annex, D14 Repackaging prior to submission to any of the operations in this Annex, D15 Storage pending any of the operations in this Annex, excluding temporary storage, pending collection, on the site where it is produced. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACA.definition: Synonyms: Arctic Council Action Plan [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACA.name: ACAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: coniferous woodland
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Coniferous woodland is defined as wooded land on which more than 75 % of the tree crown cover consists of coniferous species. [definition source: EUNIS (based on FAO definition). EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_idl.definition: Arable land not under rotation that is set at rest for a period of time ranging from one to five years before it is cultivated again, or land usually under permanent crops, meadows or pastures, which is not being used for that purpose for a period of at least one year. Arable land which is normally used for the cultivation of temporary crops but which is temporarily used for grazing is included. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_idl.name: idle land

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: A period of usually a few days up to 2-3 weeks with high ozone concentrations, characterised by daily exceedances of the thresholds set to protect human health. Ozone episodes occur under specific meteorological conditions characterised by large stagnant areas of high pressure. Since the formation of ozone requires sunlight, ozone episodes mainly occur during summer. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone episode

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MSD.definition: Synonyms: Marine Strategy Directive [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MSD.name: MSD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: A way to describe how much of a substance is contained in a sample: parts of analyte per billion parts of sample. In atmospheric chemistry this becomes volume parts of analyte per volume parts of atmosphere. [definition source: Sam Houston State University. United States. Atmospheric Chemistry Glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: parts per billion in volume

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.name: user charge
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.objectname_bg: такса, заплащана от потребителя (ползвателя) на специална екологична услуга
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.objecttrans_bg: такса, заплащана от потребителя (ползвателя) на специална екологична услуга
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_use.definition: Charge paid for a specific environmental service provided to the charge payer. Example: treating wastewater or disposing of waste. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness. Environmental issues series No 1]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.definition: Process of following up the decisions and actions within risk management in order to ascertain that risk containment or reduction with respect to a particular hazard is assured. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.name: risk monitoring

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: Synonyms: GEO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global environment outlook

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.definition: Means the exercise of agency authority at any stage of an performance where alterations might be made in the undertaking to modify its impact upon historic and cultural properties. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.name: decision

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_it: che determina(no) un minore impatto ambientale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_it: che determina(no) un minore impatto ambientale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmentally friendly
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: безвреден за околната среда, екологосъобразен
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: безвреден за околната среда, екологосъобразен

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.objectname_de: bottom-up-ansatz, vorgehen von unten nach oben, 'von-unten-nach-oben'-konzept
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.objecttrans_de: Bottom-up-Ansatz, Vorgehen von unten nach oben, 'Von-unten-nach-oben'-Konzept
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.name: bottom-up approach
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.objectname_fr: approche de la base au sommet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.objecttrans_fr: approche de la base au sommet

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_USA.definition: Synonyms: United States of America [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_USA.name: USA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Inf.definition: Synonyms: INSPIRE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Inf.name: Infrastructure for Spatial Information in Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Inf.objecttrans_en: Infrastructure for Spatial Information in Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Inf.objectname_en: infrastructure for spatial information in europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mod.name: modelling
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mod.definition: An investigative technique using a mathematical or physical representation of a system or theory that accounts for all or some its known properties. Models are often used to test the effect of changes of system components on the overall performance of the system. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological footprints
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Land use equivalent of 'use of nature' (materials + energy + pollution). [definition source: EEA. 1999. Making sustainability accountable: Eco-efficiency, resource productivity and innovation. Topic report No 11/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pou.definition: This includes domestic animals: broilers, laying hens, turkeys, ducks, geese and other poultry, e.g. quails, pheasants, guinea-fowl, pigeons, ostriches. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pou.name: poultry

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.definition: Synonyms: CROSTAT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.name: Central Bureau of Statistics of the Republic of Croatia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.objecttrans_en: Central Bureau of Statistics of the Republic of Croatia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.objectname_en: central bureau of statistics of the republic of croatia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DKK.definition: Synonyms: Danish krone [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DKK.name: DKK

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Had.definition: Synonyms: HadSST2 [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Had.name: Hadley Centre SST data set

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dic.definition: Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane: insecticide highly toxic to biota, including humans. This is a persistent biochemical which accumulates in the food chain. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dic.name: dichlorodiphenyl trichloroethane

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.objectname_lv: korektīvās metodes bīstamu vielu noplūdes seku likvidācijai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.name: remediation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.objecttrans_lv: korektīvās metodes bīstamu vielu noplūdes seku likvidācijai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.objectname_bg: прочистване от стари източници на отпадъци (от стари замърсявания предимно на почвата)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.objecttrans_bg: прочистване от стари източници на отпадъци (от стари замърсявания предимно на почвата)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.definition: Cleanup or other methods used to remove or contain a toxic spill or hazardous materials from a site. [definition source: World Bank. Glossary of Municipal Solid Waste Management Terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPR.definition: Synonyms: environmental performance review [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPR.name: EPR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: The removal of water or any soluble constituents from the soil. Leaching often occurs with soil constituents such as nitrate fertilisers with the result that nitrates end up in potable waters. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil leaching

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: An external cost is a cost not included in the market price of the goods and services being produced, i.e. a cost not borne by those who create it. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint group of experts of the scientific aspects of marine environmental protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: externality

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European sustainable cities
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_ro: oraşe europene care beneficiază de susţinere
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European sustainable cities and towns campaign was launched at the end of the European Conference on Sustainable Cities and Towns, which took place in Aalborg, Denmark from 24 to 27 May 1994. The objective of the campaign is to promote development towards sustainability at the local level through Local Agenda 21 processes, by strengthening partnership among all actors in the local community as well as inter-authority cooperation, and relating this process to the European Union's action in the field of urban environment, and the work of the Urban Environment Expert Group. The campaign is formed by municipal signatories of the Aalborg Charter as campaign participants. [definition source: ICLEI.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_ro: oraşe europene care beneficiază de susţinere

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The degree of dissolved salts in water measured by weight in parts per thousand. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water salinity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agri-environmental indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: An indicator aiming at giving synthesised information on complex interactions between agriculture and environment. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.definition: Synonyms: APHEIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.name: Air Pollution and Health: A European Information System
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_en: Air Pollution and Health: A European Information System
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_en: air pollution and health: a european information system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Radiation stemming mainly from uranium, present in small amounts in many rocks, soils, building material, etc. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: natural radioactivity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.name: forecasting scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.definition: Forecasting scenarios explore alternative developments, starting from the current situation with or without expected/desired policy efforts. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Cloudy crystal balls. Environmental issues series No 17.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ant.name: anthropogenic
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ant.definition: Produced as a result of human activities. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.name: stationary source
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.definition: A fixed-site producer of pollution, mainly power plants and other facilities using industrial combustion processes. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BMB.definition: Synonyms: Baltic Marine Biologists database on Non-indigenous Estuarine and Marine Organisms [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BMB.name: BMB NEMO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_p.e.definition: One population equivalent (p.e.) means the organic biodegradable load having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) of 60 g of oxygen per day. [definition source: Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May concerning urban waste-water treatment.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_p.e.name: p.e.

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIA.definition: A technique used for identifying the environmental effects of development projects. As a result of Directive 85/337/EEC (as amended 1997), this is now a legislative procedure to be applied to the assessment of the environmental effects of certain public and private projects which are likely to have significant effects on the environment. An EIA requires a scoping study to be undertaken in order to focus the assessment. This can be carried out in the field or as a desk study depending on the nature/scale of the project. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIA.name: EIA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ETC/BD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Biological Diversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Topic Centre on Biological Diversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european topic centre on biological diversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPA.definition: Area classified under Article 4 of the birds directive (Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds). [definition source: Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPA.name: SPA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LCP.definition: Synonyms: large combustion plant [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LCP.name: LCP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.definition: Air pollution containing ozone and other reactive chemical compounds formed by the action of sunlight on nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons, especially those in automobile exhaust. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.name: photochemical pollution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aut.definition: Synonyms: ACS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aut.name: automatic control stations

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: An international consortium brought together to assists the EEA in its work of collecting, analysing, evaluating and synthesising information on waste and material flows relevant to national and international policies. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Waste and Material Flows
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Topic Centre on Waste and Material Flows
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european topic centre on waste and material flows

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_maj.definition: The major accident reporting system (MARS) is used by both EU and OECD member countries to report industrial accidents in the MARS standard format and to exchange accidents information on this basis. It is a distributed information network, consisting of local databases on a MS-Windows platform in each Member State of the European Union and a central UNIX-based analysis system at the European Commission's Joint Research Centre in Ispra (MAHB) that allows complex text retrieval and pattern analysis. [definition source: Institute for the Protection and Security of the Citizen (EC Joint Research Center). Major Accident Hazards Bureau (MAHB).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_maj.name: major accident reporting system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: Carbon residue retained by the soil in humus form. It improves soil structure and fertility. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil organic carbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.definition: Synonyms: Regional Environmental Action Programme for Central Asia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.name: CAREAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.definition: The contamination of any material, surface, environment or person by radioactive substances. In the specific case of the human body, this radioactive contamination includes both external skin contamination and internal contamination irrespective of method of intake. [definition source: Federal Environment Agency (Austria). Tacis nuclear safety. environmental impact assessment for Rivne 4 NPP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.name: radioactive contamination

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_met.definition: Data about data; e.g. 'a library catalog is metadata because it describes publications' [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_met.name: metadata

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNF.definition: The convention was adopted on 9 May 1992, in New York, and signed at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro by more than 150 countries and the European Community. Its ultimate objective is the 'stabilisation of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system'. It contains commitments for all parties. Under the convention, parties included in annex I aim to return greenhouse gas emissions not controlled by the Montreal Protocol to 1990 levels by the year 2000. The convention entered in force in March 1994. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001 impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNF.name: UNFCCC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.definition: Formerly known as flexibility mechanisms. Economic mechanisms based on market principles that parties to the Kyoto Protocol can use in an attempt to lessen the potential economic impacts of GHG (greenhouse gases) emission-reduction requirements. They include joint implementation (Article 6), the clean development mechanisms (Article 12), and emissions trading (Article 17). [definition source: IPPC. IPCC special report on emissions scenarios.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.name: Kyoto mechanisms

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Y_yea.definition: Synonyms: y/yr [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Y_yea.name: year

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.definition: The 30 000 'existing' chemicals estimated to be on the EU market, for which little or no information is available, in particular about their long-term effects on human health or the environment. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bur.name: burden of the past

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.name: emission limit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objectname_bg: максимално допустими стойности на емисия от вредни вещества
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objecttrans_bg: максимално допустими стойности на емисия от вредни вещества
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: Legally enforceable limit on the physical, chemical or biological characteristics of a point source of emission to water or air, normally expressed as a maximum permissible concentration of a specified substance. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.definition: Synonyms: REACH [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.name: registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_en: registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_en: registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dow.definition: Chemicals that are discarded 'down-the drain', as household cleaning products and wastewater from laundry services. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dow.name: down-the-drain chemical

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNEP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations Environment Programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_lv: eiropas vides aģentūras koncepcija par vides cēloņsakarībām
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_lt: dpsir (varomosios jėgos, neigiamas poveikis aplinkai, būklė, atsakas)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_pl: dpsir, siły napędowe, parcia na środowisko, stan środowiska, wpływy, reakcje
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_pt: dpsir (forças motoras, pressões, estado, impacte, respostas)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objecttrans_pl: DPSIR, siły napędowe, parcia na środowisko, stan środowiska, wpływy, reakcje
