glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objecttrans_cs: DPSIR (rámec pro popis příčinných vztahů mezi životním prostředím a společností)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_fi: syy-yhteysketjun käsite: aiheuttaja - kuormitus - tila - vaikutus - vastaus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_bg: dpsir - съкращение за: движещи сили, налягане, състояние, въздействие, реакции (индикатори)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objecttrans_fi: syy-yhteysketjun käsite: aiheuttaja - kuormitus - tila - vaikutus - vastaus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objecttrans_bg: DPSIR - съкращение за: движещи сили, налягане, състояние, въздействие, реакции (индикатори)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.definition: The causal framework for describing the interactions between society and the environment adopted by the European Environment Agency: driving forces, pressures, states, impacts, responses (extension of the PSR model developed by OECD). [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DPS.objectname_cs: dpsir (rámec pro popis příčinných vztahů mezi životním prostředím a společností)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAT.definition: Synonyms: North Atlantic Treaty Organization [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAT.name: NATO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAP.definition: The Mediterranean action plan (MAP) strives to protect the environment and to foster sustainable development in the Mediterranean basin. It was adopted in Barcelona, Spain, in 1975 by 16 Mediterranean States and the EC, under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP). Its legal framework comprises the Barcelona Convention adopted in 1976 and revised in 1995, and six protocols covering specific aspects of environmental protection. A Mediterranean Commission for Sustainable Development was also established by MAP in 1995 to facilitate the participation of all stakeholders in the Mediterranean area. [definition source: Adapted from: UNEP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAP.name: MAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.definition: Synonyms: EECCA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.name: Eastern Europe, the Caucasus and Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.objecttrans_en: Eastern Europe, the Caucasus and Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eas.objectname_en: eastern europe, the caucasus and central asia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.definition: The Lisbon Strategy is a commitment to bring about economic, social and environmental renewal in the EU. In March 2000, the European Council in Lisbon set out a ten-year strategy to make the EU the world's most dynamic and competitive economy. The European Commission's annual Spring Report examines the Strategy in detail - on the basis of structural indicators. The Spring Report is the only document on the agenda of the Spring European Council, where EU Heads of State and Government assess the progress of the strategy and decide future priorities in order to realise the Lisbon targets. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.name: structural indicators

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lL.definition: Synonyms: litre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lL.name: l/L

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.name: monitoring
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.definition: (1) A combination of observation and measurement for the performance of a plan, programme or measure, and its compliance with environmental policy and legislation. (2) The provision of the necessary information about progress of implementation of a project, plan, etc. in order to ensure that project management and cooperation partners are able to follow the implementation of the projects and if necessary adjust activities, inputs and budgets, in order to obtain the objectives laid down for the project. [definition source: 1) European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels. 2) Danida. Ministry of Foreign Affaires. Denmark.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.definition: The Cardiff Summit (15 and 16 June 1998) laid the foundation for coordinated Community action to integrate environmental concerns into EU policies. At the same summit the European Council invited the Transport, Energy and Agriculture Councils to define strategies of their own on this point. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.name: Cardiff European Council

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_hu: elhasznált vízmennyiség, nem visszanyerhető vízmennyiség, elpárolgott vízmennyiség
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: consumptive use (of water)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_hu: elhasznált vízmennyiség, nem visszanyerhető vízmennyiség, elpárolgott vízmennyiség
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_ro: pierderile de apă în timpul folosirii
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Water abstracted which is no longer available for use because it has evaporated, transpired, been incorporated into products and crops, or consumed by man or livestock. Water losses due to leakages during the transport of water between the point or points of abstraction and the point or points of use are excluded. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on inland waters.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_ro: pierderile de apă în timpul folosirii

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.definition: Interactive exchange of information about risks among risk assessors, managers, news media, interested groups, and the general public. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.name: risk communication

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: The first stage in hazard assessment, consisting of the determination of substances of concern, the adverse effects they may have inherently on target systems under certain conditions of exposure, taking into account toxicity data. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazard identification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.name: decibel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.definition: A logarithmic scale used to denote the intensity, or pressure level, of a sound relative to the threshold of human hearing. A step of 10 dB is a 10-fold increase in intensity or sound energy and actually sounds a little more than twice as loud. [definition source: Australian Academy of Sciences. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.definition: The Corine biotopes project was initiated in 1985 to enhance reliable and accessible information about vulnerable ecosystems, habitats and species of important as background information for Community environmental assessment. The project has been aimed to select on basis of biota, the most important sites for nature conservation in each European country, using common methodology, and to gather data about these sites. The Corine biotopes database is an inventory of major natural sites. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.name: Corine biotopes

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The cooperative programme for monitoring and evaluation of the long-range transmission of air pollutants in Europe, linked to the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution (CLRTAP). The main objective of the EMEP programme is to regularly provide governments and subsidiary bodies under the CLRTAP with qualified scientific information to support the development and further evaluation of the international protocols on emission reductions negotiated within the convention. [definition source: EEA. EMEP/CORINAIR Atmospheric Emission Inventory Guidebook (Second edition).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European monitoring and evaluation programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.definition: Synonyms: mm [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.name: millimetre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAB.definition: Synonyms: Man and the Biosphere Reserves Programme [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAB.name: MAB

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAC.definition: Synonyms: maximum allowable concentrations [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAC.name: MAC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.definition: Synonyms: TEC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.name: total energy consumption

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.definition: Airview (air quality visualisation instrument for Europe on the web) allows to query Airbase and visualise air quality data (raw data or statistics) in the form of maps, graphs or tables. [definition source: ETC/AQ.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.name: AirView

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.objectname_lv: mazāk piemērotais apvidus, mazāk piemērotā platība
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.name: less favoured areas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.objecttrans_lv: mazāk piemērotais apvidus, mazāk piemērotā platība
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.definition: Set up in 1975, the less favoured areas schemes provide 'compensatory allowances' to farmers in mountainous areas or in other areas where the physical landscape results in higher production costs. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 338.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.name: implementation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.definition: (1) The carrying out of a project or programme. Involves not only the work itself, but all the practical supporting activities such as preparing terms of reference, fund-raising, setting up an organisational structure, communicating, and carrying out a project evaluation. (2) Implementation means compliance checking and compliance promotion. Implementation consists of the activities required to comply with legislation and may regard activities by inspectorates as well as companies. [definition source: 1) WHO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.definition: Generally refers to data with geographic location information included such as latitude and longitude. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.name: geo-referenced data

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_sl: baza podatkov o kvaliteti zraka airbase
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_lv: eiropas vides aģentūras gaisa kvalitātes datu bāze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_hu: {aircha} airbase, az eea (európai környezeti ügynökség) levegõminõségi adatbázisa
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_pt: airbase (base de dados sobre a qualidade do ar)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.name: Airbase
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_hu: {AIRCHA} AIRBASE, az EEA (Európai Környezeti Ügynökség) levegõminõségi adatbázisa
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_lv: Eiropas Vides aģentūras gaisa kvalitātes datu bāze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_pt: Airbase (base de dados sobre a qualidade do ar)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_fr: airbase (base de données sur la qualité de l'air)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_sl: baza podatkov o kvaliteti zraka Airbase
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objectname_bg: airbase - база данни относно качеството на въздуха и мрежите от станции за наблюдение върху него, която се поддържа от европейския тематичен център
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_fr: AirBase (base de données sur la qualité de l'air)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.objecttrans_bg: Airbase - база данни относно качеството на въздуха и мрежите от станции за наблюдение върху него, която се поддържа от Европейския тематичен център
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Air.definition: EEA air quality database. Air quality information and information on monitoring networks and stations, as collected by the European Topic Centre on Air Quality, is stored and made widely available by means of a three-layer information system Airbase, accessible on the Internet. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Air Quality. Annual topic update 1998. Topic report No 7/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: Synonyms: WB [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Bank

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Chi.definition: Synonyms: CEHAPE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Chi.name: Children's Environment and Health Action Plan for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Chi.objecttrans_en: Children's Environment and Health Action Plan for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Chi.objectname_en: children's environment and health action plan for europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEA.definition: A similar technique to environmental impact assessment (EIA) but normally applied to policies, plans, programmes and groups of projects. Strategic environmental assessment (SEA) provides the potential opportunity to avoid the preparation and implementation of inappropriate plants, programmes and projects and assists in the identification and evaluation of project alternatives and identification of cumulative effects. SEA comprises two main types: sectoral SEA (applied when many new projects fall within one sector) and regional SEA (applied when broad economic development is planned within one region). [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEA.name: SEA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEE.definition: Synonyms: South-eastern Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEE.name: SEE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bur.name: Bureau
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bur.definition: The EEA Bureau is constituted by six persons. The Bureau, in consultation with the Executive Director and the chairperson of the Scientific Committee prepares for the board meetings and takes urgent decisions necessary for the management of the EEA between two meetings of the Management Board, mostly subject to ratification by the Board at its next meeting. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biodegradable
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Capable of decomposing rapidly by microorganisms under natural conditions (aerobic and/or anaerobic). Most organic materials, such as food scraps and paper are biodegradable. [definition source: World Bank. Glossary of Municipal Solid Waste Management Terms]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_God.definition: Synonyms: GISS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_God.name: Goddard Institute for Space Studies

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: In the context of human health, structural developmental defects due to exposure to a chemical agent during formation of individual organs. [definition source: US EPA. Integrated risk information system (IRIS). Glossary of IRIS terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: teratogenic

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.definition: The purpose of this Directive is to regulate the use of sewage sludge in agriculture in such a way as to prevent harmful effects on soil, vegetation, animals and man, thereby encouraging the correct use of such sewage sludge. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.name: Council directive 86/278/EEC on the protection of the environment, and in particular of the soil, when sewage sludge is used in agriculture
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.objecttrans_en: Council directive 86/278/EEC on the protection of the environment, and in particular of the soil, when sewage sludge is used in agriculture
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.objectname_en: council directive 86/278/eec on the protection of the environment, and in particular of the soil, when sewage sludge is used in agriculture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.definition: Synonyms: NO2 [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.name: nitrogen dioxide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU-.definition: Bulgaria and Romania [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU-.name: EU-2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Synonyms: NOAA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAS.definition: Synonyms: Social and Spatial Inequalities Research [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAS.name: SASI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soc.definition: The full cost including external cost imposed on society by a given activity. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soc.name: social cost

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Waste electrical and electronic equipment or 'WEEE' means electrical or electronic equipment which is waste within the meaning of Article 1(a) of Directive 75/442/EEC, including all components, sub-assemblies and consumables, which are part of the product at the time of discarding .Council Directive 75/442/EEC of 15 July 1975 on waste: 'waste' means any substance or object which the holder disposes of or is required to dispose of pursuant to the provisions of national law in force. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste electrical and electronic equipment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_REM.definition: The project focuses on developing guidance and new frameworks to help countries provide information on policy effectiveness where required under EU legislation [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_REM.name: REM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.definition: (1) An area from which surface runoff is carried away by a single drainage system. (2) The area of land bounded by watersheds draining into a river, basin or reservoir. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.name: catchment basin

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: Synonyms: ENTEC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.name: Environmental and Engineering Consultancy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.name: storyline
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.objectname_bg: основна линия на сценарий (относно главните му признаци и взаимовръзки при реализирането му)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.objecttrans_bg: основна линия на сценарий (относно главните му признаци и взаимовръзки при реализирането му)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sto.definition: A storyline is a narrative description of a scenario which highlights its main features, and the relationships between the scenario's driving forces and its main features. [definition source: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: ILO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Labour Organisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: controlled landfill
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Controlled landfill is landfill whose operation is subject to a permit system and to technical control procedures in compliance with the national legislation in force. Includes specially engineered landfill. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2000 on the state of the environment]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Natlan (nature/land cover) is an information package designed for viewing and distributing EEA's information, data and applications on land cover and nature in a comprehensive and easy-to-use way for a wide public. Natlan is developed by EEA in close collaboration with its European Topic Centres on Land Cover (ETC/LC) and Nature Conservation (ETC/NC). [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: Natlan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.definition: Legal process, by which large industrial processes are licensed and regulated, refers specifically to the requirements of the European Commission's IPPC (integrated pollution prevention and control) Directive (96/61/EC). [definition source: European Commission, DGXI. 1999. Final report on the study of the assessment of indirect and cumulative impacts, as well as impact interactions within the environmental impact assessment (EIA) process.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPP.name: IPPC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objectname_pl: baza danych o pokryciu terenu w ramach programu corine
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objectname_pt: projecto 'land cover' (cobertura do solo) no âmbito do programa corine.
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.name: Corine land cover
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objecttrans_pl: baza danych o pokryciu terenu w ramach programu Corine
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objecttrans_pt: Projecto 'Land Cover' (cobertura do solo) no âmbito do programa Corine.
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objectname_ro: informaţii despre sol în baza de date corine
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.definition: In 1985 the Corine programme was initiated in the European Union. Corine means 'coordination of information on the environment' and it was a prototype project working on many different environmental issues. The Corine databases and several of its programme have been taken over by the EEA. One of these is an inventory of land cover in 44 classes, and presented as a cartographic product, at a scale of 1:100 000. This database is operationally available for most areas of Europe. Original inventories, based on and interpreted from satellite imagery as well as ancillary information sources, are stored within national institutions. The European reference database is owned by GISCO, the European Commission geographical information system, which is a part of the European Statistic Agency, Eurostat. ETC/TE manages the Corine database (the production database) on behalf of EEA and delivers the updated database to GISCO every 12 months. [definition source: ETC/TE.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.objecttrans_ro: informaţii despre sol în baza de date Corine

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need no be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee and rubber; this category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees and vines, but excludes land under trees for wood or timber. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: permanent crops

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.definition: A term referring to chemical reactions brought about by the light energy of the sun. The reaction of nitrogen oxides with hydrocarbons in the presence of sunlight to form ozone is an example of a photochemical reaction. [definition source: California Air Resources Board. Glossary of air pollution terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.name: photochemical reaction

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IDP.definition: Synonyms: internally displaced persons [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IDP.name: IDPs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aeo.definition: Energy extracted from wind, traditionally in a windmill, but increasingly by more complicated designs including turbines, usually to produce electricity but also for water pumping. The power available from wind is proportional to the area swept by the rotating place and the cube of the wind velocity, but less than half the available power can be recovered. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aeo.name: aeolian energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.definition: One of a group of halogen derivatives of organic hydrogen and carbon containing compounds; the group includes monohalogen compounds (alkyl or aryl halides) and polyhalogen compounds that contain the same or different halogen atoms. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.name: halogenated hydrocarbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: The capacity to do work; involving thermal energy (heat), radiant energy (light), kinetic energy (motion) or chemical energy; measured in joules. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.definition: A group of bacteria that are normally abundant in the intestinal tracts of human and other warm-blooded animals and are used as indicators (being measured as the number of individuals found per millilitre of water) when testing the sanitary quality of water. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.name: coliform

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.definition: Levels of air pollutants prescribed by regulations that may not be exceeded during a specified time in a defined area. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.name: air quality standard

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RIV.definition: Synonyms: National Institute for Public Health and the Environment, the Netherlands [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RIV.name: RIVM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.definition: Synonyms: IMR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.name: Institute of Marine Research, Norway

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Min.definition: Synonyms: MCPFE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Min.name: Ministerial Conference on the Protection of Forests in Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Min.objecttrans_en: Ministerial Conference on the Protection of Forests in Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Min.objectname_en: ministerial conference on the protection of forests in europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.definition: Disasters caused by movements and deformation of the earth's crust. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.name: geological disaster

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.name: habitats directive
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.definition: Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora. The aim of this directive is to contribute towards ensuring biodiversity through the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora in the European territory of the Member States to which the Convention on Biological Diversity applies. [definition source: Council Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora (Article 2.1, adapted)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_red.definition: 1) A publication listing the conservation status of different taxa in a given geographic area (e.g. region, country, world). 2) The series of publications produced by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). They provide an inventory on the threat to rare plants and animal species. Information includes status, geographical distribution, population size, habitat and breeding rate. The books also contain the conservation measures, if any, that have been taken to protect the species. There are five categories of rarity status: endangered species; vulnerable organisms, which are those unlikely to adapt to major environmental effects; rare organisms, which are those at risk because there are few of them in the world, such as plants which only grow on mountain peaks or on islands; out of danger species, which were formerly in the above categories, but have had the threat removed because of conservation actions; and indeterminate species, which are the plants and animals probably at risk, although not enough is known about them to assess their status. [definition source: 1) EEA. 2) EEA (GEMET).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_red.name: red book

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bat.definition: In the 1970's, Europe decided that bathing water quality should be monitored and tested in order to protect bathers from health risks and to preserve the environment from pollution. This resulted in 1976 in one of the first pieces of European environmental legislation: the Council Directive 76/160/EEC on Bathing Water Quality.The Directive was updated in 2002. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bat.name: Bathing Water Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: Elements that occur in very small quantities in living organisms. These elements include lead, silver, iron, zinc, nickel, cobalt and manganese. Some trace elements are essential for life processes, while others are detrimental. Even beneficial elements may be toxic at higher levels. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: trace elements

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IEE.definition: Synonyms: Institute for European Environmental Policy [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IEE.name: IEEP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: Synonyms: CBD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on Biological Diversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.definition: Group of single-cell micro-organisms, the smallest of the living organisms. Some are vital to sustain life, while others are responsible for causing highly dangerous human diseases, such as anthrax, tetanus and tuberculosis. Bacteria are found everywhere, in the soil,water and air. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.name: bacteria

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.objecttrans_is: sáðskipti, ræktun mismunandi afurða til skiptis
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.objectname_is: sáðskipti, ræktun mismunandi afurða til skiptis
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.name: crop rotation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.objecttrans_cs: střídání pěstovaných plodin na určitém území
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.definition: A crop rotation system means that the crops on a certain plot are following other crops according to a predefined plan. Normally the crops are changed annually, but they can also be multiannual. [definition source: Eurostat (draft definition). January, 2002.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cro.objectname_cs: střídání pěstovaných plodin na určitém území

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.definition: Radioactive waste means any material which contains or is contaminated by radio-nuclides and for which no use is foreseen. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.name: radioactive waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_O2.definition: Synonyms: oxygen [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_O2.name: O2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dep.definition: Synonyms: DFT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dep.name: Department for Transport, United Kingdom

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: The purpose of the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF) is to make the world's biodiversity data freely and universally available. GBIF works cooperatively with and in support of several other international organisations concerned with biodiversity. These include the clearing house mechanism and the global taxonomic initiative of the Convention on Biological Diversity, and regional biodiversity information networks. [definition source: Global biodiversity information facility.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global biodiversity information facility

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.name: deciduous forest
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.definition: Forest composed primarily of broad-leaved trees that shed all their leaves during one season. Such forests are found in three middle-latitude regions with a temperate climate characterised by a winter season and year-round precipitation. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land take
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_fr: utilisation des sols pour les infrastructures
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_bg: отнемане на земя поради изграждане на инфраструктура, но не задължително в смисъл на конфискация или отчуждаване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_fr: utilisation des sols pour les infrastructures
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_bg: отнемане на земя поради изграждане на инфраструктура, но не задължително в смисъл на конфискация или отчуждаване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: The area of land that is 'taken' by infrastructure itself and other facilities that necessarily go along with the infrastructure, such as filling stations on roads and railway stations. [definition source: European Commission. Phare Multi Country Transport. Programme Co-ordination Unit. 1999. Transport and the environment: A multi-country approach.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.definition: Chemicals placed on the market in volumes between 10 tonnes and 1000 tonnes per year per producer/importer. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.name: low production volume chemical

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.definition: The accumulation of soluble mineral salts near the surface of soil, usually caused by the capillary flow of water from saline ground water. Where the rate of surface evaporation is high, irrigation can exacerbate the problem by moistening the soil and causing water to be drawn from deeper levels as water evaporates from the surface. The evaporation of pure water leaves the salts behind, allowing them to accumulate, and they can reach concentrations that are toxic to plants, thus sterilising the land. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.name: salinisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IAC.definition: Synonyms: Inter-Agency Committee on Marine Science and Technology [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IAC.name: IACMST

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_5_5EA.definition: The fifth environmental action programme towards sustainability which was communicated by the Commission to the Council of Ministers in 1993, sets targets for the period from 1993-2000, together with a legislative agenda to the end of 1997. The action programmes are policy documents from the European Commission which aim to provide strategic guidance and orientation for the substantive work programmes and actions of the principal actors within the European Community. [definition source: European Commission. 1998. First report on the implementation of the Convention on biological diversity by the European Community.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_5_5EA.name: 5EAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNESCO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations educational, scientific and cultural organization

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: Synonyms: PGM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: platinum group metals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban sprawl
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.objectname_bg: разпръскване на селище в околностите на главното селище
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.objecttrans_bg: разпръскване на селище в околностите на главното селище
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: The physical pattern of low-density expansion of large urban areas under market conditions into the surrounding agricultural areas. Sprawl lies in advance of the principal lines of urban growth and implies little planning control of land subdivision. Development is patchy, scattered and strung out, with a tendency to discontinuity because it leap-frogs over some areas, leaving agricultural enclaves. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.objectname_de: 1) in dpsir: verursacher 2) general: verursacher, treibende kraft, bestimmender faktor, ursächlicher faktor, antriebskraft
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.objecttrans_de: 1) in DPSIR: Verursacher 2) general: Verursacher, treibende Kraft, bestimmender Faktor, ursächlicher Faktor, Antriebskraft
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.name: driving force
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.definition: In the EEA indicator system, indicators for driving forces describe the social, demographic and economic developments in societies and the corresponding changes in life styles, overall levels of consumption and production patterns. Primary driving forces are population growth and developments in the needs and activities of individuals. These primary driving forces provoke changes in the overall levels of production and consumption. Through these changes in production and consumption, the driving forces exert pressure on the environment. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environmental indicators.: Typology and overview. Technical report No 25.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.definition: Synonyms: SOX [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.name: sulphur oxides

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: Colourless, odourless, tasteless, non-corrosive, highly poisonous gas of about the same density as that of air. Very flammable, burning in air with bright blue flame. Although each molecule of CO has one carbon atom and one oxygen atom, it has a shape similar to that of an oxygen molecule (two atoms of oxygen), which is important with regard to its lethality. (Source: PHYMAC). [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon monoxide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_hu: {was} hulladéklerakás; szeméttelep, melyen a hulladékot hosszú távon a föld felszíne alatt tárolják
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_is: uppfylling með sorpi á landi eða neðanjarðar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_is: uppfylling með sorpi á landi eða neðanjarðar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landfill
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_hu: {WAS} hulladéklerakás; szeméttelep, melyen a hulladékot hosszú távon a föld felszíne alatt tárolják
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: A waste disposal site for the deposit of the waste onto or into land (i.e. underground). [definition source: Directive 1999/31/EC of 26 April 1999 on the landfill of waste.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cer.definition: Synonyms: CERs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cer.name: certified emission reductions

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bui.definition: Land under houses, roads, mines and quarries and any other facilities, including their auxiliary spaces, deliberately installed for the pursuit of human activities. Included area also certain types of open land (non-built-up land), which are closely related to these activities, such as waste tips, derelict land in built-up areas, junk yards, city parks and gardens, etc. Land occupied by scattered farm buildings, yards and their annexes are excluded. Land under closed villages or similar rural localities is included. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bui.name: built-up area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: That part of the continental margin that lies between the continental shelf and the bottom of the ocean. Sunlight does not penetrate this area, and mostly it is home to scavengers. It is characterised by a relatively steep slope of 3 to 6 degrees. [definition source: Geoological Society of Minnesota. Glossary of common geological terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: continental slope

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_sk: európsky program spolupráce pri monitorovaní a vyhodnocovaní škodlivín v atmosfére
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_sl: emep, program sodelovanja za spremljanje in oceno onesnaževanja zraka na velike razdalje v evropi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_el: EMEP (πρόγραμμα συνεργασίας για τη συνεχή παρακολούθηση και την εκτίμηση της μεταφοράς των ατμοσφαιρικών ρύπων σε μεγάλη απόσταση στην Ευρώπη)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_lv: emep, sadarbības programma gaisa piesārņojuma izplatības monitoringam

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_es: EMEP (Programa concertado de vigilancia continua y de evaluación de la transmisión a larga distancia de los contaminantes atmosféricos en Europa)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_pl: emep, program monitorowania i oceny dalekosiężnego przenoszenia substancji zanieczyszczających powietrze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_da: EMEP (samarbejdsprogram for overvågning og vurdering af transport af luftforurenende stoffer over store afstande i Europa)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_is: eftirlits- og matsáætlun um dreifingu mengandi efna í lofti um evrópu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_pt: emep (programa comum de vigilância contínua e de avaliação do transporte a longa distância dos poluentes atmosféricos na europa)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_es: emep (programa concertado de vigilancia continua y de evaluación de la transmisión a larga distancia de los contaminantes atmosféricos en europa)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.name: EMEP
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_pl: EMEP, Program monitorowania i oceny dalekosiężnego przenoszenia substancji zanieczyszczających powietrze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_hu: {AIRCHA} EMEP; Európai Mérõ-megfigyelõ és Értékelõ Program
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_lv: EMEP, sadarbības programma gaisa piesārņojuma izplatības monitoringam
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_lt: EMEP (Europos teršalų stebėjimo ir kontrolės programa)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_el: emep (πρόγραμμα συνεργασίας για τη συνεχή παρακολούθηση και την εκτίμηση της μεταφοράς των ατμοσφαιρικών ρύπων σε μεγάλη απόσταση στην ευρώπη)
