glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_cs: EMEP (Program spolupráce pro měření a vyhodnocování dálkového přenosu emisí do ovzduší v Evropě)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_fi: ilman epäpuhtauksien kaukokulkeutumisen tarkkailua ja arviointia koskeva euroopan yhteistyöohjelma
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_fr: emep (programme de coopération pour la surveillance continue et l'évaluation du transport à longue distance des polluants atmosphériques en europe)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_nl: emep (programma voor samenwerking inzake de bewaking en evaluatie van het transport van luchtverontreinigende stoffen over lange afstand in europa)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_sk: Európsky program spolupráce pri monitorovaní a vyhodnocovaní škodlivín v atmosfére
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_sl: EMEP, Program sodelovanja za spremljanje in oceno onesnaževanja zraka na velike razdalje v Evropi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_bg: емер - програма за мониторинг и оценка на трансграничното замърсяване на въздуха
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_fi: ilman epäpuhtauksien kaukokulkeutumisen tarkkailua ja arviointia koskeva Euroopan yhteistyöohjelma
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_fr: EMEP (Programme de coopération pour la surveillance continue et l'évaluation du transport à longue distance des polluants atmosphériques en Europe)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_bg: ЕМЕР - Програма за мониторинг и оценка на трансграничното замърсяване на въздуха
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.definition: The cooperative programme for monitoring and evaluation of the long-range transmission of air pollutants in Europe, linked to the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution (CLRTAP). The main objective of the EMEP programme is to regularly provide governments and subsidiary bodies under the CLRTAP with qualified scientific information to support the development and further evaluation of the international protocols on emission reductions negotiated within the convention. [definition source: EEA. EMEP/CORINAIR Atmospheric Emission Inventory Guidebook (Second edition).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objectname_cs: emep (program spolupráce pro měření a vyhodnocování dálkového přenosu emisí do ovzduší v evropě)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EME.objecttrans_nl: EMEP (programma voor samenwerking inzake de bewaking en evaluatie van het transport van luchtverontreinigende stoffen over lange afstand in Europa)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecotax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Tax with a potentially positive environmental impact, hence comprising energy taxes, transport taxes and taxes on pollution and resources. Also called environmental tax. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness. Environmental issues series No 1]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ins.definition: Any chemical agent used to destroy invertebrate pests. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ins.name: insecticide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ESL [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Statistical Laboratory

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_el: IPCC (διακυβερνητική ομάδα για τις κλιματικές μεταβολές)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_lv: ipcc, starpvaldību grupa klimata izmaiņu jautājumos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_pl: ipcc, międzyrządowy komitet ds. zmiany klimatu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_pt: ipcc (painel internacional sobre as alterações climáticas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.name: IPCC
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_pl: IPCC, Międzyrządowy komitet ds. zmiany klimatu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_lv: IPCC, Starpvaldību grupa klimata izmaiņu jautājumos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_el: ipcc (διακυβερνητική ομάδα για τις κλιματικές μεταβολές)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_pt: IPCC (Painel Internacional sobre as Alterações Climáticas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_fr: groupe intergouvernemental sur l'évolution du climat
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objectname_bg: мфкп - междуправителствен форум по климатични промени
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_fr: Groupe intergouvernemental sur l'évolution du climat
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.objecttrans_bg: МФКП - Междуправителствен форум по климатични промени
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.definition: Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC). Widely regarded as the most authoritative international voice on the science and impacts of climate change. Established by governments under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organisation and UN Environment Programme (UNEP) in 1988, the IPCC produces five-yearly reports assessing the state of knowledge on climate change which represent the international consensus among the more than 2 000 experts involved. It has also published reports on specific issues, such as sinks. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hot.definition: A hotspot is a center of high activity within a larger area of low activity. The term is applied to different things in different contexts: in geology, a hotspot is a location on the Earth's surface that has vulcanism for a long period of time. In meteorology, a hotspot is an area where the atmosphere is relatively hot. Examples of hotspots include the air over a desert. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hot.name: hotspot

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.definition: A stress upon an organism that disrupts the structure or function and results in a pathological process. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_les.name: lesion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.definition: Region of the ocean through which light penetrates; and the place where photosynthetic marine organisms live. [definition source: University of California. Berkeley.UCMP Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pho.name: photic zone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.definition: A judgement about whether or not the expected objectives and targets of the policy measure have been achieved. This requires comparing the effects of the measure with its intended objectives. [definition source: EEA. 2001. Why is it important to assess effects and effectiveness? Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.name: effectiveness of a measure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.definition: Energy released by nuclear fission or nuclear fusion. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.name: nuclear power

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAP.definition: The set of policy principles, regulations and subsidy mechanisms adopted by the Member States of the European Community that consolidates efforts in promoting or ensuring reasonable pricing of food products, fair standards of living for farmers, stable agricultural markets, increased farm productivity and methods for dealing with food supply or surplus. [definition source: Adapted from: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAP.name: CAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOE.definition: Greatest concentration or amount of a substance, found by observation or experiment, which causes no detectable effect. [definition source: WHO. 1994. Assessing human health risks of chemicals: Derivation of guidance values for health-based exposure limits. Environmental health criteria 170. World Health Organization, Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOE.name: NOEL

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: A programme of action to provide for present and future demands for movement of people and goods. Such a programme is preceded by a transport study and necessarily includes consideration of the various modes of transport. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: transportation planning

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.definition: The adverse effects to aquatic organisms that result from being exposed to a toxic substance. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.name: aquatic toxicity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Ecological resilience can be defined in two ways. The first is a measure of the magnitude of disturbance that can be absorbed before the (eco)system changes its structure by changing the variables and processes that control behaviour. The second, a more traditional meaning, is as a measure of resistance to disturbance and the speed of return to the equilibrium state of an ecosystem. [definition source: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological resilience

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Synonyms: NEC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: national emission ceilings

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: A fixed annual charge for heavy vehicles calculated in accordance with the damage caused to the environment and road infrastructure, necessary for using the roads in EU countries that do not levy tolls on motorways. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Eurovignette

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_Jap.definition: Synonyms: JAMA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_Jap.name: Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objectname_de: unkontrollierte abfallbeseitigung, wilde deponie von abfällen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objecttrans_de: unkontrollierte Abfallbeseitigung, wilde Deponie von Abfällen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste dumping
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The disposal of solid wastes without environmental controls. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.definition: Synonyms: COR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.name: Committee of the Regions

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.definition: Synonyms: WTTC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wor.name: World Travel and Tourism Council

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_hu: {ecorep} nemzeti számvetés (környezetvédelmi szempontok figyelembevételével készült helyesbített ~)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_it: contabilità nazionali adeguate agli aspetti ambientali
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_pl: rachunki narodowe skorygowane o wielkości związane ze środowiskiem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_it: contabilità nazionali adeguate agli aspetti ambientali
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmentally adjusted national accounts
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_pl: rachunki narodowe skorygowane o wielkości związane ze środowiskiem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_hu: {ECOREP} nemzeti számvetés (környezetvédelmi szempontok figyelembevételével készült helyesbített ~)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_cs: národní fondy upravené podle nároků životního prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_fr: comptes nationaux ajustés d'un point de vue écologique
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_nl: nationale rekeningen waarbij rekening met het milieu wordt gehouden
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: сметки, водене на сметки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_ro: contabilitate naţională ajustată în funcţie de mediul ambiant
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_fr: comptes nationaux ajustés d'un point de vue écologique
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: сметки, водене на сметки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_cs: národní fondy upravené podle nároků životního prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_ro: Contabilitate naţională ajustată în funcţie de mediul ambiant
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_nl: nationale rekeningen waarbij rekening met het milieu wordt gehouden

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: On 19 July 2000, the Council of Europe's Committee of Ministers adopted the European Landscape Convention and decided to open it for signature to the 41 Council of Europe's Member States. The European Landscape Convention aims at filling the legal vacuum caused by the absence, at European level, of a specific, comprehensive reference text devoted entirely to the conservation, management and improvement of European landscapes in the international legal instruments on the environment, regional planning and the cultural heritage. [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Landscape Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EHP.definition: Synonyms: environment and health performance review [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EHP.name: EHPR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sup.objecttrans_es: estrategia por el lado de la oferta
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sup.objectname_es: estrategia por el lado de la oferta
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sup.name: supply-side strategy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: The process which remove pollutants not adequately removed by secondary treatment, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus; accomplished by means of sand filters, microstraining, or other methods. Similar to tertiary treatment. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: tertiary treatment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sit.definition: Precautionary actions, procedures or installations undertaken to prevent or reduce harm to the environmental integrity of a physical area or location. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sit.name: site protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.definition: Any form of deposition on water, land and other surfaces that increases their acidity by contamination with acid pollutants, such as sulphur oxides, sulphates, nitrogen oxides and nitrates, and ammonium compounds. The deposition can be either dry (as in the adsorption of acid pollutants to particles) or wet (as in acid precipitation). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.name: acid deposition

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bal.definition: Equilibrium or balance is any of a number of related phenomena in the natural and social sciences. In general, a system is said to be in a state of equilibrium if all influences on the system are cancelled by the effects of others. A related concept is stability; an equilibrium may or may not be stable. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bal.name: balance + qual

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_ult.definition: Radiation in the wavelength range between visible light and X-rays, divided into wavelength bands A, B, C. Much of the ultraviolet radiations in bands B and C are prevented from reaching the earth's surface by the ozone layer present in the atmosphere. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_ult.name: ultraviolet radiation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.definition: Synonyms: CEPA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.name: Communication, Education and Public Awareness

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IEA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Energy Agency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Synonyms: PFCs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: perfluorocarbons

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: continental shelf
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: The gently seaward-sloping surface that extends between the shoreline and the top of the continental slope at about 150 m depth. The average gradient of the shelf is between 1:500 and 1:1000 and, although it varies greatly, the average width is approximately 70 km. [definition source: Allaby, 1994. Quoted in: European Topic Centre on Nature Conservation. 1998. EUNIS habitat classification. Final draft with further revisions to marine habitats. United Kingdom.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.definition: The degree of danger posed by a substance to animal or plant life. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tox.name: toxicity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: extrapolation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: A scenario describing a future that is simply a continuation of current situations and trends. [definition source: WHO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_Ozo.definition: The Ozone web system provides the public with hourly ozone information from selected stations in European countries. Users can look through an easy map-based interface at station information with ozone graphs, link to national ozone web sites for more information and study relevant documentation. Ozone - conditions across Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_Ozo.name: Ozoneweb

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEI.definition: Annual total abstraction of fresh water divided by the long-term average freshwater resources. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEI.name: WEI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organic waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: Waste containing carbon compounds. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.definition: Synonyms: IES [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Ins.name: Institute for Environment and Sustainability

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.objectname_de: ausgebranntes spaltmaterial, verbrauchter nuklearer brennstoff, abgebrannte brennelemente, bestrahlte kernbrennstoffe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.objecttrans_de: ausgebranntes Spaltmaterial, verbrauchter nuklearer Brennstoff, abgebrannte Brennelemente, bestrahlte Kernbrennstoffe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: spent nuclear fuel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: Fuel is withdrawn from a nuclear reactor following irradiation and has undergone at least one year's decay since being used as a source of energy in a power reactor. Spent nuclear fuel (SNF) has not been chemically separated from its constituent elements by reprocessing. SNF includes the special nuclear material, by-product material, source material, and other radioactive materials associated with fuel assemblies. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: primary treatment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: (1) Removal of floating solids and suspended solids, both fine and coarse, from raw sewage. (2) Primary treatment means treatment of urban wastewater by a physical and/or chemical process involving settlement of suspended solids, or other processes in which the BOD5 of the incoming wastewater is reduced by at least 20 % before discharge and the total suspended solids of the incoming wastewater are reduced by at least 50 %. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000). 2) Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May concerning urban waste-water treatment.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_hu: {aircha} szén anabolizmus, szén-dioxid komplexképzés, szén felvétele / megkötése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon sequestration
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_hu: {AIRCHA} szén anabolizmus, szén-dioxid komplexképzés, szén felvétele / megkötése
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: The uptake and storage of carbon. Trees and plants, for example, absorb carbon dioxide, release the oxygen and store the carbon. [definition source: Environmental Dictionary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: The ability of an organism to live in the presence of environmental stress, pathogens or pests. Natural resistance of crops can be increased through breeding to reduce use of pesticides and irrigation. However, resistance acquired by weeds and insects can be a problem. [definition source: Agricultural Experiment Station, Kansas State University. A glossary of agriculture, environment, and sustainable development. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: resistance

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A community of manufacturing and service businesses located together on a common property. Member businesses seek enhanced environmental, economic, and social performance through collaboration in managing environmental and resource issues. An eco-industrial park also seeks benefits for neighbouring communities to assure that the net impact of its development is positive. [definition source: Adapted from: RPP International's Industrial Ecology Research Center.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-industrial park

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.definition: Synonyms: GM crops [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.name: genetically modified crops

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cod.objecttrans_is: siðareglur um góðar starfsvenjur í landbúnaði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cod.objectname_is: siðareglur um góðar starfsvenjur í landbúnaði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cod.name: Code of Good Agricultural Practice

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: Shallow pond, usually human-made, where sunlight, bacteria and oxygen interact to help purify wastewater. The term is synonymous with sewage oxidation pond and stabilisation pond. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage oxidation pond

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAS.definition: Synonyms: Rapid Alert Systems for Food and Feed [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAS.name: RASFF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GRI.definition: DEWA~Europe/GRID-Geneva is one of UNEP's major centres for data and information management, with a unique, 'value-adding' mandate in the handling of global and regional environmental data, which in turn support the environment assessment and early-warning activities of UNEP and its partners. At the same time, DEWA~Europe occupies the niche of francophone centre for the global GRID network. DEWA~Europe/GRID-Geneva is supported by a 'Partnership Agreement' between UNEP, the Swiss Agency for Environment, Forests and Landscape (SAEFL) and the University of Geneva. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GRI.name: GRID

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Land on which no urban development has previously taken place; usually understood to be on the periphery, of an existing built-up area. [definition source: Borough Council (UK).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: greenfield site

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objecttrans_is: mjög mengað kyrrt eða rennandi vatn
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objectname_is: mjög mengað kyrrt eða rennandi vatn
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.name: heavily modified water body
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objectname_fi: vesistön osa, johon on tehty suuria muutoksia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objecttrans_fi: vesistön osa, johon on tehty suuria muutoksia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.definition: A body of surface water which as a result of physical alterations by human activity is substantially changed in character, as designated by the Member State in accordance with the provisions of Annex II of the water framework directive. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GBI.definition: The purpose of the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF) is to make the world's biodiversity data freely and universally available. GBIF works cooperatively with and in support of several other international organisations concerned with biodiversity. These include the clearing house mechanism and the global taxonomic initiative of the Convention on Biological Diversity, and regional biodiversity information networks. [definition source: Global biodiversity information facility.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GBI.name: GBIF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.definition: A power plant in which nuclear energy is converted into heat for use in producing steam for turbines, which in turn drive generators that produce electric power. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.name: nuclear power station

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: The terrestrial bio-productive system that comprises soil vegetation, other biota, and the ecological and hydrological processes that operate within the system. [definition source: UN Convention to Combat Desertification.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.definition: An essential nutrient in the food supply of plants and the diets of animals. Animals obtain it in nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly amino acids. Although in the atmosphere is nearly 80% gaseous nitrogen, very few organisms have the ability to use it in this form. The higher plants normally obtain it from the soil after micro-organisms have converted the nitrogen into ammonia or nitrates, which they can then absorb. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.name: nitrogen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ACEA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Automobile Manufacturers' Association

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landfilling
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Deposition of waste on land under controlled conditions. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.objectname_lv: barības vielu līdzsvars, biogēno elementu līdzsvars
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.name: nutrient balance
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.objecttrans_lv: barības vielu līdzsvars, biogēno elementu līdzsvars
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.definition: 1) The soil surface nitrogen balance is calculated as the difference between the total quantity of nitrogen inputs entering the soil and the quantity of nitrogen outputs leaving the soil annually, based on the nitrogen cycle. 2) Condition in which there is equilibrium between intake and excretion of nutrients. [definition source: 1) OECD Secretariat. 2001. OECD National Soil Surface Nitrogen Balances. Explanatory notes. 2) EEA (GEMET)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: The line that separates a land surface from an ocean or sea. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastline

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: Power station which operates with the free renewable source of energy provided by falling water. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydroelectric power station

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_el: βάση δεδομένων για τις υποχρεώσεις γνωστοποίησης
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_lv: rod, obligātās vides informācijas datu bāze internetā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_es: base de datos de obligaciones de informar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_pl: bank danych wynikający ze zobowiązań składania doniesień
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_pt: rod (base de dados de troca de informação)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_es: base de datos de obligaciones de informar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.name: reporting obligations database
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_pl: Bank danych wynikający ze zobowiązań składania doniesień
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_lv: ROD, Obligātās vides informācijas datu bāze Internetā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_el: βάση δεδομένων για τις υποχρεώσεις γνωστοποίησης
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_pt: ROD (Base de Dados de Troca de Informação)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_fr: base de données relative aux obligations d'information
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_bg: база данни за докладване по изпълнението на задължения
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objectname_ro: baza de date cu privire la obligaţiile de raportare
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_fr: Base de données relative aux obligations d'information
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_bg: база данни за докладване по изпълнението на задължения
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.definition: Database holding information on EEA member countries' different obligations to international and EU organisations with regard to environmental reporting that follows from both international and EU legislation and other international and EU cooperation. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rep.objecttrans_ro: Baza de date cu privire la obligaţiile de raportare

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_el: βιοαέριο / αέριο από τη ζύμωση αποβλήτων
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biogas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_el: βιοαέριο / αέριο από τη ζύμωση αποβλήτων
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Gas, rich in methane, which is produced by the fermentation of animal dung, human sewage or crop residues in an air-tight container. It is used as a fuel to heat stoves, lamps, run small machines and to generate electricity. The residues of biogas production are used as a low-grade organic fertiliser. Biogas fuels do not usually cause any pollution to the atmosphere, and because they come from renewable energy resources they have great potential for future use. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The system of pipes supplying water to communities and industries. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water distribution network

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: The mineral material from which a soil forms. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: parent material

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: A method of production, which puts the highest emphasis on environmental protection and, with regard to livestock production, animal welfare considerations. It avoids or largely reduces the use of synthetic chemical inputs such as fertilisers, pesticides, additives and medical products. [definition source: DG Agriculture. Organic farming in the EU - Fact and figures.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organic farming

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: The body of policy and administrative decisions and operational activities which pertain to the various stages of a disaster at all levels. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: disaster management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objectname_sl: snov, ki povzroča tanjšanje ozonske plasti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objectname_de: ozonabbauender stoff, stoff, der zum abbau der ozonschicht führt, stoff, der zur zerstörung der ozonschicht führt, ozonkiller
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objecttrans_de: ozonabbauender Stoff, Stoff, der zum Abbau der Ozonschicht führt, Stoff, der zur Zerstörung der Ozonschicht führt, Ozonkiller
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objectname_pt: substâncias que destroem a camada de ozono
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone-depleting substance
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objecttrans_pt: substâncias que destroem a camada de ozono
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objecttrans_sl: snov, ki povzroča tanjšanje ozonske plasti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: A compound that contributes to stratospheric ozone depletion. Ozone-depleting substances (ODS) include CFCs, HCFCs, halons, methyl bromide, carbon tetrachloride, and methyl chloroform. ODS are generally very stable in the troposphere and only degrade under intense ultraviolet light in the stratosphere. When they break down, they release chlorine or bromine atoms, which then deplete ozone. [definition source: US EPA. Ozone Depletion Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tec.definition: An unexpected incident, failure or loss occurring through the application of practical or mechanical sciences to industry or commerce that poses potential harm to persons, property or the environment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tec.name: technological accident

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: The amount of oxygen used for biochemical oxidation by a unit volume of water at a given temperature and for a given time. BOD is an index of the degree of organic pollution in water. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biochemical oxygen demand

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fug.objectname_lv: ar filtru sistēmām neuztvertā gāzu emisija
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fug.name: fugitive emission
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fug.objecttrans_lv: ar filtru sistēmām neuztvertā gāzu emisija
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fug.definition: Emissions not caught by a capture system which are often due to equipment leaks, evaporative processes and windblown disturbances. [definition source: California Air Resources Board. Glossary of Air Pollution Terms]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_den.definition: 1) The loss of nitrogen from soil by biological or chemical means. It is a gaseous loss, unrelated to loss by physical processes such as through leachates. 2) The breakdown of nitrates by soil bacteria, resulting in the release of free nitrogen. This process takes place under anaerobic conditions, such as are found in water-logged soil, and it reduces soil fertility. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_den.name: denitrification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tax.name: tax differentiation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tax.definition: Tax differentiation relates to variations in existing indirect taxes, such as excise duties, sales taxes, or value added taxes for environmental ends. Goods and services that are associated with environmental damage in production and consumption may be taxed more heavily. [definition source: OECD. 1996. Implementation strategies for environmental taxes. France.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_en: nomenclature of territorial units for statistics
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_es: NUTS; Nomenclatura de las unidades territoriales estadísticas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_sv: standardindelningen av territoriella enheter för statistikändamål
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_it: Nomenclatura delle unità territoriali per la statistica
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_da: nomenklatur for statistiske territoriale enheder; nuts
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_de: systematik der gebietseinheiten für die statistik
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_de: Systematik der Gebietseinheiten für die Statistik
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_da: nomenklatur for statistiske territoriale enheder; NUTS
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_it: nomenclatura delle unità territoriali per la statistica
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_es: nuts; nomenclatura de las unidades territoriales estadísticas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.name: nomenclature of territorial units for statistics
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_en: nomenclature of territorial units for statistics
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_nl: nomenclatuur van territoriale eenheden voor de statistiek
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_bg: номенклатура на териториалните единици за статистиката
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_sv: Standardindelningen av territoriella enheter för statistikändamål
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objectname_ro: nomenclatură a unităţilor teritoriale pentru statistici
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_bg: номенклатура на териториалните единици за статистиката
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.definition: The nomenclature of territorial units for statistics (NUTS) was drawn up by Eurostat to be a single, cohesive system of territorial groupings for the compilation of EU regional statistics. The NUTS nomenclature subdivides the economic territory of the EU into 77 regions at NUTS level 1, 206 regions at NUTS level 2 and 1031 regions at NUTS level 3. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_ro: nomenclatură a unităţilor teritoriale pentru statistici
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nom.objecttrans_nl: nomenclatuur van territoriale eenheden voor de statistiek

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.name: protected area
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.definition: A geographically defined area which is designated or regulated and managed to achieve specific conservation objectives. [definition source: The Convention on Biological Diversity.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cd.definition: Synonyms: cadmium [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cd.name: Cd

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hid.definition: The movement of the unused materials associated with the extraction of raw materials, domestically and abroad. [definition source: Eurostat. 2001. Economy-wide material flow accounts and derived indicators. Luxembourg.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hid.name: hidden flow

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_des.name: desert
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_des.definition: (1) An ecosystem with <100 mm precipitation per year. (2) A wide, open, comparatively barren tract of land with few forms of life and little rainfall. [definition source: (1) IPCC. Climate change 2001: Impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.definition: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland and/or tidal waters, and/or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. A great flow along a watercourse or a flow causing inundation of lands not normally covered by water. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.name: flooding

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNS.definition: Synonyms: United Nations Statistics Division [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNS.name: UNSD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EC_.definition: The European Community (EC) initiative to encourage the promotion of environmentally friendly products. The scheme came into operation in late 1992 and was designed to identify products which are less harmful to the environment than equivalent brands. For example, eco-labels will be awarded to products that do not contain chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) which damage ozone layer, to those products that can be, or are, recycled, and to those that are energy efficient. The labels are awarded on environmental criteria set by the EC. These cover the whole life cycle of a product, from the extraction of raw materials, through manufacture, distribution, use and disposal of the product. The first products to carry the EC eco-labels were washing machines, paper towels, writing paper, light bulbs and hairsprays. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EC_.name: EC ecolabel

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: The region occupied by an aquatic species that is used for commercial harvesting. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fishery

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.definition: The non-living portion of the earth, excluding the atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere. [definition source: Agricultural experiment station, Kansas State University. A glossary of agriculture, environment, and sustainable development. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.name: geosphere

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water erosion
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_bg: водна ерозия, ерозия в резултат на въздействие на водата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_bg: водна ерозия, ерозия в резултат на въздействие на водата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The breakdown of solid rock into smaller particles and its removal by water. As weathering, erosion is a natural geological process, but more rapid soil erosion results from poor land-use practices, leading to the loss of fertile topsoil and to the silting of dams, lakes, rivers and harbours. There are three classes of erosion by water: (a) splash erosion occurs when raindrops strike bare soil, causing it to splash, as mud, to flow into spaces in the soil and to turn the upper layer of soil into a structureless, compacted mass that dries with a hard, largely impermeable crust; (b) surface flow occurs when soil is removed with surface run-off during heavy rain; (c) channelised flow occurs when a flowing mixture of water and soil cuts a channel, which is then deepened by further scouring. A minor erosion channel is called a rill, a larger channel a gully. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mob.name: mobility
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mob.definition: The ability of groups or individuals to relocate or change jobs, or to physically move from one place to another. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tar.definition: Synonyms: TV [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tar.name: target value

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: The total time period over which contacts occur between the agent and a target. For, example, if an individual is in contact with an agent for 10 minutes a day, for 300 days over a one-year time period, the exposure duration is one year. [definition source: The international programme on chemical safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure duration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: Synonyms: SeaWiFS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: sea-viewing wide field-of-view sensor

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Acc.definition: The sum of the differences between hourly ozone concentration and 40 ppb for each hour when the concentration exceeds 40 ppb during a relevant growing season, e.g. for forest and crops. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Acc.name: Accumulated Ozone over a threshold of 40ppb
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Acc.objecttrans_en: Accumulated Ozone over a threshold of 40ppb
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Acc.objectname_en: accumulated ozone over a threshold of 40ppb

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_O3.definition: Ozone, the triatomic form of oxygen (O3), is a gaseous atmospheric constituent. In the troposphere - at ground level - it is created both naturally and by photochemical reactions involving gases resulting from human activities (photochemical smog). In high concentrations, tropospheric ozone can be harmful to a wide range of living organisms. In the stratosphere, ozone is created by the interaction between solar ultraviolet (UV) radiation and molecular oxygen (O2). Stratospheric ozone plays a decisive role in protecting life on earth from ultraviolet radiation from the sun. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_O3.name: O3

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ESPON [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Spatial Planning Observation Network

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: In 2000, the European Commission adopted a Decision on the implementation of a European pollutant emission register (EPER) according to Article 15 of Council Directive 96/61/EC concerning iIntegrated pollution prevention and control (IPPC). The general purpose of the IPPC Directive is to reduce pollution by industry and to control emissions from larger facilities. National governments of all EC Member States are required to maintain inventories of emission data from specified industrial sources and to report emissions from individual facilities to the European Commission. The reported data will be made accessible in a public register (EPER), which is intended to provide environmental information on major industrial activities. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European pollutant emission register

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MNP.definition: Synonyms: The Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MNP.name: MNP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: ICCM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Conference on Chemicals Management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PEC.definition: This is the estimated concentration of a chemical in an environmental compartment calculated from available information on its properties, its use and discharge patterns, and the quantities involved. [definition source: Heriot Watt University (UK).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PEC.name: PEC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GHG.definition: A gas that contributes to the natural greenhouse effect. The Kyoto Protocol covers a basket of six greenhouse gases (GHGs) produced by human activities: carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulphur hexafluoride. Annex I Parties' emissions of these gases taken together are to be measured in terms of carbon dioxide equivalents on the basis of the gases' global warming potential. An important natural GHG that is not covered by the protocol is water vapour. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GHG.name: GHG

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exploratory scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: Exploratory scenarios (also known as descriptive scenarios) are those that begin in the present and explore trends into the future. [definition source: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cam.definition: Synonyms: CERA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cam.name: Cambridge Energy Research Associates

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.objectname_hu: ramsari lista, nemzetközi jelentőségű vizes területek jegyzéke
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.name: Ramsar list
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.objecttrans_hu: Ramsari Lista, Nemzetközi Jelentőségű Vizes Területek Jegyzéke
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.definition: At the time of joining the Convention on Wetlands (Ramsar Convention), each contracting party undertakes to designate at least one site for inclusion in the list of wetlands of international importance (the 'Ramsar list'). The inclusion of a site in the Ramsar list confers upon it the prestige of international recognition and obliges the government to take all steps necessary to ensure the maintenance of the ecological character of the site. At any time, contracting parties may designate additional wetlands for the list or extend the boundaries of those already included. They select wetlands within their territories on the basis of their international significance in terms of ecology, botany, zoology, limnology or hydrology, as measured by reference to the convention's criteria for identifying wetlands of international importance. [definition source: Ramsar Convention web site.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.definition: Precautionary measures, equipment or structures implemented to guard or defend people, property and lands from an unusual accumulation of water above the ground. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.name: flood protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: Synonyms: COP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Conference of the Parties

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objectname_de: in dpsir: maßnahme, general: reaktion, antwort, maßnahme, abhilfemaßnahme
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objecttrans_de: in DPSIR: Maßnahme, general: Reaktion, Antwort, Maßnahme, Abhilfemaßnahme
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: response
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: In the EEA indicator system, response indicators refer to responses by groups (and individuals) in society, as well as government attempts to prevent, compensate, ameliorate or adapt to changes in the state of the environment. Some societal responses may be regarded as negative driving forces, since they aim at redirecting prevailing trends in consumption and production patterns. Other responses aim at raising the efficiency of products and processes, through stimulating the development and penetration of clean technologies. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environmental indicators: Typology and overview. Technical report No 25. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_can.definition: A substance that causes cancer in humans and animals. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_can.name: cancerogen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: An external benefit is a benefit not included in the market price of the goods and services being produced, i.e. a benefit not paid by those who receive it. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint group of experts of the scientific aspects of marine environmental protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: external benefit

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objectname_lv: (ekoloģiskā) elastība, ekosistēmas spēja saglabāt savu struktūru
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: resilience
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objecttrans_lv: (ekoloģiskā) elastība, ekosistēmas spēja saglabāt savu struktūru
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objectname_bg: способност за възстановяване на екосистема след вредно въздействие, екологична издръжливост
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.objecttrans_bg: способност за възстановяване на екосистема след вредно въздействие, екологична издръжливост
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Ecological resilience can be defined in two ways. The first is a measure of the magnitude of disturbance that can be absorbed before the (eco)system changes its structure by changing the variables and processes that control behaviour. The second, a more traditional meaning, is as a measure of resistance to disturbance and the speed of return to the equilibrium state of an ecosystem. [definition source: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.definition: Unit of measure of goods transport which represents the transport of one tonne over one kilometre. The distance to be taken into consideration is the distance actually run. [definition source: Eurostat, ECMT, UN/ECE. 1997. Glossary for Transport Statistics. Document prepared by the Intersecretariat Working Group on Transport Statistics. Second edition.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.name: tonne-km

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pes.definition: Any substance or mixture of substances which through physiological action protects the plants against parasites, fungi, virus, or other damaging factors. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pes.name: pesticides

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rur.definition: Geographical area where the population density of humans is low and the main economic activity is agriculture, forestry, or hunting. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rur.name: rural area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.definition: The progenitors of the compounds that contribute to the problem of acidification, such as sulphur oxides, sulphates, nitrogen oxides and nitrates, and ammonium compounds [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aci.name: acidifying compounds

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Energy security or security of supply can be defined as the availability of energy at all times in various forms, in sufficient quantities, and at reasonable and/or affordable prices. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: security of supply

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ref.name: reforestation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ref.definition: (1) Planting of forests on lands that have previously contained forests but that have been converted to some other use. (2) The reestablishment of forest cover either naturally (by natural seeding, coppice, or root suckers) or artificially (by direct seeding or planting). [definition source: (1) IPCC. Climate change 2001: Impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vol.name: voluntary agreement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vol.definition: A contract between the public administration and the industry in which the firm agrees to achieve a certain environmental objective and receives a subsidy to change its technology though R&D and innovation. The agreement is bilateral, between one firm and the administration, and requires a voluntary element on both sides. [definition source: Adapted from: Carraro, C. and Siniscalo, D. Voluntary agreements in environmental policy. A theoretical appraisal. Fondazione Eni Enrico Mattei. Italy.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.name: heavy metal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.definition: Metal or metalloid which are stable and which have a density greater that 4.5 g/cm3, namely lead, copper, nickel, cadmium, platinum, zinc, mercury and arsenic. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 113. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: The third step in the process of hazard assessment aiming at the determination of the qualitative and quantitative relationship between exposure to a hazard under certain conditions, including attendant uncertainties and the resultant adverse effect. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazard evaluation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Synonyms: PFOA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: perfluorooctanoic acid

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IMR.definition: Synonyms: Institute of Marine Research, Norway [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IMR.name: IMR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.objectname_lv: eitrofikācija, organisko barības vielu uzkrāšanās ezeros un upēs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.name: eutrophication
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.objecttrans_lv: eitrofikācija, organisko barības vielu uzkrāšanās ezeros un upēs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.objectname_bg: еутрофиране (на води, водещо напр. до затлачаване)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.objecttrans_bg: еутрофиране (на води, водещо напр. до затлачаване)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eut.definition: Excessive enrichment of waters with nutrients, and the associated adverse biological effects. [definition source: EEA. 1994. European rivers and lakes. EEA Environmental Monographs 1.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IWMI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Water Management Institute

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAH.definition: Synonyms: Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Sciences [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAH.name: SAHFOS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.definition: Synonyms: dl [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dec.name: decilitre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objectname_sl: na različnih ciljnih strategijah zasnovan scenarij
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objectname_hu: {sceana} visszatekintő forgatókönyv, a kívánt helyzet / állapot elérésére
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.name: backcasting scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objecttrans_hu: {SCEANA} visszatekintő forgatókönyv, a kívánt helyzet / állapot elérésére
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objectname_fi: haluttuun tulevaan tilanteeseen tähtääviä strategioita koskeva skenaario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objecttrans_sl: na različnih ciljnih strategijah zasnovan scenarij
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.objecttrans_fi: haluttuun tulevaan tilanteeseen tähtääviä strategioita koskeva skenaario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.definition: Backcasting scenarios reason from a desired future situation and offer a number of different strategies to reach this situation. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Cloudy crystal balls. Environmental issues report No 17.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nan.definition: Synonyms: ng [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nan.name: nanogram

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.name: nutrient removal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.definition: Elimination of nutrients from wastewater in order to prevent water eutrophication. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IWM.definition: Synonyms: International Water Management Institute [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IWM.name: IWMI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.definition: The degree of dissolved salts in water measured by weight in parts per thousand. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sal.name: salinity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.objectname_hu: ramsari egyezmény, egyezmény a nemzetközi jelentőségű vizes területekről, különösen mint a vízi-madarak élőhelyéről
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.name: Ramsar Convention
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.objecttrans_hu: Ramsari Egyezmény, Egyezmény a nemzetközi jelentőségű vizes területekről, különösen mint a vízi-madarak élőhelyéről
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Ram.definition: The Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, signed in Ramsar, Iran, in 1971, is an intergovernmental treaty which provides the framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and wise use of wetlands and their resources. [definition source: Ramsar Convention web site.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WWF.definition: Synonyms: World Wildlife Fund for Nature [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WWF.name: WWF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IMO.definition: Synonyms: International Maritime Organisation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IMO.name: IMO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.definition: According to Aarhus Convention the state of the environment report represents comprehensive publication (in printed or electronic forms), which provides information about the state of elements of the environment, such as air and atmosphere, water, soil, land, landscape and natural sites, biological diversity and its components, including genetically modified organisms, and the interaction among these elements; about the factors, such as substances, energy, noise and radiation, and activities or measures, including administrative measures, environmental agreements, policies, legislation, plans and programmes, affecting or likely to affect the elements of the environment, and cost-benefit and other economic analyses and assumptions used in environmental decision-making and the information about the state of human health and safety, conditions of human life, cultural sites and built structures, in as much as they are or may be affected by the state of the elements of the environment or, through these elements, by the factors, activities or measures referred above. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.name: State of the environment report

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: Any substance or mixture of substances which through physiological action protects the plants against parasites, fungi, virus, or other damaging factors. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: plant-health products

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ETC/RWM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european topic centre on resource and waste management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Ser.definition: Synonyms: SEEA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Ser.name: Serbian Energy Efficiency Agency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: The quantity of oxygen used in biological and non-biological oxidation of materials in water; a measure of water quality. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical oxygen demand

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: wastewater charge
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Imposed fee, expense, or cost for the management of spent or used water that contains dissolved or suspended matter from a home, community farm, or industry. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCI.definition: Site of Community importance means a site which, in the biogeographical region or regions to which it belongs, contributes significantly to the maintenance or restoration at a favourable conservation status of a natural habitat type in Annex I or of a species in Annex II and may also contribute significantly to the coherence of Natura 2000 referred to in Article 3, and/or contributes significantly to the maintenance of biological diversity within the biogeographic region or regions concerned. For animal species ranging over wide areas, sites of Community importance shall correspond to the places within the natural range of such species which present the physical or biological factors essential to their life and reproduction. [definition source: Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora (art 1 k).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCI.name: SCI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biological wastewater treatment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Processes which employ aerobic or anaerobic microorganisms and result in decanted effluents and separated sludge containing microbial mass together with pollutants. Biological treatment processes are also used in combination and/or in conjunction with mechanical and advanced unit operations. Similar to secondary treatment. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: Action taken to reduce potential hazards. [definition source: EEA. 1991. Late lessons from early warnings: the precautionary principle 1896-2000.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: precautionary prevention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_enr.name: enrichment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_enr.definition: Addition of nitrogen, phosphorous and carbon compounds or other nutrients into a water body, thereby increasing the potential for growth of algae and other aquatic plants. Most frequently, enrichment results from the inflow of sewage effluents or from agricultural run-off. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A description of the aspects and impacts of a product, system or service over its entire life, from raw material extraction, through manufacturing and use, to end-of-life disposal or recycling. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental product declaration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_sl: jeklena ali betonska zaščita jedrskega reaktorja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: containment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_sl: jeklena ali betonska zaščita jedrskega reaktorja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: The reinforced steel or concrete vessel that encloses a nuclear reactor. It is designed to withstand minor explosions in the core, to keep radionuclides from escaping into the environment, and to be safe against terrorist attack. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arm.definition: Synonyms: AMD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arm.name: Armenian dram

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_sk: európske tematické centrum pre problematiku suchozemského ivotného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_sl: evropski tematski center za kopensko okolje
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_el: Ευρωπαϊκό Θεματικό Κέντρο για το χερσαίο περιβάλλον
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Topic Centre on Terrestrial Environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_lv: eiropas vides aģentūras tēmu centrs par sauszemes vidi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_es: Centro temático europeo sobre el medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_da: det europæiske temacenter for det terrestriske miljø (etc/te)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_da: Det Europæiske Temacenter for det terrestriske Miljø (ETC/TE)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_pt: centro temático europeu sobre ambiente terrestre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_es: centro temático europeo sobre el medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Terrestrial Environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_lv: Eiropas Vides aģentūras tēmu centrs par sauszemes vidi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_el: ευρωπαϊκό θεματικό κέντρο για το χερσαίο περιβάλλον
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_pt: Centro Temático Europeu sobre Ambiente Terrestre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european topic centre on terrestrial environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_cs: Evropské tématické středisko pro suchozemské prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_fr: centre thématique européen de l'environnement terrestre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_nl: europees thematisch centrum voor de terrestrisch omgeving
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_sk: Európske tematické centrum pre problematiku suchozemského ivotného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_sl: Evropski tematski center za kopensko okolje
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_ro: centrul european specializat asupra mediului terestru
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_fr: centre thématique européen de l'environnement terrestre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: It technically supports EEA in the implementation of the soil monitoring and assessment framework through the keeping and further developing of databases and information for indicator development and reporting on soil and land issues, including the terrestrial aspects of coastal environment. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. The soil protection communication (draft October 2001). Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_cs: evropské tématické středisko pro suchozemské prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_ro: Centrul European Specializat asupra mediului terestru
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_nl: Europees thematisch centrum voor de terrestrisch omgeving

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wil.objectname_lv: wtp, gatavība maksāt (par preci vai pakalpojumu)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wil.name: willingness to pay
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wil.objecttrans_lv: WTP, gatavība maksāt (par preci vai pakalpojumu)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wil.definition: The amount an individual is willing to pay to acquire some good or service. This may be elicited from stated or revealed preference approaches. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_on-.definition: The conservation of ecosystems and natural habitats and the maintenance and recovery of viable populations of species in their natural surroundings and, in the case of domesticated or cultivated species, in the surroundings where they have developed their distinctive properties. [definition source: Convention on Biological Diversity (art.2).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_on-.name: on-site conservation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_scr.definition: Synonyms: SIDS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_scr.name: screening information data set

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Geographic area with a high density of people over a limited area. Homes and other types of buildings tend to be close together. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.definition: The number of people relative to the space occupied by them. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.name: population density

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AWI.definition: Synonyms: The Alfred Wegener Institute [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AWI.name: AWI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.name: noise barrier
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: Barriers for reducing the propagation of sound: they are widely used in industry and alongside roads and railways to shield receivers from noise sources. Barriers can be made of various materials but they need proper planning in order to be effective. [definition source: Adapted from: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIS.definition: Synonyms: Goddard Institute for Space Studies [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIS.name: GISS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: USA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United States of America

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.objectname_lv: potenciālais kontakts, cilvēka kontakts ar piesārņotājiem 24 stundu uzturēšanās laikā ārpus telpām
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pot.name: potential exposure
