glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_fi: rakennetut alueet, teollisuusalueet ja muut keinotekoiset elinympäristöt
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_ro: habitate construite, industriale sau alte tipuri de habitate artificiale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_fr: habitats construits, habitats industriels et autres habitats artificiels
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_bg: изградени, промишлени и други изкуствени хабитати
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. They are primarily human settlements, buildings, industrial developments, the transport network, waste dump sites. Includes highly artificial saline and non-saline waters with wholly constructed beds or heavily contaminated water (such as industrial lagoons and saltworks) which are virtually devoid of plant and animal life. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_cs: uměle vybudované, průmyslové a obdobné biotopy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_ro: habitate construite, industriale sau alte tipuri de habitate artificiale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_nl: bebouwde, industriële en andere niet-natuurlijke habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_no: bebygd og opparbeidet areal og andre kunstige habitater

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: An animal that eats meat. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carnivore

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.definition: Synonyms: CAFE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.name: Clean Air for Europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objectname_hu: hangafüves terület, harasztos, fenyér, hangás, sztyeppe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.name: heathland
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.objecttrans_hu: hangafüves terület, harasztos, fenyér, hangás, sztyeppe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hea.definition: A community dominated by dwarf shrubs most typically belonging to the family Ericaceae. [definition source: Allaby 1994. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: Compulsory tax levied on fuels in accordance with their carbon content, with the aim to encourage using less carbon-intensive fuels and to reduce energy consumption. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon tax

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nim.definition: Synonyms: SMMR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nim.name: Nimbus-7 Scanning Multichannel Microwave Radiometer

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_End.definition: Directive 2000/53/EC on end-of life vehicles lays down measures which aim, as a first priority, at the prevention of waste from vehicles and, in addition, at the reuse, recycling and other forms of recovery of end-of life vehicles and their components so as to reduce the disposal of waste, as well as at the improvement in the environmental performance of all of the economic operators involved in the life cycle of vehicles and especially the operators directly involved in the treatment of end-of life vehicles. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_End.name: End-of-life vehicle directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NP.definition: Areas of outstanding natural beauty, set aside for the conservation of flora, fauna and scenery, and for recreation, if this does not conflict with the conservation objectives of the parks and their landscapes. Hunting, logging, mining, commercial fishing, agriculture and livestock grazing are all controlled within national parks, as is industrial activity. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NP.name: NP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dre.name: dredging
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dre.definition: Removal of mud from the bottom of water bodies for deepening through the use of special mechanical devices. Dredging disturbs the ecosystem and can kill aquatic life. Dredging of contaminated muds can expose aquatic life to heavy metals and other toxic materials. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.definition: Synonyms: BDE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.name: bromo diphenyl ether

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_goo.definition: The standard of farming which a reasonable farmer would follow in the region concerned. Usual good farming practices are compatible with the need to safeguard the environment and maintain the countryside, in particular by sustainable farming. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_goo.name: good farming practice

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rai.definition: A permanent track composed of a line of parallel metal rails fixed to sleepers, for transport of passengers and goods in trains. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rai.name: railway line

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NO.definition: Gas formed by combustion under high pressure and high temperature in an internal combustion engine. It changes into nitrogen dioxide in the ambient air and contributes to photochemical smog. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NO.name: NO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: Steps required to prevent the erosion of the coast. The stabilisation of beaches or dunes is achieved by mechanical or vegetational means, or through erecting heavy sea walls or revetments. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NM.definition: A natural/cultural feature which is of outstanding or unique value because of its inherent rarity, representative of aesthetic qualities or cultural significance. Guidance for selection of a natural monument is: a) The area should contain one or more features of outstanding significance (appropriate natural features include spectacular waterfalls, caves, craters, fossil beds, sand dunes and marine features, along with unique or representative fauna and flora; associated cultural features might include cave dwellings, cliff-top forts, archaeological sites, or natural sites which have heritage significance to indigenous peoples).; b) The area should be large enough to protect the integrity of the feature and its immediately related surroundings. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NM.name: NM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewer
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.objectname_bg: канал за отпадъчни и дъждовни води
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.objecttrans_bg: канал за отпадъчни и дъждовни води
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: Channel or conduit that carries wastewater, sewage and storm water from their source to a treatment plant or receiving stream. A sanitary sewer conveys household and commercial wastes, a storm sewer transports rain run-off and a combined sewer is used for both purposes. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NC.definition: Synonyms: national communication [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NC.name: NC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.definition: The amount of oxygen used for biochemical oxidation by a unit volume of water at a given temperature and for a given time. BOD is an index of the degree of organic pollution in water. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BOD.name: BOD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SDT.definition: Synonyms: sustainable development of Tourism [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SDT.name: SDT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inj.definition: A stress upon an organism that disrupts the structure or function and results in a pathological process. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inj.name: injury

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCP.definition: Synonyms: sustainable consumption and production [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCP.name: SCP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WMO.definition: Synonyms: World Meteorological Organization [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WMO.name: WMO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENE.definition: Synonyms: European network of environmental authorities [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENE.name: ENEA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A management tool comprising a systematic, documented, periodic and objective evaluation of how well a project, organisation or equipment is performing with the aim of helping to safeguard the environment. The audit should facilitate management control of environmental practices and assess compliance with policy objectives and regulatory requirements. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environmental concerns into development and economic cooperation. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-audit

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BDE.definition: Synonyms: bromo diphenyl ether [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BDE.name: BDE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: Agricultural chemical used in crop and food production including pesticide, feed additive, veterinary drug and related compounds. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agricultural chemical

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Synonyms: PCA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: priority conservation area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.definition: Irrigation using a tape or pipe with small holes that releases water near the roots of plants and eliminates runoff. [definition source: Agricultural experiment atation, Kansas State University. A glossary of agriculture, environment, and sustainable development. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.name: drip irrigation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.name: overgrazing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.objectname_bg: злоупотреба при ползването на пасищата, прекомерна експлоатация на пасища
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.objecttrans_bg: злоупотреба при ползването на пасищата, прекомерна експлоатация на пасища
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.definition: Intensive grazing by livestock that exceeds the environmental carrying capacity of a given piece of land. It can lead to impoverishment of the sward, dominance of certain unpalatable species, soil erosion and even a (complete) loss of vegetation. [definition source: EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ex_.definition: Ex ante evaluation refers to forward-looking assessment of the likely future effects of new policies of proposals. [definition source: EEA. 2001. Why is it important to assess effects and effectiveness? Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ex_.name: ex ante evaluation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: (1) Plant where, through physical-chemical and biological processes, organic matter, bacteria, viruses and solids are removed from residential, commercial and industrial wastewaters before they are discharged in rivers, lakes and seas. (2) Installations to render wastewater, sludge, storm water or cooling water fit to meet applicable environmental standards or other quality norms for recycling or reuse. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000). 2) Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage treatment plant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Companies providing goods and services for environmental protection. The term includes the provision of clean technologies, renewable energy, waste recycling, nature and landscape protection, and ecological renovation of urban areas. [definition source: Adapted from:]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-industry

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_met.definition: In some poisonings, haemoglobin (the substance in the red blood cells to which the oxygen is fixed) may be transformed to methaemoglobin. Methaemoglobin lacks the ability of binding the oxygen; consequently lack of oxygen occurs in the organism. When a certain amount of haemoglobin has been transformed to methaemoglobin, mucous membranes and skin become bluish and discoloured. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_met.name: methaemoglobinaemia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mix.name: mixed woodland
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mix.definition: Wooded land on which neither coniferous, nor broadleaved species account for more than 75 % of the crown cover. [definition source: EUNIS (based on FAO definition). EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: A commodity agreement by 32 producing countries and 32 consuming countries for tropical timber, renewed in 1994, and with a Secretariat in Japan. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Tropical Timber Agreement

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_can.definition: The ability or tendency of a substance or physical agent to cause or produce cancer. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_can.name: cancerogenicity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: precautionary principle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objectname_bg: принцип на вземане на предпазни мерки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objecttrans_bg: принцип на вземане на предпазни мерки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: (1) Principle adopted by the UN Conference on thr Environment and Development (1992) that in order to protect the environment, a precautionary approach should be widely applied, meaning that where there are threats of serious or irreversible damage to the environment, lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing cost-effective measures to prevent environmental degradation. (2) The precautionary principle permits a lower level of proof of harm to be used in policy-making whenever the consequences of waiting for higher levels of proof may be very costly and/or irreversible. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000); 2) EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 278. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyp.definition: Water with a low concentration of oxygen. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyp.name: hypoxic water

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_sk: map (akčný plán na ochranu prostredia v stredozemskej oblasti)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_es: Plan de acción en el Mediterráneo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_pl: plan działań na rzecz ochrony obszaru śródziemnomorskiego
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_pt: plano de acção para o mediterrâneo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_es: plan de acción en el mediterráneo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.name: Mediterranean action plan
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_pl: Plan działań na rzecz ochrony obszaru śródziemnomorskiego
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_pt: Plano de Acção para o Mediterrâneo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_cs: MAP (Akční plán činnosti na ochranu Středozemní oblasti)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_sk: MAP (Akčný plán na ochranu prostredia v Stredozemskej oblasti)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_ro: plan de acţiune pentru marea mediterană
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.definition: The Mediterranean action plan (MAP) strives to protect the environment and to foster sustainable development in the Mediterranean basin. It was adopted in Barcelona, Spain, in 1975 by 16 Mediterranean States and the EC, under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP). Its legal framework comprises the Barcelona Convention adopted in 1976 and revised in 1995, and six protocols covering specific aspects of environmental protection. A Mediterranean Commission for Sustainable Development was also established by MAP in 1995 to facilitate the participation of all stakeholders in the Mediterranean area. [definition source: Adapted from: UNEP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objectname_cs: map (akční plán činnosti na ochranu středozemní oblasti)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Med.objecttrans_ro: Plan de Acţiune pentru Marea Mediterană

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: The part of the shoreline that is submerged at high tide and exposed at low tide. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: intertidal zone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wor.definition: Synonyms: WG [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wor.name: working group

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: The number of exposure intervals in an exposure duration. [definition source: The international programme on chemical safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure frequency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: ICCAT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: international commission for the conservation of atlantic tunas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.objectname_hu: {chehea} diszpergálás (az anyag fejleges felületének aprításával történő növelése, és a keletkezett nagy fajlagos felületű részecskék szétszórása valamely közegben.); {aircha} diszperzió (olyan anyagrendszer, amelyben az egymástól független részecskék folytonos közegben vannak elosztva.)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: dispersion
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.objecttrans_hu: {CHEHEA} diszpergálás (Az anyag fejleges felületének aprításával történő növelése, és a keletkezett nagy fajlagos felületű részecskék szétszórása valamely közegben.); {AIRCHA} diszperzió (Olyan anyagrendszer, amelyben az egymástól független részecskék folytonos közegben vannak elosztva.)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.objectname_bg: дисперсия, разпространяване на вредни вещества, разпръскване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.objecttrans_bg: дисперсия, разпространяване на вредни вещества, разпръскване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: A distribution of finely divided particles in a medium. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.definition: Synonyms: KEO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.name: Carpathians Environment Outlook

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ate.definition: some test element [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ate.name: atest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: A natural fuel containing methane and hydrocarbons that occurs in certain geologic formations. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: natural gas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dif.definition: Diffuse pollution sources (i.e. without a single point of origin or not introduced into a receiving stream from a specific outlet). Common non-point sources are agriculture, forestry, urban, mining, construction, dams, channels, land disposal, saltwater intrusion and city streets. [definition source: Adapted fom: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dif.name: diffuse source

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Water destined for private and public use in a town. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban water

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lea.definition: A heavy toxic bluish-white metallic element that is highly malleable; occurs principally as galena and is used in alloys, accumulators, cable sheaths, paints, and as a radiation shield. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lea.name: lead

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_m.definition: Synonyms: metre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_m.name: m

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.definition: Corinair is a programme to establish an inventory of emissions of air pollutants in Europe. It was initiated by the European Environment Agency Task Force and was part of the Corine (Coordination of information on the environment) work programme set up by the European Council of Ministers in 1985. In 1995 the Agency's European Topic Centre on Air Emissions (ETC/AEM) was contracted to continue the Corinair programme. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Recommendations for revised data systems for air emission inventories. Topic report No 12/1996. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cor.name: Corinair

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dra.definition: The area of land that drains water, sediment and dissolved materials to a common outlet at some point along a stream channel. [definition source: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dra.name: drainage area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: Combined cycles use both gas and steam turbine cycles in a single plant to produce electricity with high conversion efficiencies and low emissions. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: combined cycle gas turbine

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.name: dematerialisation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objectname_bg: абсолютно или относително намаляване на дела на ползване на природата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.objecttrans_bg: абсолютно или относително намаляване на дела на ползване на природата
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.definition: Absolute or relative reduction in 'use of nature' (materials + energy + pollution) per unit of output. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Making sustainability accountable: Eco-efficiency, resource productivity and innovation. Topic report No 11/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: Soil erosion consists in the removal of soil material by water or wind. It is a natural phenomenon but it can be accelerated by human activities. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil erosion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.definition: Council Directive 96/82/EEC on the control of major-accident hazards involving dangerous substances. This directive is aimed at the prevention of major accidents which involve dangerous substances, and the limitation of their consequences for man and the environment, with a view to ensuring high levels of protection throughout the Community in a consistent and effective manner. [definition source: Council Directive 96/82/EEC (art. 1)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.name: Seveso II Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objectname_hu: {eio} információ rendelkezésre bocsájtása, információval való megtöltés
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objectname_de: 1) informationen eingeben in, inhalte eingeben in 2) daten eingeben in, mit daten versorgen, mit informationen versorgen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objecttrans_de: 1) Informationen eingeben in, Inhalte eingeben in 2) Daten eingeben in, mit Daten versorgen, mit Informationen versorgen
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.name: populate
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objecttrans_hu: {EIO} információ rendelkezésre bocsájtása, információval való megtöltés

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ERU.definition: Synonyms: emission reduction units [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ERU.name: ERUs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental convention
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: конвенция за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: Конвенция за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Multilateral environmental agreement. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.objectname_lv: pārejas zonu ūdeņi (starp saldūdeni un jūras ūdeni)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.objecttrans_is: vatn sem er mitt á milli þess að teljast ferskvatn eða sjór
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.objectname_is: vatn sem er mitt á milli þess að teljast ferskvatn eða sjór
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: transitional waters
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.objecttrans_lv: pārejas zonu ūdeņi (starp saldūdeni un jūras ūdeni)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: Bodies of surface water in the vicinity of river mouths which are partly saline in character as a result of their proximity to coastal waters but which are substantially influenced by freshwater flows. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPS.definition: The Global Positioning System, usually called GPS (the US military refers to it as NAVSTAR), is an intermediate circular orbit (ICO) satellite navigation system used for determining one's precise location and providing a highly accurate time reference almost anywhere on Earth or in Earth orbit. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPS.name: GPS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPP.definition: Synonyms: green public procurement [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPP.name: GPP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.definition: The part of the shoreline that is submerged at high tide and exposed at low tide. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.name: tidal area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM.definition: A collective name for fine solid or liquid particles added to the atmosphere by processes at the earth's surface. Particulate matter includes dust, smoke, soot, pollen and soil particles. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM.name: PM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: conurbation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objectname_bg: сливане, срастване на малки градчета, населени места
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.objecttrans_bg: сливане, срастване на малки градчета, населени места
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: A large area occupied by urban development, which may contain isolated rural areas, and formed by the merging together of expanding towns that formerly were separate. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hel.definition: The Helsinki Commission (HELCOM) administers the Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment of the Baltic Sea Area, 1992 (entered into force on 17 January 2000), also called Helsinki Convention. [definition source: HELCOM website (]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hel.name: Helsinki Commission

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EFT.definition: Synonyms: Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EFT.name: EFTA-4

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPR.definition: Synonyms: European Pollutants Release and Transfer Register [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPR.name: EPRTR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCF.definition: Synonyms: hydrochlorofluorocarbons [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCF.name: HCFCs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UN.definition: Synonyms: United Nations [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UN.name: UN

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Synonyms: PPM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: primary particle matter

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: A collective name for fine solid or liquid particles added to the atmosphere by processes at the earth's surface. Particulate matter includes dust, smoke, soot, pollen and soil particles. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: suspended particulate matter

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPA.definition: Synonyms: global programme of action [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GPA.name: GPA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pea.name: peat bog
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pea.definition: Acidic peat environment typical of wetlands. Peat bogs are colonised by characteristic low vegetation including moss, rushes and heather. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: The number of 'parts' by weight of a substance per billion parts of water. Used to measure extremely small concentrations. [definition source: US Geological Survey. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: parts per billion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: The combination of natural processes by which soils are formed. It is also known as pedogenesis. The most important soil-forming factors are parent material, terrain, climate, aspect, vegetation cover, microorganisms in the soil and the age of the land surface. Some pedologists would add to this list the influence of human activities. All the factors exhibit varying degrees of interrelationship and some are more important than others, with climate often being singled out as the most important. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil formation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: The process by which account is taken of the environmental dimensions of development interventions in each phase of the project cycle. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental appraisal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cet.definition: An aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea, including whales, porpoises and dolphins. [definition source: American Cetacean Society. Glossary of terms related to cetaceans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cet.name: cetacean

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-efficiency
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A concept and strategy enabling sufficient delinking of the 'use of nature' from economic activity needed to meet human needs (welfare) to allow it to remain within carrying capacities; and to permit equitable access and use of the environment by current and future generations. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Making sustainability accountable: Eco-efficiency, resource productivity and innovation. Topic report No 11/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.definition: Synonyms: TACIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.name: EU assistance programme Technical Assistance to the Commonwealth of Independent States
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.objecttrans_en: EU assistance programme Technical Assistance to the Commonwealth of Independent States
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.objectname_en: eu assistance programme technical assistance to the commonwealth of independent states

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wee.name: weed
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wee.definition: Simply any plant growing where it is not wanted. In agriculture, used for a plant which has good colonising capability in a disturbed environment, and can usually compete with a cultivated species therein. Weeds are typically considered as unwanted, economically useless or pest species. [definition source: FAO. Glossary of biotechnology and genetic engineering.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pb.definition: A heavy toxic bluish-white metallic element that is highly malleable; occurs principally as galena and is used in alloys, accumulators, cable sheaths, paints, and as a radiation shield. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pb.name: Pb

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UV_.definition: Radiation in the wavelength range between visible light and X-rays, divided into wavelength bands A, B, C. Much of the ultraviolet radiations in bands B and C are prevented from reaching the earth's surface by the ozone layer present in the atmosphere. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UV_.name: UV radiation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objectname_lv: ozona prekursors, ķīmisks savienojums, kura reakcijas rezultātā veidojas ozons
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone precursor
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objecttrans_lv: ozona prekursors, ķīmisks savienojums, kura reakcijas rezultātā veidojas ozons
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: Chemical compounds, such as carbon monoxide (CO), methane (CH4), NMVOCs and nitrogen oxide (NOx), which in the presence of solar radiation react with other chemical compounds to form ozone, mainly in the troposphere. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Tax with a potentially positive environmental impact, hence comprising energy taxes, transport taxes and taxes on pollution and resources. Also called environmental tax. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness. Environmental issues series No 1]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental tax

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNH.definition: Synonyms: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNH.name: UNHCR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: The international nuclear event scale (INES) is a tool to promptly and consistently communicate to the public the safety significance of reported events at nuclear installations. It was designed by an international group of experts convened jointly by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Events are classified on the Scale at seven levels. [definition source: The International Atomic Energy Agency.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: international nuclear event scale

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: Process to render sludge fit to meet applicable environmental standards, land-use regulations or other quality norms for recycling or reuse. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on inland waters]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage sludge treatment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EoI.definition: Synonyms: exchange of information decision [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EoI.name: EoI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: Organisms, mostly plants, which are most sensitive to slight changes in environmental factors. When identified their reaction can serve as an early warning of the endangerment of the health of a community. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: pollution indicator

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: Synonyms: CMS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on Migratory Species

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IFOAM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: international federation of organic agriculture movements

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.name: mutagenicity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.objectname_bg: мутагенност, способност да породи генетични мутации
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.objecttrans_bg: мутагенност, способност да породи генетични мутации
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.definition: The property of chemical or physical agents of inducing changes in genetic material that are transmitted during cell division. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPI.definition: Developed by the Major Accident Hazards Bureau of the Joint Research Centre, the 'Seveso plants information retrieval system' (SPIRS) allows easy visualisation of important hazard and risk related information from such plants and estimation of their hazard and risk potential. The main objective of SPIRS is to support the Member States in their risk management related decision making processes by giving an insight into the geographical component of risk from Seveso plants. This is done by providing a map of all Seveso plants in the EU as well as a flexible tool to rank the hazard/risk potential of such plants. [definition source: Adapted from: European Agency for Safety and Health at Work.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPI.name: SPIRS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.definition: Synonyms: LIFE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.name: EU financial instrument for the environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.objecttrans_en: EU financial instrument for the environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.objectname_en: eu financial instrument for the environment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOV.definition: Synonyms: Mapping of Soil and Terrain Vulnerability in Central and Eastern Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOV.name: SOVEUR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fac.definition: Factor 10 refers to a number of countries that met for the first time in 1992 in Carnoules (France) because of mounting concerns over the unchartered role of human-induced global material flows, and the ecological ramifications of their unchecked growth, with the aim to draw attention to the need for substantially reducing global material flows in a timely manner. [definition source: Adapted from: The Factor 10 Institute.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fac.name: factor 10

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.objectname_hu: {natbio} táplálkozási körforgás (a táplálkozási lánc nemcsak vertikális, hanem horizontális kiterjedésben is), talaj-növény-állat-ember tápláléklánc; {marenv} táplálkozási háló (a táplálkozási lánc nem csak vertikális, de horizontális kiterjedésben is), talaj-növény-állat-ember tápláléklánc
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.name: food web
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.objecttrans_hu: {NATBIO} táplálkozási körforgás (a táplálkozási lánc nemcsak vertikális, hanem horizontális kiterjedésben is), talaj-növény-állat-ember tápláléklánc; {MARENV} táplálkozási háló (a táplálkozási lánc nem csak vertikális, de horizontális kiterjedésben is), talaj-növény-állat-ember tápláléklánc
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.definition: The network of feeding relationships within an ecosystem or a community i.e. the predator-prey relationships. [definition source: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.objectname_lv: nta, jaunā transatlantiskā programma (sadarbībai starp eiropas un asv vides aģentūrām)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.name: New Transatlantic Agenda
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.objecttrans_lv: NTA, Jaunā transatlantiskā programma (sadarbībai starp Eiropas un ASV vides aģentūrām)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_New.definition: A cooperation effort of the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The New Transatlantic Agenda (NTA) between the EU and the US was signed in Madrid, Spain, in December 3, 1995. NTA's principal goal is to improve the effectiveness of EU-US partnership. Specifically, the NTA intends to improve the effectiveness of multilateral efforts to protect the environment by strengthening the exchange of information and reporting on global environmental issues such as climate change, biodiversity, ozone layer depletion, persistent organic pollutants, desertification and erosion, water quality and quantity, land-based sources of marine pollution, hazardous wastes and contaminated soils, forest issues and trade and the environment. [definition source: EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eme.definition: Synonyms: EM-DAT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eme.name: Emergency Disasters Data Base

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objecttrans_is: hvatningarskattar, hvataskattar, skattaálögur sem hvetja eða letja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objectname_is: hvatningarskattar, hvataskattar, skattaálögur sem hvetja eða letja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: incentive tax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objecttrans_cs: daň působící jako stimul, stimulační daň
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: Tax designated to change the behaviour of producers and/or consumers. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness. Environmental issues series No 1]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objectname_cs: daň působící jako stimul, stimulační daň

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cad.definition: Synonyms: Cd [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cad.name: cadmium

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: Luting, making watertight, waterproofing. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: sealing

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.name: forest
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.definition: Land with a tree canopy cover of more than 10 % and an area of more than 0.5 ha. [definition source: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.definition: Something that takes place or comes to pass. Occurrence and happening are the most general: an everyday occurrence; a happening of no great importance.Event usually signifies a notable occurrence: major world events reported on the evening news. 'Great events make me quiet and calm; it is only trifles that irritate my nerves' Victoria.Incident may apply to a minor occurrence: a small incident blown out of proportion.The term may also refer to a distinct event of sharp identity and significance: a succession of exciting incidents.An episode is an incident in the course of a progression or within a larger sequence: 'Happiness was but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain' Thomas Hardy.Circumstance denotes a particular incident or occurrence: 'Billy had found Alice, thus bringing about the odd circumstance of their renewing their acquaintanceship' Eleanor H. Porter. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.name: occurrence

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICL.definition: Synonyms: International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICL.name: ICLEI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: Convention adopted at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. The objectives of this convention are the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising out of the utilisation of genetic resources, including by appropriate access to genetic resources and by appropriate transfer of relevant technologies, taking into account all rights over those resources and to technologies, and by appropriate funding. [definition source: Convention on Biological Diversity (art.1).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on bBological Diversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_usu.definition: The standard of farming which a reasonable farmer would follow in the region concerned. Usual good farming practices are compatible with the need to safeguard the environment and maintain the countryside, in particular by sustainable farming. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_usu.name: usual good farming practice

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.definition: Biological, chemical or physical processes which result in the loss of the productive potential of natural resources in areas covered by forests and/or used by agriculture. Degradation may be permanent, although some forest areas may recover naturally or with human assistance. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.name: forest degradation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TAC.definition: The quantity of fish that can be taken from each stock each year. In the European Union, the figure is agreed by the Fisheries Council of Ministers each December for the following year. EU Member States are allocated a fixed proportion of the total allowable catch as their national quota. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TAC.name: TAC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewerage network
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: System of collectors, pipelines, conduits and pumps to conduct wastewater from the point of generation to the place of disposal or treatment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.definition: Quality of life is largely a matter of individual preference and perception and overlaps the concept of social wellbeing. Generally the emphasis is on the amount and distribution of public goods, such as health care and well-fare services, protection against crime, regulation of pollution, preservation of fine landscapes and historic townscapes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.name: quality of life

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.definition: Integration of evidence, reasoning, and conclusions collected in hazard identification, dose-response assessment, and exposure assessment and the estimation of the probability, including attendant uncertainties, of occurrence of an adverse effect if an agent is administered, taken, or absorbed by a particular organism or population. It is the last step of risk assessment. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.name: risk characterisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.objectname_lv: kvantitatīvais statuss, gruntsūdeņu nošķirtības pakāpes rādītājs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.name: quantitative status
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.objecttrans_lv: kvantitatīvais statuss, gruntsūdeņu nošķirtības pakāpes rādītājs
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.definition: An expression of the degree to which a body of groundwater is affected by direct and indirect abstractions. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Integration can be seen as a concept, a strategy and a process designed to achieve the more sustainable development of economic activities - one of the main conclusions of the Cardiff European Council, June 1998. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integration of environmental concerns into sectoral policies
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_en: integration of environmental concerns into sectoral policies
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_en: integration of environmental concerns into sectoral policies

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WB.definition: Synonyms: World Bank [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WB.name: WB

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: A sharp seasonal decrease in stratospheric ozone concentration that occurs over Antarctica in the spring. First detected in the late 1970s, the ozone hole continues to appear as a result of complex chemical reaction in the atmosphere that involves CFCs. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone hole

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Had.definition: Synonyms: Hadley Centre SST data set [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Had.name: HadSST2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tre.definition: Waste treatment capacity for a waste recovery and disposal should be calculated as the total amount of waste allowed to be treated under facility permit/licence. Treatment capacity should be calculated for every disposal operation D1 - D11 and recovery operation R1 - R10 according to Annex II to Directive 75/442/EEC as amended by Commission Decision 96/350/EC. Total treatment capacity of waste facilities should be calculated as sum of capacities of waste disposal and waste recovery facilities. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tre.name: treatment capacity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.definition: Synonyms: SOER-RF [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.name: State of the Environment Report - Russian Federation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_en: State of the Environment Report - Russian Federation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_en: state of the environment report - russian federation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ion.definition: The emission of alpha or beta particles or gamma rays from radioisotopes. These emitted particles can dislodge one or more electrons from atoms they strike. The free electrons can form charged ions in living tissue that can react with and damage cells. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ion.name: ionising radiation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The system of pipes supplying water to communities and industries. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water distribution system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IPIECA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Petroleum Industry Environmental Conservation Association
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: International Petroleum Industry Environmental Conservation Association
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: international petroleum industry environmental conservation association

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EU [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Union

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.definition: An energy produced by tapping the earth's internal heat.At present, the only available technologies to do this are those that extract heat from hydrothermal convection systems, where water or steam transfer the heat from the deeper part of the earth to the areas where the energy can be tapped. The amount of pollutants found in geothermal vary from area to area but may contain arsenic, boron, selenium, lead, cadmium, and fluorides. They also may contain hydrogen sulphide, mercury, ammonia, radon, carbon dioxide, and methane. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.name: geothermal energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hec.definition: Synonyms: ha [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hec.name: hectare

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ITO.definition: Synonyms: International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ITO.name: ITOPF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sou.definition: Physical quantity of sound measured, usually expressed in decibels. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sou.name: sound level

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AQD.definition: Synonyms: Air Quality Daughter Directives [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_AQD.name: AQDD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.definition: The concept that market does not reflect the full societal costs of all economic activity and, in particular, the economic costs imposed on third parties. [definition source: Based on: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.name: market failure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.definition: Chemical elements which are involved in the construction of living tissue and which are needed by both plant and animal. The most important in terms of bulk are carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, with other essential ones including nitrogen, potassium, calcium, sulphur and phosphorus. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nut.name: nutrient

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.definition: Synonyms: ISS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cen.name: Central Public Health Institute, Italy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: A forest largely undisturbed by human activities. [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: natural forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SMM.definition: Synonyms: Nimbus-7 Scanning Multichannel Microwave Radiometer [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SMM.name: SMMR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water framework directive
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_fr: directive cadre dans le domaine de l'eau
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_ro: directiva cu privire la politicile hidrologice
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_fr: directive cadre dans le domaine de l'eau
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Directive 2000/60/EC establishing a framework for the Community action in the field of water policy. It aims to secure the ecological, quantitative and qualitative functions of water. It requires that all impacts on water will have to be analysed and actions will have to be taken within river basin management plans. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. The soil protection communication (draft October 2001). Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_ro: directiva cu privire la politicile hidrologice

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACS.definition: Synonyms: automatic control stations [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACS.name: ACS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEB.definition: Synonyms: Streamlining European Biodiversity Indicators [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEB.name: SEBI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_el: επιβάρυνση για την απόσβεση του κόστους
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_it: imposta per la copertura dei costi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_it: imposta per la copertura dei costi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.name: cost-covering charge
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_el: επιβάρυνση για την απόσβεση του κόστους
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objectname_nl: heffing ter dekking van de kosten
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.definition: A charge designed to cover costs of environmental services and abatements measures. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness. Environmental issues series No 1]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cos.objecttrans_nl: heffing ter dekking van de kosten

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental review
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: преглед по въпроси на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: преглед по въпроси на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: In Eco-management and Auditing Scheme, environmental review means an initial comprehensive analysis of the environmental issues, impact and performance related to a site. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: watershed
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The land area that drains into a stream; the watershed for a major river may encompass a number of smaller watersheds that ultimately combine at a common point. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: Compounds used as replacements for chloro-fluorocarbons (CFCs) in various applications because they are less active ozone depleters. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrochloro-fluorocarbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: CVD is the name for the group of disorders of the heart and blood vessels and include: - Hypertension (high blood pressure) - Coronary heart disease (heart attack) - Cerebrovascular disease (stroke) - Peripheral vascular disease - Heart failure - Rheumatic heart disease - Congenital heart disease - Cardiomyopathies [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: cardiovascular disease

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: Noise emission exhaust systems of motor vehiclesmeans a complete set of parts necessary to reduce the noise produced by the vehicle's engine exhaust. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.name: noise emission exhaust system of motor vehicles
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.objecttrans_en: noise emission exhaust system of motor vehicles
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.objectname_en: noise emission exhaust system of motor vehicles

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lar.definition: Synonyms: LMEs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lar.name: large marine ecosystems

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bag.name: bagged waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bag.definition: Mixed waste collected from households and other sources. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Environmental signals 2000. Environmental assessment report No 6. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECM.definition: Synonyms: European Conference of Ministers of Transport [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECM.name: ECMT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water demand management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_fr: gestion de la demande en eau
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_fr: gestion de la demande en eau
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water demand management refers to the implementation of policies or measures which serve to control or influence the amount of water used. [definition source: UKWIR/EA. 1996. Economics of demand management - Main report and practical guidelines. UK Water Industry Research Limited. London. Quoted by: EEA. 2001. Sustainable water use in Europe: Part 2. Copenhagen]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EEHC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Environment and Health Committee

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: A fixed proportion of the total allowable catch allocated to each fishing nation. This national quota allocation is further sub-divided into quotas for specific areas, seasons, fisheries or organisations, e.g. producers' organisations. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fishing quota

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cor.definition: A concept whereby companies voluntarily integrate social and environmental concerns in their business and the way they interact with stakeholders. This implies going over and above legal requirements, integrating economic, social and environmental concerns in their business, and adopting new approaches to business management. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cor.name: corporate social responsibility

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CLR.definition: Synonyms: Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CLR.name: CLRTAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_hu: {envins} környezetvédelmi kísérő jegyzet, mellékelt környezetvédelmi adatok
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_pl: konto oboczne rachunku ekonomicznego dla kosztów ochrony środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental satellite account
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_pl: konto oboczne rachunku ekonomicznego dla kosztów ochrony środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_hu: {ENVINS} környezetvédelmi kísérő jegyzet, mellékelt környezetvédelmi adatok
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: сателитни сметки' за състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: сателитни сметки' за състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: The satellite accounts provide physical and economic information of particular relevance for the integration of economic and environmental policies in a form consistent with the normal economic statistics in general and national accounts in particular. [definition source: European Commission. 1994. Environmental indicators and green accounting. COM(94) 670 final.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEE.definition: Waste electrical and electronic equipment or 'WEEE' means electrical or electronic equipment which is waste within the meaning of Article 1(a) of Directive 75/442/EEC, including all components, sub-assemblies and consumables, which are part of the product at the time of discarding .Council Directive 75/442/EEC of 15 July 1975 on waste: 'waste' means any substance or object which the holder disposes of or is required to dispose of pursuant to the provisions of national law in force. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WEE.name: WEEE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A dynamic complex of plant, animal and micro-organism communities and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit. [definition source: The Convention on Biological Diversity.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_JRC.definition: The JRC is a Directorate-General of the European Commission under the responsibility of Louis Michel, European Commissioner for Research. Its Board of Governors assists and advices the Director General on matters relating to the role and the scientific, technical and financial management of the JRC.The Directorate-General is located in Brussels. The seven JRC institutes are located on five separate sites in Belgium, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain. The Institutes are: Institute for Reference Materials and Measurements (IRMM), Institute for Transuranium Elements (ITU), Institute for Energy (IE), Institute for the Protection and the Security of the Citizen (IPSC), Institute for Environment and Sustainability (IES), Institute for Health and Consumer Protection (IHCP), Institute for Prospective Technological Studies (IPTS). In Brussels is the Institutional and Scientific relations Directorate and the Programme and Resource Management Directorate is based in Brussels and in Ispra, Italy. The Ispra Site Directorate is responsible for the site management and for the nuclear decommissioning, safety, security and protection. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_JRC.name: JRC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_raw.definition: Natural water that is untreated. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_raw.name: raw water

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dBA.definition: Decibels with the sound pressure scale adjusted to conform with the frequency response of the human ear. A sound level meter that measures A-weighted decibels has an electrical circuit that allows the meter to have the same sensitivity to sound at different frequencies as the average human ear. There are also B-weighted and C-weighted scales, but the A-weighted scale is the one most commonly used for measuring loud noise. [definition source: Australian Academy of Sciences. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dBA.name: dB(A)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICP.definition: The cooperative programme on assessment and monitoring of air pollution effects on forest (ICP forests) was launched in 1985 under the Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). [definition source: ICP forests web site.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICP.name: ICP forests

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_hu: {marenv} primer produkció, elsõdleges produkció, elsődleges szénmegkötés
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: primary production
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_hu: {MARENV} primer produkció, elsõdleges produkció, elsődleges szénmegkötés
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Fixation of inorganic carbon by organisms able to utilise inorganic sources of carbon as starting materials in the formation of organic compound by living organisms by the use of sunlight. [definition source: EEA. 1994. European rivers and lakes. EEA Environmental Monographs 1.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bed.objectname_hu: {soi} alapkõzet, ágykőzet, fekükőzet, felszíni réteg alatti kőzetek
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bed.name: bedrock
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bed.objecttrans_hu: {SOI} alapkõzet, ágykőzet, fekükőzet, felszíni réteg alatti kőzetek
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bed.definition: The solid rock beneath the soil and superficial rock. A general term for solid rock that lies beneath soil, loose sediments, or other unconsolidated material. [definition source: US Geological Survey. United States.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.definition: Dose per unit time. [definition source: The International programme on chemical safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.name: dose rate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GBP.definition: Synonyms: Great Britain pound [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GBP.name: GBP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.definition: Synonyms: ACIA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.name: Arctic Climate Impact Assessment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IUC.definition: Synonyms: International Union for Nature Conservation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LPG.definition: Synonyms: liquified petroleum gas [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LPG.name: LPG

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vul.name: vulnerability
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vul.definition: The degree to which a systems is susceptible to, and unable to cope with, injury damage or harm. [definition source: IPPC. Methodological and Technological issues in technology transfer.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sha.definition: Synonyms: SEIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sha.name: Shared Environmental Information System for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sha.objecttrans_en: Shared Environmental Information System for Europe
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sha.objectname_en: shared environmental information system for europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.definition: Electricity produced from renewable energy sources shall mean electricity produced by plants using only renewable energy sources, as well as the proportion of electricity produced from renewable energy sources in hybrid plants also using conventional energy sources and including renewable electricity used for filling storage systems, and excluding electricity produced as a result of storage systems. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.name: electricity produced from renewable energy sources
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.objecttrans_en: electricity produced from renewable energy sources
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.objectname_en: electricity produced from renewable energy sources

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_de: akteur, interessent, interessierte partei, interessierte kreise, betroffene partei, betroffener, beteiligter
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_de: Akteur, Interessent, interessierte Partei, interessierte Kreise, betroffene Partei, Betroffener, Beteiligter
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.name: stakeholder
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.definition: An institution, organisation, or group that has some interest in a particular sector or system. [definition source: WHO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fly.definition: Air-borne solid particles that result from the burning of coal and other solid fuel. [definition source: California Air Resources Board. Glossary of air pollution terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fly.name: fly ash

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.name: overfishing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.objectname_bg: злоупотреба с възможностите за риболов, екстензивен риболов
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.objecttrans_bg: злоупотреба с възможностите за риболов, екстензивен риболов
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ove.definition: Taking out of the sea more than natural population growth can sustain. Overfishing has a number of causes, the most ruthless being 'chronic over capacity' of modern fishing fleets to effectively take far more fish than can be replaced. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.definition: The violent shaking of the ground produced by deep seismic waves, beneath the epicentre, generated by a sudden decrease or release in a volume of rock of elastic strain accumulated over a long time in regions of seismic activity (tectonic earthquake). The magnitude of an earthquake is represented by the Richter scale; the intensity by the Mercalli scale. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.name: earthquake

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_san.name: sanitation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_san.definition: The application of measures and techniques aimed at ensuring and improving general hygiene in the community, including the collection, evacuation and disposal of liquid and solid wastes, as well as measures for creating favourable environmental conditions for health and disease prevention. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEI.definition: Synonyms: Shared Environmental Information System for Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEI.name: SEIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LOA.definition: Lowest concentration or amount of a substance, found by observation or experiment, which causes an adverse effect. [definition source: WHO. 1994. Assessing human health risks of chemicals: Derivation of guidance values for health-based exposure limits. Environmental health criteria 170. World Health Organization, Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LOA.name: LOAEL

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EBCC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Bird Census Council

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.objecttrans_it: sistema singolo dal monitoraggio alla relazione
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.objectname_it: sistema singolo dal monitoraggio alla relazione
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mon.name: monitoring-to-reporting system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.name: tonne

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.definition: Council Directive 98/83/EC of 3 November 1998 concerning the quality of water intended for human consumption. The Directive is intended to protect human health by laying down healthiness and purity requirements which must be met by drinking water within the Community. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.name: Council directive 98/83/EC concerning the quality of water intended for human consumption
