glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cou.objectname_en: council directive 98/83/ec concerning the quality of water intended for human consumption

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_equ.definition: Equilibrium or balance is any of a number of related phenomena in the natural and social sciences. In general, a system is said to be in a state of equilibrium if all influences on the system are cancelled by the effects of others. A related concept is stability; an equilibrium may or may not be stable. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_equ.name: equilibrium

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.objectname_tr: baltık ve kuzey denizlerindeki küçük deniz memelilerinin korunması anlaşması
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.definition: Agreement concluded in 1991, under the auspices of the Bonn Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (UNEP/CMS) to coordinate and implement conservation measures for dolphins, porpoises and other toothed whales in the Baltic and North Seas. Currently (year 2002) eight European countries - Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Sweden and the United Kingdom - are parties to the agreement. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.objecttrans_tr: Baltık ve Kuzey denizlerindeki küçük deniz memelilerinin korunması anlaşması
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.name: Agreement on the conservation of small cetaceans of the Baltic and North Seas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.objecttrans_en: Agreement on the conservation of small cetaceans of the Baltic and North Seas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Agr.objectname_en: agreement on the conservation of small cetaceans of the baltic and north seas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biota
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: All living organisms of an area; the flora and fauna considered as a unit. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001: Impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water reuse
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Treated wastewater can be indirectly reused when it is discharged into a watercourse, diluted and used again downstream. Direct reuse means the direct supply of treated effluent from the treatment plant to the user. It also can apply to the recharge of an aquifer. [definition source: EEA. 2001. Sustainable water use in Europe: Part 2. Copenhagen]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dob.definition: Measurement unit for determining the total amount of ozone present in a vertical column of air above the surface of the earth. The ozone in a layer of ozone at atmospheric pressure of 1013 hPa and temperature of 298 K which measures 1 mm in thickness and is equivalent to 100 Dobson units. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dob.name: Dobson unit

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Energy and environmental problems are closely related, since it is nearly impossible to produce, transport, or consume energy without significant environmental impact. The environmental problems directly related to energy production and consumption include air pollution, climate change, water pollution, thermal pollution, and solid waste disposal. The emission of air pollutants from fossil fuel combustion is the major cause of urban air pollution. Burning fossil fuels is also the main contributor to the emission of grenhouse gases. Diverse water pollution problems are associated with energy usage. One problem is oil spills. In all petroleum-handling operations, there is a finite probability of spilling oil either on the earth or in a body of water. Coal mining can also pollute water. Changes in groundwater flow produced by mining operations often bring otherwise unpolluted waters into contact with certain mineral materials which are leached from the soil and produce an acid mine drainage. Solid waste is also a by-product of some forms of energy usage. Coal mining requires the removal of large quantities of earth as well as coal. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental impact of energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.objectname_lv: piesārņotāja vai ķīmiskas vielas ceļš no avota līdz nonākšanai organismā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.objectname_hu: {chehea} szennyezőanyag terjedési útja; {aircha} szennyezőanyag terjedési útja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.name: pathway
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.objecttrans_hu: {CHEHEA} szennyezőanyag terjedési útja; {AIRCHA} szennyezőanyag terjedési útja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.objecttrans_lv: piesārņotāja vai ķīmiskas vielas ceļš no avota līdz nonākšanai organismā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.definition: The physical course a chemical or pollutant takes from its source to the exposed organism. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: Means the reduction of the quantity and of the harmfulness for the environment of:- materials and substances contained in packaging and packaging waste,- packaging and packaging waste at production process level and at the marketing, distribution, utilization and elimination stages, in particular by developing 'clean` products and technology. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: prevention of packaging waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tri.definition: A very toxic organic compound containing tin. It is used in antifouling paints on vessels and fixed marine structures. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tri.name: tributyltin

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IES.name: IES

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_is: gæði vatns sem tekið er frá uppsprettu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water removed from any sources, either permanently or temporarily. Mine water and drainage are included. Similar to water withdrawal. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_acc.definition: An unexpected occurrence, failure or loss with the potential for harming human life, property or the environment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_acc.name: accident

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECO.definition: Synonyms: Development of environmental health indicators for European Union countries [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECO.name: ECOEHIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon dioxide equivalent
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: A metric measure used to compare the emissions from various greenhouse gases based upon their global warming potential (GWP). Carbon dioxide equivalents are commonly expressed as 'million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents (MMTCDE)'. The carbon dioxide equivalent for a gas is derived by multiplying the tonnes of the gas by the associated GWP. MMTCDE = (million metric tonnes of a gas) * (GWP of the gas). For example, the GWP for methane is 21 and for nitrous oxide 310. This means that emissions of 1million metric tonnes of methane and nitrous oxide respectively is equivalent to emissions of 21 and 310 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide. [definition source: EEA, based on: IPCC Third Assessment Report, 2001]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urbanisation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Urbanisation is the increase in the proportion of people living in towns and cities. Urbanisation occurs because people move from rural areas (countryside) to urban areas (towns and cities). This usually occurs when a country is still developing. [definition source: Internet geography.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objectname_nl: habitats bestaande uit grasland en hoge ruigtekruiden
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objecttrans_sl: habitati, poračeni s travo in visokimi zelenimi rastlinami
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objecttrans_fi: ruohoalueet ja korkeita ruohokasveja kasvavat elinympäristöt
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objectname_ro: habitate de pajişti şi ierburi înalte
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. Non-coastal habitats which are dry or only seasonally wet (with the water table at or above ground level for less than half of the year) with greater than 30 % vegetation cover. The dominant vegetation is grasses and other non-woody vegetation (including moss-, lichen-, fern- and sedge-dominated communities). Includes successional weedy communities and managed grasslands such as recreation fields and lawns. Does not include regularly tilled habitats dominated by cultivated herbaceous vegetation such as arable fields. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objecttrans_ro: habitate de pajişti şi ierburi înalte
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gra.objecttrans_nl: habitats bestaande uit grasland en hoge ruigtekruiden

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dus.definition: Small solid particles, conventionally taken as those particles below 75 micrometers in diameter, which settle out under their own weight but which may remain suspended for some time. [definition source: International Standardization Organisation. 1994. ISO 4225.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dus.name: dust

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAC.definition: NACE is the acronym (from the French 'Nomenclature statistique des Activites economiques dans la Communaute Europeenne'-Statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community) used to designate various statistical classifications of economicactivities developed since 1970 by the European Union; it is designed to categorise datarelating to 'statistical units', in this case a unit of activity, for example an individual plant orgroup of plants constituting an economic entity such as an enterprise. It provides the basis forpreparing a large range of statistics (output, inputs to the production process, capital formationand financial transactions) of such units. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAC.name: NACE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EEB [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Environmental Bureau

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objectname_lv: ppm , daļas uz miljonu - mazu koncentrāciju rādītājs (masas vienībās)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objectname_lt: santykinis skaičius pagal svorį milijonui vandens dalelių
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.name: ppm
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objecttrans_lv: ppm , daļas uz miljonu - mazu koncentrāciju rādītājs (masas vienībās)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objecttrans_lt: santykinis skaičius pagal svorį milijonui vandens dalelių
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objecttrans_cs: ppm - jednotka pro měření množství polutantu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.definition: The number of 'parts' by weight of a substance per million parts of water. This unit is commonly used to represent pollutant concentrations. [definition source: US Geological Survey. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objectname_cs: ppm - jednotka pro měření množství polutantu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Principle established in the EC Framework Directive on waste. The principle of self-sufficiency requires that most waste should be treated or disposed of within the region in which it is produced. [definition source: Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (UK).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: principle of self-sufficiency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: The common fisheries policy (CFP) covers the exploitation of living aquatic resources and aquaculture, and the processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products. These activities take place on the territory of Member States or in Community fishing waters or are performed by fishing vessels flying a European flag. Community fishing waters means waters under the sovereignty or jurisdiction of Member States. The objective is to allow sustainable rational and responsible exploitation of living aquatic resources and aquaculture in economic and social conditions appropriate to the sector. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: common fisheries policy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: Energy and environmental problems are closely related, since it is nearly impossible to produce, transport, or consume energy without significant environmental impact. The environmental problems directly related to energy production and consumption include air pollution, climate change, water pollution, thermal pollution, and solid waste disposal. The emission of air pollutants from fossil fuel combustion is the major cause of urban air pollution. Burning fossil fuels is also the main contributor to the emission of grenhouse gases. Diverse water pollution problems are associated with energy usage. One problem is oil spills. In all petroleum-handling operations, there is a finite probability of spilling oil either on the earth or in a body of water. Coal mining can also pollute water. Changes in groundwater flow produced by mining operations often bring otherwise unpolluted waters into contact with certain mineral materials which are leached from the soil and produce an acid mine drainage. Solid waste is also a by-product of some forms of energy usage. Coal mining requires the removal of large quantities of earth as well as coal. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy environmental impact

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_The.definition: Synonyms: AWI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_The.name: The Alfred Wegener Institute

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: Gas naturally produced by animals during respiration and through decay of biomass, and used by plants during photosynthesis. Although it only constitutes 0.04 percent of the atmosphere, it is one of the most important greenhouse gases. The combustion of fossil fuels is increasing carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere, which is believed to be contributing to global warming. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon dioxide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mot.definition: Motorway means a road specially designed and built for motor traffic, which does not serve properties bordering on it, and which:(i) is provided, except at special points or temporarily, with separate carriageways for the two directions of traffic, separated from each other either by a dividing strip not intended for traffic or, exceptionally, by other means; (ii) does not cross at grade with any road, railway or tramway track, or footpath; (iii) is specifically designated as a motorway. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mot.name: motorway

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veh.name: vehicle-kilometre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veh.definition: Unit of measurement representing the movement of a vehicle over one kilometre. The distance to be considered is the distance actually run. It includes movements of empty vehicles. Units made up of a tractor and a semi-trailer or a lorry and a trailer are counted as one vehicle. [definition source: Eurostat, ECMT, UN/ECE. 1997. Glossary for Transport Statistics. Document prepared by the Intersecretariat Working Group on Transport Statistics. Second edition.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.definition: Synonyms: Regional Environmental Centre for Central Asia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.name: CAREC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_sl: organizmi, ki živijo na dnu reke, jezera, morja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_is: lífverur á eða við botn sjávar, stöðuvatns eða fljóts
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_is: lífverur á eða við botn sjávar, stöðuvatns eða fljóts
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.name: benthos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_fi: vesistön tai meren pohjassa elävät organismit, bentos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_sl: organizmi, ki živijo na dnu reke, jezera, morja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_fi: vesistön tai meren pohjassa elävät organismit, bentos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.definition: All plants (phytobenthos) and invertebrate animals that live in or on seabed habitats, including the intertidal zone. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bes.definition: Synonyms: BREF [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bes.name: Best Available Technology Reference Documents

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.definition: Synonyms: HBM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.name: human biomonitoring

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: A plastic that is used for many purposes. Various additives, such as plasticisers, lead and cadmium are added to polyvinyl chloride (PVC) to make it usable. Almost every stage of this PVC life-cycle can create pollution problems, for example, environmental contamination with mercury, chlorinated solvents and dioxins. In terms of health, PVC dust can damage the lungs of workers. [definition source: Adapted from: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: polyvinyl chloride

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.name: human settlements
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.definition: Integrative concept that comprises (a) physical components of shelter and infrastructure and (b) services to which the physical elements provide support, that is to say, community services such as education, health, culture, welfare, recreation and nutrition. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEO.definition: Synonyms: Global Earth Observation System of Systems [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEO.name: GEOSS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MS.definition: Synonyms: Member State [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MS.name: MS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Areas allocated to preserve and protect certain animals and plants, or both. They differ from national park, which are largely a place for public recreation, because they are provided exclusively to protect species for their own sake. Endangered species are increasingly being kept in nature reserves to prevent them from extinction, particularly in India, Indonesia and some African countries. Natural reserves were used once to preserve the animals that landowners hunted, but, in the 19th century, they became places where animals were kept to prevent them from dying out. Special refuges and sanctuaries are also often designated to protect certain species or groups of wild animals or plants, especially if their numbers and distribution have been significantly reduced. They also serve as a place for more plentiful species to rest, breed or winter. Many parts of the world also have marine and aquatic reserves to protect different species of sea or freshwater plant and animal life. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: natural reserve

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: The aim of Directive 91/157/EEC on batteries and accumulators containing certain dangerous substances is to approximate the laws of the Member States on the recovery and controlled disposal of those spent batteries and accumulators containing dangerous substances in accordance with Annex I. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directive 91/157/EEC on batteries and accumulators containing certain dangerous substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_en: Directive 91/157/EEC on batteries and accumulators containing certain dangerous substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objectname_en: directive 91/157/eec on batteries and accumulators containing certain dangerous substances

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.definition: Station to monitor background concentration levels of air polluting substances that are significant for a given region or for the globe as a whole. Regional stations are located far enough away from industry and urban areas in order not to pick up day-by-day fluctuations in pollution levels. The purpose is to measure long-term changes in the composition of the atmosphere. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bac.name: background station (air monitoring)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Integration can be seen as a concept, a strategy and a process designed to achieve the more sustainable development of economic activities - one of the main conclusions of the Cardiff European Council, June 1998. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: sectoral integration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPE.definition: Synonyms: Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPE.name: SPECA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Roy.definition: Synonyms: RCEP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Roy.name: Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Synonyms: EPA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental protection agency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DDT.definition: Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane: insecticide highly toxic to biota, including humans. This is a persistent biochemical which accumulates in the food chain. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DDT.name: DDT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HNV.definition: Synonyms: high nature value [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HNV.name: HNV

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological corridor
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A thin strip of vegetation used by wildlife and potentially allowing movement of biotic factors between two areas. [definition source: Conservation Management Institute. United States.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MA.definition: Synonyms: Millennium Ecosystem Assessment [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MA.name: MA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.definition: Synonyms: SCALE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.name: Science, Children, Awareness, EU Legislation and Continuous Evaluation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.objecttrans_en: Science, Children, Awareness, EU Legislation and Continuous Evaluation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.objectname_en: science, children, awareness, eu legislation and continuous evaluation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_est.definition: Area at the mouth of a river where it broadens into the sea, and where fresh and sea water intermingle to produce brackish water. The estuarine environment is very rich in wildlife, particularly aquatic, but it is very vulnerable to damage as a result of the actions of humans. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_est.name: estuary

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CH4.definition: Colourless gas given off by rotting materials. The main constituent of natural gas. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CH4.name: CH4

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NUT.definition: The nomenclature of territorial units for statistics (NUTS) was drawn up by Eurostat to be a single, cohesive system of territorial groupings for the compilation of EU regional statistics. The NUTS nomenclature subdivides the economic territory of the EU into 77 regions at NUTS level 1, 206 regions at NUTS level 2 and 1031 regions at NUTS level 3. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NUT.name: NUTS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nem.definition: A group of worms, some of which may cause intestinal and other diseases. [definition source: IMO/UNESCO/WMO/WHO/IAEA/UN/UNEP. Joint Group of Experts of the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nem.name: nematodes

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: extensive farming
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: Farming system often practised on larger farms, characterised by low levels of inputs per unit area of land; in such situations the stocking rate, the number of livestock units per area, is low. [definition source: Adapted from: ETC/CDS. General environmental multilingual thesaurus (GEMET 2000).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_el: Euroairnet (πανευρωπαϊκό δίκτυο για την ποιότητα του αέρα)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_lv: euroairnet, viseiropas gaisa kvalitātes monitoringa staciju tīkls
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_lt: euroairnet (europos oro kokybės stebėjimo ir kontrolės sistema)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_pl: euroairnet, ogólnoeuropejska sieć stacji monitorowania jakości powietrza
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_pt: euroairnet (rede europeia de monitorização da qualidade do ar)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Euroairnet

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_lv: Euroairnet, Viseiropas gaisa kvalitātes monitoringa staciju tīkls

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_el: euroairnet (πανευρωπαϊκό δίκτυο για την ποιότητα του αέρα)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_pt: Euroairnet (rede europeia de monitorização da qualidade do ar)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_cs: Euroairnet (Evropská síť pro monitorování kvality ovzduší)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_bg: евроеърнет: паневропейска мрежа от станции за наблюдение върху качеството на въздуха
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_bg: Евроеърнет: паневропейска мрежа от станции за наблюдение върху качеството на въздуха
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European air quality monitoring network. The main goal of Euroairnet is to establish a network with sufficient spatial coverage, representativeness and quality to provide the basic data as soon as possible, with a time delay not longer than six months, to fulfil the information requirement of the EEA. Euroairnet comprises a selection from already existing stations in the countries. Data from Euroairnet are reported to Airbase, the European air quality database. Euroairnet and Airbase are managed by the European Topic Centre on Air Quality and climate change under contract to the EEA. [definition source: NILU.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_cs: euroairnet (evropská síť pro monitorování kvality ovzduší)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EICTA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Information & Communications Technology Industry Association
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Information & Communications Technology Industry Association
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european information & communications technology industry association

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DMC.definition: Synonyms: domestic material consumption [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DMC.name: DMC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.definition: Sudden and permanent change in the structure of a gene or chromosome. May occur spontaneously or may be caused by the action of one or more mutagens. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mut.name: mutation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Synonyms: Wh [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: watt hour

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: The area of land from which all surface run-off flows through a sequence of streams, rivers and, possibly, lakes into the sea at a single river mouth, estuary or delta. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrographic basin

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DMI.definition: Synonyms: direct material input [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DMI.name: DMI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: Hazardous substance means substances or group of substances that are toxic, persistent and liable to bio-accumulate, and other substances or groups of substances which give rise to an equivalent level of concern. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazardous substance

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Synonyms: CPR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: continuous plankton recorder

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EBD.definition: Synonyms: Environmental Burden of Disease [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EBD.name: EBD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objectname_lt: bendras daugelio kalbų aplinkos apsaugos terminų tezauras
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objecttrans_es: Tesauro General Multilingüe sobre Medio ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objectname_es: tesauro general multilingüe sobre medio ambiente

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objecttrans_lt: bendras daugelio kalbų aplinkos apsaugos terminų tezauras
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objectname_bg: гемет - общоевропейски многоезичен тезаурус за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.objecttrans_bg: ГЕМЕТ - Общоевропейски многоезичен тезаурус за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gen.definition: The general multilingual environmental thesaurus (GEMET) was developed for the European Environment Agency (EEA) by the Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche (CNR) and Umwelt-Bundesamt (UBA), as a reference indexing and retrieval tool for the EEA catalogue of data sources and other EEA databases. [definition source: EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_leu.definition: A progressive, malignant disease of the blood forming organs; a distorted proliferation and development of leukocytes and their precursors in the blood and bone marrow. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_leu.name: leukaemia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_lv: noteikumu izstrādes un to izpildes kontroles instrumenti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: command-and-control
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_lv: noteikumu izstrādes un to izpildes kontroles instrumenti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: 1) In relation to policy and management, command-and-control instruments (e.g. mechanisms, laws, measures) rely on prescribing rules and standards and using sanctions to enforce compliance with them. 2) Command-and-control regulation requires polluters to meet specific emission-reduction targets and often requires the installation and use of specific types of equipment to reduce emissions. [definition source: 1) Adapted from: Scialabba. 1998. Quoted by FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.definition: A stimulus or succession of stimuli of such magnitude as to tend to disrupt the homeostasis of the organism. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_str.name: stress

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: The Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal (the Basel Convention) entered into force in 1992. A central goal of the Basel Convention is to protect human health and the environment by minimising hazardous waste production whenever possible through environmentally sound management. The convention requires that the production of hazardous wastes be managed using an integrated life-cycle approach, which involves strict controls from its generation to storage, transport, treatment, reuse, recycling, recovery and final disposal. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_en: Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_en: convention on the control of transboundary movements of hazardous wastes and their disposal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Synonyms: PFOS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: perfluorooctane sulfonic acid

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_toe.definition: Synonyms: tonnes of oil equivalent [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_toe.name: toe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fod.definition: Edible parts of plants, other than separated grain, that can provide feed for grazing animals or that can be harvested for feeding. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fod.name: fodder

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sew.definition: The purpose of this Directive is to regulate the use of sewage sludge in agriculture in such a way as to prevent harmful effects on soil, vegetation, animals and man, thereby encouraging the correct use of such sewage sludge. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sew.name: Sewage sludge directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HPV.definition: Chemicals placed on the EU market in volumes exceeding 1000 tonnes per year per manufacturer or importer. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HPV.name: HPVC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ECDC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european centre for disease prevention and control

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CCS.definition: Synonyms: carbon capture and storage [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CCS.name: CCS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sil.definition: Southern part of Poland and neighbouring small parts of Germany and the Czech Republic [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sil.name: Silesia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC). Widely regarded as the most authoritative international voice on the science and impacts of climate change. Established by governments under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organisation and UN Environment Programme (UNEP) in 1988, the IPCC produces five-yearly reports assessing the state of knowledge on climate change which represent the international consensus among the more than 2 000 experts involved. It has also published reports on specific issues, such as sinks. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppb.definition: The number of 'parts' by weight of a substance per billion parts of water. Used to measure extremely small concentrations. [definition source: US Geological Survey. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppb.name: ppb

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fish farm
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: Raising of fish in inland waters, estuaries or coastal waters. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPE.definition: In 2000, the European Commission adopted a Decision on the implementation of a European pollutant emission register (EPER) according to Article 15 of Council Directive 96/61/EC concerning iIntegrated pollution prevention and control (IPPC). The general purpose of the IPPC Directive is to reduce pollution by industry and to control emissions from larger facilities. National governments of all EC Member States are required to maintain inventories of emission data from specified industrial sources and to report emissions from individual facilities to the European Commission. The reported data will be made accessible in a public register (EPER), which is intended to provide environmental information on major industrial activities. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EPE.name: EPER

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objecttrans_is: þaulræktun, landnýtin ræktun, ræktun sem stefnir að sem mestum afrakstri af sem minnstu landsvæði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.objectname_is: þaulræktun, landnýtin ræktun, ræktun sem stefnir að sem mestum afrakstri af sem minnstu landsvæði
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: intensive farming
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Farming characterised by high input use that strives for maximum production, often at the expense of environmental considerations. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: Controlled process by which solid, liquid, or gaseous combustible wastes are burned and changed into gases; residue produced contains little or no combustible material. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: incineration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: Synonyms: SSM/I [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: special sensor microwave/imager

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bau.definition: Synonyms: Federal Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, Germany [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bau.name: BauA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cla.definition: 1. A loose, earthy, extremely fine-grained, natural sediment or soft rock composed primarily of clay-size or colloidal particles and characterised by high plasticity and by a considerable content of clay mineral and subordinate amounts of finely divided quartz, decomposed feldspar, carbonates, ferruginous matter, and other impurities; it forms a plastic, moldable mass when finely ground and mixed with water, retains its shape on drying, and becomes firm, rocklike and permanently hard on heating or firing. 2. The property of clay minerals that causes ions in solution to be fixed on clay surface or within internal sites applies to all types of ions, including organic molecules like pesticides. Clays can be an important vehicle for transporting and widely dispersing contaminants from one area to another. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cla.name: clay

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IFCS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: Intergovernmental Forum on Chemical Safety

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_sk: systém ochrany životného prostredia a ekologických auditov
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_lv: es projekts rūpniecības uzņēmumu brīvprātīgai iesaistei vides aizsardzības pasākumos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_es: Sistema comunitario de gestión y auditoría medioambientales
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_it: sistema di ecogestione e di audit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_it: sistema di ecogestione e di audit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_pt: sistema comunitário de ecogestão e auditoria (emas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_es: sistema comunitario de gestión y auditoría medioambientales
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.name: eco-management and auditing scheme
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_lv: ES projekts rūpniecības uzņēmumu brīvprātīgai iesaistei vides aizsardzības pasākumos
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_pt: Sistema Comunitário de Ecogestão e Auditoria (EMAS)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_fr: système de management environnemental et d'audit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_no: emas, ordning for miljøstyring og miljørevisjon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_sk: systém ochrany životného prostredia a ekologických auditov
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objectname_bg: схема за екоуправление и екоодит емас
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_fr: système de management environnemental et d'audit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_bg: Схема за екоуправление и екоодит ЕМАС
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.definition: A Community scheme allowing voluntary participation by companies performing industrial activities, established for the evaluation and improvement of the environmental performance of industrial activities and the provision of the relevant information to the public. The objective of the scheme is to promote continuous improvements in the environmental performance of industrial activities by:(a) the establishment and implementation of environmental policies, programmes and management systems by companies, in relation to their sites;(b) the systematic, objective and periodic evaluation of the performance of such elements;(c) the provision of information of environmental performance to the public. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eco.objecttrans_no: EMAS, Ordning for miljøstyring og miljørevisjon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WSS.definition: World Summit on Sustainable Development, held in Johannesburg (South Africa) in August 2002, ten years after the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Rio Conference). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WSS.name: WSSD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECN.definition: Synonyms: European Centre for Nature Conservation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECN.name: ECNC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Euro III vehicles that comply with the emission limits as defined in Directive 98/69/EC. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Euro III

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: A species occurring in an area outside of its historically known natural range as a result of intentional or accidental dispersal by human activities. Also referred to as introduced species or exotic species. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: introduced species

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fjo.definition: A narrow, long, deep inlet of the seas usually formed by glaciers and found along coasts such as those of Norway and Alaska. [definition source: The gardenweb glossary of botanical terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fjo.name: fjord

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_lv: primārās daļiņas, daļiņas, kas rodas tiešā gaisa plūsmā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: primary particles
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_lv: primārās daļiņas, daļiņas, kas rodas tiešā gaisa plūsmā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Particulate matter originated from direct air emissions. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Environmental signals 2000. Environmental assessment report No 6. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: The EEA 'Environmental issues reports' provide background knowledge and analysis of particular environmental issue, with the aim of providing support to the development and implementation of environmental policies. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.name: Environmental issue report

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.definition: Synonyms: International Programme on Chemical Safety [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPC.name: IPCS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEF.definition: The multi-billion-dollar global environment facility (GEF) was established by the World Bank, UNDP and UNEP in 1990. It operates the Convention on Biological Diversity's 'financial mechanism' on an interim basis and funds developing-country projects that have global biodiversity benefits. [definition source: CUB. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEF.name: GEF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOE.definition: Synonyms: State of the Environment Report - Russian Federation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOE.name: SOER-RF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reh.definition: The return of a degraded ecosystem to an undegraded condition but which may also be different from its original condition. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reh.name: rehabilitation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.definition: Accumulation of leaves, twigs and other forms of organic matter on the soil surface. In most soils, the surface layer of litter is at various stages of decomposition. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.name: litter

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: Ozone, the triatomic form of oxygen (O3), is a gaseous atmospheric constituent. In the troposphere - at ground level - it is created both naturally and by photochemical reactions involving gases resulting from human activities (photochemical smog). In high concentrations, tropospheric ozone can be harmful to a wide range of living organisms. In the stratosphere, ozone is created by the interaction between solar ultraviolet (UV) radiation and molecular oxygen (O2). Stratospheric ozone plays a decisive role in protecting life on earth from ultraviolet radiation from the sun. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ECHO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Commission Humanitarian Aid Office

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MCE.definition: Main component elements (MCE) are nominated by member countries and are nationally funded institutions/organisations which at the national level are regular collectors and suppliers of environmental data and/or possess relevant knowledge regarding environmental science, monitoring or modelling. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MCE.name: MCE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_riv.name: river basin
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_riv.definition: The area of land from which all surface run-off flows through a sequence of streams, rivers and, possibly, lakes into the sea at a single river mouth, estuary or delta. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Intervention scenarios (in the context of environmental studies) depict the future consequences of policy interventions. In other words, they describe the future state of society and the environment under influence of directed environmental policies. Intervention scenarios are also known as 'pollution control' or 'mitigation' or 'policy' scenarios. [definition source: Adapted from: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: intervention scenario

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.name: benchmark
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_bg: репер, мащаб за извършване на сравнения, вкл. и на анализи, скален знак
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_bg: репер, мащаб за извършване на сравнения, вкл. и на анализи, скален знак
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.definition: A measurable variable used as a baseline or reference in evaluating the performance of an organisation. Benchmarks may he drawn from internal experience or that of other organisations or from legal requirement and are often used to gauge changes in performance over time. [definition source: Sustainability Northwest website. England. Environmental Issues for Business. Glossary of terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_es: clasificación del uso de la tierra
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_pt: classificação do uso da terra; classificação do uso do solo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_es: clasificación del uso de la tierra
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land-use classification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_pt: classificação do uso da terra; classificação do uso do solo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_nl: classificatie op basis van het grondgebruik
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Classification providing information on land cover and the types of human activity involved in land use. It may also facilitate the assessment of environmental impacts on, and potential or alternative uses of, land. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_nl: classificatie op basis van het grondgebruik

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: Plant for heating all houses in a district; it consists of a large, efficient, centralized boiler plant or 'waste' steam from a power station. The heat is distributed by means of low-pressure steam or high-temperature water to the consumers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: district heating plant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objectname_hu: {agrare} pihentetés, szántóföldek be nem vetése kompenzációfizetés ellenében
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objectname_pt: 'set-aside' (programa que limita a produção através de restrições ao uso da terra)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.name: set-aside
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objecttrans_hu: {AGRARE} pihentetés, szántóföldek be nem vetése kompenzációfizetés ellenében
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objecttrans_pt: 'set-aside' (programa que limita a produção através de restrições ao uso da terra)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objectname_nl: braaklegging, het uit productie nemen (van landbouwgrond)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objectname_bg: преустановяване земеползването на селскостопански площи за определен период от време
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objecttrans_bg: преустановяване земеползването на селскостопански площи за определен период от време
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_set.objecttrans_nl: braaklegging, het uit productie nemen (van landbouwgrond)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water column
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The open-water environment, as distinct from the bed or shore, which may be inhabited by swimming marine or freshwater organisms. [definition source: EUNIS (October 1998 version). Quoted by: European Topic Centre on Nature Conservation. 1998. EUNIS habitat classification. Final draft with further revisions to marine habitats. United Kingdom.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: The rational application of a combination of biological, biotechnical, chemical, cultural or plant-breeding measures whereby the use of chemical plant protection products is limited to the strict minimum necessary to maintain the pest population at levels below those causing economically unacceptable damage or loss. [definition source: Oskam, A.J., Vijftigschild, R.A.N., Graveland, C.1997. Additional EU policy instruments for plant protection products. Final report.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated plant protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pac.definition: EC Directive proposed on 15 July 1992 aiming at harmonizing national measures concerning the management of packaging and packaging waste; the directive covers all packaging placed on the market. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pac.name: Packaging directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: The Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (also known as CMS or the Bonn Convention) aims to conserve terrestrial, marine and avian migratory species throughout their range. It is one of a small number of intergovernmental treaties concerned with the conservation of wildlife and wildlife habitats on a global scale. Since the Convention's entry into force on 1 November 1983, its membership has grown steadily to include 80 (as of 1 September 2002) Parties from Africa, Central and South America, Asia, Europe and Oceania. [definition source: Convention of Migratory Species website.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_en: Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_en: convention on the conservation of migratory species of wild animals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: High nature value farmland comprises the 'hot spots' of biodiversity in rural areas and is usually characterised by extensive farming practices. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.name: high nature value farmland

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.definition: 'Supporting surface' on which an organism grows. The substrate may simply provide structural support, or may provide water and nutrients. A substrate may be inorganic, such as rock or soil, or it may be organic, such as wood. [definition source: University of California, Berkeley. UCMP Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sub.name: substrate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_lv: primārā enerģija, enerģija dabiskajos resursos pirms tās antropogēniskās pārveidošanas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIR.definition: Centre of Information Resources for Collaboration on the Environment. The electronic workplace of EIONET consists of many interlinked, customised installations of CIRCA (Communication and Information Resource Centre Administrator) and other services linked to it, supporting it and integrated by it, i.e. the software component of e-EIONET. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIR.objectname_cs: circle -centrum informačních zdrojů pro spolupráci v oblasti životního prostředí

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objectname_is: heildarmagn fasts sorps sem fellur til
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste stream
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The total flow of solid waste from homes, businesses, institutions and manufacturing plants that is recycled, burned, or disposed of in landfills, or segments thereof such as the 'residential waste stream' or the 'recyclable waste stream.' [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objectname_lv: multimediālā pieeja, kopīga pieeja vairākiem vides pamatsektoriem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objectname_lt: kompleksinis požiūris į visas gamtines sistemas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objecttrans_lv: multimediālā pieeja, kopīga pieeja vairākiem vides pamatsektoriem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objecttrans_lt: kompleksinis požiūris į visas gamtines sistemas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objectname_fi: yhtenäinen lähestymistapa useampaan ympäristön osaan (esim. vesi, ilma)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objecttrans_fi: yhtenäinen lähestymistapa useampaan ympäristön osaan (esim. vesi, ilma)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.definition: Joint approach to several environmental media, such as air, water, and land. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_old.name: old-growth forest
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_old.definition: The old growth forests have been described by the adjective primeval, ancient, wilderness, virgin, pristine while in forester's terminology they are called as over-matured, decadent, and senescent, old growth. The old growth forests may be defined as a climax forest that has never been disturbed by man. The old growth forests can be classified as per the age and disturbance criteria. [definition source: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Indicative glossary on forest ecosystems and forest biological diversity. Montreal.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EFNCP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Forum on Nature Conservation and Pastoralism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Forum on Nature Conservation and Pastoralism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european forum on nature conservation and pastoralism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.definition: Synonyms: mg [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.name: milligram

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTT.definition: Synonyms: World Travel and Tourism Council [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTT.name: WTTC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A plausible description of how the future may unfold based on 'if-then' propositions; usually a scenario is one of a set of alternative pathways. A typical environmental scenario includes a representation of the initial situation, an image of the future and a storyline that describes the key driving forces and the step-wise changes that lead to this image of the future. Note that scenarios are neither predictions nor forecast. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental scenario

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEC.definition: Synonyms: national emission ceilings [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEC.name: NEC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bon.definition: The Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (also known as CMS or the Bonn Convention) aims to conserve terrestrial, marine and avian migratory species throughout their range. It is one of a small number of intergovernmental treaties concerned with the conservation of wildlife and wildlife habitats on a global scale. Since the Convention's entry into force on 1 November 1983, its membership has grown steadily to include 80 (as of 1 September 2002) Parties from Africa, Central and South America, Asia, Europe and Oceania. [definition source: Convention of Migratory Species website.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bon.name: Bonn Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wes.definition: Synonyms: WCE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wes.name: Western and Central Europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cur.definition: Synonyms: CLE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cur.name: current legislation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCI.definition: Synonyms: sites of community interest [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SCI.name: SCIs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fra.name: fragmentation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fra.definition: The breaking-up of continuous tracts of ecosystems creating barriers to migration or dispersal of organisms and reducing the size of homogenous areas. Fragmentation may be induced by human activities (e.g. road infrastructures, dams) or by natural processes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_hu: {envins} benchmarking (a benchmarking az adott területen legkiemelkedõbb szereplõk és eredmények elemzése, majd a módszereknek a körülmények által lehetõvé tett formában történõ átvétele.)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.name: benchmarking
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_hu: {ENVINS} benchmarking (A benchmarking az adott területen legkiemelkedõbb szereplõk és eredmények elemzése, majd a módszereknek a körülmények által lehetõvé tett formában történõ átvétele.)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objectname_bg: означаване, маркиране със знак, определяне на модел за сравнение
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.objecttrans_bg: означаване, маркиране със знак, определяне на модел за сравнение
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.definition: A management tool for comparing performance against an organisation that is widely regarded as outstanding in one or more areas, in order to improve performance. [definition source: NEI Transport. 2000. Phare multi-country transport programme (ZZ-9610). Road transport charges. Rotterdam.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: A European Commission database used to store and distribute information collected under Regulation 793/93 on the evaluation and control of the risks of existing substances. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission. 2001. White paper on Strategy for a Future Chemical Policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Uniform Chemical Information Database

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sit.definition: Synonyms: SCIs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sit.name: sites of community interest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: Wastewater produced by residential and commercial establishments and discharged into sewers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: An approach to farming which aims to balance production with economic and environmental considerations by means of a combination of measures including crop rotation, cultivations, appropriate crop varieties and careful use of inputs. [definition source: English Nature. 1996. Glossary of Agri-Environmental Terms. Research Reports No. 159. Mitchell, K. and Baldock, D. ISSN 0967-876X.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated farming

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spo.definition: Synonyms: SUV [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spo.name: sport utility vehicle

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: Subdivisions of the continental surfaces distinguished from one another on the basis of the form, roughness, and surface composition of the land. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: terrestrial area

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM2.definition: particulate matter with an average aerodynamic diameter of up to 2.5 µm, referred to as the fine particle fraction (which per definition includes the ultrafine particles) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM2.name: PM2.5

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.definition: Growth regulators influence the life processes of plants, other than as a nutrient. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.name: growth regulator

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_es: informe sobre el estado del medio ambiente
