glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_es: informe sobre el estado del medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.name: state-of-the-environment report
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_el: έκθεση για την κατάσταση του περιβάλλοντος
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_nl: milieurapport, toestand van het milieu-rapport, milieubalans
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_bg: доклад върху състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_bg: доклад върху състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.definition: A written account on the level of integrity and conditions of the ecosystem and natural resources in a given region, usually presented by an official person or body mandated to protect human health and the environment in that region. [definition source: GEMET 2000]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_nl: milieurapport, toestand van het milieu-rapport, milieubalans

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_E-W.definition: Envirowindows is the EIONET's interface to external partners. It provides an information 'marketplace' for businesses, local authorities and their stakeholders. The service is designed to:(a) facilitate consumer access to company's information on products, best practices, use of natural resources and corporate environmental performance, and;(b) help local authorities to communicate with concerned citizens, professionals, policy-makers and companies. Envirowindows is based on two main services: interest groups and information portals. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_E-W.name: e-windows

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: Intervention scenarios (in the context of environmental studies) depict the future consequences of policy interventions. In other words, they describe the future state of society and the environment under influence of directed environmental policies. Intervention scenarios are also known as 'pollution control' or 'mitigation' or 'policy' scenarios. [definition source: Adapted from: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: policy scenario

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_sl: dvig spodnjih plasti vode na površino
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_hu: {marenv} alsóbb vízszintek felfelé való mozgása, felszállása
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_it: "upwelling" (richiamo in costa di acque di fondo e allontanamento di acque superficiali verso il largo)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_it: "upwelling" (richiamo in costa di acque di fondo e allontanamento di acque superficiali verso il largo)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.name: upwelling
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_hu: {MARENV} alsóbb vízszintek felfelé való mozgása, felszállása
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_cs: vzedmutí (stoupnutí) spodních vod na hladinu (zejm. v oceánu)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_fi: viileän, ravinnepitoisen veden liike pintaa kohti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_sl: dvig spodnjih plasti vode na površino
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_bg: повдигане, изтласкване на долни слоеве вода, изтласкване на твърди тела във вода
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_fi: viileän, ravinnepitoisen veden liike pintaa kohti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objecttrans_bg: повдигане, изтласкване на долни слоеве вода, изтласкване на твърди тела във вода
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.definition: Upward movement of cool and nutrient-rich sub-surface waters towards the surface. There exist various types of upwelling. For fisheries, the most important type is the wind-induced coastal upwelling where the upward movement is a consequence of wind stress (along shore) and Eckman transport (offshore). [definition source: FAO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upw.objectname_cs: vzedmutí (stoupnutí) spodních vod na hladinu (zejm. v oceánu)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land consumption
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_nl: (a) bebouwing (b) gebruik van land (c) consumptief landgebruik
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: 'Consumption' of land cover means: (a) The expansion of built-up area which can be directly measured; (b) the absolute extent of land that is subject to exploitation by agriculture, forestry or other economic activities; and (c) the over-intensive exploitation of land that is used for agriculture and forestry. [definition source: EEA. 1997. The concept of environmental space. Copenhagen]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_nl: (a) bebouwing (b) gebruik van land (c) consumptief landgebruik

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.definition: ETCs are institutions/organisations contracted by the EEA to execute tasks identified in the multiannual work programme. They are designated by the management board after a competitive expertise/capacity selection process. Guiding principles for selection should be the cost-efficient use of existing and potential capacities in the member countries and avoidance of duplication of work and capacities. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.name: ETC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The Blue Flag is an ecolabel awarded to beaches and marinas. The award of the Blue Flag is based on 27 specific criteria for beaches and 16 specific criteria for marina. Though the specific requirements are different for the two types of sites, they cover the same four aspects: water quality, environmental education and information, environmental management, and safety and services. The Blue Flag Campaign is owned and run by the independent non-profit organisation Foundation for Environmental Education (FEE). [definition source: Adapted from: Blue Flag website.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Blue Flag

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: Process designed to determine factors contributing to the possible adverse effects of a substance to which a human population or an environmental compartment could be exposed. The process includes three steps: hazard identification, hazard characterisation, and hazard evaluation. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazard assessment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.definition: Regional services mean transport services operated to meet the transport needs of a region. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.name: regional services

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water cycle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The paths water takes through its various states - vapour, liquid, solid - as it moves throughout the ocean, atmosphere, groundwater, streams, etc. [definition source: The Groundwater Foundation.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Z_zon.definition: The control of land use by only allowing land development in fixed areas or zones. [definition source: City Council of Cape Town. A to Z dictionary of environmental words.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Z_zon.name: zoning

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_def.name: deforestation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_def.definition: The long-term removal of trees from a forested site to permit other site uses. [definition source: IUFRO Silva term database]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETS.definition: Synonyms: emissions trading scheme [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETS.name: ETS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETR.definition: Synonyms: environmental tax reform [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETR.name: ETR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objectname_lv: eiropas vides aģentūras ūdens datu bāze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objectname_pt: waterbase (base de dados sobre a qualidade da água)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.name: Waterbase
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objecttrans_lv: Eiropas Vides aģentūras ūdens datu bāze
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objecttrans_pt: Waterbase (base de dados sobre a qualidade da água)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objectname_bg: уотърбейс - база данни за качеството на водите в рамките на ееа
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.objecttrans_bg: Уотърбейс - база данни за качеството на водите в рамките на ЕЕА
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wat.definition: EEA water database. It contains water quality information for all kinds of water bodies. EEA is developing waterbase to help improve data comparability and provide the information relevant to the water framework directive. [definition source: Adapted from: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 430. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyr.definition: Synonyms: KCBTA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyr.name: Kyrgyz Community Based Tourism Organisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chl.definition: Chlorinated hydrocarbon (CHC) is a generic term given to compounds containing chlorine, carbon and hydrogen. The term can be used to describe organochlorine pesticides such as lindane and DDT, industrial chemicals such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB), and chlorine waste products such as dioxins and furans. These compounds are persistent in the environment and most bioaccumulates in the food chain. The human and environmental health risks of chlorinated hydrocarbons depend on the compound in question. As a general statement, exposure to chlorinated hydrocarbon has been associated with suppression of the immune system and cancer. [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chl.name: chlorinated hydrocarbon

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objecttrans_es: Librería virutal de información sobre el medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objecttrans_it: Virtual library of environmental information (biblioteca virtuale di informazioni ambientali)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objectname_da: virtual library of environmental information (virtuelt bibliotek med miljøoplysninger)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objecttrans_da: Virtual Library of Environmental Information (virtuelt bibliotek med miljøoplysninger)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objectname_it: virtual library of environmental information (biblioteca virtuale di informazioni ambientali)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objectname_es: librería virutal de información sobre el medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.name: virtual library of environmental information
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objectname_bg: виртуална библиотека за информация по околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objectname_ro: bibliotecă virtuală de informare despre mediul înconjurător
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objecttrans_bg: Виртуална библиотека за информация по околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.definition: Just as a library contains a card catalogue and books, an electronic virtual library consists of an electronic catalogue and the information resources described in the catalogue. The information resources of the virtual library can be databases, maps and documents, available on the web or not, events, organisations, etc. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_Vir.objecttrans_ro: Bibliotecă virtuală de informare despre mediul înconjurător

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_tr: tehlike altäąndaki vahåi fauna ve flora tãŧrlerinin uluslararasäą ticareti hakkäąnda konvansiyon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: An international treaty to restrict and monitor trade in endangered species, agreed by 123 parties, with a Secretariat in Switzerland. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_tr: Tehlike AltÄąndaki VahÅi Fauna ve Flora TÃŧrlerinin UluslararasÄą Ticareti HakkÄąnda Konvansiyon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_en: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_en: convention on international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: The integrated change in total ozone per unit mass emission of a specific compound, relative to the integrated change in the total ozone per unit mass of CFC-11. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 101. Environmental assessment report No 2]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone-depleting potential

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mar.definition: Synonyms: MSD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mar.name: Marine Strategy Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oli.objectname_hu: {wat} ún. tiszta  tápanyagban szegény  vizek; {marenv} oligotróf vizek
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oli.name: oligotrophic
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oli.objecttrans_hu: {WAT} ún. tiszta  tápanyagban szegény  vizek; {MARENV} oligotróf vizek
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oli.definition: Waters that are relatively low in nutrients and cannot support much plant life. [definition source: Based on: FishBase Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_key.definition: A species that influences the ecological composition, structure, or functioning of its community far more than its abundance would suggest. [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_key.name: keystone species

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mor.definition: The number of sick persons or cases of disease in relationship to a specific population. [definition source: CMD. 1997. Taber's cyclopedic medical dictionary. Quoted by: WHO. 1999. Air quality guidelines.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mor.name: morbidity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Synonyms: RLNP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: research laboratory of nature protection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Green pricing refers to an optional utility service that allows customers of traditional utilities support a greater level of utility investment in renewable energy by paying a premium on their electric bill to cover any above-market costs of acquiring renewable energy resources. [definition source: US EPA. Clean energy home. Glossary of terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green pricing (energy)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.definition: Change in the state or dynamics of a system caused by the action of an agent. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.name: effect

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_N%2.definition: An essential nutrient in the food supply of plants and the diets of animals. Animals obtain it in nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly amino acids. Although in the atmosphere is nearly 80% gaseous nitrogen, very few organisms have the ability to use it in this form. The higher plants normally obtain it from the soil after micro-organisms have converted the nitrogen into ammonia or nitrates, which they can then absorb. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_N%2.name: N, N2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.definition: Energy intensity denotes the ratio between energy consumption and GDP. It expresses the extent to which there is a decoupling between energy consumption and economic growth. Relative decoupling occurs if energy consumption grows, but at a lower pace than the economy. Absolute decoupling occurs if the economy grows while energy consumption decreases. An absolute decoupling is likely to alleviate the environmental pressures of energy production and consumption. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Ene.name: Energy intensity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SUV.definition: Synonyms: sport utility vehicle [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SUV.name: SUV

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: ETC/WTR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Topic Centre on Water

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fee.definition: The price per unit of electricity that a utility or supplier has to pay for renewable electricity from private generators. The government regulates the tariff rate. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fee.name: feed-in tariff

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oxy.definition: Synonyms: O2 [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_oxy.name: oxygen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HFC.definition: Synonyms: hydrofluorocarbons [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HFC.name: HFCs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objectname_hu: sport-, szabadidő- és üdülőterület; szabadidő eltöltésére alkalmas terület
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.name: recreational land
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objecttrans_hu: sport-, szabadidő- és üdülőterület; szabadidő eltöltésére alkalmas terület
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.definition: Land used for purposes of recreation, for example, sports fields, gymnasiums, playgrounds, public parks and green areas, public beaches and swimming pools and camping sites. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Synonyms: SDT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable development of Tourism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.name: endemic species
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_end.definition: Species native to, and restricted to, a particular geographical region. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.definition: The Cardiff Summit (15 and 16 June 1998) laid the foundation for coordinated Community action to integrate environmental concerns into EU policies. At the same summit the European Council invited the Transport, Energy and Agriculture Councils to define strategies of their own on this point. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Car.name: Cardiff Summit

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: A location where as a result of human activity an unacceptable hazard to human health and ecosystems exists. Local contamination (contaminated sites) is a problem in restricted areas (or sites) around the source, where there is a direct link to the source of contamination. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: contaminated land

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rap.definition: Synonyms: RAPEX [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rap.name: Rapid Alert System for non-food consumer products
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rap.objecttrans_en: Rapid Alert System for non-food consumer products
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rap.objectname_en: rapid alert system for non-food consumer products

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DO.definition: Amount of gaseous oxygen (O2) actually present in water expressed in terms either of its presence in the volume of water (milligrams of O2 per litre) or of its share in saturated water (percentage). [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DO.name: DO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.definition: Synonyms: CSD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.name: Commission on Sustainable Development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tur.objectname_pt: turvação, aspecto turvo; aspecto lodoso ou barrento
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tur.name: turbidity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tur.objecttrans_pt: turvação, aspecto turvo; aspecto lodoso ou barrento
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tur.definition: Hazy or cloudy condition of water due to the presence of suspended particles. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: policy scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objectname_bg: сценарий относно бъдещи мерки в областта на екологичната политика
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objecttrans_bg: сценарий относно бъдещи мерки в областта на екологичната политика
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: Policy scenarios (in the context of environmental studies) depict the future consequences of policy interventions. In other words, they describe the future state of society and the environment under influence of directed environmental policies. Policy scenarios are also sometimes known as 'pollution control' or 'mitigation' or 'intervention' scenarios. [definition source: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: The electromagnetic spectrum extends from electric power at the long-wavelength end to gamma radiation at the short-wavelength end, covering wavelengths from thousands of kilometres down to fractions of the size of an atom. The spectra of radiation absorbed and emitted by matter is used to obtain information about matter. This kind of information is also used in remote sensing from satellites. Onboard scanners are equiped with sensors which digitally record images in separate spectral channels. Data from such spectral images are valuable in several environment analyses. Following are the main spectra bands from minimum to maximum wavelength.? = Gamma raysHX = Hard X-raysSX = Soft X-RaysEUV = Extreme ultravioletNUV = Near ultravioletVisible lightNIR = Near infraredMIR = Moderate infraredFIR = Far infraredRadio waves:EHF = Extremely high frequency (Microwaves)SHF = Super high frequency (Microwaves)UHF = Ultrahigh frequencyVHF = Very high frequencyHF = High frequencyMF = Medium frequencyLF = Low frequencyVLF = Very low frequencyVF = Voice frequencyELF = Extremely low frequency [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: spectral

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DES.definition: Synonyms: Decade of Education for Sustainable Development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DES.name: DESD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: The EU Directive on the conservation of wild birds (79/49/EEC) seeks to protect all wild birds and the habitats of listed species, in particular through the designation of special protection areas (SPA). [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directive on the conservation of wild birds
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_en: Directive on the conservation of wild birds
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objectname_en: directive on the conservation of wild birds

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.definition: The more or less decomposed organic matter in the soil. Besides being the source of most of the mineral salts needed by plants, humus improves the texture of the soil and holds water, so reducing the loss of nutrients by leaching. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hum.name: humus

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.objectname_hu: {envins} környezetvédelmi adó (az adókból származó bevételek növelésére)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fiscal environmental tax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.objecttrans_hu: {ENVINS} környezetvédelmi adó (az adókból származó bevételek növelésére)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: Tax designated mainly to raise revenues. [definition source: EEA. 1996. Environmental Taxes Implementation and Environmental Effectiveness.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MIM.definition: Synonyms: Ministry of Environment of Spain [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MIM.name: MIMAM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fin.name: final energy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fin.objectname_nl: finaal energie gebruik, energie gebruik door eindgebruikers
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fin.definition: Energy supplied that is available to the consumer to be converted into useful energy (e.g. electricity at the wall outlet). [definition source: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fin.objecttrans_nl: finaal energie gebruik, energie gebruik door eindgebruikers

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: The number of 'parts' by weight of a substance per million parts of water. This unit is commonly used to represent pollutant concentrations. [definition source: US Geological Survey. United States.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: parts per million

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENT.definition: Synonyms: Environmental and Engineering Consultancy [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ENT.name: ENTEC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RLN.definition: Synonyms: research laboratory of nature protection [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RLN.name: RLNP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: The natural, rocklike, brown to black derivative of forest-type plant material, usually accumulated in peat beds and progressively compressed and indurated until it is finally altered in to graphite-like material. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: A biofuel produced by the fermentation of plants rich in sugar/starch (e.g. sugar cane, corn). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: bioethanol

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fee.definition: A legal obligation on utilities to purchase electricity from renewable sources. [definition source: EEA. 2001. Renewable energies: success stories. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fee.name: feed-in law

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Congested infrastructure means a section of infrastructure for which demand for infrastructure capacity cannot be fully satisfied during certain periods even after coordination of the different requests for capacity. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: congested infrastructure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_smo.definition: Action, device or announcement that serves to give caution or notice to the level of air pollutants typically associated with oxidants in a given area. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_smo.name: smog warning

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_OSC.definition: Synonyms: Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_OSC.name: OSCE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SID.definition: Synonyms: SIAM [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SID.name: SIDS initial assessment meeting

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_6_6EA.definition: The sixth environment action programme of the European Community (Environment 2010: our future, our choice) provides the environmental component of the Community's forthcoming strategy for sustainable development for the period 2001-2010. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_6_6EA.name: 6EAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Farming characterised by high input use that strives for maximum production, often at the expense of environmental considerations. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: intensive agriculture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mol.definition: All animals in the Phylum mollusca including: gastropods, e.g. whelks and winkles; bivalves, e.g. cockles and mussels; cephalopods, e.g. squid and cuttlefish. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mol.name: mollusc

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NER.definition: Synonyms: National Environmental Research Institute, Denmark [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NER.name: NERI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_thr.name: threshold
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_thr.definition: The dose or exposure level below which a significant adverse effect is not expected. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nan.definition: Planktonic organisms that are 2-20 micometres in size. [definition source: State University of New York at Stony Brook. Glossary on marine biology.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nan.name: nanoplankton

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.name: noise pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: Harmful or unwanted sounds in the environment, which in specific locals, can be measured and averaged over a period of time. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eme.name: Emerald network
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eme.definition: The Emerald network is a network of areas of special conservation interest (ASCIs), which is to be established in the territory of the contracting parties and observer States to the Bern Convention, including, among others, central and east European countries and the EU Member States. For EU Member States, Emerald network sites are those of the Natura 2000 network. [definition source: Council of Europe.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNC.definition: The Convention was adopted in Paris on 17 June 1994. It entered into force on 26 December 1996. The objective of this Convention is to combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought in countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in Africa, through effective action at all levels, supported by international cooperation and partnership arrangements, in the framework of an integrated approach which is consistent with Agenda 21, with a view to contributing to the achievement of sustainable development in affected areas. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNC.name: UNCCD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imm.name: immunesuppression
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imm.definition: The suppression of immune response. Immunosuppressor: A substance, an agent or a condition that prevents or diminishes the immune response. [definition source: FAO. Glossary of biotechnology and genetic engineering.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: Directive 2000/53/EC on end-of life vehicles lays down measures which aim, as a first priority, at the prevention of waste from vehicles and, in addition, at the reuse, recycling and other forms of recovery of end-of life vehicles and their components so as to reduce the disposal of waste, as well as at the improvement in the environmental performance of all of the economic operators involved in the life cycle of vehicles and especially the operators directly involved in the treatment of end-of life vehicles. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directive 2000/53/EC on end-of life vehicles

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veg.definition: 1) The plants of an area considered in general or as communities, but not taxonomically; the total plant cover in a particular area or on the Earth as a whole. 2) The total mass of plant life that occupies a given area. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_veg.name: vegetation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.definition: Synonyms: MOSUS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.name: Modelling opportunities and limits for restructuring Europe towards sustainability
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.objecttrans_en: Modelling opportunities and limits for restructuring Europe towards sustainability
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mod.objectname_en: modelling opportunities and limits for restructuring europe towards sustainability

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.definition: The presence in food of harmful, unpalatable, or otherwise objectionable foreign substances, e.g. chemicals, microorganisms or diluents, before, during, or after processing or storage. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_foo.name: food contamination

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.definition: Inorganic form of nitrogen. An important plant nutrient and type of inorganic fertilizer (most highly oxidized phase in the nitrogen cycle). In water, the major sources of nitrates are septic tanks, feed lots and fertilizers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.name: nitrate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_km.name: km

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Wh.name: Wh

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: Synonyms: CRF [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: common reporting format

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: European Organisation for the Safety of Air Navigation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: Eurocontrol

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: Modifications of soil features or, more generally, of its chemical and biological balance, caused by the discharge of polluting substances. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil contamination

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CMS.definition: Synonyms: Convention on Migratory Species [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CMS.name: CMS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Reg.name: Regional Environmental Reconstruction Programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cli.definition: Synonyms: CRU [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cli.name: Climatic Research Unit

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.definition: An international consortium brought together to assists the EEA in its work of collecting, analysing, evaluating and synthesising information on waste and material flows relevant to national and international policies. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.name: ETC/WMF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tai.definition: Any collection of liquid effluents or wastewater drained or separated out during the processing of crops or mineral ores. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tai.name: tailings waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.definition: Vehicle exhaust system, which uses catalysis (a process for altering the speed of a chemical reaction) to reduce the emissions of pollutants. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cat.name: catalytic converter

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.objectname_pt: floresta de espécies de folhas largas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.name: broadleaved woodland

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.definition: Wooded land on which more than 75 % of the tree crown cover consists of broadleaved species. [definition source: EUNIS (based on FAO definition). EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: Terrestrial ecosystem monitoring sites (TEMS) is an international directory of sites (named T sites) and networks that carry out long-term terrestrial monitoring and research activities. The database provides information on the 'who, what and where' in long-term terrestrial monitoring that can be useful to both the scientific community and policy-makers. [definition source: FAO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: terrestrial ecosystem monitoring sites

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAF.definition: Synonyms: Clean Air for Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAF.name: CAFE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sou.definition: Synonyms: SEE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sou.name: South-eastern Europe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental audit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: одит на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: одит на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A management tool comprising a systematic, documented, periodic and objective evaluation of how well a project, organisation or equipment is performing with the aim of helping to safeguard the environment. The audit should facilitate management control of environmental practices and assess compliance with policy objectives and regulatory requirements. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environmental concerns into development and economic cooperation. Brussels.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hel.definition: Synonyms: HCMR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_Hel.name: Hellenic Centre for Marine Research

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bas.name: Basel Convention
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bas.definition: The Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal (the Basel Convention) entered into force in 1992. A central goal of the Basel Convention is to protect human health and the environment by minimising hazardous waste production whenever possible through environmentally sound management. The convention requires that the production of hazardous wastes be managed using an integrated life-cycle approach, which involves strict controls from its generation to storage, transport, treatment, reuse, recycling, recovery and final disposal. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.definition: Destruction of wildlife habitats by increasing pressure for land by fast-growing human populations, pollution and over-exploitation. Whole species or populations of plants and animals have disappeared causing a loss of genetic resource that is not only regrettable from an aesthetic or philosophical point of view but also threatens man's food supply. Habitat loss takes several forms: outright loss of areas used by wild species; degradation, for example, from vegetation removal and erosion, which deprive native species of food, shelter, and breeding areas; and fragmentation, when native species are squeezed onto small patches of undisturbed land surrounded by areas cleared for agriculture and other purposes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hab.name: habitat destruction

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.definition: Energy that does not come from fossil fuels. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.name: non-conventional energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.name: freshwater
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.definition: Naturally occurring water having a low concentration of salts, which is often acceptable as suitable for abstraction and treatment to produce drinking water; [definition source: Directive 91/676/EEC of 12 December 1991 concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bas.definition: The Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal (the Basel Convention) entered into force in 1992. A central goal of the Basel Convention is to protect human health and the environment by minimising hazardous waste production whenever possible through environmentally sound management. The convention requires that the production of hazardous wastes be managed using an integrated life-cycle approach, which involves strict controls from its generation to storage, transport, treatment, reuse, recycling, recovery and final disposal. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. They are non-coastal habitats with less than 30 % vegetation cover (other than where the vegetation is chasmophytic or on scree and or cliff) which are dry or only seasonally wet (with the water table at or above ground level for less than half of the year). Subterranean non-marine caves and passages including underground waters. Habitats characterised by the presence of permanent snow and surface ice other than marine ice bodies. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objectname_cs: stanoviště vnitrozemských oblastí bez rostlinstva nebo řídce porostlé

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Council of Chemical Associations

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EfE.definition: Synonyms: Environment for Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EfE.name: EfE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.definition: Synonyms: GEOSS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.objectname_en: global earth observation system of systems

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: The Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats was adopted in Bern on 19 September 1979 and came into force on 1 June 1982. Forty-five European and African States as well as the European Community are parties to the convention. It has a threefold objective: to conserve wild flora and fauna and their natural habitats; to promote co-operation between states; and to give particular emphasis to endangered and vulnerable species, including endangered and vulnerable migratory species. [definition source: Council of Europe.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_en: Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_en: convention on the conservation of european wildlife and natural habitats

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.name: earmarked tax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.objectname_nl: gereserveerde heffing/belasting, voorbestemde belasting, ge-oormerkte belasting
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.definition: Tax collected and used for a specific purpose. [definition source: NEI Transport. 2000. Phare multi-country transport programme (ZZ-9610). Road transport charges. Rotterdam.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ear.objecttrans_nl: gereserveerde heffing/belasting, voorbestemde belasting, ge-oormerkte belasting

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MED.definition: The Mediterranean action plan (MAP) and the Barcelona Convention are being implemented through a series of protocols and the programmes are being carried out by relevant MAP regional activity centres. Among these programmes is the long-term programme for pollution monitoring and research in the Mediterranean (Medpol), designed to assess the extent of marine pollution in the Mediterranean. [definition source: Adapted from: UNEP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MED.name: Medpol

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.definition: Synonyms: NGO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_non.name: non-governmental organisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: A rubber ring placed over the rim of a wheel of a road vehicle to provide traction and reduce road shocks, especially a hollow inflated ring consisting of a reinforced outer casing enclosing an inner tube. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: car tyre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.definition: Something that takes place or comes to pass. Occurrence and happening are the most general: an everyday occurrence; a happening of no great importance.Event usually signifies a notable occurrence: major world events reported on the evening news. 'Great events make me quiet and calm; it is only trifles that irritate my nerves' Victoria.Incident may apply to a minor occurrence: a small incident blown out of proportion.The term may also refer to a distinct event of sharp identity and significance: a succession of exciting incidents.An episode is an incident in the course of a progression or within a larger sequence: 'Happiness was but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain' Thomas Hardy.Circumstance denotes a particular incident or occurrence: 'Billy had found Alice, thus bringing about the odd circumstance of their renewing their acquaintanceship' Eleanor H. Porter. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_occ.name: occurrence + qual

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: Refers to actions to save fuels by better building design, the modification of production processes, better selection of road vehicles and transport policies, the adoption of district heating schemes in conjunction with electrical power generation, and the use of domestic insulation and double glazing in homes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy efficiency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water consumption
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water abstracted which is no longer available for use because it has evaporated, transpired, been incorporated into products and crops, consumed by man or livestock, ejected directly into sea, or otherwise removed from freshwater resources. Water losses during transport of water between the points or points of abstractions and point or points of use are excluded. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.definition: The farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants with some sort of intervention in the rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being cultivated. [definition source: FAO Fishery Glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fis.name: fish farming

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Synonyms: GAINS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: greenhouse gas and air pollution interactions and synergies
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.objecttrans_en: greenhouse gas and air pollution interactions and synergies
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.objectname_en: greenhouse gas and air pollution interactions and synergies

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UV.definition: Radiation in the wavelength range between visible light and X-rays, divided into wavelength bands A, B, C. Much of the ultraviolet radiations in bands B and C are prevented from reaching the earth's surface by the ozone layer present in the atmosphere. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UV.name: UV
