glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.objecttrans_bg: паневропейска стратегия за сушата и биологичното разнообразие
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.definition: The strategy establishes an international framework for cooperation for consolidating and extending existing schemes and programmes in the conservation field. Endorsed at the third pan-European Conferences of Ministers of the Environment 'Environment for Europe' held in Sofia in October 1995, it concerns 54 countries of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. The Council of Europe and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) are responsible for the strategy's secretariat. [definition source: Council of Europe.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.objectname_cs: celoevropská strategie biologické a krajinné rozmanitosti
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.objecttrans_ro: strategia paneuropenă cu privire la ambient şi la diversitatea biologică
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.objecttrans_nl: pan-Europese strategie voor landschappen en biologische diversiteit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pan.objecttrans_no: felleseuropeisk strategi for landskap og biologisk mangfold

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOX.definition: Synonyms: sulphur oxides [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SOX.name: SOX

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life cycle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_bg: цикъл на живот (като фази на производство)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_bg: цикъл на живот (като фази на производство)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: Consecutive and interlinked stages of a product system, from raw material acquisition or generation of natural resources to the final disposal. [definition source: EEA. 1998. Life cycle assessment. Environmental issues series No 6.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: person-kilometre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Unit of measurement of the transport of persons. When 15 persons drive 10 km in an omnibus, they have accumulated 150 person-km. [definition source: Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety. Time to act. Environment management in financial institutions. Germany.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.definition: The region in which electromagnetic radiation from a source exerts an influence on another object with or without there being contact between them. [definition source: National Radiological Protection Board. UK. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.name: electromagnetic field

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objectname_lv: atkritumvielu otrreizēja izmantošana (var būt atšķirīga no oriģinālās izmantošanas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.name: reclamation of materials
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rec.objecttrans_lv: atkritumvielu otrreizēja izmantošana (var būt atšķirīga no oriģinālās izmantošanas)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.definition: The Seveso II Directive aims to ensure high levels of protection against accidents involving dangerous substances. Operators of establishments where certain quantities of dangerous substances are present (called Seveso plants or Seveso installations) are requested to notify the competent authorities and to establish and implement a major implement prevention policy. [definition source: Based on: Environmental Commission. Handbook on the Implementation of EC environmental legislation.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sev.name: Seveso plant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bog.definition: A commonly used term in Scotland and Ireland for a stretch waterlogged, spongy ground, chiefly composed of decaying vegetable matter, especially of rushes, cotton grass, and sphagnum moss. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bog.name: bog

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dri.definition: Council Directive 98/83/EC of 3 November 1998 concerning the quality of water intended for human consumption. The Directive is intended to protect human health by laying down healthiness and purity requirements which must be met by drinking water within the Community. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dri.name: Drinking water directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EWC.definition: The EWC is a hierarchical list of waste descriptions established by Commission decision 2000/532/EC2. It is divided into twenty main chapters, most of which are industry-based but some of which are based on materials and processes. Each of these has a two digit code between 01 and 20. Chapters have one or more subchapters (with four figure codes, the first two of which are the two digits of the chapter). Within these there are codes for individual wastes each of which is assigned a six figure code. Hazardous wastes are signified by entries where the code is followed by an asterisk. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EWC.name: EWC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.definition: An event (characterised by duration and degree of exceedance) where the concentration of a pollutant is greater than, or equal to, the appropriate air quality standard. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.name: exceedance

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: That part of the Earth and atmosphere capable of supporting living organisms. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biosphere

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tol.definition: Toll means payment of a specified amount for a vehicle travelling the distance between two points on the infrastructures, the amount shall be based on the distance travelled and the type of the vehicle. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tol.name: toll

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LUL.definition: land use, land-use change and forestry [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LUL.name: LULUCF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.name: coliform organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_col.definition: Micro-organism found in the intestinal tract of human beings and animals. Its presence in water indicates faecal pollution and potentially dangerous bacterial contamination. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Coniferous woodland is defined as wooded land on which more than 75 % of the tree crown cover consists of coniferous species. [definition source: EUNIS (based on FAO definition). EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: coniferous forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The collection, transport, treatment and disposal of waste (including after-care of disposal sites). [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on waste]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: Any substance used in or resulting from a reaction involving changes to atoms or molecules. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: A closed list of 100/106 'existing' chemicals governed by Regulation 793/93 on the evaluation and control of the risks of existing substances. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European inventory of existing commercial chemical substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European inventory of existing commercial chemical substances
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european inventory of existing commercial chemical substances

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: Synonyms: HNV [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.name: high nature value

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agricultural structure
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: The characteristics of the farm sector; most often used in describing changes in the number, size distribution, production traits, and business composition (i.e. type of ownership) of farms and agribusiness firms. [definition source: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress. United States. A Glossary of Agricultural Terms, Programs and Laws.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: EC Directive proposed on 15 July 1992 aiming at harmonizing national measures concerning the management of packaging and packaging waste; the directive covers all packaging placed on the market. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.name: Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_en: Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objectname_en: directive 94/62/ec on packaging and packaging waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_P.definition: It is an essential component of living systems and is found in nervous tissue, bones and cell protoplasm. Phosphorus exists in several allotropic forms including white (or yellow), red, and black (or violet). White phosphorus has two modifications. Ordinary phosphorus is a waxy white solid. When pure, it is colourless and transparent. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in carbon disulphide. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_P.name: P

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: The renewable source of energy provided by falling water that drives the turbines. There are two types of hydroelectric power plants: a) run-of-river power plants for the use of affluent water; b) storage power plants (power stations with reservoir) where the influx can be regulated with the help of a reservoir. Mostly greater differences in altitudes are being used,like mountain creeks. Power stations with reservoirs are generally marked by barrages with earth fill dam or concrete dams. Though hydropower generally can be called environmentally acceptable, there exist also some problems: a) change of groundwater level and fill up of the river bed with rubble b) risk of dam breaks c) great demand for land space for the reservoir d) diminution,but partly also increase of value of recreation areas. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydroelectric power

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dou.name: double dividend
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dou.definition: It refers to the notion that environmental taxes can both reduce pollution (the first dividend) and reduce the overall economic costs associated with the tax system by using the revenue generated to displace other more distortionary taxes that slow economic growth at the same time (the second dividend). [definition source: Resources for the Future. United States.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FAO.definition: Synonyms: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FAO.name: FAO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objectname_sv: uttunning av ozonskiktet; nedbrytning av ozonskiktet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.name: ozone layer depletion
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.objecttrans_sv: uttunning av ozonskiktet; nedbrytning av ozonskiktet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ozo.definition: The fragile shield of ozone is being damaged by chemicals released on earth. The main chemicals that are depleting stratospheric ozone are chlorofluorocarbons which are used in refrigerators, aerosols, and as cleaners in many industries, and halons, which are used in fire extinguishers. The damage is caused when these chemicals release highly reactive forms of chlorine and bromine. Over the past 30 years ozone levels over parts of Antarctica have dropped by almost 40 % during some months and a 'hole' in ozone concentrations is clearly visible in satellite observations. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objecttrans_it: 'top soil' (copertura organica e vegetale che fertilizza il suolo)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.objectname_it: 'top soil' (copertura organica e vegetale che fertilizza il suolo)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.name: top soil
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_top.definition: The upper part of the soil profile that is relatively rich in humus, which is technically known as the A-horizon of the soil profile. [definition source: State of California Surface Mining Reclamation Act. Quoted by: Download soils and soil science glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: Natura 2000
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: European Union network of sites designated by Member States under the birds directive and under the habitats directive. [definition source: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: ICARDA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: International Centre for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: International Centre for Agricultural Research in the Dry Areas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: international centre for agricultural research in the dry areas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.definition: Synonyms: IACMST [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.name: Inter-Agency Committee on Marine Science and Technology
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objecttrans_en: Inter-Agency Committee on Marine Science and Technology
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_Int.objectname_en: inter-agency committee on marine science and technology

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Unified, combined and coordinated management of problems which correlates relevant organisations, groups, individuals and disciplines by bringing the parts together for a complete approach. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: integrated management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.definition: Process of evaluating alternative regulatory and non-regulatory responses to risk and selecting among them. The selection process necessarily requires the consideration of legal, economic and social factors. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ris.name: risk management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UN [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_def.name: defoliation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_def.definition: Natural or disease-related shedding of leaves. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.definition: The European Topic Centre on Air and Climate Change (ETC/ACC) has been established by EEA in 2001. This centre builds on the experience gained by the former ETC on Air Emissions and Air Quality. It is an international consortium brought together to assists the EEA in its work of collecting, analysing, evaluating and synthesising information on air and climate change relevant to national and international policies. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.name: ETC/ACC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.definition: 1) The largest long-term average catch or yield that can be taken from a stock or stock complex under prevailing ecological and environmental conditions. 2) Maximum use that a renewable resource can sustain without impairing its renewability through natural growth or replenishment. [definition source: 1) US National Marine Fisheries Services (NOOA). NOAA Fisheries strategic plan. glossary of terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.name: maximum sustainable yield

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.definition: A nuclide that exhibits radioactivity. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.name: radionuklide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exo.definition: A species occurring in an area outside of its historically known natural range as a result of intentional or accidental dispersal by human activities. Also referred to as introduced species or exotic species. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exo.name: exotic species

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_har.definition: Equilibrium or balance is any of a number of related phenomena in the natural and social sciences. In general, a system is said to be in a state of equilibrium if all influences on the system are cancelled by the effects of others. A related concept is stability; an equilibrium may or may not be stable. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_har.name: harmony

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.name: run-off
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.objectname_bg: изтичане на определено количество вода от дъжд, сняг или иригационна вода
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.objecttrans_bg: изтичане на определено количество вода от дъжд, сняг или иригационна вода
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_run.definition: Portion of rainfall, melted snow or irrigation water that flows across the ground's surface and is eventually returned to streams. Run-off can pick up pollutants from air or land and carry them to receiving waters. [definition source: United Nations. 1997. Quoted by: FAO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.definition: Synonyms: GFN [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.name: Global Footprint Network

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.definition: Synonyms: European Topic Centre on Water [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ETC.name: ETC/WTR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: prevention of waste generation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objectname_fr: prévention de la formation de déchets
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objecttrans_fr: prévention de la formation de déchets

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: The number of species within a region. (A term commonly used as a measure of species diversity, but technically only one aspect of diversity.) [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: species richness

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ass.name: assumption
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ass.definition: The 'if' statements used to frame a scenario. 'If this policy is adopted, if this trend continues, if this event happens, then'. Often referred to as assumption sets. [definition source: WHO.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_g.definition: Synonyms: gram [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_g.name: g

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Synonyms: NASA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_neg.definition: A contract between the public administration and the industry in which the firm agrees to achieve a certain environmental objective and receives a subsidy to change its technology though R&D and innovation. The agreement is bilateral, between one firm and the administration, and requires a voluntary element on both sides. [definition source: Adapted from: Carraro, C. and Siniscalo, D. Voluntary agreements in environmental policy. A theoretical appraisal. Fondazione Eni Enrico Mattei. Italy.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_neg.name: negotiated agreement

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: Land-use system in which woody perennials are maintained or planted, in some form of spatial arrangement or temporal sequence, on the same land as agricultural crops and/or livestock. [definition source: European Commission. Forest in sustainable development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agroforestry

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sep.definition: The collection of individual components of solid waste from any source, usually separated into different collection containers, in order to recover, reuse or recycle the material or to facilitate its collection and disposal. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sep.name: separated collection

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEP.definition: Synonyms: Caspian Environment Programme [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEP.name: CEP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: (1) The liquid wastes deriving from domestic, commercial and industrial activities of an urban settlement. (2) Urban wastewater means domestic wastewater or the mixture of domestic wastewater with industrial wastewater and/or run-off rain water. [definition source: 1) ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000). 2) Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May 1991 concerning urban waste-water treatment.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban sewage

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cri.definition: Synonyms: CEPF [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cri.name: Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PEE.definition: Synonyms: Pan-European Ecological Network [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PEE.name: PEEN

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SO2.name: SO2

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: An unexpected incident with potential for harm occurring through the movement or collision of vessels, vehicles or persons along a land, water and air. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_riv.definition: The area of land and sea, made up of one or more neighbouring river basins together with their associated groundwaters and coastal waters, which is identified under Article 3(1) (of the water framework directive) as the main unit for management of river basins. [definition source: Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.objectname_pt: planície de inundação; planície de cheia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_flo.definition: Any normally dry land area that is susceptible to being inundated by water from any natural source. This area is usually low land adjacent to a stream or lake. [definition source: Environment Canada. Glossary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eEu.definition: The initiative 'eEurope, an information society for all' was launched in 1999 by the European Commission to bring the benefits of the information society to all Europeans. [definition source: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.definition: Edible parts of plants, other than separated grain, that can provide feed for grazing animals or that can be harvested for feeding. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bra.definition: Water with a salt concentration between 5 and 18 ppt (dividing point from the surface water directive (75/440/EEC) Annex II). [definition source: Council Directive 75/440/EEC of 25 July 1975 concerning the quality required of surface water intended for the abstraction of drinking water in the Member States (Annex II)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pne.definition: A rubber ring placed over the rim of a wheel of a road vehicle to provide traction and reduce road shocks, especially a hollow inflated ring consisting of a reinforced outer casing enclosing an inner tube. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pne.name: pneumatics

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: land classification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Land categories, reflecting quality classes, capability classes or grade, depending upon the characteristics of the land and/or its potential for agricultural use. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_din.definition: Microscopic alga characterised by the presence of two whip-like flagella. [definition source: Fisheries and Oceans Canada.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_din.name: dinoflagellate

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAP.name: RAPEX

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_fi: 1) saasteiden luonnossa hajoamisen aste 2) aineenvaihduntaan imeytymisen ja siihen vaikuttamisen aste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_fi: 1) saasteiden luonnossa hajoamisen aste 2) aineenvaihduntaan imeytymisen ja siihen vaikuttamisen aste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: 1)The degree of availability to biodegradation of pollutants in contaminated soil or land. 2) Degree of ability to be absorbed and ready to interact in organism metabolism. [definition source: 1) K. ten Kate & S.A. Laird. 1999. The Commercial Use of Biodiversity - Access to Genetic Resources and Benefit-Sharing. European Commission. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary. Montreal.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wit.definition: Annual total abstraction of fresh water divided by the long-term average freshwater resources. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wit.name: withdrawal ratio

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pas.definition: This indicator is defined as the ratio between passenger-km (inland modes) and GDP (Gross Domestic Product in constant 1995 EUR). It is indexed on 1995. The unit used is the passenger-kilometre (pkm), which represents one passenger travelling a distance of one kilometre. It is based on transport by passenger cars, buses and coaches, and trains. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pas.name: passenger transport intensity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.definition: Marine fish farming (aquaculture). Raising of marine animals and plants in the ocean. [definition source: FAO fisheries glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.name: mariculture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.definition: Processes which employ aerobic or anaerobic microorganisms and result in decanted effluents and separated sludge containing microbial mass together with pollutants. Biological treatment processes are also used in combination and/or in conjunction with mechanical and advanced unit operations. Similar to secondary treatment. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sec.name: secondary treatment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bla.name: black smoke
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bla.objecttrans_hu: {AIRCHA} légszennyeződés (légszűrő berendezés filterében megakadt szilárd halmazállapotú szennyezőanyagok)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bla.objecttrans_fi: ilman leijuma, joka määritetään sen tahran mustuuden perusteella, joka syntyy ilman läpäistessä suodatinpaperin
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bla.definition: The fraction of the total suspended particulates in air determined from the blackness measurement of the stain produced by passing the air through standard filter paper. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objecttrans_es: hábitats de aguas superficiales de interior
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objectname_pt: habitats de águas interiores de superfície
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objectname_es: hábitats de aguas superficiales de interior
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.name: inland surface water habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objecttrans_pt: habitats de águas interiores de superfície
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objectname_fr: habitats des eaux intérieures de surface
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objectname_ro: habitate încorporate de ape de suprafaţă
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objecttrans_fr: habitats des eaux intérieures de surface
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. Inland surface water habitats are non-coastal above-ground open fresh or brackish waterbodies (e.g. rivers, streams, lakes and pools, springs), including their littoral zones. Also includes dune slack pools. Includes constructed inland freshwater, brackish or saline waterbodies (such as canals, ponds, etc.) which support a semi-natural community of both plants and animals; normally wet habitats which may be dry seasonally (temporary or intermittent rivers and lakes and their littoral zones). Freshwater littoral zones include those parts of banks or shores which are sufficiently frequently inundated to prevent the formation of closed terrestrial vegetation. Excludes permanent snow and ice. Note that habitats which intimately combine waterlogged habitats with pools of open water are considered as complexes. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inl.objecttrans_ro: habitate încorporate de ape de suprafaţă

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vit.definition: Formation of a glassy or noncrystalline material. Also a method of immobilizing waste that produces a glass-like solid that permanently captures the radioactive materials. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_V_vit.name: vitrification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_t.definition: Synonyms: tonne [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_t.name: t

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ISS.definition: Synonyms: International Standard Statistical Classification of Aquatic Animals and Plants [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ISS.name: ISSCAAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: A zone separating the emergent continents from the deep-sea bottom; generally consists of the continental shelf, slope, and rise. [definition source: Fishbase glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: continental margin

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_hu: {soi} földcsuszamlás, sziklaomlás, hegyomlás; {nathaz} földcsuszamlás, sziklaomlás, hegyomlás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landslide
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_hu: {SOI} földcsuszamlás, sziklaomlás, hegyomlás; {NATHAZ} földcsuszamlás, sziklaomlás, hegyomlás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Mass-movement landforms and processes involving the downslope transport, under gravitationary influence of soil and rock material en masse. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eq.definition: Synonyms: equivalent [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eq.name: eq

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NMV.definition: Organic chemical compounds, excluding methane, that under normal conditions can vaporise and enter the atmosphere. NMVOCs include such compounds as benzene, xylene, propane and butane. NMVOCs are mainly emitted from transportation, industrial processes and use of organic solvents. See also VOCs. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NMV.name: NMVOC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NO3.definition: Inorganic form of nitrogen. An important plant nutrient and type of inorganic fertilizer (most highly oxidized phase in the nitrogen cycle). In water, the major sources of nitrates are septic tanks, feed lots and fertilizers. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NO3.name: NO3

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.name: radionuclide
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.definition: Radioactive particle, man-made (anthropogenic) or natural, with a distinct atomic weight number. Can have a long life as soil or water pollutant. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological economics
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Questions of the social costs and benefits that accompany issues relating to pollution, resource depletion, and environmental degradation fall within the area of environmental economics. Few today would disagree that a factory emitting large amounts of smoke causes air pollution, which affects the health of local residents. A fundamental issue in environmental economics is the assessment of the costs of that pollution to the residents, in terms of illness; to society, in terms of health-care costs and lost work time; and, ultimately, to the world, as the factory smoke contributes to the formation of acid rain and may increase the likelihood of global warming. Equally important, however, is the inclusion in the cost equation, of the values created by the activities of the polluting factory: the usefulness of its products and the worth of the jobs it creates. [definition source: AMES Laboratory. US Department of Energy.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.definition: Synonyms: CCMS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.name: Committee on the Challenges of Modern Society
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.objecttrans_en: Committee on the Challenges of Modern Society
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Com.objectname_en: committee on the challenges of modern society

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Synonyms: NEHAP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Environment and Health Action Plan
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objecttrans_en: National Environment and Health Action Plan
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objectname_en: national environment and health action plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste operator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objectname_bg: собственик (оператор) на съоръжение за третиране (обезвреждане) на отпадъци
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.objecttrans_bg: собственик (оператор) на съоръжение за третиране (обезвреждане) на отпадъци

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_KEO.definition: Synonyms: Carpathians Environment Outlook [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_KEO.name: KEO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAM.definition: NAMEA (national accounting matrix including environmental accounts) is an environmental accounting framework developed by Statistics Netherlands at the end of the 1980s. It consists of a conventional national accounting matrix extended with environmental accounts in physical units. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NAM.name: NAMEA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FIS.definition: Synonyms: software for fishery statistics [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FIS.name: FISHSTAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil compaction
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: An increase in bulk density (mass per unit volume) and a decrease in soil porosity resulting from applied loads, vibration or pressure. More compacted soils (or other materials) can support greater loads (load-bearing capacity). Bulk density can be increased by controlling the moisture content, compaction forces and treatment procedures, as well as by manipulating the type of material being compacted. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nor.definition: Synonyms: NSR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nor.name: Northern Sea Route

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Sustainable development indicators are indicators that measure progress made in sustainable growth and development. They can provide an early warning, sounding the alarm in time to prevent economic, social and environmental damage. They are also important tools to communicate ideas of sustainable development. Indicators for monitoring progress towards sustainable development are needed in order to assist decision-makers and policy-makers at all levels and to increase focus on sustainable development. Beyond the commonly used economic indicators of well-being, however, social, environmental and institutional indicators have to be taken into account as well to arrive at a broader, more complete picture of societal development. A core set of 58 indicators and methodology sheets are now available for all countries to use. This core set was adopted by the Commission on Sustainable Development (CSD) at its Third Session in April 1995. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable developent indicators

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.definition: The multi-billion-dollar global environment facility (GEF) was established by the World Bank, UNDP and UNEP in 1990. It operates the Convention on Biological Diversity's 'financial mechanism' on an interim basis and funds developing-country projects that have global biodiversity benefits. [definition source: CUB. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_glo.name: global environment facility

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO2.definition: A metric measure used to compare the emissions from various greenhouse gases based upon their global warming potential (GWP). Carbon dioxide equivalents are commonly expressed as 'million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents (MMTCDE)'. The carbon dioxide equivalent for a gas is derived by multiplying the tonnes of the gas by the associated GWP. MMTCDE = (million metric tonnes of a gas) * (GWP of the gas). For example, the GWP for methane is 21 and for nitrous oxide 310. This means that emissions of 1million metric tonnes of methane and nitrous oxide respectively is equivalent to emissions of 21 and 310 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide. [definition source: EEA, based on: IPCC Third Assessment Report, 2001]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO2.name: CO2 equivalent

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Applying a monetary rate or value at which water can be bought or sold. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water tarrifing

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FSA.definition: Synonyms: Food Standards Agency [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FSA.name: FSA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: The physical course a chemical or pollutant takes from its source to the exposed organism. [definition source: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure pathway

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.name: drinking water
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dri.definition: Water intended for human consumption. According to the drinking water dDirective it shall mean: (a) all water either in its original state or after treatment, intended for drinking, cooking, food preparation or other domestic purposes, regardless of its origin and whether it is supplied from a distribution network, from a tanker, or in bottles or containers; (b) all water used in any food-production undertaking for the manufacture, processing, preservation or marketing of products or substances intended for human consumption unless the competent national authorities are satisfied that the quality of the water cannot affect the wholesomeness of the foodstuff in its finished form. [definition source: Directive 98/83/EC of 3 November 1998 on the quality of water intended for human consumption.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: Comprehensive statements of the objectives and policies which a local transport authority intends to pursue; it includes an estimate of transport expenditure, a statement of transport objectives, etc. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: transport policy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pri.definition: Primary energy consumption is defined by the Energy Efficiency Directive (2013/12/EU) as gross inland energy consumption minus non-energy uses. [definition source: Directive 2013/12/EU]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pri.name: Primary energy consumption

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: индикатор за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: индикатор за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A parameter or a value derived from parameters that describe the state of the environment and its impact on human beings, ecosystems and materials, the pressures on the environment, the driving forces and the responses steering that system. An indicator has gone through a selection and/or aggregation process to enable it to steer action. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.definition: 1) The loss of nitrogen from soil by biological or chemical means. It is a gaseous loss, unrelated to loss by physical processes such as through leachates. 2) The breakdown of nitrates by soil bacteria, resulting in the release of free nitrogen. This process takes place under anaerobic conditions, such as are found in water-logged soil, and it reduces soil fertility. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nit.name: nitrogen removal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nor.name: normative scenario
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nor.definition: Normative scenarios take values and interests into account. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Cloudy crystal balls. Environmental issues series No 17]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The EWC is a hierarchical list of waste descriptions established by Commission decision 2000/532/EC2. It is divided into twenty main chapters, most of which are industry-based but some of which are based on materials and processes. Each of these has a two digit code between 01 and 20. Chapters have one or more subchapters (with four figure codes, the first two of which are the two digits of the chapter). Within these there are codes for individual wastes each of which is assigned a six figure code. Hazardous wastes are signified by entries where the code is followed by an asterisk. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European waste catalogue

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MSC.definition: Synonyms: Meteorological Synthesizing Centre-East [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MSC.name: MSC-East

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PRT.definition: Synonyms: Pollutant Release and Transfer Register [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PRT.name: PRTR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MCP.definition: Synonyms: Ministerial Conference on the Protection of Forests in Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MCP.name: MCPFE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Materials that are not prime products (that is, products produced for the market) for which the generator has no further use in terms of his/her own purposes of production, transformation or consumption, and of which he/she wants to dispose. Wastes may be generated during the extraction of raw materials, the processing of raw materials into intermediate and final products, the consumption of final products, and other human activities. Residuals recycled or reused at the place of generation are excluded. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_Joi.definition: The JRC is a Directorate-General of the European Commission under the responsibility of Louis Michel, European Commissioner for Research. Its Board of Governors assists and advices the Director General on matters relating to the role and the scientific, technical and financial management of the JRC.The Directorate-General is located in Brussels. The seven JRC institutes are located on five separate sites in Belgium, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain. The Institutes are: Institute for Reference Materials and Measurements (IRMM), Institute for Transuranium Elements (ITU), Institute for Energy (IE), Institute for the Protection and the Security of the Citizen (IPSC), Institute for Environment and Sustainability (IES), Institute for Health and Consumer Protection (IHCP), Institute for Prospective Technological Studies (IPTS). In Brussels is the Institutional and Scientific relations Directorate and the Programme and Resource Management Directorate is based in Brussels and in Ispra, Italy. The Ispra Site Directorate is responsible for the site management and for the nuclear decommissioning, safety, security and protection. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_Joi.name: Joint Research Centre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CI.definition: Synonyms: confidence interval [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CI.name: CI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exo.objectname_de: nicht heimische art, nicht einheimische art/arten
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exo.objecttrans_de: nicht heimische Art, nicht einheimische Art/Arten
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exo.name: exotic species

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEM.definition: Digital Terrain Models (DTM) sometimes called Digital Elevation Models (DEM) is a topographic model of the bare Earth that can be manipulated by computer programs.The data files contain the elevation data of the terrain in a digital format which relates to a rectangular grid. Vegetation, buildings and other cultural features are removed digitally - leaving just the underlying terrain.DTMs are used especially in civil engineering, geodesy & surveying, geophysics, geography and remote sensing. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEM.name: DEM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_epi.definition: Something that takes place or comes to pass. Occurrence and happening are the most general: an everyday occurrence; a happening of no great importance.Event usually signifies a notable occurrence: major world events reported on the evening news. 'Great events make me quiet and calm; it is only trifles that irritate my nerves' Victoria.Incident may apply to a minor occurrence: a small incident blown out of proportion.The term may also refer to a distinct event of sharp identity and significance: a succession of exciting incidents.An episode is an incident in the course of a progression or within a larger sequence: 'Happiness was but the occasional episode in a general drama of pain' Thomas Hardy.Circumstance denotes a particular incident or occurrence: 'Billy had found Alice, thus bringing about the odd circumstance of their renewing their acquaintanceship' Eleanor H. Porter. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_epi.name: episode

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNHCR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations high commissioner for refugees

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: Terrestrial environment information system (TERRIS) is the geographical information system that contains the geo-referenced information available at the EEA, organised in an optimum and consistent way. TERRIS allows managing the relevant data for the calculation and maintenance of a core set of indicators related to land and soil issues. [definition source: ETC/TE.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: terrestrial environment information system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.definition: Species of fish that live on, or in close proximity to, the seabed. The term also applies to fishing gear that is worked on the seabed. [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dem.name: demersal

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_el: MDIAR (κύκλωμα παρακολούθησης, δεδομένων, πληροφοριών, εκτίμησης και υποβολής εκθέσεων του ΕΙΟΝΕΤ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_lv: mdiar, eionet monitoringa, datu un informācijas apstrādes tīkls
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_hu: {eio} megfigyelés, adatkezelés, információ, számvitel és értesítési lánc (az eionet értéklánca)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_es: MDIAR (Monitoring, Data, Information, Assessment and Reporting)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_is: Eftirlits-, gagna, upplýsinga-, mats- og skýrslugerðarkeðja EIONET (MDIAR)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_da: mdiar (monitoring, data, information, assessment and reporting) (=overvågning, data, oplysninger, vurdering og rapportering)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_pl: mdiar, łańcuch monitorowania, danych, informacji, oceny i sprawozdawczości w ramach eionet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_da: MDIAR (Monitoring, Data, Information, Assessment and Reporting) (=Overvågning, data, oplysninger, vurdering og rapportering)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_is: eftirlits-, gagna, upplýsinga-, mats- og skýrslugerðarkeðja eionet (mdiar)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_es: mdiar (monitoring, data, information, assessment and reporting)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.name: MDIAR
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_pl: MDIAR, łańcuch monitorowania, danych, informacji, oceny i sprawozdawczości w ramach EIONET
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_hu: {EIO} megfigyelés, adatkezelés, információ, számvitel és értesítési lánc (az EIONET értéklánca)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_lv: MDIAR, EIONET monitoringa, datu un informācijas apstrādes tīkls
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_el: mdiar (κύκλωμα παρακολούθησης, δεδομένων, πληροφοριών, εκτίμησης και υποβολής εκθέσεων του ειονετ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_fi: eionetin seuranta-, tieto-, informointi-, arviointi- ja raportointiketju
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objectname_bg: мдиар - система от стойности за мониторинг, данни, информация, оценка и докладване в еионет
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_fi: EIONETin seuranta-, tieto-, informointi-, arviointi- ja raportointiketju
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.objecttrans_bg: МДИАР - система от стойности за мониторинг, данни, информация, оценка и докладване в ЕИОНЕТ
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MDI.definition: The monitoring/data/information/assessment/reporting (MDIAR) chain is the flow of data and information from national monitoring to European reporting. [definition source: EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCH.definition: Synonyms: hexachlorocyclohexane [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCH.name: HCH

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.name: Scientific Committee
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sci.definition: The EEA Management Board appoints a Scientific Committee (SC), that assists the Management Board and the Executive Director on any scientific matter concerning the EEA's activity. The SC consists of up to 20 members appointed for four years. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Blu.definition: 'Plan Bleu' (Blue Plan) has several meanings: a process of reflection on the Mediterranean region in all its vastness and complexity; a research centre where this reflective process is carried out; and the infrastructure of a non-profit organisation for management and operations. [definition source: Plan Bleu website.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Blu.name: Blue Plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCB.definition: Synonyms: hexachlorobenzene [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HCB.name: HCB

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: permafrost
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.objectname_bg: трайно замръзнала земя, вечно замръзнала почва
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.objecttrans_bg: трайно замръзнала земя, вечно замръзнала почва
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Soil, silt and rock located in perpetually cold areas which remains frozen year-round. Though a thin layer may thaw during summer months, the majority of the permafrost in a given location will remain frozen until the local climate dramatically changes, as from continental drift toward the equator or global warming. [definition source: Geological Society of America Bulletin; v.100; p.948; 1988. Science; v.234; p.689; 1986. Quoted by: Sam Houston State University. United States. Atmospheric Chemistry Glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PNE.definition: An ecotoxicological measure for multiple species systems. It can be defined as the concentration below which a specified percentage of species in an ecosystem are expected to be protected. [definition source: Adapted from: David W. Pennington. Extrapolating ecotoxicological measures from small data sets.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PNE.name: PNEC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HEL.definition: The Helsinki Commission (HELCOM) administers the Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment of the Baltic Sea Area, 1992 (entered into force on 17 January 2000), also called Helsinki Convention. [definition source: HELCOM website (]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HEL.name: HELCOM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.name: coastal ecosystem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_coa.definition: Marine environments bounded by the coastal land margin (seashore) and the continental shelf 100-200 m below sea level. Ecologically, the coastal and nearshore zones grade from shallow water depths, influenced by the adjacent landmass and input from coastal rivers and estuaries, to the continental shelf break, where oceanic processes predominate. Among the unique marine ecosystems associated with coastal and nearshore waterbodies are seaweed-dominated communities, coral reefs and upwellings. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCM.definition: Synonyms: World Conservation Monitoring Centre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WCM.name: WCMC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.name: discharge
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dis.definition: 1) Wastewater discharge means the amount of water (in m3) or substance (in kg BOD/d or comparable) added /leached to a water body from a point or a non point source. 2) Sewage effluent (or discharge) means treated sewage discharged from a sewage treatment plant. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on inland waters]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: (1) Removal of large solids, oils, fat and other material from sewage so as to protect wastewater treatment facilities engaged in further treatment. (2) The first stage of wastewater treatment which removes debris, sand, grit and fine particles. [definition source: (1) United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: pretreatment (of wastewater)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chl.name: chlorofluorocarbon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chl.definition: Gases formed of chlorine, fluorine and carbon whose molecules normally do not react with other substances; they are therefore used as spray can propellants because they do not alter the material being sprayed. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MTF.definition: Synonyms: maximum feasible technical reduction [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MTF.name: MTFR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Applying a monetary rate or value at which water can be bought or sold. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water pricing

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.definition: Forest stands established by planting or/and seeding in the process of afforestation or reforestation. They are either: A) of introduced species (all planted stands), or B) intensively managed stands of indigenous species which meet all the following criteria: one or two species at plantation, even age class, regular spacing. It excludes stands which are established as plantations but which have been without intense management for a significant period of time; these should be considered semi-natural. [definition source: TBRA 2000]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pla.name: plantation forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.definition: Accidental release of radiation occurring in civil nuclear facilities, exceeding the internationally established safety levels. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nuc.name: nuclear accident

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MIO.definition: Synonyms: Mediterranean Information Office for Environment, Culture and Sustainable Development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MIO.name: MIO-ECSDE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cop.definition: The practice of cutting trees at or near the ground and allowing it to sprout from the stamp to generate a new crop of poles. [definition source: The Encyclopedia of Ecology & Environment Management. Ed. Peter Calow. Blackwell Science Ltd. 1998.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cop.name: coppice

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bes.name: best available techniques
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bes.objectname_bg: най-добрите техники, технологии, които са на разположение
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bes.objecttrans_bg: най-добрите техники, технологии, които са на разположение
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bes.definition: The most effective and advanced stage in the development of activities and their methods of operation which indicate the practical suitability of particular techniques for providing in principle the basis for emission limit values designed to prevent and, where that is not practicable, generally to reduce emissions and impact on the environment as a whole. [definition source: Directive 96/61/EC of 24 September 1996 concerning integrated pollution prevention and control.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dan.definition: Synonyms: DEPA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dan.name: Danish Environmental Protection Agency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: Waste generated in the fuel cells of a nuclear reactor. It is typically stored at reactor sites and nuclear fuel reprocessing plants. In the absence of shielding, it represents a serious health threat. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.name: high-level radioactive waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: Synonyms: SST [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: sea surface temperature

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Reg.definition: Synonyms: CAREC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Reg.name: Regional Environmental Centre for Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Reg.objecttrans_en: Regional Environmental Centre for Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Reg.objectname_en: regional environmental centre for central asia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: An official record proving that a specified amount of green electricity has been generated. Green certificates represent the environmental value of renewable energy production. The certificates can be traded separately from the energy produced. [definition source: Reinhard Haas (ed). 2001. Promotion strategies for electricity from renewable energy sources in EU countries.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green certificate (electricity)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_unt.name: untreated wastewater
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_unt.definition: Wastewater discharged without any wastewater treatment. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 168. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lun.definition: The volume of air the lungs can hold. Lung capacity depends on a person's age, weight, sex and the degree of physical activity. The total lung capacity of an average-sized adult male is about five litres. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lun.name: lung capacity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNW.definition: Synonyms: United Nations World Tourism Organisation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNW.name: UNWTO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_sl: soglasje, ki temelji na predhodnem poznavanju okoliščin
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_lv: pic, procedūra informācijas saņemšanai par importējamajām potenciāli bīstamajām ķimikālijām
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_pt: procedimento da prévia informação e consentimento
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.name: prior informed consent
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_lv: PIC, procedūra informācijas saņemšanai par importējamajām potenciāli bīstamajām ķimikālijām
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_pt: procedimento da prévia informação e consentimento
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_sl: soglasje, ki temelji na predhodnem poznavanju okoliščin
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objectname_bg: съгласие, което се дава след запознаване с обстоятелствата, съгласие на база предварително осведомяване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.objecttrans_bg: съгласие, което се дава след запознаване с обстоятелствата, съгласие на база предварително осведомяване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pri.definition: Procedure that helps participating countries learn more about the characteristics of potentially hazardous chemicals that may be shipped to them, initiates a decision making process on the future import of these chemicals by the countries themselves and facilitates the dissemination of this decision to other countries. The aim is to promote a shared responsibility between exporting and importing countries in protecting human health and the environment from the harmful effects of certain hazardous chemicals being traded internationally. [definition source: FAO International Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.objectname_hu: {agrare} biogazdálkodás, biológiai gazdálkodás, organikus gazdálkodás, ökologikus gazdálkodás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organic agriculture
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.objecttrans_hu: {AGRARE} biogazdálkodás, biológiai gazdálkodás, organikus gazdálkodás, ökologikus gazdálkodás
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: A method of production, which puts the highest emphasis on environmental protection and, with regard to livestock production, animal welfare considerations. It avoids or largely reduces the use of synthetic chemical inputs such as fertilisers, pesticides, additives and medical products. [definition source: DG Agriculture. Organic farming in the EU - Fact and figures.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lig.definition: Coal of relatively recent origin consisting of accumulated layers of partially decomposed vegetation, intermediate between peat and bituminous coal; often contains patterns from the wood from which it is formed. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lig.name: lignite

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_it: determinazione del prezzo di base in base al costo pieno, prezzatura al costo pieno
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_da: salgsprisberegning på grundlag af de samlede omkostninger
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_pl: kalkulacja cen z uwzględnieniem pełnych kosztów
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_da: salgsprisberegning på grundlag af de samlede omkostninger
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_it: determinazione del prezzo di base in base al costo pieno, prezzatura al costo pieno
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_pt: fixação de preços tendo em conta os custos totais
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.name: full cost pricing
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_pl: kalkulacja cen z uwzględnieniem pełnych kosztów
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_pt: fixação de preços tendo em conta os custos totais
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_fr: fixation du prix en fonction du coût total
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_nl: prijsbepaling op grond van de totale kosten
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objectname_ro: fixarea preţului în funcţie de cheltuielile totale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_fr: fixation du prix en fonction du coût total
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.definition: The pricing of commercial goods, such as electric power, that would include in the final prices faced by the end user not only the private costs of inputs, but also the costs of the externalities created by their production and use. [definition source: Inter Governmental Panel on Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_ro: Fixarea preţului în funcţie de cheltuielile totale
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.objecttrans_nl: prijsbepaling op grond van de totale kosten

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BWD.definition: In the 1970's, Europe decided that bathing water quality should be monitored and tested in order to protect bathers from health risks and to preserve the environment from pollution. This resulted in 1976 in one of the first pieces of European environmental legislation: the Council Directive 76/160/EEC on Bathing Water Quality.The Directive was updated in 2002. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BWD.name: BWD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bir.definition: The EU Directive on the conservation of wild birds (79/49/EEC) seeks to protect all wild birds and the habitats of listed species, in particular through the designation of special protection areas (SPA). [definition source: Countryside Council for Wales. 2001. A glossary on marine nature conservation and fisheries. United Kingdom.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bir.name: Birds Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: An action plan or system which addresses the how, when, who, where and what of integrating environmental mitigation and monitoring measures throughout an existing or proposed operation or activity. It encompasses all the elements that are sometimes addressed separately in mitigation, monitoring and action plans. [definition source: European Commission. Environmental Integration Manual.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental management plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAC.definition: Site designated according to the habitats directive. Special area of conservation means a site of Community importance designated by the Member States through a statutory, administrative and/or contractual act where the necessary conservation measures are applied for the maintenance or restoration, at a favourable conservation status, of the natural habitats and/or the populations of the species for which the site is designated. [definition source: Directive 92/43/EEC of 21 May 1992 on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora (art.1).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAC.name: SAC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dat.definition: Process by which data sets are distributed among organisations and users. Information about the source of each data set and its geographical and temporal coverage is attached as metadata. Rules about distribution are written in data sharing protocols, copyrights or relevant contracts. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dat.name: data distribution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_sk: pravidelne alebo novo obhospodarované poľnohospodárske, záhradné a domáce lokality
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_sl: redno ali nedavno obdelani kmetijski, hortikulturni in hini habitati
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_el: τακτικά ή πρόσφατα καλλιεργηθέντες γεωργικοί, φυτοκομικοί και οικιστικοί οικότοποι
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_en: regularly or recently cultivated agricultural, horticultural and domestic habitats
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_lv: regulāri vai pēdējā laikā kultivēti lauksaimniecības, dārzkopības un mājas biotipi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_lt: reguliariai kultivuojamos arba neseniai pradėtos kultivuoti emės ūkio, gėlininkystės ir namų ūkio buveinės
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_et: regulaarselt kultiveeritavad või hiljuti kultiveeritud põllumajanduslikud, aianduslikud või kodused elupaigad ja kasvukohad
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_hu: általánosan vagy nemrégiben mezőgazdasági, kertészeti vagy háztartási használat alá vett terület
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_es: hábitats agrícolas, hortícolas y domésticos cultivados reciente o regularmente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_sv: livsmiljöer på regelbundet eller nyligen odlad jordbruks- eller trädgårdsmark
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objecttrans_is: búland, skrúðgarðaland eða heimabúsvæði í reglulegri rækt eða í rækt þar til fyrir skemmstu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.definition: One of the main habitat types in the EUNIS habitats classification. They are habitats maintained solely by frequent tilling or arising from recent abandonment of previously tilled ground such as arable land and gardens. Includes tilled ground subject to inundation. Excludes shrub orchards, tree nurseries and tree-crop plantations. [definition source: Davies, C. E. and Moss, D. 1999. Quoted by: EUNIS. EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.objectname_cs: stanoviště pravidelně nebo nedávno obdělávané zemědělské a zahradní půdy a půdy v lidské péči

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_noi.definition: Noise consists of all unwanted sound; sound that is loud, unpleasant or unexpected. [definition source: European Commission. Commission Green Paper, of 4 November 1996, on future noise policy]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sir.objectname_en: sir alister hardy foundation for ocean sciences

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NO2.name: NO2
