glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.objectname_en: national snow and ice data centre

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European topic centre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: ETCs are institutions/organisations contracted by the EEA to execute tasks identified in the multiannual work programme. They are designated by the management board after a competitive expertise/capacity selection process. Guiding principles for selection should be the cost-efficient use of existing and potential capacities in the member countries and avoidance of duplication of work and capacities. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEP.definition: Synonyms: Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CEP.name: CEPF

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Processes concerning living organisms. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biological process

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: Toxic and persistent chemical used as electric insulator. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: polychlorinated triphenyl

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objectname_pl: polityka przedsiębiorstwa w odniesieniu do środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: company environmental policy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.objecttrans_pl: polityka przedsiębiorstwa w odniesieniu do środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: In Eco-management and Auditing Scheme, environmental policy means the company's overall aims and principles of action with respect to the environment including compliance with all relevant regulatory requirements regarding the environment. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECD.definition: Synonyms: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ECD.name: ECDC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_psu.definition: Synonyms: practical salinity units [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_psu.name: psu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: Synonyms: ETS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.name: emissions trading scheme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.objecttrans_el: εξαφανισθέν είδος / είδος που έχει εκλείψει
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: extinct species
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.objectname_el: εξαφανισθέν είδος / είδος που έχει εκλείψει
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: A species is presumed extinct when exhaustive surveys in known and/or expected habitat, at appropriate times (diurnal, seasonal, annual) throughout its historic range failed to record an individual. [definition source: IUCN Red List Categories]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIP.definition: Synonyms: environmental impact of products [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EIP.name: EIPRO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: UNWTO [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations World Tourism Organisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO.definition: Colourless, odourless, tasteless, non-corrosive, highly poisonous gas of about the same density as that of air. Very flammable, burning in air with bright blue flame. Although each molecule of CO has one carbon atom and one oxygen atom, it has a shape similar to that of an oxygen molecule (two atoms of oxygen), which is important with regard to its lethality. (Source: PHYMAC). [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CO.name: CO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: The term 'high-speed traffic' encompasses all trains running at speeds over 200 km/h but also trains running at 200 km/h if the terrain, population density or economic reasons do not justify higher speeds. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.name: high speed railway

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.name: geographic information system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_geo.definition: Group of principles, methods, instruments and geo-referenced data used to capture, store, extract, measure, transform, analyse and map phenomena and processes in a given geographic area. [definition source: Fisheries and Oceans Canada.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mac.definition: An individual alga large enough to be seen easily with the unaided eye. [definition source: State University of New York at Stony Brook. Glossary on marine biology.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mac.name: macrophyte

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hem.definition: One-half of the Earth (or other planetary or stellar body; see also New World and Old World) Eastern Hemisphere and Western Hemisphere, Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hem.name: hemisphere

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objectname_lv: transatlantiskais biznesa dialogs (eiropas un asv vides aģentūru sadarbība privātā sektora jomā)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objecttrans_es: Diálogo transatlántico sobre el sector privado
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objectname_pt: cooperação transatlântica entre agências do ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objectname_es: diálogo transatlántico sobre el sector privado
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.name: Transatlantic Business Dialogue
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objecttrans_lv: Transatlantiskais biznesa dialogs (Eiropas un ASV vides aģentūru sadarbība privātā sektora jomā)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.objecttrans_pt: Cooperação Transatlântica entre Agências do Ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tra.definition: A cooperation effort of the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).The enabling idea behind the New Transatlantic Agenda from a private sector perspective (the Transatlantic Business Dialogue) concerns the search for best practices, mutual interests, and cost effectiveness. [definition source: EEA]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cef.definition: Synonyms: European Chemical Industry Council [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cef.name: Cefic

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dig.definition: Digital Terrain Models (DTM) sometimes called Digital Elevation Models (DEM) is a topographic model of the bare Earth that can be manipulated by computer programs.The data files contain the elevation data of the terrain in a digital format which relates to a rectangular grid. Vegetation, buildings and other cultural features are removed digitally - leaving just the underlying terrain.DTMs are used especially in civil engineering, geodesy & surveying, geophysics, geography and remote sensing. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dig.name: digital terrain model

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.definition: Synonyms: MTFR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.name: maximum feasible technical reduction

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biodiversity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: 1) Genetic diversity: the variation between individuals and between populations within a species; species diversity: the different types of plants, animals and other life forms within a region; community or ecosystem diversity: the variety of habitats found within an area (grassland, marsh, and woodland for instance. 2) An umbrella term to describe collectively the variety and variability of nature. It encompasses three basic levels of organisation in living systems: the genetic, species, and ecosystem levels. Plant and animal species are the most commonly recognized units of biological diversity, thus public concern has been mainly devoted to conserving species diversity. (Source: WRES / GILP96) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.definition: The aim of Directive 94/67/EC on the incineration of hazardous waste is to provide for measures and procedures to prevent or, where that is not practicable, to reduce as fas as possible negative effects on the environment, in particular the pollution of air, soil, surface and groundwater, and the resulting risks to human health, from the incineration of hazardous waste and, to that end, to set up and maintain appropriate operating conditions and emission limit values for hazardous waste incineration plants within the Community. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_Was.name: Waste incineration directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.definition: Discharge of effluent from wastewater treatment plants which receive wastewater from households, commercial establishments, and industries. Combined sewer/separate storm overflows are included in this category. [definition source: Based on: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.name: municipal discharge

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICE.definition: The International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) is the oldest intergovernmental organisation in the world concerned with marine and fisheries science. The council was first established in Copenhagen in 1902, but now operates under the terms of the 1964 Convention for the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea. Since its establishment in 1902, ICES has been a leading scientific forum for the exchange of information and ideas on the sea and its living resources, and for the promotion and coordination of marine research by scientists within its member countries. The area of competence of the council is, broadly speaking, the Atlantic Ocean and its adjacent seas, with an emphasis on the North Atlantic. There is no precise delimitation of this area. [definition source: Internet guide to international fisheries law.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICE.name: ICES

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Met.definition: Synonyms: MSC-East [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Met.name: Meteorological Synthesizing Centre-East

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WFD.definition: Directive 2000/60/EC establishing a framework for the Community action in the field of water policy. It aims to secure the ecological, quantitative and qualitative functions of water. It requires that all impacts on water will have to be analysed and actions will have to be taken within river basin management plans. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. The soil protection communication (draft October 2001). Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WFD.name: WFD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.definition: The process of estimating or measuring the intensity, frequency, and duration of exposure to an agent. Ideally, it describes the sources, pathways, routes, magnitude, duration, and patters of exposure; the characteristics of the population exposed; and the uncertainties in the assessment. [definition source: The international programme on chemical safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exp.name: exposure assessment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biomagnification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_nl: stapsgewijs toenemende bioaccumulatie (van één trofisch niveau naar de volgende)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_bg: нарастване, увеличение по биологичен път, магнификация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_bg: нарастване, увеличение по биологичен път, магнификация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Bioaccumulation through ingestion of prey items, such that contaminant concentration increases from one trophic level to the next. [definition source: European Commission, DG Environment. 1999. Compilation of EU dioxin exposure and health data. Task 7 - Ecotoxicology.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_nl: stapsgewijs toenemende bioaccumulatie (van één trofisch niveau naar de volgende)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.definition: Synonyms: ACAP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Arc.name: Arctic Council Action Plan

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: Synonyms: SD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CER.definition: Synonyms: certified emission reductions [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CER.name: CERs

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: A dynamic association of crops, pastures, livestock, other flora and fauna, atmosphere, soils, and water. Agroecosystems are contained within larger landscapes that include uncultivated land, drainage networks, rural communities, and wildlife. [definition source: US EPA. Mid-Atlantic integrated assessment. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agroecosystem

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIF.definition: Synonyms: Cross-compliance Indicators in the context of the Farm Advisory System [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CIF.name: CIFAS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objectname_lv: aizvietotājindikators (parādību vai situāciju pētīšanai, par kurām nav pieejama nepastarpināta informācija)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objecttrans_is: vísir án beinna forsendna úr gögnum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objectname_is: vísir án beinna forsendna úr gögnum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.name: proxy indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objecttrans_lv: aizvietotājindikators (parādību vai situāciju pētīšanai, par kurām nav pieejama nepastarpināta informācija)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objectname_fi: tieto, jonka avulla tutkitaan tilannetta, jota varten ei ole saatavilla suoranaisia mitattuja tietoja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.objecttrans_fi: tieto, jonka avulla tutkitaan tilannetta, jota varten ei ole saatavilla suoranaisia mitattuja tietoja
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.definition: Proxy data: data used to study a situation, phenomenon or condition for which no direct information - such as instrumental measurements - is available. [definition source: Kemp, David D. 1998. The environment dictionary. Routledge. London.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.definition: The second of four steps in risk assessment, consisting of the analysis of the relationship between the total amount of an agent absorbed by a group of organisms and the changes developed in the group in reaction to the agent, and inferences derived from such an analysis with respect to the entire population. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.name: dose-response assessment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.definition: A programme of action to provide for present and future demands for movement of people and goods. Such a programme is preceded by a transport study and necessarily includes consideration of the various modes of transport. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tra.name: transport planning

This directive concerns the collection, treatment and discharge of urban wastewater and the treatment and discharge of wastewater from certain industrial sectors. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental impact of products

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bat.definition: The aim of Directive 91/157/EEC on batteries and accumulators containing certain dangerous substances is to approximate the laws of the Member States on the recovery and controlled disposal of those spent batteries and accumulators containing dangerous substances in accordance with Annex I. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Bat.name: Batteries Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEH.definition: Synonyms: National Environment and Health Action Plan [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEH.name: NEHAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PAH.definition: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a group of compounds formed during the incomplete combustion of coal, oil, gas, wood, garbage or other organic substances. In most cases PAHs occur as a mixture of several compounds, not as a single chemical. Several PAHs are produced commercially to be used in the industrial organic synthesis. Once released into the aquatic environment, degradation by micro-organisms is often slow, leading to their accumulation in exposed sediments, soils, aquatic and terrestrial plants, fish and invertebrates. In terms of human health, prolonged exposure to PAHs can have a deleterious effect, and individuals exposed to mixtures of PAHs, [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PAH.name: PAH

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CSI.definition: For the EEA the core set of indicators is a set of story lines by theme/sector, clusters of indicators by theme/sector grouped by generic and more specific policy questions, and sets of indicator fact sheets or description sheets. Fact sheets are available for indicators that have already been developed. More information about core set of indicators is available on http://themes.eea.eu.int/indicators/coreset [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CSI.name: CSI

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.definition: The top of the water surface in the saturated part of an aquifer. [definition source: US geological survey. Water science glossary of terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gro.name: groundwater surface

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.name: chronic toxicity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.definition: The capacity of a substance to cause long-term poisonous health effects in humans, animals, fish, and other organisms. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_map.definition: A map is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional space. The science of making maps is called cartography. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_map.name: map

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU-.definition: The 15 pre-2004 EU Member States: Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, the United Kingdom [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU-.name: EU-15

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_sk: hodnotenie životného cyklu výrobku, ekologická bilancia výrobku
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life cycle assessment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objectname_fr: évaluation du cycle de la vie
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_sk: hodnotenie životného cyklu výrobku, ekologická bilancia výrobku
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.objecttrans_fr: évaluation du cycle de la vie
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: Life-cycle assessment (LCA) is a process of evaluating the effects that a product has on the environment over the entire period of its life thereby increasing resource-use efficiency and decreasing liabilities. It can be used to study the environmental impact of either a product or the function the product is designed to perform. LCA is commonly referred to as a "cradle-to-grave" analysis. LCA's key elements are: (1) identify and quantify the environmental loads involved; e.g. the energy and raw materials consumed, the emissions and wastes generated; (2) evaluate the potential environmental impacts of these loads; and (3) assess the options available for reducing these environmental impacts. [definition source: UNEP.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Synonyms: EBRD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european bank for reconstruction and development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: The renewable source of energy provided by falling water that drives the turbines. There are two types of hydroelectric power plants: a) run-of-river power plants for the use of affluent water; b) storage power plants (power stations with reservoir) where the influx can be regulated with the help of a reservoir. Mostly greater differences in altitudes are being used,like mountain creeks. Power stations with reservoirs are generally marked by barrages with earth fill dam or concrete dams. Though hydropower generally can be called environmentally acceptable, there exist also some problems: a) change of groundwater level and fill up of the river bed with rubble b) risk of dam breaks c) great demand for land space for the reservoir d) diminution,but partly also increase of value of recreation areas. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydroelectric energy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CSD.definition: Synonyms: Commission on Sustainable Development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CSD.name: CSD

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Conference of Ministers of Transport
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objecttrans_en: European Conference of Ministers of Transport
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_en: european conference of ministers of transport

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UND.name: UNDP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.definition: A way to describe how much of a substance is contained in a sample: parts of analyte per million parts of sample. In atmospheric chemistry this become volume parts of analyte per volume parts of atmosphere. [definition source: Sam Houston State University. United States. Atmospheric Chemistry Glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_ppm.objectname_cs: ppmv - jednotka pro měření množství částic polutantu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.definition: 1) Wastewater discharge means the amount of water (in m3) or substance (in kg BOD/d or comparable) added /leached to a water body from a point or a non point source. 2) Sewage effluent (or discharge) means treated sewage discharged from a sewage treatment plant. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on inland waters]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eff.name: effluent

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Synonyms: ENHIS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environment and health information system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEH.definition: Synonyms: European Environment and Health Committee [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEH.name: EEHC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biogeographical region
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Area of similar character in terms of the biota (fauna & flora) present in it. Each biogeographic region is based on similarity of composition in terms of the systematics (and hence evolutionary history) of the biota. The extent and boundaries of each region have been determined by changes in climate and the movement of continents, and accompanying changes in the physical and climatic barriers to migration. [definition source: The Encyclopedia of Ecology & Environment Management. Ed. Peter Calow. Blackwell Science Ltd. 1998.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.name: quantitative scenarios
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.objectname_bg: сценарий на база количествени индикатори и на база моделиране
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.objecttrans_bg: сценарий на база количествени индикатори и на база моделиране
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Q_qua.definition: Quantitative scenarios can provide needed numerical information in the form of tables and graphs. Thus quantitative scenarios are usually based upon models or simulations, which have the advantage of providing transparent and comprehensive sets of assumptions in the form of model equations, model inputs and coefficients. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_buf.name: buffer capacity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_buf.definition: A measure of the capacity of a solution or liquid to neutralize acids or bases. This is a measure of the capacity of water for offering a resistance to changes in pH. [definition source: Environmental Dictionary.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.definition: The Kyoto Protocol was adopted at the Third Session of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in 1997 in Kyoto, Japan. It contains legally binding commitments, in addition to those included in the UNFCCC. Countries included in Annex B of the Protocol (most OECD countries and EITs) agreed to reduce their anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (CO2, CH4, N2O, HFCs, PFCs, and SF6) by at least 5 % below 1990 levels in the commitment period 2008 to 2012. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001 impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.name: Kyoto Protocol

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_M.definition: Synonyms: million [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_M.name: M

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_roa.definition: Circulation of motor vehicles and people on the road network. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_roa.name: road traffic

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inv.name: invasive species
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inv.objectname_fi: muualta tuotu laji, joka leviää luonnonympäristöön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inv.objecttrans_fi: muualta tuotu laji, joka leviää luonnonympäristöön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inv.definition: Non-native species which threaten ecosystems, habitats or species. [definition source: UNEP/CBD/SBSTTA/6/INF/5.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.name: landscape
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: The traits, patterns, and structure of a specific geographic area, including its biological composition, its physical environment, and its anthropogenic or social patterns. An area where interacting ecosystems are grouped and repeated in similar form. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: That component of biodiversity that contributes to food and agriculture production. The term agrobiodiversity encompasses within-species, species and ecosystem diversity. [definition source: FAO. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agricultural biological diversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sco.definition: A procedure for attempting to ensure that an environmental assessment focuses on the key environmental issues associated with a project, omitting irrelevant material. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upl.definition: The elevated, typically forested lands beyond the lowlands that border rivers and coasts. [definition source: State of the coast web site.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_upl.name: uplands

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: The system consisting of the airways (nose, mouth, throat, bronchi) the lungs and the respiratory muscles that pump the air into and out of the body. See also lung function. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: respiratory system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GHS.definition: Synonyms: globally harmonized system [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GHS.name: GHS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_loa.name: loading
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_loa.definition: The influx of pollutants to a selected water body. [definition source: Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission. United States.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green gross national product
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.objectname_bg: зелен брутен национален продукт, зелен бнп

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: Primary activities involved in the extraction of non-renewable resources. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: extractive industry

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lan.definition: The Landsat program is the longest running enterprise for acqusition of imagery of Earth from space. The first Landsat satellite was launched in 1972; the most recent, Landsat 7, was launched on April 15, 1999. The instruments on the Landsat satellites have acquired millions of images. The images, archived in the United States and at Landsat receiving stations around the world, are a unique resource for global change research and applications in agriculture, geology, forestry, regional planning, education and national security. History: The program was called the Earth Resources Observation Satellites Program when it was initiated in 1966, but the name was changed to Landsat in 1975.Landsat 1 - launched July 23, 1972, terminated operations in 1978, Landsat 2 - launched January 22, 1975, terminated in 1981, Landsat 3 - launched March 5, 1978, terminated 1983, Landsat 4 - launched July 16, 1982, terminated 1993, Landsat 5 - launched March 1, 1984, Landsat 6 - launched October 5, 1993, failed to reach orbit, Landsat 7 - launched April 15, 1999. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lan.name: Landsat

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ren.definition: Energy sources that do not rely on fuels of which there are only finite stocks. The most widely used renewable source is hydroelectric power; other renewable sources are biomass energy, solar energy, tidal energy, wave energy, and wind energy. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_ren.name: renewable energy source

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.definition: Synonyms: SF6 [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.name: sulphur hexafluoride

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objectname_no: kjemikalier som produseres i svært store mengder
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objectname_ro: producţie în masă de substanţe chimice
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objecttrans_fr: produit chimique à volume de production élevé
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: Chemicals placed on the EU market in volumes exceeding 1000 tonnes per year per manufacturer or importer. [definition source: European Commission. 2001. White paper on strategy for a future chemical policy. COM(2001) 88 final. Brussels.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objecttrans_ro: Producţie în masă de substanţe chimice
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objecttrans_nl: chemische stof die in grote hoeveelheden wordt geproduceerd
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.objecttrans_no: kjemikalier som produseres i svært store mengder

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: greenhouse gas
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: A gas that contributes to the natural greenhouse effect. The Kyoto Protocol covers a basket of six greenhouse gases (GHGs) produced by human activities: carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulphur hexafluoride. Annex I Parties' emissions of these gases taken together are to be measured in terms of carbon dioxide equivalents on the basis of the gases' global warming potential. An important natural GHG that is not covered by the protocol is water vapour. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: The physical, thermal, chemical or biological processes, which change the characteristics of the waste in order to reduce its volume or hazardous nature, to facilitate its handling or to enhance recovery. [definition source: Joint OECD/Eurostat questionnaire 2002 on the state of the environment, section on waste]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.name: waste treatment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.objecttrans_is: úði, smásæjar agnir í lofti sem mynda úða [t.d. þoka, reykur]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.objectname_is: úði, smásæjar agnir í lofti sem mynda úða [t.d. þoka, reykur]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.name: aerosol
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aer.definition: System of solid or liquid particles suspended in a gaseous medium, having a negligible falling velocity. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of Environment Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mic.definition: Benthic organisms (animals or plants) whose shortest dimension is less than 0.1 mm. [definition source: State University of New York at Stony Brook. Glossary on marine biology.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mic.name: microbenthos

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.definition: The way any form of radiation (ultraviolet, visible, infrared) from the sun is absorbed scattered or returned around the earth and can be expressed as some radiation arrival rate per the unit of area of the surface. The radiation flux can be the total amount of radiation that the earth and its atmosphere absorb, convert into heat and re-emit. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rad.name: radiation flux

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.name: halocarbon
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.definition: One of a group of halogen derivatives of organic hydrogen and carbon containing compounds; the group includes monohalogen compounds (alkyl or aryl halides) and polyhalogen compounds that contain the same or different halogen atoms. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fue.name: fuel efficiency
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fue.definition: The proportion of energy released by fuel combustion that is converted into useful energy. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.definition: Farming system often practised on larger farms, characterised by low levels of inputs per unit area of land; in such situations the stocking rate, the number of livestock units per area, is low. [definition source: Adapted from: ETC/CDS. General environmental multilingual thesaurus (GEMET 2000).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ext.name: extensive agriculture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_da: rangordning ud fra indsats og resultater på miljøområdet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_da: rangordning ud fra indsats og resultater på miljøområdet
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental performance ranking
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: позиция в списъка на класиране по поведението спрямо околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: позиция в списъка на класиране по поведението спрямо околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Various assessment methods have been developed by several organisations to meet the need to identify and quantify environmental exposure in order to avoid costs, encourage awareness of environmental issues, and/or to improve financial performance. This phenomenon, which can be called environmental rating or ranking, being an ambition to equal the credit rating systems, is a practise developed during the 1990s. [definition source: International Institute for Industrial Development Economics at Lund University. 2000. Continuity, credibility and comparability. Sweden.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: A residential district situated on the outskirts of a city or town. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban fringe

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LIF.definition: Synonyms: EU financial instrument for the environment [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LIF.name: LIFE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Synonyms: EAP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environment action programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.name: high-density polyethylene
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hig.definition: A kind of plastic used in the manufacturing of bottles and other products. It produces toxic fumes when burned and is often recycled. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_abs.definition: Any exposure surface that may allow diffusion of an agent into a target. Examples of absorption barriers are the skin, lung tissue, and gastrointestinal track wall. [definition source: The international programme on chemical safety. 2001. Glossary on key exposure assessment terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_abs.name: absorption barrier

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nic.definition: The place occupied by a species in its ecosystem and its role: where it lives, what it feeds on and when it performs all its activities. [definition source: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nic.name: niche

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOx.definition: Nitrogen oxides refers to nitric oxide gas (NO) and nitrogen dioxide gas (NO2) and many other gaseous oxides containing nitrogen. The main source of these gases in urban areas are motor vehicle exhaust and indoor gas stoves and kerosene heaters. The brown haze sometimes seen over cities is mainly nitrogen oxides. These gases are also partly responsible for the generation of ozone, which is produced when nitrogen oxides react with other chemicals in the presence of sunlight. Exposure to high levels of nitrogen dioxide can interfere with the ability of blood to carry oxygen, leading to dizziness and shortness of breath. Prolonged exposure can lead to respiratory failure. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOx.name: NOx

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazard
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: A threatening event, or the probability of occurrence of a potentially damaging phenomenon within a given time period and area. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.definition: Synonyms: toe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.name: tonnes of oil equivalent

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.definition: Synonyms: GMAPS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Glo.name: Global Model of Ambient Particulates

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.definition: Accidental release occurring during the production, transportation or handling of hazardous chemical substances. [definition source: United Nations. Internationally agreed glossary of basic terms related to disaster management.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_che.name: chemical accident

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOB.definition: Synonyms: North European and Baltic Network on Invasive Alien Species [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOB.name: NOBANIS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.name: forecast
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_for.definition: An estimate or prediction of a future condition. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dam.definition: Damage means a measurable adverse change in a natural resource or measurable impairment of a natural resource service which may occur directly or indirectly. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dam.name: damage

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_INE.definition: The international nuclear event scale (INES) is a tool to promptly and consistently communicate to the public the safety significance of reported events at nuclear installations. It was designed by an international group of experts convened jointly by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Events are classified on the Scale at seven levels. [definition source: The International Atomic Energy Agency.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_INE.name: INES

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ind.name: indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ind.definition: Observed value representative of a phenomenon to study. In general, indicators quantify information by aggregating different and multiple data. The resulting information is therefore synthesised. In short, indicators simplify information that can help to reveal complex phenomena. [definition source: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: An increase in the mean level of the ocean. Eustatic sea level rise is a change in global average sea level brought about by an alteration to the volume of the world ocean. Relative sea level rise occurs where there is a net increase in the level of the ocean relative to local land movements. Climate modelers largely concentrate on estimating eustatic sea level change. Impact researchers focus on relative sea level change. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001 impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: sea level rise

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PFC.definition: Family of industrial gases included in the basket of six greenhouse gases (GHGs) covered by the Kyoto Protocol. Although total emissions are relatively small, PFCs are extremely potent GHGs, with 100-year global warming potential of between 6 500 and 9 200. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PFC.name: PFC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAC.definition: Synonyms: regional activity centre [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAC.name: RAC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.definition: Synonyms: C6H6 [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_ben.name: benzene

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon sink
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_bg: въглеродна падина' h119(гори и други екосистеми, абсорбиращи въглерод)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_bg: въглеродна падина' H119(гори и други екосистеми, абсорбиращи въглерод)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: Forests and other ecosystems that absorb carbon, thereby removing it from the atmosphere and offsetting CO2 emissions. The Kyoto Protocol allows certain human-induced sinks activities undertaken since 1990 to be counted towards Annex I Parties' emission targets. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cul.definition: The practice of growing and nurturing plants outside of their wild habitat (i.e., in gardens, nurseries, arboreta). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cul.name: cultivation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sle.definition: Sleep disturbance is self-reported noise-induced sleep disturbance and increase of noise induced awakenings during the habitual sleeping time. Sleep disturbance is seen as a health effect on its own, but may cause also after effects like mood changes, fatigue (and therewith related accidents) and other impaired functions. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sle.name: sleep disturbance

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental communication
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: комуникации в областта на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: комуникации в областта на околната среда

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DIS.definition: The overall objective of the desertification information system to support national action programmes in the Mediterranean (DIS/MED) project is to improve the capacity of national administrations in the Mediterranean countries to effectively program measures and policies to combat desertification and the effects of drought by reinforcing communication, facilitating the exchange of information and establishing a common information system to monitor the physical and socio-economic conditions in areas threatened or affected by desertification and drought and to assess the extent, severity and trends of land degradation in those areas. [definition source: UNCCD Secretariat. 2001. Desertification information system to support national action programmes in the Mediterranean (DIS/MED). Technical workshop on NAP information needs: terms of reference.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DIS.name: DIS/MED

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.definition: Synonyms: SPAs [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_spe.name: special protection areas

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SSM.definition: Synonyms: special sensor microwave/imager [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SSM.name: SSM/I

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.name: multimedia model
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objectname_fi: yhtenäinen malli useampaa ympäristön osaa varten (esim. vesi, ilma)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.objecttrans_fi: yhtenäinen malli useampaa ympäristön osaa varten (esim. vesi, ilma)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mul.definition: Multimedia models are based on the subdivision of a 'unit-world' into representative fractions of relevant media, such as the air, surface and groundwaters, soil and biota. Chemicals are distributed between the media according to certain physico-chemical properties. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 125. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIW.definition: Synonyms: Global International Waters Assessments [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GIW.name: GIWA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cru.definition: A comparatively volatile liquid bitumen composed principally of hydrocarbon, with traces of sulphur, nitrogen or oxygen compounds; can be removed from the earth in a liquid state. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cru.name: crude oil

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.definition: The gathering of information from an object or surface without direct contact. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rem.name: remote sensing

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NGO.definition: Synonyms: non-governmental organisation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NGO.name: NGO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICZ.definition: Integrated coastal zone management (ICZM) is a dynamic, multidisciplinary and iterative process to promote sustainable management of coastal zones. It covers the full cycle of information collection, planning (in its broadest sense), decision making, management and monitoring of implementation. ICZM uses the informed participation and cooperation of all stakeholders to assess the societal goals in a given coastal area, and to take actions towards meeting these objectives. ICZM seeks, over the long-term, to balance environmental, economic, social, cultural and recreational objectives, all within the limits set by natural dynamics. 'Integrated' in ICZM refers to the integration of objectives and also to the integration of the many instruments needed to meet these objectives. It means integration of all relevant policy areas, sectors, and levels of administration. It means integration of the terrestrial and marine components of the target territory, in both time and space. [definition source: CEC Communication 2000/547 ICZM.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICZ.name: ICZM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GAI.definition: Synonyms: greenhouse gas and air pollution interactions and synergies [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GAI.name: GAINS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_The.definition: Synonyms: MNP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_The.name: The Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_lv: kvantitatīvā attiecība starp vielas daudzumu un tās izraisīto saindēšanās pakāpi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_sv: sambandet mellan dos och effekt; dos-respons-samband
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_is: tengsl lyfjaskammts og viðbragða við honum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_da: forhold mellem dosis og virkning; dosis-responsforhold
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_da: forhold mellem dosis og virkning; dosis-responsforhold
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_is: tengsl lyfjaskammts og viðbragða við honum
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.name: dose-response relationship
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_lv: kvantitatīvā attiecība starp vielas daudzumu un tās izraisīto saindēšanās pakāpi
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_bg: количествено отношение между доза и въздействие
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_sv: sambandet mellan dos och effekt; dos-respons-samband
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_bg: количествено отношение между доза и въздействие
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.definition: The quantitative relationship between the amount of exposure to a substance and the extent of toxic injury or disease produced. [definition source: Oak Ridge National Laboratory. US Department of Energy.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.name: restoration
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_res.definition: Measures taken to return a site to pre-violation conditions. [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.definition: Synonyms: M [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mil.name: million

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.definition: Transportation of goods by ship, aircraft or other vehicles. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fre.name: freight transport

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_alg.definition: Harmful algal blooms (HAB) can occur when certain types of microscopic algae grow quickly in water, forming visible patches that may harm the health of the environment, plants, or animals. HABs can deplete the oxygen and block the sunlight that other organisms need to live, and some HAB-causing algae release toxins that are dangerous to animals and humans. HABs can occur in marine, estuarine, and fresh waters. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_alg.name: algal bloom (harmful)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Buc.definition: The Convention on the Protection of the Black Sea against Pollution (Bucharest Convention) was adopted in 1992 (in force in 1994). Its objectives are to undertake all necessary measures consistent with international law and in accordance with the provisions of this convention to prevent, reduce, and control pollution thereof in order to protect and preserve the marine environment of the Black Sea. [definition source: Yearbook of international cooperation on environment and development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_Buc.name: Bucharest Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.definition: The highest hourly reading of air pollution obtained during the time period under study. [definition source: UK National Air Quality Information Archive. Glossary of air pollution terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_max.name: maximum hourly average

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objectname_sl: davek na obremenitev zraka z emisijo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.name: emission tax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objectname_fr: régime fiscal en faveur de la réduction des émissions
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objecttrans_sl: davek na obremenitev zraka z emisijo
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objectname_bg: данък върху емисии на вредни вещества
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objecttrans_fr: régime fiscal en faveur de la réduction des émissions
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.objecttrans_bg: данък върху емисии на вредни вещества
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: Emission taxes involve tax payments that are directly related to the measurement (or estimation) of the pollution caused. [definition source: OECD. 1996. Implementation strategies for environmental taxes. France.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICC.definition: Synonyms: International Conference on Chemicals Management [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ICC.name: ICCM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDM.definition: The Kyoto Protocol establishes the clean development mechanism (CDM) to enable Annex I Parties (listed in Annex B of the Kyoto Protocol) to finance emission-reduction projects in the countries of non-Annex I Parties. These Annex I Parties will receive certified emission reductions (CERs) for doing so. The goals of the CDM are: (1) to assist non-Annex I Parties in achieving sustainable development and in contributing to the ultimate objective of the convention and (2) to assist Annex I Parties in meeting their targets. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Work programme for RTD actions in support of 'competitive and sustainable growth' 1998-2000.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDM.name: CDM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.name: municipal wastewater
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mun.definition: Discharge of effluent from wastewater treatment plants which receive wastewater from households, commercial establishments, and industries. Combined sewer/separate storm overflows are included in this category. [definition source: Based on: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Synonyms: NC [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: national communication

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lon.definition: Atmospheric transport of air pollutants within a moving air mass for a distance greater than 100 kilometres. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of Eenvironment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lon.name: long-range transport of air pollutants

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.objecttrans_is: veitir (jarðlag sem vatn rennur hlutfallslega greitt um)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.objectname_is: veitir (jarðlag sem vatn rennur hlutfallslega greitt um)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.name: aquifer
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_aqu.definition: 1) Aquifer means a subsurface layer or layers of rock or other geological strata of sufficient porosity and permeability to allow either a significant flow of groundwater or the abstraction of significant quantities of groundwater. 2) Layers of rock, sand or gravel that can absorb water and allow it to flow. An aquifer acts as a groundwater reservoir when the underlying rock is impermeable. This may be tapped by wells for domestic, agricultural or industrial use. A serious environmental problem arises when the aquifer is contaminated by the seepage of sewage or toxins from waste dumps. If the groundwater in coastal areas is over-used salt water can seep into the aquifer. [definition source: 1) Directive 2000/60/EC of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy (Water Framework Directive). 2) EEA (GEMET)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAI.definition: Synonyms: Regional Air Pollution Information and Simulation model [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RAI.name: RAINS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.definition: The desired relationship between agriculture and environment can be captured by the term 'sustainable agriculture'. The 5th environmental action programme refers to sustainable development as 'development, which meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs'. Sustainable agriculture entails the management of natural resources in a way, which ensures that the benefits are also available in the future. A broader understanding of sustainability extends to the protection of landscapes, habitats, and biodiversity, and to overall objectives such as the quality of drinking water and air. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sus.name: sustainable agriculture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_goo.definition: Transportation of goods by ship, aircraft or other vehicles. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_goo.name: goods transportation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ex-.name: ex-situ conservation
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ex-.objecttrans_hu: {NATBIO} élőlények eredeti környezetén kívüli életbentartása / szaporítása

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ex-.definition: The conservation of components of biological diversity outside their natural habitats. [definition source: Convention on Biological Diversity (art.2).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.name: marine environment
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.definition: Marine environments include estuaries, coastal marine and nearshore zones, and open-ocean-deep-sea regions. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Urb.definition: One of the four Community initiatives which will operate in 2000-2006. Its work focuses on the economic and social regeneration of towns and urban areas in difficulty to promote sustainable urban development. Its funding for 2000-2006 will total EUR 700 million. The other three initiatives are Leader+ (rural development), Equal (equal opportunities) and Interreg (cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation). [definition source: European Commission. Glossary Inforegio.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Urb.name: Urban initiative

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cou.definition: Area outside the limits of any incorporated or inincorporated city, town, village, or any other designated residential or commercial area such as a subdivision, a business or shopping center, or community development. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cou.name: countryside

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDR.definition: The Central Data Repository is part of the ReportNet architechture. The Central Data Repository is like a bookshelf, with data reports on the environment as submitted to international clients. Each country either has a collection () for its deliveries or a referral () to a different preferred repository. The data reports within each country collection are arranged under the relevant reporting obligations or agreements [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDR.name: CDR

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.definition: The Kyoto Protocol and the Marrakech Accords allow industrial countries to discount their greenhouse gas emissions by certain land-use change and forestry activities. These activities are limited to strictly defined cases including afforestation, reforestation and deforestation since 1990, sometimes called 'Kyoto forest'. 'Kyoto Forest' is a minimum area of land of 0.05-1.0 hectares with tree crown cover (or equivalent stocking level) of more than 10-30 per cent with trees with the potential to reach a minimum height of 2-5 metres at maturity in situ. A forest may consist either of closed forest formations where trees of various storeys and undergrowth cover a high portion of the ground open forest. Young natural stands and all plantations which have yet to reach a crown density of 10-30 per cent or tree height of 2-5 metres are included under forest, as are areas normally forming part of the forest area which are temporarily unstocked as a result of human intervention such as harvesting or natural causes but which are expected to revert to forest. [definition source: Marrakech Accords Decision 11/CP.7, Annex 1(a)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kyo.name: Kyoto forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: Indicators that relate environmental pressures to human activities. These indicators provide insight in the efficiency of products and processes: Efficiency in terms of the resources used, the emissions and waste generated per unit of output. [definition source: Adapted from: EEA. 1999. Environmental indicators: Typology and overview. Technical report No 25.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-efficiency indicator

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RD.definition: Synonyms: research and development [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_RD.name: R&D

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.name: genotoxicity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.definition: Some metabolites are genotoxic: they can react with the DNA chains of cell nuclei to which foreign molecules have become attached and which thus no longer function normally. [definition source: Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. Persistent organic pollutants. Sweden.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objectname_tr: biyoã§eåitlilik iåbirliäi ve bilgi aläąåveriåi mekanizmasäą
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: A network of parties and partners working together to facilitate implementation of the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, which was signed in Rio at the 1992 Earth Summit. The Convention created a mechanism to translate the goal of partnerships and cooperation into action: the clearing house mechanism. It also facilitates access to and exchange of information on biodiversity around the world. Created in accordance with Article 18, the Clearing House is a key to archiving the Convention's three principal objectives: the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of benefits from the use of genetic resources. [definition source: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. The biodiversity clearing-house mechanism (CHM). Montreal]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.objecttrans_tr: biyoÃ§eÅitlilik iÅbirliÄi ve bilgi alÄąÅveriÅi mekanizmasÄą
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biodiversity clearing-house mechanism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEA.definition: Synonyms: national environmental action plan [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NEA.name: NEAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TOF.definition: Synonyms: tropospheric ozone forming potentials [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_TOF.name: TOFP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.definition: A governmental authority designated by a Party to be responsible for receiving the notification of a transboundary movement of hazardous wastes or other wastes, and any information related to it, and for responding to the notification. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_com.name: competent authority

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.definition: Synonyms: EoI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.name: exchange of information decision

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objectname_bg: подготовка (усвояване) на земя или терени за обработка или за застрояване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.objecttrans_bg: подготовка (усвояване) на земя или терени за обработка или за застрояване
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lan.definition: Planning of infrastructures, services and industrial settlements in order to promote the socio-economic growth of certain land area. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_JAM.definition: Synonyms: Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_J_JAM.name: JAMA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mer.definition: Synonyms: Hg [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mer.name: mercury

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: Life-cycle assessment (LCA) is a process of evaluating the effects that a product has on the environment over the entire period of its life thereby increasing resource-use efficiency and decreasing liabilities. It can be used to study the environmental impact of either a product or the function the product is designed to perform. LCA is commonly referred to as a "cradle-to-grave" analysis. LCA's key elements are: (1) identify and quantify the environmental loads involved; e.g. the energy and raw materials consumed, the emissions and wastes generated; (2) evaluate the potential environmental impacts of these loads; and (3) assess the options available for reducing these environmental impacts. [definition source: UNEP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life cycle analysis

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Established under UNESCO's man and the biosphere (MAB) programme, biosphere reserves are a series of protected areas linked through a global network, intended to demonstrate the relationship between conservation and development. [definition source: GBA. Quoted by: European Community Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism. Glossary of terms related to the CBD.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biosphere reserve

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.name: persistent organic pollutant
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.objectname_bg: траен (постоянен) органичен замърсител на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.objecttrans_bg: траен (постоянен) органичен замърсител на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_per.definition: Chemical substance that persists in the environment, bioaccumulates though the food web, and poses a risk of causing adverse effects to human health and the environment. [definition source: UNEP. 1998 Persistent organic pollutants: A global issue; UNECE. 1998. Draft protocol to the Convention of long-range transboundary air pollution on persistent organic pollutants. Quoted by EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 113. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_ro: directiva cu privire la de raportarea standardizată
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.definition: Directive 91/692/EEC. This directive provides for the harmonisation of sector reports on the implementation of 27 directives in the air, water and waste sectors. Member States have to produce sector reports every three years on these directive, based on a questionnaire format provided by the Commission. One exception is the bathing water directive (76/160/EEC) which has to be reported on to the Commission on an annual basis so as to provide the public with information at the earliest opportunity. [definition source: European Commission. Handbook on the implementation of EC environmental legislation.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_ro: Directiva cu privire la de raportarea standardizată
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_nl: richtlijn m.b.t. de standaardisering van verslagen

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objectname_pl: niedostatek wody związane z jakością lub zasobami wody
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water stress
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.objecttrans_pl: niedostatek wody związane z jakością lub zasobami wody
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Water stress occurs when the demand for water exceeds the available amount during a certain period or when poor quality restricts its use. Water stress causes deterioration of fresh water resources in terms of quantity (aquifer over-exploitation, dry rivers, etc.) and quality (eutrophication, organic matter pollution, saline intrusion, etc.). [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Page 155. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: European spatial development perspective (ESDP) is a common frame of reference for the totality of the institutions that are involved in spatial planning and the development of space: European Commission, Member States, regions, self-governments, etc. This frame of reference, which is not binding, aims to reinforce synergies and trans-national cooperation in the sector of the development of space. A draft ESDP was agreed in 1997. A final version was approved at Potsdam in May 1999. [definition source: Based on: MedRegio.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.name: tonne-kilometre
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ton.definition: Unit of measure of goods transport which represents the transport of one tonne over one kilometre. The distance to be taken into consideration is the distance actually run. [definition source: Eurostat, ECMT, UN/ECE. 1997. Glossary for Transport Statistics. Document prepared by the Intersecretariat Working Group on Transport Statistics. Second edition.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fue.definition: One of the simplest approaches to the control of acid gas emissions, involving the replacement of high-sulphur fuels with low-sulphur alternatives. The most common form of fuel switching is the replacement of high-sulphur coal with a low-sulphur coal. Coal may also be replaced entirely by oil or natural gas. [definition source: Kemp, David D. 1998. The environment dictionary. Routledge. London.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EM-.definition: Synonyms: Emergency Disasters Data Base [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EM-.name: EM-DAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.name: marsh
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mar.definition: Type of wetland that does not accumulate appreciable peat deposits and is dominated by herbaceous vegetation. Marshes may be either fresh or saltwater, and tidal or non-tidal. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.definition: A projection is a potential future evolution of a quality or set of quantities, often computed with the aid of a model. [definition source: IPCC. Climate Change 2001 Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDD.definition: Database on areas designated at national and international levels in Europe. In 1996, the Council of Europe, the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre (WCMC) integrated their respective databases and established a single common database of designated areas in Europe, together with the mechanism to maintain it. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CDD.name: CDDA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecological rucksack
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.objectname_fi: tuotteen valmistuksen vaatiman raaka-ainemäärän ja tuotteen painon erotus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.objecttrans_fi: tuotteen valmistuksen vaatiman raaka-ainemäärän ja tuotteen painon erotus
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: The material input of a product (service) minus the weight of the product itself. The material input is defined as the life cycle wide total quantity (in kg) of natural material moved (physically displaced) by humans in order to generate a good. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Making sustainability accountable: Eco-efficiency, resource productivity and innovation. Topic report No 11/1999.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_amm.name: ammonium

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: A naturally occurring process in humid climates that has long been the subject of research, whose findings suggest acid precipitation on the productivity of terrestrial plants is summarised as follows: as soil becomes more acidic the basic cations (Ca, Mg) on the soil exchange are replaced by hydrogen ions or solubilized metals. The basic cation, now in solution, can be leached through the soil. As time progresses the soil becomes less fertile and more acidic. Resultant decreases in soil pH cause reduced, less-active population of soil microorganisms, which in turn slow decomposition of plant residues and cycling of essential plant nutrients. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil acidification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Z_zoo.definition: All permanent establishments where animals of wild species are kept for exhibition to the public for 7 or more days a year, with the exception of circuses, pet shops and establishments which Member States exempt from the requirements of this Directive on the grounds that they do not exhibit a significant number of animals or species to the public and that the exemption will not jeopardise the objectives of this Directive. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_Z_zoo.name: zoo

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_was.definition: Waste-to-energy scheme means incineration of waste with recovery of generated energy. Waste-to-energy schemes turn waste into steam or electricity to heat, cool, light and/or otherwise power homes and industry through the process of combustion. Just as coal, oil or natural gas is burned in boilers to generate electricity, waste is used as a fuel to generate power. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

[definition source: Baldock, 1995. Quoted by: Wageningen Agricultural University. 1997. Additional EU policy instruments for plant protection products.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: The Environmental Policy Review Group (EPRG) has its origin in the fifth Community environmental action programme, 'Towards sustainability'. It is composed of representatives of the Commission, the Member States and the candidate countries at director-general level. Its mission is to develop a mutual understanding and exchange of views on environmental policies and measures. It is a dialogue group for getting Commission, Member States and candidate countries together to discuss on environmental issues at an early stage and not only at Council level on proposals; being a think tank where ideas on environmental issues can be explored or tested, prior to administrative and legislative developments, in the light of Member States ground reality. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
