glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.objecttrans_hu: {EIO} Infromáció-forrástár. A 'Directory of Information Resources' (DIR) az EEA által kiadott autorizált információk tára (EEA kiadványok, EIONET partnerek, környezetvédelmi jogszabályok stb).
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dir.definition: The Directory of Information Resources (DIR) is the EEA's official directory of authoritative information (EEA publications, EIONET partners, environmental legislation, etc). The DIR is maintained by the European Topic Centre on Catalogue of Data Sources. [definition source: EEA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_lv: attiecība starp vielas daudzumu un tās iedarbību
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_sv: sambandet mellan dos och effekt; dos-respons-samband
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objectname_da: forhold mellem dosis og virkning; dosis-responsforhold
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_da: forhold mellem dosis og virkning; dosis-responsforhold
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.name: dose-effect relationship
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_lv: attiecība starp vielas daudzumu un tās iedarbību
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.objecttrans_sv: sambandet mellan dos och effekt; dos-respons-samband
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dos.definition: The relation between the quantity of a given substance and a measurable or observable effect. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.definition: Natural or man-made areas which have been reserved for conservation, scientific, educational and/or recreational purposes. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pro.name: protected landscape

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.definition: The part of the shoreline that is submerged at high tide and exposed at low tide. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Protecting the oceans from land-based activities.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lit.name: littoral zone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BAT.definition: The most effective and advanced stage in the development of activities and their methods of operation which indicate the practical suitability of particular techniques for providing in principle the basis for emission limit values designed to prevent and, where that is not practicable, generally to reduce emissions and impact on the environment as a whole. [definition source: Directive 96/61/EC of 24 September 1996 concerning integrated pollution prevention and control.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_BAT.name: BAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.name: household waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.definition: Solid waste composed of garbage and rubbish, which normally originates from houses. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.name: genetically modified organism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gen.definition: The modification of the genetic characteristics of a microorganism, plant or animal by inserting a modified gene or a gene from another variety or species. Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) may be microorganisms designed for use as biopesticides or seeds that have been altered genetically to give a plant better disease resistance or growth. [definition source: K. ten Kate & S.A. Laird. 1999. The Commercial Use of Biodiversity: Access to Genetic Resources and Benefit-Sharing. European Commission. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CRO.definition: Synonyms: Central Bureau of Statistics of the Republic of Croatia [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CRO.name: CROSTAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.definition: The second step in the process of hazard assessment, consisting in the qualitative and, wherever possible, quantitative description of the nature of the hazard associated with a biological, chemical, or physical agent, based on one or more elements, such as mechanisms of action involved, biological extrapolation, dose-response and dose-effect relationships, and their respective attendant uncertainties. [definition source: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry. Risk assessment terminology. Chemistry International Vol. 23, No. 2. March 2001. John H. Duffus.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_haz.name: hazard characterisation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPS.definition: Synonyms: Institute for the Protection and Security of the Citizen [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IPS.name: IPSC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.definition: Synonyms: Community Assistance for Reconstruction, Development and Stabilisation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_CAR.name: CARDS

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.definition: The volume of water that can be held in a soil. Also refers to the ratio of the volume of voids to the total volume of the soil. [definition source: Okanagan University College.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_soi.name: soil porosity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACE.definition: Synonyms: European Automobile Manufacturers' Association [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ACE.name: ACEA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dan.definition: Synonyms: DKK [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dan.name: Danish krone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COD.objecttrans_is: aðferð til að mæla gæði vatns
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COD.objectname_is: aðferð til að mæla gæði vatns
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COD.name: COD
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_COD.definition: The quantity of oxygen used in biological and non-biological oxidation of materials in water; a measure of water quality. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organic matter
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: 1) Carbonaceous waste originating from human and animal sources. 2) Plant and animal residue that decomposes and becomes a part of the soil. [definition source: 1) EEA. 2) EEA (GEMET).]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nor.definition: The International Conferences on the Protection of the North Sea are political events where the ministers responsible for the protection of the environment meet for a broad and comprehensive assessment of the measures needed to protect the North Sea environment. Participants to the conference are either delegates from North Sea states or international observer organisations. The results of the conferences are recorded in the Conference Declarations. [definition source: Ministry of Environment of Norway.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nor.name: North Sea Conference

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.definition: Wooded land on which more than 75 % of the tree crown cover consists of broadleaved species. [definition source: EUNIS (based on FAO definition). EUNIS habitats classification. Glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bro.name: broadleaved forest

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Fed.definition: Synonyms: UBA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_Fed.name: Federal Environment Agency (Austria and Germany)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sup.definition: Synonyms: SUTOUR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sup.name: Supporting tourism enterprises for eco-labelling and environmental management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sup.objecttrans_en: Supporting tourism enterprises for eco-labelling and environmental management
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sup.objectname_en: supporting tourism enterprises for eco-labelling and environmental management

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_edg.definition: When integrating vector layers or mosaicking images together, it is possible that each vector or image may not precisely join or geometrically edgematch to an adjacent vector or image. Visual inspection of the integrated vector layer or image mosaic should be performed to ensure that features on the ground along the edge of each vector or image line up exactly with the same features on the edge of the adjacent vector or image.Many GIS or IP (Image Processing) SW have semiautomated tools to help in edgematching process. Futher control of attributes is necessary in case of edgematching of vector layers with line or polygonial topology. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_edg.name: edgematching

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HBM.definition: Synonyms: human biomonitoring [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HBM.name: HBM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTP.definition: The amount an individual is willing to pay to acquire some good or service. This may be elicited from stated or revealed preference approaches. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. Belgian Clearing-House Mechanism.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_WTP.name: WTP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Ldn.name: Ldn
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Ldn.definition: Day-night level. It is a descriptor of noise level based on energy equivalent noise level (Leq) over the whole day with a penalty of 10 dB(A) for night time noise (22.00-7.00 hrs). [definition source: EEA. 2001. TERM 2001. Copenhagen]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.definition: European Environment Agency regular indicator-based assessment reports the aim of which is improve the actuality of the data and the capacities for delivering short-term environmental outlooks, in order to describe present situation. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Env.name: Environmental signals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cro.definition: Synonyms: CIFAS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cro.name: Cross-compliance Indicators in the context of the Farm Advisory System
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cro.objecttrans_en: Cross-compliance Indicators in the context of the Farm Advisory System
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cro.objectname_en: cross-compliance indicators in the context of the farm advisory system

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dec.definition: Synonyms: DESD [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dec.name: Decade of Education for Sustainable Development
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dec.objecttrans_en: Decade of Education for Sustainable Development
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dec.objectname_en: decade of education for sustainable development

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pan.definition: Synonyms: PEBLDS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pan.name: Pan-European Biological and Landscape Diversity Strategy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pan.objecttrans_en: Pan-European Biological and Landscape Diversity Strategy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_Pan.objectname_en: pan-european biological and landscape diversity strategy

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biofuel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: A fuel produced from dry organic matter or combustible oils produced by plants. Examples of biofuel include alcohol (from fermented sugar), black liquor from the paper manufacturing process, wood and soybean oil. [definition source: IPCC. Climate Change 2001 Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.definition: Waste electrical and electronic equipment or 'WEEE' means electrical or electronic equipment which is waste within the meaning of Article 1(a) of Directive 75/442/EEC, including all components, sub-assemblies and consumables, which are part of the product at the time of discarding .Council Directive 75/442/EEC of 15 July 1975 on waste: 'waste' means any substance or object which the holder disposes of or is required to dispose of pursuant to the provisions of national law in force. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ele.name: electrical and electronic waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ali.name: alien species
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_ali.definition: A species occurring in an area outside of its historically known natural range as a result of intentional or accidental dispersal by human activities. Also referred to as introduced species or exotic species. [definition source: UNEP. 1995. Global Biodiversity Assessment. Annex 6, Glossary. Quoted by: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: greenhouse effect
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Warming of the atmosphere due to the reduction in outgoing solar radiation resulting from concentrations of gases such as carbon dioxide. [definition source: Environment Protection Agency. 2000. Ireland's environment. A millennium report. Ireland]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_sk: informačný systém o stave životného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_el: σύστημα πληροφόρησης σχετικά με τις εκθέσεις για την κατάσταση του περιβάλλοντος
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_en: state of the environment reporting information system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_lv: seris, informācijas sistēma par eiropas valstu vides stāvokļa ziņojumiem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_es: Sistema de información sobre la situación del medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_sv: system för rapportering av information om tillståndet i miljön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_it: State of the Environment Reporting Information System (sistema di coordinamento delle informazioni sullo stato dell'ambiente)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_de: informationssystem für die berichte über den zustand der umwelt
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_de: Informationssystem für die Berichte über den Zustand der Umwelt
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_it: state of the environment reporting information system (sistema di coordinamento delle informazioni sullo stato dell'ambiente)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_pt: seris (sistema de informação sobre documentação relativa ao estado do ambiente)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_es: sistema de información sobre la situación del medio ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.name: state of the environment reporting information system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_lv: SERIS, Informācijas sistēma par Eiropas valstu vides stāvokļa ziņojumiem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_el: σύστημα πληροφόρησης σχετικά με τις εκθέσεις για την κατάσταση του περιβάλλοντος
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_pt: SERIS (Sistema de Informação sobre documentação relativa ao Estado do Ambiente)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_en: state of the environment reporting information system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_cs: Informační systém o stavu životního prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_fr: state of the environment reporting information system (système de coordination des informations sur l'environnement)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_sk: Informačný systém o stave životného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_bg: серис - интернет базирана система за информацията по доклади върху състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_sv: system för rapportering av information om tillståndet i miljön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_ro: sistemul de informare cu privire la rapoartele despre starea mediului înconjurător
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_fr: State of the Environment Reporting Information System (système de coordination des informations sur l'environnement)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_bg: СЕРИС - интернет базирана система за информацията по доклади върху състоянието на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.definition: The state of the environment reports information system (SERIS) is an Internet-based database of state-of-the-environment reports in European countries. The system provides an overview of state-of-the-environment (SoE) documents (paper reports, internet publications and policy-related products) by country and of key organisations involved in SoE reporting. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objectname_cs: informační systém o stavu životního prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sta.objecttrans_ro: Sistemul de informare cu privire la rapoartele despre starea mediului înconjurător

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.definition: A place in which plants are grown, studied and exhibited. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bot.name: botanical garden

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rio.definition: World Summit on Sustainable Development, held in Johannesburg (South Africa) in August 2002, ten years after the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil (Rio Conference). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rio.name: Rio+10 Conference

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.definition: Heavy, pungent, colourless gas formed primarily by the combustion of fossil fuels. It is harmful to human beings and vegetation, and contributes to the acidity in precipitation. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sul.name: sulphur dioxide

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sol.definition: Device which converts the energy from light into electricity. The collector system contains a concentrator and a receiver. The concentrator redirects and focuses sunlight on the receiver by using mirrors or lenses, and the receiver absorbs solar radiation and converts it to heat. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sol.name: solar collector

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.definition: A monitoring system for national economies based on methodically organised accounts and denoting the total amounts of material used in the economy. Material flow accounting enables monitoring of total consumption of natural resources and the associated indirect flows, as well as calculation of indicators. [definition source: Eurostat. 2001. Economy-wide material flow accounts and derived indicators. Luxembourg.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mat.name: material flow accounting

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objectname_lv: pm10, vielas daļiņas gaisā ar arodinamisko diametru < 10 mikroniem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.name: PM10
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objecttrans_lv: PM10, vielas daļiņas gaisā ar arodinamisko diametru < 10 mikroniem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objectname_fi: hiukkaset, joiden aerodynaaminen halkaisija on pienempi kuin 10 mikronia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objectname_bg: pm10 е един от седемте замърсители на въздух, които агенцията за защита на околната среда (епа) регламентира в (naaqs), т.е. в национални стандарти за качеството на околния въздух
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objecttrans_fi: hiukkaset, joiden aerodynaaminen halkaisija on pienempi kuin 10 mikronia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.objecttrans_bg: PM10 е един от седемте замърсители на въздух, които Агенцията за защита на околната среда (ЕПА) регламентира в (NAAQS), т.е. в Национални Стандарти за качеството на околния въздух
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PM1.definition: An air pollutant consisting of small particles with an aerodynamic diameter less than or equal to a nominal 10 micrometer (about 1/7 the diameter of a single human hair). Their small size allows them to make their way to the air passages deep within the lungs where they may be deposited and result in adverse health effects. PM10 also causes visibility reduction. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_pl: system zarządzania w zakresie dotyczącym środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental management system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_pl: system zarządzania w zakresie dotyczącym środowiska
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: система за управление на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: система за управление на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A means of ensuring effective implementation of an environmental management plan or procedures and compliance with environmental policy objectives and targets. A key feature on any effective environmental management system (EMS) is the preparation of documented system procedures and instructions to ensure effective communication and continuity of implementation. There are certification systems for EMS ISO 14001 and EC's EMAS scheme (EMAS is now compatible with ISO 14001) which demonstrate that a system is operated to an internationally recognised standard. Alternatively a customised system can be developed addressing the particular needs of the operation. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environmental concerns into development and economic cooperation. Brussels.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: A mathematical method of constructing new data points from a discrete set of known data points. When a number of data points has been obtained - by sampling or experiment - one can construct a calculation (interpolation) that closely fits these data points. [definition source: EEA Ozone web]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: interpolation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.name: tidal energy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.objectname_bg: енергия, генериране от приливи и отливи на океан
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.objecttrans_bg: енергия, генериране от приливи и отливи на океан
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.definition: Mechanical power, which may be converted to electrical power, generated by the rise and fall of ocean tides. The possibilities of utilising tidal power have been studied for many generations, but the only feasible schemes devised so far are based on the use of one or more tidal basins, separated from the sea by dams (known as barrages), and of hydraulic turbines through which water passes on its way between the basins and the sea. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy intensity
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: Ratio of energy consumption and economic or physical output. At the national level, energy intensity is the ratio of total domestic primary energy consumption or final energy consumption to gross domestic product or physical output. [definition source: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEA.definition: 32 member countries of the EEA (EU-15 + EU-10 + EFTA-4 + Romania, Bulgaria and Turkey) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEA.name: EEA-32

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOA.definition: Synonyms: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NOA.name: NOAA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: A furnace in which wastes are burned. [definition source: UNEP. Basel Convention web site.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: incineration plant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ILO.definition: Synonyms: International Labour Organisation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_ILO.name: ILO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.objecttrans_de: Informationen für die Öffentlichkeit, Verständigung der Öffentlichkeit
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pub.name: public information

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_der.objecttrans_es: suelo virgen; terreno baldío; terreno inculto; terreno sin romper; terreno sin roturar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_der.objectname_es: suelo virgen; terreno baldío; terreno inculto; terreno sin romper; terreno sin roturar
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_der.name: derelict land
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_der.definition: Land damaged by extractive or other industrial processes and then abandoned. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental load
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: критично въздействие върху околната среда без сериозно увреждане
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: критично въздействие върху околната среда без сериозно увреждане
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Observed (or predicted) environmental concentration of a compound in an environmental compartment. [definition source: Oskam, A.J., Vijftigschild, R.A.N., Graveland, C.1997. Additional EU policy instruments for plant protection products. Final report.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_no-.definition: Greatest concentration or amount of a substance, found by observation or experiment, which causes no detectable adverse effect. Effects may be detected at this level, which are not judged to be adverse. [definition source: WHO. 1994. Assessing human health risks of chemicals: Derivation of guidance values for health-based exposure limits. Environmental health criteria 170. World Health Organization, Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_no-.name: no-observed-adverse-effect level

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.name: sewage sludge
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sew.definition: The accumulated settled solids separated from various types of water either moist or mixed with liquid component as a result of natural or artificial processes. [definition source: Eurostat/OECD Joint Questionnaire on Environmental Statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.definition: Avoiding wasting energy. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_ene.name: energy saving

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.definition: Synonyms: PHARE [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EU_.name: EU Pre-accession assistance programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pra.definition: Synonyms: psu [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pra.name: practical salinity units

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.definition: The objective of the project is to map the international environmental conventions signed and ratified by the European Commission and assist the European Environment Agency to streamline the reporting systems implemented in them. [definition source: EEA. 2001. EEA support to the European Community in reporting obligations within the framework of international environmental conventions - Legislative instruments, international programmes and conventions. Technical report No 62.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.name: reporting on environmental conventions

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FAO.definition: Synonyms: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations' Statistical Database [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_FAO.name: FAOSTAT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objectname_lt: e-eionet (elektroninis europos aplinkos apsaugos stebėjimo ir informacijos tinklas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objectname_hu: {eio} elektronikus eionet (európai környezeti információs és megfigyelő hálózat)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.name: e-EIONET
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_hu: {EIO} elektronikus EIONET (Európai Környezeti Információs és Megfigyelő Hálózat)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_lv: e-EIONET, elektroniskais vides informācijas un datu izplatīšanas tīkls
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_lt: e-EIONET (elektroninis Europos aplinkos apsaugos stebėjimo ir informacijos tinklas)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objectname_el: ηλεκτρονικό εδπππ (ευρωπαϊκό δίκτυο πληροφοριών και παρατηρήσεων για το περιβάλλον / ειονετ)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_cs: e-EIONET (elektronická síť Evropské agentury životního prostředí)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_sk: Elektronická sieť Európskej agentúry životného prostredia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_sl: EIONET (Elektronska evropska mreža za okoljske informacije in opazovanje okolja)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objectname_bg: е-еионет - европейска електронна мрежа за информация и наблюдение на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objecttrans_bg: е-ЕИОНЕТ - Европейска електронна мрежа за информация и наблюдение на околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.definition: Electronic EIONET. Formerly also called the EIONET telematics network. It facilitates cooperation and flow of data and information between EIONET partners and with the EEA. [definition source: EEA, European Environment Agency, Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_e-E.objectname_cs: e-eionet (elektronická síť evropské agentury životního prostředí)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objectname_lv: p.e., populācijas ekvivalents, mērvienība komunālo notekūdeņu attīrīšanā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.name: population equivalent
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objecttrans_lv: p.e., populācijas ekvivalents, mērvienība komunālo notekūdeņu attīrīšanā
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objectname_bg: еквивалент на биохимична/биологична потребност от кислород на глава от населението
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.objecttrans_bg: еквивалент на биохимична/биологична потребност от кислород на глава от населението
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pop.definition: One population equivalent (p.e.) means the organic biodegradable load having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) of 60 g of oxygen per day. [definition source: Directive 91/271/EEC of 21 May concerning urban waste-water treatment.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_equ.definition: Synonyms: eq [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_equ.name: equivalent

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.definition: The pricing of commercial goods, such as electric power, that would include in the final prices faced by the end user not only the private costs of inputs, but also the costs of the externalities created by their production and use. [definition source: Inter Governmental Panel on Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_ful.name: full-cost pricing

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: The rate of deaths occurring in the first year of life for a given population. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: infant mortality

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: Synonyms: CI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: confidence interval

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUW.definition: Synonyms: EU Water Initiative - Mediterranean component [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EUW.name: EUWI MED

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: 1) Genetic diversity: the variation between individuals and between populations within a species; species diversity: the different types of plants, animals and other life forms within a region; community or ecosystem diversity: the variety of habitats found within an area (grassland, marsh, and woodland for instance. 2) An umbrella term to describe collectively the variety and variability of nature. It encompasses three basic levels of organisation in living systems: the genetic, species, and ecosystem levels. Plant and animal species are the most commonly recognized units of biological diversity, thus public concern has been mainly devoted to conserving species diversity. (Source: WRES / GILP96) [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biological diversity

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.name: half-life of a pollutant
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objectname_bg: период от време, необходим на вредно вещество да изпусне 1/2 от първоначалната си концентрация в околната среда, период на полуразпадане
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objectname_ro: timp de înjumătăţire a unui poluant
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objecttrans_bg: период от време, необходим на вредно вещество да изпусне 1/2 от първоначалната си концентрация в околната среда, период на полуразпадане
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.definition: 1) The time required for a pollutant to lose one-half of its original concentration. For example, the biochemical half-life of DDT in the environment is 15 years. 2) The time required for the elimination of half a total dose from the body. [definition source: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.objecttrans_ro: Timp de înjumătăţire a unui poluant

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objecttrans_es: Sistema de descarga doble de agua
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objectname_pt: autoclismo com duplo doseador de descarga
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objectname_es: sistema de descarga doble de agua
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.name: dual flushing system
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objecttrans_pt: autoclismo com duplo doseador de descarga
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objectname_bg: система за тоалетни с два режима
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objectname_ro: dispozitiv cu două opţiuni de jet de apă
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objecttrans_bg: система за тоалетни с два режима
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.definition: Water flushing system in toilets that can release either 4.5 or 9 litres at will. It constitutes a means of saving water. [definition source: Adapted from: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dua.objecttrans_ro: dispozitiv cu două opţiuni de jet de apă

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sed.definition: Deposition of material of varying size, both mineral and organic, away from its site of origin by the action of water, wind, gravity or ice. [definition source: New South Wales Environment Protection Authority . State of environment 2000. Australia.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sed.name: sedimentation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sol.definition: Directive 1999/13/EC on the limitation of emissions of volatile organic compounds due to the use of organic solvents in certain activities and installations. Its purpose is to prevent or reduce the direct and indirect effects of emissions of volatile organic compounds into the environment, mainly into air, and the potential risks to human health. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Sol.name: Solvents Directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sep.name: septic tank
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sep.definition: Underground tank receiving wastewater directly from the home. Organic sewage/waste is decomposed by bacteria and settles down in the tank; effluents flow out of the tank into the ground; and the sludge is periodically pumped out. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.definition: Concept adopted at the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea (1982), whereby a coastal state assumes jurisdiction over the exploration and exploitation of marine resources in its adjacent section of the continental shelf, taken to be a band extending 200 miles from the shore. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment etatistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_exc.name: exclusive economic zone

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.definition: Compounds of hydrogen and carbon in various combinations that are present in petroleum products and natural gas. Some hydrocarbons are major air pollutants, some may be carcinogenic and others contribute to photochemical smog. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment statistics.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hyd.name: hydrocarbons

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: A federation of non-governmental organisation. Its main purpose is to liaise between its member organisation and the EU Institutions in order to improve EU's impact on the environment. [definition source: European Environment Bureau.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.name: European Environment Bureau

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_sl: davek na obremenitev zraka z emisijo co2
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_pt: taxa para redução de emissões de dióxido de carbono
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon dioxide tax
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_pt: taxa para redução de emissões de dióxido de carbono
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_cs: daň z obsahu uhlíkatých sloučenin v palivu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_fr: taxe sur le dioxyde de carbone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_sl: davek na obremenitev zraka z emisijo CO2
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objecttrans_fr: taxe sur le dioxyde de carbone
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: Compulsory tax levied on fuels in accordance with their carbon content, with the aim to encourage using less carbon-intensive fuels and to reduce energy consumption. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.objectname_cs: daň z obsahu uhlíkatých sloučenin v palivu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tri.definition: Since 1978, The Netherlands, Denmark and Germany have been working together on the protection and conservation of the Wadden Sea covering management, monitoring and research, as well as political matters. In 1982, a joint declaration on the protection of the Wadden Sea was agreed upon in which the countries declare their intention to coordinate their activities and measures for the protection of the Wadden Sea. In 1997, a trilateral Wadden Sea plan was adopted. [definition source: Common Wadden Sea Secretariat.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_Tri.name: Trilateral Wadden Sea Cooperation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pac.name: packaging waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pac.definition: Waste comprised of materials, or items, used to protect, contain or transport a commodity or product and usually considered a type of consumer waste. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_alt.name: alternative energy
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_alt.definition: Energy that does not come from fossil fuels. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.definition: Mechanical power, which may be converted to electrical power, generated by the rise and fall of ocean tides. The possibilities of utilising tidal power have been studied for many generations, but the only feasible schemes devised so far are based on the use of one or more tidal basins, separated from the sea by dams (known as barrages), and of hydraulic turbines through which water passes on its way between the basins and the sea. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tid.name: tidal power

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objectname_lv: partneru tīkls ano bioloģiskās dažādības konvencijas mērķu sasniegšanai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objecttrans_es: Mecanismo de compensación (de una red de información)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objectname_pt: mecanismo do centro de intercâmbio de informação
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objectname_es: mecanismo de compensación (de una red de información)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.name: clearing house mechanism
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objecttrans_lv: partneru tīkls ANO Bioloģiskās dažādības konvencijas mērķu sasniegšanai
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objecttrans_pt: Mecanismo do Centro de Intercâmbio de Informação
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objectname_bg: централна организация за събиране, класифициране и разпращане на информация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.objecttrans_bg: Централна организация за събиране, класифициране и разпращане на информация
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cle.definition: A network of parties and partners working together to facilitate implementation of the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, which was signed in Rio at the 1992 Earth Summit. The convention created a mechanism to translate the goal of partnerships and cooperation into action: the clearing house mechanism. It also facilitates access to and exchange of information on biodiversity around the world. Created in accordance with Article 18, the clearing house is a key to achieving the convention's three principal objectives: the conservation of biological diversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of benefits from the use of genetic resources. [definition source: Convention of Biological Diversity Secretariat. The Biodiversity Clearing-House Mechanism (CHM). Montreal]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ope.definition: A plot of vegetated land separating or surrounding areas of intensive residential or industrial use and devoted to recreation or park uses. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_ope.name: open spaces

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fra.definition: Synonyms: FP [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_F_fra.name: framework programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: An individual constituted to carry out all life functions. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organism

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mem.definition: Synonyms: MS [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mem.name: Member State

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_INS.definition: Synonyms: Infrastructure for Spatial Information in Europe [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_INS.name: INSPIRE

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Aar.definition: The convention on access to information, public participation in decision-making and access to justice in environmental matters was adopted at Fourth Ministerial Conference "Environment for Europe" in Aarhus, Denmark, on 25 June 1998. Objective of the Convention is to contribute to the protection of the right of every person of present and future generations to live in an environment adequate to his or her health and well-being, each Contracting Party to this convention shall guarantee the rights of access to information, public participation in decision-making, and access to justice in environmental matters in accordance with the provisions of this Convention. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_Aar.name: Aarhus Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SIA.definition: Synonyms: SIDS initial assessment meeting [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SIA.name: SIAM

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: The Convention was adopted in Paris on 17 June 1994. It entered into force on 26 December 1996. The objective of this Convention is to combat desertification and mitigate the effects of drought in countries experiencing serious drought and/or desertification, particularly in Africa, through effective action at all levels, supported by international cooperation and partnership arrangements, in the framework of an integrated approach which is consistent with Agenda 21, with a view to contributing to the achievement of sustainable development in affected areas. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: United Nations convention to combat desertification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objecttrans_en: United Nations convention to combat desertification
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.objectname_en: united nations convention to combat desertification

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: ecosystem
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: A dynamic complex of plant, animal and micro-organism communities and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit. [definition source: The Convention on Biological Diversity.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cap.definition: Synonyms: CAPACT [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cap.name: Capacity Building for Air Quality Management and the Application of Clean Coal Combustion Technologies in Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cap.objecttrans_en: Capacity Building for Air Quality Management and the Application of Clean Coal Combustion Technologies in Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Cap.objectname_en: capacity building for air quality management and the application of clean coal combustion technologies in central asia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: Life-cycle assessment (LCA) is a process of evaluating the effects that a product has on the environment over the entire period of its life thereby increasing resource-use efficiency and decreasing liabilities. It can be used to study the environmental impact of either a product or the function the product is designed to perform. LCA is commonly referred to as a "cradle-to-grave" analysis. LCA's key elements are: (1) identify and quantify the environmental loads involved; e.g. the energy and raw materials consumed, the emissions and wastes generated; (2) evaluate the potential environmental impacts of these loads; and (3) assess the options available for reducing these environmental impacts. [definition source: UNEP.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: life cycle inventory analysis

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.name: regulatory instrument
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.definition: A category of environmental policy instruments whereby public authorities mandate the environmental performance to be achieved or the technologies to be used. [definition source: Adapted from: The European Union Research Network on Market-based Instruments for Sustainable Development. Voluntary approaches. Environmental policy research briefs, No 1. Ireland.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.definition: A way of living based on identifiable patterns of behaviour which are determined by the interplay between an individual's personal characteristics, social interactions, and socio-economic and environmental living conditions. [definition source: WHO. 1998. Health promotion glossary. Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_lif.name: lifestyle

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bor.definition: One of the 11 biogeographical regions of Europe as indicated on the map of biogeographical regions, situated in north-eastern Europe between the Arctic and the continental biogeographical region. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tun.definition: A zone between the perpetual snow and ice of Arctic regions and the tree line (boreal taiga), having a permanently frozen sub-soil and supporting low-growing vegetation such as lichens, mosses, dwarf shrubs and stunted trees. [definition source: EUNIS]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tun.name: tundra

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Programme launched in June 2000 by the European Commission. Its goal is to identify and develop all the necessary elements of a EU strategy to implement the Kyoto Protocol. [definition source: Adapted from: European Commission.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.name: state indicator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objectname_nl: statusindicator, indicator voor de toestand van het milieu
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.definition: Indicator for the condition of different environmental compartments and systems in physical (e.g. temperature), chemical (e.g. atmospheric CO2 concentrations) or biological (fish stocks) variables. [definition source: EEA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sta.objecttrans_nl: statusindicator, indicator voor de toestand van het milieu

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green accounting
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.objectname_bg: зелено' счетоводство (съобразено с изискванията на околната среда)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.objecttrans_bg: зелено' счетоводство (съобразено с изискванията на околната среда)
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Systematic presentation of data on environmentally important stocks and flows (e.g. stocks of life-sustaining natural resources, flows of pollutants), accompanying conventional economic accounts (e.g. measures of gross domestic product) with the ultimate objective of providing a comprehensive measure of the environmental consequences of economic activity. [definition source: European Commission. Forward Studies Unit. 1999. Scenarios Europe 2010. Five possible futures for Europe. Working paper.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.name: biodiesel
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bio.definition: Biofuel is a gaseous, liquid or solid fuel that contains energy derived from a biological source. For example, rapeseed oil or fish liver oil can be used in place of diesel fuel in modified engines. A commercial application is the use of modified rapeseed oil, which as rapeseed methyl ester (RME) can be used in modified diesel engines, and is sometimes named biodiesel. [definition source: FAO. Glossary of biotechnology and genetic engineering.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LOE.definition: Lowest concentration or amount of a substance, found by observation or experiment, which causes an effect. [definition source: WHO. 1999. Air quality guidelines. Geneva.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_LOE.name: LOEL

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.name: total material requirement
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.objectname_bg: индикатор за общо количество първични природни ресурси
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.objecttrans_bg: индикатор за общо количество първични природни ресурси
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tot.definition: The total material requirement (TMR) expresses the total mass of primary materials extracted from nature to support human activities. TMR is a highly aggregated indicator for the material basis of an economy. [definition source: EEA. 2000. Environmental signals 2000. Environmental assessment report No 6.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.definition: Synonyms: USSR [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_Uni.name: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.definition: A way to describe how much of a substance is contained in a sample: parts of analyte per million parts of sample. In atmospheric chemistry this becomes volume parts of analyte per volume parts of atmosphere. [definition source: Sam Houston State University. United States. Atmospheric Chemistry Glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_par.name: parts per million in volume

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lan.definition: The Landsat program is the longest running enterprise for acqusition of imagery of Earth from space. The first Landsat satellite was launched in 1972; the most recent, Landsat 7, was launched on April 15, 1999. The instruments on the Landsat satellites have acquired millions of images. The images, archived in the United States and at Landsat receiving stations around the world, are a unique resource for global change research and applications in agriculture, geology, forestry, regional planning, education and national security. History: The program was called the Earth Resources Observation Satellites Program when it was initiated in 1966, but the name was changed to Landsat in 1975.Landsat 1 - launched July 23, 1972, terminated operations in 1978, Landsat 2 - launched January 22, 1975, terminated in 1981, Landsat 3 - launched March 5, 1978, terminated 1983, Landsat 4 - launched July 16, 1982, terminated 1993, Landsat 5 - launched March 1, 1984, Landsat 6 - launched October 5, 1993, failed to reach orbit, Landsat 7 - launched April 15, 1999. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_Lan.name: Land Remote Sensing Satellite Program

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.definition: Incorporation of an externality into the market decision making process through pricing or regulatory interventions. In the narrow sense, internalisation is achieved by charging polluters (for example) with the damage costs of the pollution generated by them, in accordance with the polluter pays principle. [definition source: European Conference of Ministers of Transport. Social costs glossary. CEMT/CS(97)12.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_int.name: internalisation of external costs

TERM is steered jointly by the European Commission and the EEA. The main output of TERM is a regular indicator-based report through which the effectiveness of transport and environment integration strategies is monitored. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

[definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environment concerns into development and economic cooperation. Draft version 1.0. Brussels]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.definition: The presence of contaminant or pollutant substances in the air at a concentration that interferes with human health or welfare, or produces other harmful environmental effects. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_air.name: air pollution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: Monitoring network designated to collect data on the status and trends of Europe's water resources in terms of quality and quantity and analyse how this reflects pressures on the environment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.objectname_cs: eurowaternet (monitorovací síť pro evropské vnitrozemské vody)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.definition: The integration of environmental aspects into the product development process, by balancing ecological and economic requirements. Eco-design considers environmental aspects at all stages of the product development process, striving for products which make the lowest possible environmental impact throughout the product life cycle. [definition source: UNEP. 2001. Cleaner production: a guide to information sources.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_eco.name: eco-design

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.definition: Marine algae, saltwater dwelling, simple organisms that fall into the rather outdated, general category of 'plants'. Most of them are red (6 000 species), brown (2 000 species) or green (1 200 species) and most are attached by holdfasts, which have an anchorage function. [definition source: National University of Ireland, Galway.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sea.name: seaweed

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.name: incinerator
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objectname_bg: завод, съоръжение за изгаряне на смет
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.objecttrans_bg: завод, съоръжение за изгаряне на смет
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inc.definition: A furnace in which wastes are burned. [definition source: UNEP. Basel Convention web site.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.definition: The concept of terrestrial environment relates to the interaction between natural components of the geosphere and biosphere as well as to their interaction with social and economic factors, with special emphasis on the territory in which they are deeply rooted. [definition source: ETC/TE.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_ter.name: terrestrial environment
