glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_atm.objecttrans_fr: guide pour l'établissement des inventaires des émissions atmosphériques
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_atm.objecttrans_bg: регистри (указатели) - за изпускания, емисии на вредни вещества, които се публикуват от ЕЕА
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_atm.definition: Joint EMEP/Corinair atmospheric emission inventory guidebook. The guidebook has been prepared by the expert panels of the UNECE/EMEP Task Force on Emission Inventories and published by the European Environment Agency. It is intended for general reference and for use by parties to the Convention on Long-range Transboundary Air Pollution for reporting to the UNECE Secretariat in Geneva. The guidebook is designed to provide a comprehensive guide to the state-of-the-art of atmospheric emissions inventory methodology. [definition source: EMEP/CORINAIR. 1999. Atmospheric Emission Inventory Guidebook. Second edition.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_atm.objecttrans_nl: handleiding voor de inventarisering van atmosferische uitstoot/emissies
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_atm.objecttrans_no: veiledning for oversikt over utslipp til luft

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NFP.definition: National focal points (NFPs) are appointed and funded by member countries and are in charge of national cooperation with the EEA and national coordination of activities related to the EEA work programme. [definition source: EEA. G. McInnes. 2001. A brief guide to who does what in the EEA and EIONET. Copenhagen.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_NFP.name: NFP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEO.definition: Synonyms: global environment outlook [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_GEO.name: GEO

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rar.name: rare species
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rar.definition: Species which have a restricted (world) range. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gui.name: guideline value
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gui.objectname_bg: отправна стойност, която се препоръчва от водеща институция да бъде спазвана като задължителна
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gui.objecttrans_bg: отправна стойност, която се препоръчва от водеща институция да бъде спазвана като задължителна

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.definition: In March 2000 the European Commission introduced a logo bearing the words 'Organic Farming - EC Control System' [Regulation (EEC) No 2092/91] to be used on a voluntary basis by producers whose systems and products have been found on inspection to satisfy EU regulations. [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_O_org.name: organic farming label

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.objectname_de: chronische exposition, dauerexposition, langzeitexposition, dauerbelastung, dauergefährdung
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.objecttrans_de: chronische Exposition, Dauerexposition, Langzeitexposition, Dauerbelastung, Dauergefährdung
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.name: chronic exposure
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_chr.definition: Multiple exposures occurring over an extended period of time or over a significant fraction of an animal's or human's lifetime (usually seven years to a lifetime). [definition source: US EPA.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.definition: UNESCO's programme on man and the biosphere (MAB) develops the basis, within the natural and the social sciences, for the sustainable use and conservation of biological diversity, and for the improvement of the relationship between people and their environment globally. The MAB programme encourages interdisciplinary research, demonstration and training in natural resource management. [definition source: UNESCO.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_man.name: man and biosphere programme

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mac.definition: One of the 11 biogeographical regions of Europe as indicated on the map of biogeographical regions, covering Macaronesia (the Canaries, Madeira and the Azores). [definition source: European Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mac.name: Macaronesian

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_the.name: thermal pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_the.definition: The excessive raising or lowering of water temperature above or below normal seasonal ranges in streams, lakes, or estuaries or oceans as the result of discharge of hot or cold effluents into such water. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.definition: Directive 91/692/EEC. This directive provides for the harmonisation of sector reports on the implementation of 27 directives in the air, water and waste sectors. Member States have to produce sector reports every three years on these directive, based on a questionnaire format provided by the Commission. One exception is the bathing water directive (76/160/EEC) which has to be reported on to the Commission on an annual basis so as to provide the public with information at the earliest opportunity. [definition source: European Commission. Handbook on the implementation of EC environmental legislation.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_rep.name: reporting directive

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNE.definition: Synonyms: United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UNE.name: UNESCAP

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.definition: Green chemistry is the design of chemical products and processes that reduce or eliminate the use and generation of hazardous substances. [definition source: Anastas et al. 2000. Quoted by: Green Chemistry Institute.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_gre.name: green chemistry

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objecttrans_is: meginreglan um að sá sem mengi beri kostnaðinn
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objectname_pl: zasada naprawy szkód przez sprawcę skażenia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objectname_is: meginreglan um að sá sem mengi beri kostnaðinn
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.name: polluter-pays principle
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objecttrans_pl: zasada naprawy szkód przez sprawcę skażenia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objectname_bg: принцип на заплащане на разходите за подобряване на състоянието на околната среда за сметка на причинителя на замърсяването
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.objecttrans_bg: принцип на заплащане на разходите за подобряване на състоянието на околната среда за сметка на причинителя на замърсяването
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pol.definition: The principle that those causing pollution should meet the costs to which it gives rise. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.definition: Description of an agent that induces illness. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Caring for our future. Brussels]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pat.name: pathogenic

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objectname_pt: abordagem fundamentada no princípio da precaução
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.name: precautionary approach
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objecttrans_pt: abordagem fundamentada no princípio da precaução
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objectname_bg: метод (подход) на вземане на предпазни мерки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.objecttrans_bg: метод (подход) на вземане на предпазни мерки
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_pre.definition: A decision to take action, based on the possibility of significant environmental damage, even before there is conclusive, scientific evidence, that the damage will occur. [definition source: European Commission. 1999. Integrating environmental concerns into development and economic cooperation. Brussels.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.definition: The uptake and storage of carbon. Trees and plants, for example, absorb carbon dioxide, release the oxygen and store the carbon. [definition source: Environmental Dictionary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_car.name: carbon uptake

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wet.definition: Areas that are inundated by surface or ground water with frequency sufficient to support a prevalence of vegetative or aquatic life that requires saturated or seasonally saturated soil conditions for growth or reproduction. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wet.name: wetland

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAR.definition: Synonyms: International Convention for the Prevention of Marine Pollution from Ships [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_MAR.name: MARPOL

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_acc.name: acceptable daily intake
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_acc.definition: The measurement of the amount of any chemical substance that can be safely consumed by a human being in a day. Calculations are usually based on the maximum level of a substance that can be fed to animals without producing any harmful effects. This is divided by a 'safety factor' to allow for the differences between animals and humans and to take account of the variation in human diets. [definition source: GEMET 2000]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HNV.definition: High nature value farmland comprises the 'hot spots' of biodiversity in rural areas and is usually characterised by extensive farming practices. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_HNV.name: HNV farmland

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_reg.name: regional priority goals

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Pollution that occurs in cities from the burning of fossil fuels, the emissions of industrial processes and other sources. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PVC.definition: A plastic that is used for many purposes. Various additives, such as plasticisers, lead and cadmium are added to polyvinyl chloride (PVC) to make it usable. Almost every stage of this PVC life-cycle can create pollution problems, for example, environmental contamination with mercury, chlorinated solvents and dioxins. In terms of health, PVC dust can damage the lungs of workers. [definition source: Adapted from: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_P_PVC.name: PVC

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: The Kyoto Protocol allows Parties listed in Annex B to participate in trading of their assigned amounts for the purposes of fulfilling their emissions commitments. Parties buying parts of assigned amounts can add these to their assigned amounts under the Protocol, while Parties selling must deduct them. Such trading must be supplemental to domestic actions. The Conference of the Parties is to define the rules and modalities for trading. [definition source: European Commission. Climate change: Glossary of common terms and acronyms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rot.definition: The Rotterdam Convention on the prior informed consent (PIC) procedure for certain hazardous chemicals and pesticides in international trade was opened for signature in 1998. It will come into force when 50 countries provide final ratification. The Convention will enable the world to monitor and control the trade in various chemicals that threaten human and environmental health. It will give importing countries the power to decide which chemicals they want to receive and to exclude those they cannot manage safely. If trade does take place, requirements for labelling and provision of information on potential health and environmental effects will promote the safe use of these chemicals. [definition source: UNEP-Balkans.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_R_Rot.name: Rotterdam Convention

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.definition: The basic network or foundation of capital facilities or community investments which are necessary to support economic and community activities. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_inf.name: infrastructure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SAC.definition: Synonyms: special areas of conservation [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.definition: Any spending done by a person living alone or by a group of people living together in shared accommodation and with common domestic expenses. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hou.name: household expenditure

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_emi.definition: Projections of the future state of the society and environment based on specific assumptions about key determinants such as population, economic growth, technological change, or environmental policies. [definition source: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Quoted by: Alcampo, J. Scenarios as Tools for International Environmental Assessments]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_EEZ.definition: Concept adopted at the Third United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea (1982), whereby a coastal state assumes jurisdiction over the exploration and exploitation of marine resources in its adjacent section of the continental shelf, taken to be a band extending 200 miles from the shore. [definition source: United Nations. Glossary of environment etatistics.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mon.definition: The Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer was adopted in Montreal in 1987, and subsequently adjusted and amended in London (1990), Copenhagen (1992), Vienna (1995), Montreal (1997), and Beijing (1999). It controls the consumption and production of chlorine- and bromine-containing chemicals that destroy stratospheric ozone, such as CFCs, methyl chloroform, carbon tetrachloride, and many others. [definition source: IPCC. Climate change 2001 impacts, adaptation and vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_Mon.name: Montreal Protocol

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_Eur.definition: The European Topic Centre on Air and Climate Change (ETC/ACC) has been established by EEA in 2001. This centre builds on the experience gained by the former ETC on Air Emissions and Air Quality. It is an international consortium brought together to assists the EEA in its work of collecting, analysing, evaluating and synthesising information on air and climate change relevant to national and international policies. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_DEW.definition: DEWA~Europe/GRID-Geneva is one of UNEP's major centres for data and information management, with a unique, 'value-adding' mandate in the handling of global and regional environmental data, which in turn support the environment assessment and early-warning activities of UNEP and its partners. At the same time, DEWA~Europe occupies the niche of francophone centre for the global GRID network. DEWA~Europe/GRID-Geneva is supported by a 'Partnership Agreement' between UNEP, the Swiss Agency for Environment, Forests and Landscape (SAEFL) and the University of Geneva. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

[definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

This pollution can arise from tobacco smoke, pesticides, cleaning agents, gases released from building materials, rugs, household products, etc. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cli.definition: Climate change refers to any change in climate over time, whether due to natural variability or as a result of human activity. This usage differs from that in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which defines 'climate change' as: 'a change of climate which is attributed directly or indirectly to human activity that alters the composition of the global atmosphere and which is in addition to natural climate variability observed over comparable time periods.' [definition source: IPCC. Climate Change 2001 Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_cli.name: climatic change

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.definition: Agricultural chemical used in crop and food production including pesticide, feed additive, veterinary drug and related compounds. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_A_agr.name: agrochemical

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.definition: Synonyms: IA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_imp.name: impact assessment

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.definition: Areas allocated to preserve and protect certain animals and plants, or both. They differ from national park, which are largely a place for public recreation, because they are provided exclusively to protect species for their own sake. Endangered species are increasingly being kept in nature reserves to prevent them from extinction, particularly in India, Indonesia and some African countries. Natural reserves were used once to preserve the animals that landowners hunted, but, in the 19th century, they became places where animals were kept to prevent them from dying out. Special refuges and sanctuaries are also often designated to protect certain species or groups of wild animals or plants, especially if their numbers and distribution have been significantly reduced. They also serve as a place for more plentiful species to rest, breed or winter. Many parts of the world also have marine and aquatic reserves to protect different species of sea or freshwater plant and animal life. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_nat.name: nature reserve

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.definition: Synonyms: NERI [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_N_Nat.name: National Environmental Research Institute, Denmark

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dom.definition: Synonyms: DEU [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dom.name: domestic extraction used

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPO.definition: Satellite Pour l'Observation de la Terre (SPOT).SPOT - the Satellite Earth Observation System was designed in France, and developed with the participation of Sweden and Belgium. The system comprises a series of spacecrafts plus ground facilities for satellite control and programming, image production and distribution.The SPOT satellites capture panchromatic and multispectral imagery in resolutions ranging from 2.5m to 20m. The satellites are fitted with two independent imaging instruments, containing detector arrays that operate using a 'Push Broom' technique. This results in high geometric accuracy across the full 60km wide swath. Each instrument is also fitted with a steerable mirror that allows it to image areas up to 27 degrees east or west off the vertical, which increases the revisit capability and provides stereo imagery for digital elevation modelling. Importantly, the SPOT satellites can be programmed to target client specific areas of interest. History: SPOT 1 was launched on 22 February 1986 with 10m panchromatic and 20m multispectral capability. The satellite was withdrawn from active service on 31 December 1990. SPOT 2 was launched on 22 January 1990 and is still operational. SPOT 3 was launched on 26 September 1993. An incident occurred on 14 November 1997 and after 4 years in orbit the satellite stopped functioning. SPOT 4 was launched on 24 March 1998 and includes an extra Short Wave Infrared band and a (low resolution) vegetation instrument. SPOT 5 was launched on 4 May 2002 with 2.5m, 5m and 10m capability, as well as along-track stereoscopic sensors. System continuity will be assured by a constellation of new-generation minisatellites known as Pleiades. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SPO.name: SPOT

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mg.definition: Synonyms: milligram [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mg.name: mg

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEE.definition: Synonyms: Serbian Energy Efficiency Agency [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_SEE.name: SEEA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.definition: The time required for a living organism to eliminate, by natural processes, half the amount of a substance that has entered it. [definition source: Society for Risk Analysis. Glossary of risk analysis terms.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_H_hal.name: half-life (biological)

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dat.definition: In general, validation is the process of checking if something satisfies a certain criterium. Examples would be: checking if a statement is true, if an appliance works as intended, if a computer system is secure, or if computer data is compliant with a standard. This should not be confused with verification. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dat.name: data validation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UAA.definition: All the area of arable land, permanent meadow and pasture, and land developed to permanent crops and kitchen gardens. [definition source: Eurostat/Ministère de l'Agriculture e de la Pêche. Agriculture in the European Union. Éditions Agreste. France.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_UAA.name: UAA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sum.name: summer smog
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_sum.definition: Photochemical smog, or simply summer smog, is formed in the lowest few kilometers of the atmosphere. It has adverse effects on human health, agriculture crops, natural vegetation, and materials. The main component of smog is ozone, although levels of other aggressive oxidants are elevated as well. [definition source: EEA. 1999. Environment in the European Union at the turn of the century. Environmental assessment report No 2]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IG.definition: Collaboration areas for projects in CIRCA (Communication and Information Resource Centre Administrator). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IG.name: IG

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.definition: The aggregation of water molecules from vapor to liquid or solid when the saturation concentration is exceeded. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_con.name: condensation

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bul.name: bulky waste
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bul.definition: Large items of waste material such as electric appliances, furniture, large car parts, trees, etc. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water table
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: The top of the water surface in the saturated part of an aquifer. [definition source: US geological survey. Water science glossary of terms.]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IA.definition: Synonyms: impact assessment [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_I_IA.name: IA

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_lv: ķīmisko vai bioloģisko piesārņotāju liktenis vidē
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_hu: {chehea} szennyezőanyag-életútelemzés, biológiai vagy kémiai szennyezőanyag sorsa a természetbe való kibocsájtása után
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_pt: destino final (de um poluente) no ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental fate
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_hu: {CHEHEA} szennyezőanyag-életútelemzés, biológiai vagy kémiai szennyezőanyag sorsa a természetbe való kibocsájtása után
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_lv: ķīmisko vai bioloģisko piesārņotāju liktenis vidē
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_pt: destino final (de um poluente) no ambiente
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_cs: osud polutantu po uvolnění do prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_fi: kemiallisen tai biologisen saasteen kohtalo, kun se on päästetty ympäristöön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: съдбата на химични или биологични вредни вещества след изпускането им в околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_fi: kemiallisen tai biologisen saasteen kohtalo, kun se on päästetty ympäristöön
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: съдбата на химични или биологични вредни вещества след изпускането им в околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: The destiny of a chemical or biological pollutant after release into the environment. [definition source: US EPA.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_cs: osud polutantu po uvolnění do prostředí

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bre.name: breeding bird
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bre.definition: The individuals in a bird population that are involved in reproduction during a particular period in a given place. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.definition: The Convention on the Protection of the Black Sea against Pollution (Bucharest Convention) was adopted in 1992 (in force in 1994). Its objectives are to undertake all necessary measures consistent with international law and in accordance with the provisions of this convention to prevent, reduce, and control pollution thereof in order to protect and preserve the marine environment of the Black Sea. [definition source: Yearbook of international cooperation on environment and development.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.name: Convention on the Protection of the Black Sea against Pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objecttrans_en: Convention on the Protection of the Black Sea against Pollution
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_C_Con.objectname_en: convention on the protection of the black sea against pollution

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Spe.definition: Synonyms: SPECA [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Spe.name: Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Spe.objecttrans_en: Special Programme for the Economies of Central Asia
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_S_Spe.objectname_en: special programme for the economies of central asia

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.name: low-level radioactive wastes
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.objectname_bg: отпадъци с ниско ниво на радиоактивност
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.objectname_ro: reziduuri cu un nivel radioactiv scăzut
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.objecttrans_bg: отпадъци с ниско ниво на радиоактивност
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.definition: A general term for a wide range of wastes containing low quantities of radionuclide. Industries, hospitals and medical, educational, or research institutions; private or government laboratories; and nuclear fuel cycle facilities (e.g., nuclear power reactors and fuel fabrication plants) using radioactive materials generate low-level wastes as part of their normal operations. [definition source: Based on: US Nuclear Regulatory Commission.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_L_low.objecttrans_ro: reziduuri cu un nivel radioactiv scăzut

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dob.definition: A report on the state of the environment requested by the environment Ministers for the whole Europe at the ministerial conference held in Dobris Castle, near Prague, in June 1991, prepared by EEA in 1995. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_Dob.name: Dobris report

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bil.definition: Synonyms: bn [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_B_bil.name: billion

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gro.definition: Gross final energy consumption is defined in Directive 2009/28/EC on renewable energy sources as energy commodities delivered for energy purposes to final consumers (industry, transport, households, services, agriculture, forestry and fisheries), including the consumption of electricity and heat by the energy branch for electricity and heat production, and including losses of electricity and heat in distribution and transmission. The accounting rules in the Directive prescribe that electricity generated by hydropower and wind have to be normalised for annual variations (hydro 15 years and wind 5 years). [definition source: Directive 2009/28/EC]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_G_Gro.name: Gross final energy consumption

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tum.definition: Any new and abnormal growth, specifically one in which cell multiplication is uncontrolled and progressive. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_T_tum.name: tumour

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.definition: Noise emitted from various sources in an urban environment. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_U_urb.name: urban noise

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.name: water use
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_W_wat.definition: Three types of water use are distinguished: (a) withdrawal, where water is taken from a river, or surface or underground reservoir, and after use returned to a natural water body, e.g. water used for cooling in industrial processes. Such return flows are particularly important for downstream users in the case of water taken from rivers; (b) consumptive, which starts with withdrawal but in this case without any return, e.g. irrigation, steam escaping into the atmosphere, water contained in final products, i.e. it is no longer available directly for subsequent uses; (c) non-withdrawal, i.e. the in situ use of a water body for navigation (including the floating of logs by the lumber industry), fishing, recreation, effluent disposal and hydroelectric power generation. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: A medical discipline that deals with environmentally-related disease. Also used in some contexts as a synonym for environmental health. [definition source: WHO. Quoted by: International Society of Doctors for the Environment (ISDE). Primer on International Environment and Health Politics (version of September 2001).]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.name: environmental medicine
environmental risk
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_cs: ekologické riziko, riziko pro životní prostředí
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_bg: риск за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objecttrans_bg: риск за околната среда
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.definition: Likelihood, or probability, of injury, disease, or death resulting from exposure to a potential environmental hazard. [definition source: ETC/CDS. General Environmental Multilingual Thesaurus (GEMET 2000)]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_E_env.objectname_cs: ekologické riziko, riziko pro životní prostředí

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dom.definition: Solid waste composed of garbage and rubbish, which normally originates from houses. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_D_dom.name: domestic waste

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_moi.definition: The water vapour content of the atmosphere, or the total water substances (gaseous, liquid and solid) present in a given volume of air. 2) Water that is dispersed through a gas in the form of water vapour or small droplets, dispersed through a solid, or condensed on the surface of a solid. [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_moi.name: moisture

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kie.definition: Indicator-based state of the environment report prepared by the EEA for the conference of environment ministers of all European countries in Kiev (May 2003). [definition source: EEA multilingual environmental glossary]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_K_Kie.name: Kiev report

glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mac.definition: The component of the plankton that consists of large organisms 2 to 20 cm in size. [definition source: McGraw Hill. PAE virtual glossary.]
glossary.eea.europa.eu_EEAGlossary_M_mac.name: macroplankton
